DOC.HEAD: Washington Party-Giver, Idaho Native, Dies at 46
DOC.TEXT: Steven A. Martindale, Washington lawyer and lobbyist known for the parties he threw, died Wednesday at George Washington University Hospital. Martindale, 46, had AIDS and had been writing an article on his struggle with the disease for Washingtonian magazine, which will publish it in a forthcoming issue. A native of Pocatello, Idaho, Martindale served on the staff of then-Sen. Charles Goodell, R-N.Y. and turned to public relations when Goodell left the Senate in 1971. Recently he had been associated with Saudi billionaire Adnan Kashoggi and wrote a book about him published last year in Britain under the title ``By Hook or By Crook.'' He was the subject of a Washington Post profile in 1974 describing how his parties gained him entree into the circles of the powerful. In a 1987 article in the newspaper he was asked why the powerful Washington party hostesses _ he was a rare host in the calling _ had disappeared. His answer, in part: ``The press scared everybody off.'' He is survived by his parents and a brother.

DOC.HEAD: Defeated Moderates Weigh Future
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 13th graf pvs to UPDATE with news conference by the Rev. Richard Land, head of the Christian Life Commission. Edits throughout to tighten and CORRECT that fundamentalists won top office for 12th straight year sted have held it 12 years.
DOC.TEXT: Defeated Southern Baptist moderates on Wednesday weighed an uncertain, perhaps separate future from their fundamentalist-dominated convention as it undercut a religious-liberty agency in the nation's capital. Unless the denomination's ruling bloc becomes more inclusive and ``accepts the rest of us brothers and sisters,'' some are going to leave, said the Rev. Daniel Vestal, defeated moderate candidate for the denomination's presidency. Similar break-away sentiments came from others in that camp, which charges fundamentalists with using their appointive powers to control agencies and institutions of the 14.9-million-member denomination. The Rev. Morris Chapman, whose election as president Tuesday extended fundamentalist control for a 12th straight year, has supported moving the staff of the country's largest Protestant body toward a unanimous belief that the Bible is error-free. The convention Wednesday slashed support of the Washington-based Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs, the influential religious liberty lobby of nine Baptist groups for 50 years. Fundamentalists have assailed it for opposing prayer sponsored by public schools and for not fighting abortion. The convention cut 87 percent of its support to the agency by shifting $346,796 to the $1.3 million budget of the Christian Life Commission. In so doing, it gave the job of lobbying for religious freedom to an agency whose primary mission is upholding morality. With that change, ``they'll laugh us off Capitol Hill,'' said the Rev. Ron Sisk of Tiburon, Calif. The convention also gave some of the religious liberty function to the Public Affairs Committee, creating three, perhaps conflicting, voices. The Rev. James Dunn, head of the Baptist Joint Committee, said it would keep up its defense of church-state separation and against ``government intrusion into religion.'' ``We won't downgade our religious-liberty agenda,'' he said, noting that assurances of supplemental financing were coming from state and local Southern Baptist churches across the country. He told reporters that with the multiple agencies, there likely will be ``contradictory testimony at times. It's something we'll have to live with.'' The Rev. Richard Land, head of the Christian Life Commission, said his agency shares the joint committee's stand on church-state separation and many other issues. Land predicted that ``conflicts will be far fewer than sometimes has been supposed.'' But he added that ``there are many places where misinterpretation'' of Supreme Court decisions against sponsored school prayers have produced a ``brooding hostility'' to religion. He said the ``greatest threat to religious liberty in the last decade of this century comes not from violation'' of the Constitution's ban against establishing religion but from violating the reglious free-exercise guarantee. He charged there were ``infringements and restraints on people's religious conscience.' The Rev. Grady Cothen of Coral Springs, Fla., head of of a newly formed Religious Liberty Council to back the denominationally downgraded joint agency, said the convention had ``turned a very sharp corner to the right.'' ``It implies that the powers-that-be do not want to bring along the rest of us Christian brethren. They obviously want to be free of us, but they won't make it.'' However, Cothen, former president of the denomination's Sunday School Board, added in an interview: ``Some will pull out. It's inevitable.'' Vestal, trounced in an election in which Chapman took 58 percent of the ballots by more than 38,000 ``messengers,'' said moderates soon would convene a meeting to consider their future. ``Let me confess some mystery about that future,'' he told reporters. ``It's premature to talk about separation.'' But he said there would be departures unless the current regime broadens its inclusiveness. ``A lot of people are now ready to do something tangible to express their dicontent and alienation,'' said the Rev. Stan Hastey of Washington, executive director of the Baptist Alliance. They group was formed to pursue alternatives to the current denominational administration. He said several moderate groups, including the alliance, Baptist Committed to the Southern Baptist Convention, and Women in Ministries, would participate in the meeting about future steps, probably in August.

DOC.HEAD: Astronomers Say Evidence Shows Indians Saw Supernova 900 Years Ago
DOC.TEXT: A pottery bowl painted with a 23-pointed star shows that an exploding star witnessed by ancient Asians and Arabs was also seen by prehistoric Indians in the Southwest, scientists said Tuesday. ``The bowl provides us with the best supported historic record from the Western Hemisphere of the supernova that created the Crab Nebula,'' said R. Robert Robbins, an astronomy professor at the University of Texas at Austin. ``In fact, the bowl is the most certain record of the supernova that has ever been discovered outside China and Japan,'' he said during the 176th meeting of the American Astronomical Society. The white earthenware, Mimbres Indian bowl _ made between 1000 and 1150 A.D. and found in what is now southwestern New Mexico _ also shows the black-painted figure of a rabbit curled into a crescent shape to symbolize the moon, Robbins said. In many Indian cultures in the New World, the rabbit commonly represents the moon because Indians tended to see a rabbit in the moon rather than a man in the moon, he said. Chinese astronomers recorded the appearance of the Crab Nebula supernova in 1054 in the constellation Taurus. Their records showed the star was so bright it could be seen in the daytime for 23 days. The supernova also was recorded by the Japanese, Robbins said. Steve Maran, senior staff scientist at the Goddard Space Flight Center at Greenbelt, Md., said the supernova also was noticed in Baghdad, where it was recorded in an 11th century medical publication. The Mimbres bowl is decorated with a small black-painted sunburst with 23 rays at one of the rabbit's rear feet. The 23 rays represent the 23 days the supernova was clearly visible during the day, Robbins said. The Crab Nebula is a huge cloud of gas in space that is the remnant of the supernova. Supernovas are dying stars that blow up and eject matter in all directions. The Crab Nebula is about 6 light years wide and about 6,500 light years from Earth. One light year equals almost 6 trillion miles, which is the distance light travels in one year. American astronomers discovered early in this century that the Crab Nebula is expanding at a rate implying an explosion beginning about 900 years ago when first seen from Earth. A computer analysis shows the position of the sunburst and the rabbit generally coincides with the location of the supernova and the crescent moon on the morning of July 5, 1054, Robbins said. ``It shows us how sophisticated these people were,'' said Robbins, who worked with photo technician Russell Westmoreland of the University of Texas at Austin's astronomy department. The Mimbres lived in small farming villages. The bowl was from a village called Galaz, and was found in the 1930s by scientists from the University of Minnesota, Robbins said

DOC.HEAD: Captain Says Explosion a Mystery; Smoke Curtailed Rescue Efforts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that blasts occurred Friday, sted Saturday; SUBS 7th graf, `The Norwegian ...,' to conform; INSERTS 5 grafs after 11th graf, `Maidhara said ...,' to UDPATE with further quotes from captain on disaster; picks up 12th graf, `Leikvang said ...' ^LaserPhotos HT5, HT8
DOC.TEXT: At least 3 million gallons of oil spilled into the Gulf of Mexico from the Mega Borg, officials said Wednesday, and the captain said the explosions that ripped through the supertanker came without warning. ``I was in the radio room, alone, and suddenly the door swung open, the lights went out, and glass was crashing down,'' said Capt. C.M. Mahidhara told a panel questioning the Norwegian vessel's crew. Fires sparked by the blasts Friday were under control but continued to burn Wednesday. Crews have found a hole in the center tank of the 886-foot ship, said Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene. ``A minimum of 3 million gallons has left the cargo tanks and I'm presuming that most of that has gone into the water,'' Greene said. ``I don't see any risk of losing cargo from the other tanks.'' Most of the spilled light crude oil has burned or evaporated, authorities said. Greene said between 12,000 gallons and 40,000 gallons remained in the water. The Coast Guard had initially estimated that up to 100,000 gallons of the ship's 38 million gallon cargo had leaked. The Norwegian government convened a board of inquiry Wednesday at a Galveston hotel to question the crew. The captain said he noticed nothing wrong before the explosions, which occurred around 11:30 p.m. Friday as oil was being transferred to a smaller tanker 57 miles southeast of Galveston. ``As far as I could see, everything was in good order,'' said Mahidhara, a sailor for 17 years and a captain for nine. The crew is being questioned by Erik Leikvang, general consul of Norway, and Ole Leithe, a Norwegian maritime investigator. They are trying to determine the ship's seaworthiness and whether there is any criminal liability stemming from the explosions and leak. The Coast Guard also is participating in the hearing. Mahidhara said the crew went over a safety checklist before transferring the fuel and all checks were satisfactory. Mahidhara said after the explosion, choking black smoke kept him from locating and commanding his 41-member crew. Two men were killed and two others are missing and presumed dead. Seventeen crewmen were injured. Mahidhara and five other crewmen stayed aboard the burning tanker to search for four missing men. The remains of the ship's chief officer, Tojo Sagar, were found outside the pump room, he said. The body of crewman Bernardo Cortez had been crushed by a falling skylight and also was found outside the pump room, he said. Mahidhara, a seaman for 17 years and a captain for nine, said he considered trying to launch a rescue effort for two men seen in the engine room, but decided against it because of the smoke and fire. ``I did not think it was wise to send people down there. It was too dangerous. I would have lost more people,'' he said. ``I looked forward and saw bright flames were coming from the pump room and ventilators,'' he said. ``The flames were licking up right over the bridge. The top of the pump room had been completely blown off.'' Leikvang said the hearing was only for fact-finding. ``I don't think we can find the reason for the explosion from this hearing,'' said Leithe. ``Maybe later, when the ship is empty and cleaned, we will know more.'' An oil sheen streched 12 miles from the tanker on Wednesday, said Greene. The oil had begun forming tar balls, and Greene said he could not determine where the balls might wash ashore or how soon. Salvage boats and Coast Guard ships were skimming the water and using containment booms to try to corral the slick. The Coast Guard said winds picked up on the gulf, hampering the booms' work, but that the choppier waters would help chemical dispersants sprayed over the spill. Six fireboats aimed a dozen streams of water on the rear of the ship, leaving it shrouded in a cloud of steam and gray smoke. In the afternoon crews tried using flame-dousing foam on fire pockets in the engine room but, as had been feared, the fire flared up again and they returned to using water, said Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Todd Nelson. ``The reflash is a minor setback,'' Nelson said. ``There is very little fire left on the ship.'' Meanwhile, the Coast Guard said the Texas Land and Water commissions can test a process that uses bacteria to ``eat'' oil on the Mega Borg spill, provided the federal Environmental Protection Agency approves a plan to be submitted Thursday. The rear of the Mega Borg has dropped more than 60 feet since the tanker caught fire, and waves were washing over the deck. An 825-foot British-registered tanker, the Vic Bilh, was standing by to transfer the remainder of the Mega Borg's cargo. But Coast Guard officials have said that operation could be dangerous because the ship was listing slightly and crews might have to pump water into the holds to keep the vessel balanced. The Mega Borg, operated by Mosvolds Shipping of Farsund, Norway, was bound from Palanca, Angola. It was scheduled to travel to Aruba after Galveston. Elf Trading Inc., a Houston subsidiary of a French oil and gas company, owned the cargo and said it would participate in the cleanup. The Mega Borg was carrying more than three times as much oil as was spilled by the Exxon Valdez off Alaska in March 1989 in the nation's worst oil spill. But authorities noted the oil spilled in Alaska was heavy crude, which doesn't dissipate nearly as rapidly as light crude.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Disaster Latest in String of Sea Accidents
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The fire that crippled the Norwegian supertanker Mega Borg in the Gulf of Mexico was one of a series of recent spills and other maritime mishaps in U.S. waters. Here's a list of some incidents since the Exxon Valdez spill in March 1989. The information comes from Associated Press reports and Golob's Oil Pollution Bulletin of Cambridge, Mass.

June 23, 1989 _ Greek tanker World Prodigy runs aground on Brenton Reef just outside Narragansett Bay, R.I., spilling 420,000 gallons of No. 2 heating oil. June 23, 1989 _ Barge Coastal 2514 collides with the Panamanian tanker Rachel B in the Houston Ship Channel, spilling 252,000 gallons of slurry oil. June 24, 1989 _ Uruguayan tanker Presidente Rivera runs aground in the Delaware River, spilling 300,000 gallons of No. 6 fuel oil. Aug. 12, 1989 _ Fish processing vessel Ocean Pacific sinks, leaking 19,000 gallons of diesel fuel in the Tongass Narrows, Ketchikan, Alaska. Feb. 7, 1990 _ The tanker American Trader using old charts gashes itself on its anchor in shallow water, spilling 400,000 of Alaska crude off Huntington Beach. Feb. 28, 1990 _ Exxon barge E-25 spills 25,000 gallons of No. 6 fuel oil through a hole of undetermined origin into the Kill Van Kull, Bayonne, N.J. Mar. 7, 1990 _ The barge Cibro Savannah explodes in the Arthur Kill between New Jersey and New York City, spilling 100,000 gallons of No. 2 fuel oil. May 29, 1990 _ The cruise ship Regent Star runs aground on a sand bar in Delaware Bay, stranding 1,360 passengers and crew. Passengers are ferried ashore and the ship refloated without a fuel spill. June 10, 1990 _ The cruise ship Bermuda Star hits a rocky ledge off Cape Cod in Buzzards Bay, ripping a 90-foot gash in the hull and spilling 7,500 gallons of diesel fuel. The threat remains that the rest of the 100,000 gallons aboard will spill. June 10, 1990 _ British tanker BT Nautilus runs aground because of human error, leaking 260,000 gallons of No. 6 fuel oil into the Kill Van Kull, Bayonne, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Smugglers Dodge Armies Between Lebanon, Syria and Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: On most nights, the Nightingale, the Flying Carpet and the King clamber along the rocky smugglers' trail in the foothills of Mount Hermon between Lebanon, Syria and Israel. Carrying American cigarettes, Scotch whisky and electrical appliances for Syria on their backs, they run the gantlet of Syrian and Israeli soldiers dug in along a front that threads across the snow-capped, 9,200-foot mountain. On the return leg, they carry diesel fuel from Iran and other goods that are prized in lawless Lebanon, where civil war began in 1975 and central authority collapsed long ago. The Nightingale, the Flying Carpet and the King are mules specially trained for the six-hour trek on and around Mount Hermon, where the borders of Lebanon, Syria and Israel intersect. Because of their special skills, each mule is worth about $3,000, twice the average for a pack animal in southeast Lebanon. Those skills include recognizing and running from anyone in military uniform and leading pack trains of up to 100 mules. ``It's a no-man's land out there,'' said Adnan Daher, a 16-year-old smuggler. ``The Israelis are on a hill to the west, the Syrians on a hill to the east and Lebanon behind us.'' No accurate figures on the smuggling trade are available, but diplomats in Syria say it amounts to hundreds of millions of dollars a year. Shebaa, a predominantly Sunni Moslem town in the Israeli-occupied sector of south Lebanon, has been a smugglers' haven for decades. The men of Shebaa have traditionally defied authority. About 5,000 of Shebaa's original population of 200,000 still live there, said Mohammed Zoheiri, a sprightly man of 90 who has been mukhtar, or mayor, for 45 years. The others went to Beirut, other parts of Lebanon or the oil-rich Persian Gulf states because ``work opportunities are scarce here,'' Zoheiri said whlle sipping tea with visitors. He said the ``mulers'' as he calls them, ``have known no other way of making a living. They were born on muleback.'' Some of his 40 grandsons are mulers, as his own father was, Zoheiri said, and added: ``It's Shebaa's profession.'' Over the border in Syria is Sirghaya, the nerve center of Syrian smugglers, where half the 15,000 people live off the contraband business. ``They'd have to arrest the whole town if they wanted to stop us,'' said a merchant in nearby Madaya, the main outlet for the smuggled goods. He was unwrapping high-heeled Italian shoes that had just crossed the frontier. Although it costs money in lost tax revenue, diplomats say, the illegal trade also helps the troubled Syrian economy. A recent report by the U.S. Embassy in Damascus said: ``The off-the-books economy is both a sore point and a salvation. The black market provides badly needed goods and in many ways keeps the economy going.'' Because of the steady flow of contraband, the planners of Syria's socialist economy do not have to divert precious foreign exchange for imports. President Hafez Assad's government generally turns a blind eye as long as the trade keeps to border towns. Diplomats in Damascus said there even was a sizable illicit trade in goods from Israel through the Israeli-occupied zone in south Lebanon. Iron reinforcing bars and other building materials are particularly prized in Syria. The U.S. Embassy report said Syrian construction workers ``would be out of jobs but for smuggled building materials.'' Daher, the 16-year-old smuggler from Shebaa, said after a recent nocturnal expedition: ``We provide whatever our Syrian partners demand.'' He said the Shebaa men hand over their loads to Syrian mule trains. Each mule carries about 100 kilograms, or 220 pounds. Each smuggler owns two mules and clears about $100 a week, four times the average wage in Lebanon. ``Syrian soldiers usually start intercepting us after the snow melts,'' said a smuggler who identified himself only as Ahmed. ``We move to another unloading spot close to the Israeli-controlled hill. The Syrians don't go there.'' A few days earlier, a Syrian customs patrol fired on a pack train from Shebaa and killed a mule, but the smugglers escaped with the rest of their animals. Shebaa smugglers have 600 to 800 mules, said Amin, a 51-year-old who has been in the trade since boyhood. ``It's a dangerous profession, but Shebaa's smugglers rarely get killed,'' he said. ``We know our way and the lead mules are well trained.'' Most Shebaa men killed in recent years were victims of land mines, he said. Amin said it takes up to three months to train a lead mule, which should be ``big, strong, healthy and smart.'' A mule chosen as a leader is kept in an ``isolated, dark stable without food or water for two days,'' he said. ``Then a man, who shouldn't be a smuggler because the mule would get used to his smell, goes in dressed as a soldier and beats the mule with a stick,'' Amin said. ``A smuggler goes in after him and gives the mule food and water.'' He said the ``soldier'' fires a rifle near the mule during the beating. ``The `soldier' becomes the mule's enemy,'' he explained, ``and the animal tries to escape the minute a soldier is seen or a bullet is fired. At this point, the mule becomes eligible to lead a caravan.''

DOC.HEAD: California's `Worst of the Worst' Moving to High-Tech Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: There is a new home for the ``worst of the worst,'' the most violent and escape-prone of California's 92,000 prison inmates. It is Pelican Bay, an eerie, high-tech prison within a prison that is touted as the nation's most secure lockup. Its name ay make it sound like a resort, but Pelican Bay is a stark, silent, X-shaped place monitored by video cameras and microphones. Here, more than 1,000 prisoners live in a world of concrete and steel and silence, confined to their 80-square-foot cells for 22{ hours a day. They are allowed out for a 90-minute exercise period, alone and without athletic equipment, in a tiny concrete ``yard'' with 20-foot-high walls. The prisoners in the Security Housing Unit, the core of the Pelican Bay State Prison, are set apart from the rest of the prison population. They live in eight-cell ``pods,'' one man to a cell. Each pod has its own adjacent exercise area. The other inmates, about 1,700 in the general population, are treated like conventional prisoners. They have access to barbells and basketballs. They eat in the prison kitchen and spend time in the ``day room,'' with telephones and cable television. They can have conjugal visits with spouses. But the Security Housing Unit prisoners exist in isolation. ``These are the worst of the worst, the ones who have shown they can't be managed safely,'' said Lt. Al Deines, a prison spokesman. ``They have assaulted the staff, or they have had heavy possession of drugs, or they are verified members of gangs.'' Pelican Bay opened its well-secured doors seven months ago. Previously, the state's worst prisoners usually went to San Quentin or Folsom prisons _ places rich in the folklore of criminology but no longer adequate for the state's huge prison population. At Pelican Bay, prisoners are shackled and flanked by two truncheon-wielding officers every time they are moved outside their cells. Aside from that, guards have little direct contact with the prisoners. They open the sliding cell doors _ slabs of steel perforated with small holes _ by remote control pneumatics, and they use loudspeakers to direct the inmates in and out. Except for the periodic sound of a door slamming or a voice on a speaker, the Security Housing Unit _ the ``Shu'' _ is strangely quiet. ``Listen!'' an officer tells a visitor. ``What do you hear? Nothing. It's not like other prisons.'' An armed guard in an enclosed glass-and-steel control booth monitors groups of pods. Above the corridors, a heavy mesh screen allows guards to walk overhead, and the upper ceiling is laced with pipes that can spew water or tear gas in an emergency. The design for the Shu was patterned partly after a 700-inmate prison in Florence, Ariz., but the Pelican Bay prison is larger, with major differences in design. Warden Charles Marshall describes it as ``unique in the nation.'' Outside, the gray gravel compound is as deserted as a ghost-town, ringed by concentric chain-link fences topped with razor wire and armed guards. Although surrounded by California's lushest forests, the fenced prison site has no shrubs, no vegetation at all to break the line of sight. The inner fence sounds an alarm at a touch. In the ground, just under the earth, special sensor cables criss-cross the prison grounds, and will trigger an alarm if more than 40 pounds of pressure is applied. The guards, one each in 11 towers spaced 700 feet apart, are armed with .223-caliber carbines. The prison is a scant 50 yards from U.S. 101, but invisible behind dense coastal forests. There are no signs, no marked turnoffs, no direct access from the highway to the prison, about 10 miles south of the Oregon line and four miles from the ocean. Occasionally, passersby catch a glimpse of a guard tower through the trees and wander onto the grounds surrounding the compound to investigate the nearly quarter-billion-dollar prison. ``That makes the tower guards very nervous,'' Deines said.

DOC.HEAD: Aging Teacher Corps Could Hinder Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: America's teaching force is aging, and reformers fear the trend could thwart the drive toward school improvement. During the last 20 years, the average age of the nation's 2.3 million public school teachers rose from 36 to 41, according to statistics from the National Education Association. Unpublished data from the 1988 Current Population Survey of the Census Bureau shows that 48.4 percent are 40 or older. Educators have usually invoked such statistics as evidence that mass teacher retirements lie ahead _ with no certainty that the profession is attractive enough to draw young recruits. Half to 54 percent of the nation's teachers will be eligible for retirement by the year 2000, said Jewell Gould, research director of the American Federation of Teachers. This ``graying'' of the profession contains other worrisome messages, several reformers believe. Age statistics suggest that a decade of school reform has been at least partly misdirected. ``School reformers haven't looked a lot at the fact that in a decade, many of the teachers who will be in the schools are not there now,'' said Linda Darling-Hammond, a professor at Columbia Teachers College and an authority on the teaching profession. Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, said the numbers mean the nation had better pay more heed to improving the training of the next generation of teachers. He said this group will carry the burden of reform for years to come. He said it was a mistake to focus almost exclusively on present teachers. ``Both older and younger teachers have to be considered, but if I were to draw a conclusion, I'd say we have been far too neglectful of educating the new generation of teachers who will be determining where schools will be going in the first quarter of the 21st century,'' said Boyer in a recent interview. Darling-Hammond added it's generally easier to train a new teacher in reform techniques such as team teaching than it is to persuade a veteran teacher to break long-cherished classroom habits. Some teacher colleges have begun to address these problems. The ``Holmes Group,'' a coalition of about 100 education schools interested in reform, is fostering programs allowing student teachers to practice new techniques in public school classrooms. Several such programs have started recently in Michigan, for example. The rise in the average age of teachers during the last two decades mirrors declining student enrollments and tight state school budgets. Those trends have been most pronounced in the Midwest and Northeast. Not all states keep teacher age data. But a check of state departments of education and local union affiliates found the average age of teachers in Connecticut, for example, is 43.3; in Georgia, 42; Indiana, 42; Michigan, 44; Maryland, 41.1; and New Jersey, 42.5. The median age in New York was 42.4 as the 1988-89 school year, and 25.1 percent of the teaching force is 49 or older. In Massachusetts, suffering the effects of a decade-old tax revolt measure and a worsening budget crisis, the average age is 47. By contrast, teachers in New Mexico, a Sunbelt state with a growing student population, average 37.7. Reformers concerned over average age emphasize they don't mean to belittle the skills of veteran teachers. ``More experienced teachers are more productive. They just won't make the mistakes a younger teacher would,'' said Gould. Nonetheless, the age statistics lend urgency to the need to update the skills of veteran teachers and create more collegial environments in public schools, said Darling-Hammond. ``By and large, teacher effectiveness increases during the first five to seven years of a career, then levels off and may even decline. Whether that happens depends on the school environment. Collegial environments that have lots of opportunities to develop and learn help foster professional growth. But that's not typical,'' she said. Educators believe that school improvement is most likely to take root in schools with a balanced mix of young and old teachers. ``From what I see, whether or not a person is willing to take a look at innovative ideas has little to do with age,'' said Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association. ``I hear as many innovative ideas from 50 year-olds as 25 year-olds.'' But statistics suggest that the balance has swung toward a heavier concentration of veteran teachers, many of whom have seen reform waves come and go with little apparent effect and may be viewing current reform efforts skeptically. ``I think all teachers want to be part of exciting changes,'' Boyer said. ``But we have to ask: Which teachers will be prepared to harness technology? Will they be prepared to deal with an increasingly bilingual population? Will they be prepared to be creative and not just conforming?''

DOC.HEAD: Summer Reruns Dominate Top 10
With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: Summertime, and the programming's easy. Eight of the top 10 shows on television last week were reruns. A ``Roseanne'' retread on ABC was No. 1. A carbon of NBC's ``Cheers'' was No. 2. A replay of ``The Cosby Show'' on NBC and a rehash of ``Designing Women'' on CBS tied for third, according to figures Tuesday from the A.C. Nielsen Co. NBC was No. 1, as usual. But CBS, in last place for virtually all of the fall season, continued its spring and summer revival by placing second. ABC was last. The only original programming in the top 10 were the comedy ``The Seinfeld Chronicles'' on NBC, which tied for seventh place, and ``The Search for Matthew,'' a ``48 Hours'' special on CBS, which ranked 10th. Fox did not duplicate its precedent-setting finish in the previous week's ratings, when it placed two shows in the top 10. ``The Simpsons'' dropped to No. 13, and ``Married ... With Children'' fell to 19th. Both were reruns. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 16.8; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 15.4; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC and ``Designing Women,'' CBS, both 14.7; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 14.6; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 14.4; ``The Seinfeld Chronicles,'' NBC, 14.2; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 14.2; ``Coach,'' ABC, 13.8; and ``48 Hours'' special, CBS, 13.7. Overall, NBC had an average rating of 10.8, CBS a 9.8 and ABC a 9.7. In the network news battle, ABC was way out in front with a 9.5 average. CBS had a 7.7 and NBC 7.4.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker Wants His Cash Converted to West German Marks, Lawyer Says
DOC.TEXT: Erich Honecker's lawyer says the ousted East German leader should be allowed to convert his cash to West German marks when the German states merge their economies next month, a newspaper reported. The 77-year-old former hard-line Communist Party chief and his wife, Margot, have about 300,000 East German marks in personal savings, according to attorney Friedrich Wolff, the West German newspaper Die Welt said. It quoted Wolff as saying the money was legally acquired and should be treated like the savings of other East Germans. West German marks will become the currency of East Germany on July 2, when the nations merge their economies, a key step in unification. Under a formula for replacing the nearly worthless East German mark, older people would have savings of up to 6,000 marks converted at a 1-to-1 rate, and amounts higher than that at a 2-to-1 rate. Honecker's money would be valued at 153,000 West German marks ($90,270). Honecker and other officials of the former Communist regime, toppled in October, were taken to a police hospital in East Berlin on May 28. The mostly elderly ex-leaders are being examined to determine whether they are physically and mentally fit to be prosecuted for alleged crimes. Honecker is in failing health and had been in a Soviet military hospital in the town of Beelitz before he was brought to East Berlin. East German officials have changed signals several times on whether to prosecute members of the old guard. Most of the charges against Honecker and other officials center on abuse of office and corruption. Party leaders are believed to have amassed large amounts of cash and property. Die Welt said in Tuesday's report that the government has begun criminal proceedings aimed at confiscating Honecker's wealth, making it unlikely the former party chief will be allowed to convert his cash. Wolff said he would file a claim for compensation on Honecker's behalf unless the ex-leader is allowed to convert his savings. He said he does not expect Honecker to be prosecuted. ``Already today can I determine ... actual legal grounds for criminal prosecution are not apparent,'' he was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Surfaces as Major Issue in German Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Abortion has emerged as one of the most emotional unification issues facing the Germanys, and people in both nations are debating which state's abortion law should prevail. West Germany restricts abortions to three situtions: medical necessity, rape or incest, and dire social or economic hardship. In East Germany, first trimester abortions are performed cost-free upon demand. Numbers reflect the widely varying laws. In East Germany, with a population of 16 million, 73,000 abortions were performed last year. In West Germany, whose population is four times higher, there were 75,297 legal abortions. East German doctors are prohibited from performing abortions on foreigners except in cases of emergency, but pregnant West German women are already crossing the border, hoping to take advantage of the looser law. The two Germanys plan to unite under the West German constitution as the quickest way to merge. Economic unity is to take place on July 2 and full union could come later this year. The West German government, led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, says its constitution bars an abortion law such as East Germany's. ``The right of the unborn child to live is not open to question under our constitution,'' said Norbert Greis, a legal expert for West Germany's Christian Social Union, the Bavarian sister party to Kohl's Christian Democrats. Not everyone in Kohl's coalition agrees, however. West German Justice Minister Hans Engelhard has suggested two different abortion laws could exist for an interim period after unification. The arch-conservative Christian Social Union says that would be out of the question. The West German Social Democrats say East Germany's law is a good model for a united Germany's abortion regulations, arguing it places more importance on a woman's rights. ``Women in East Germany would certainly not abide seeing their long-valid abortion law fall victim to a harmonization of inter-German law,'' said lawmaker Renate Schmidt, a Social Democrat. Many East German women say he's right. ``Changing the abortion regulations would only bring trouble for us,'' said a young, pregnant East German woman, registering for an abortion at a women's clinic in Heiligenstadt, a rural East German border town. East Germans are expected to face considerable economic hardship following unification because thousands of people are expected to lose their jobs and prices will soar. Many fear an abortion law like West Germany's could increase the economic burden on families by forcing them to have unwanted children. Christa Schmidt, East Germany's minister for family and women's affairs, said she would not ``budge an inch'' on abortion rights. Although East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere has not spoke out on the issue, many members of his Christian Democratic Union disagree with Ms. Schmidt. Dr. Rudolf Kessel, chief doctor at the Heiligenstadt clinic, says he thinks East German women are too easygoing about abortions. ``For a lot of women abortion is simply seen as a form of birth control, especially in the big industrial cities. This is the dark side of our law,'' Kessel said. West Germany's law, passed in 1972, makes it extremely difficult for a woman to get an abortion. Those who request abortions on economic or social grounds must get two doctors to confirm their case is legitimate, and must show proof of being counseled on adoption and welfare assistance. In East Germany, a doctor can reject a request for an abortion only if the first 12 weeks of a pregnany have passed, Kessel said. Many West German women travel to the Netherlands for abortions, where the law is less strict. Some fear a type of ``abortion tourism'' will extend to East Germany unless the nations bring their abortion laws into line. Abortion has long been a highly emotional issue in West Germany. Last year, the conviction of a prominent Bavarian gynecologist caused a huge national stir and is still widely debated. Dr. Horst Theissen, found guilty by a Bavarian court of failing to follow abortion guidelines, was banned from practicing as a gynecologist for three years. Bavaria state, predominantly Catholic, also tried 156 of Theissen's patients, who were accused of having abortions under the hardship clause without proof of the required counseling. Most were fined up to $1,600. The trial resulted in charges among opposition politicians that West Germany's abortion law was ``one of the most backward in Europe.'' Abortion has not been such a heated issue in predominantly Protestant East Germany. Nonetheless, there are strong anti-abortion sentiments in Roman Catholic pockets, such as Heiligenstadt.

DOC.HEAD: Oakland to Chicago Airliner Loses Pressure, Lands Safely in Omaha
DOC.TEXT: An American Airlines jetliner with 70 people on board made an emergency landing in Omaha after losing cabin pressure, but no one was injured, officials said. ``I think everybody was pretty calm,'' said Jeremy Turk, 33, a passenger on Flight 840 from Oakland to Chicago. ``It was quite uneventful.'' The McDonnell Douglas Super 80, carrying 64 passengers and a six-member crew, made the unscheduled but safe landing at Eppley Airfield at 11:50 a.m. CDT, officials said. Passengers remained in the twin-engine jet for about an hour before entering the airport, and were given boarding passes for another flight to Chicago. The cause of the loss in cabin pressure was not known, said American Airlines spokesman Al Becker. Becker did not know the plane's altitude when the problem developed. Most of the people on the jet were asleep when pressure was lost, several passengers said. ``All of a sudden, it was `Ding, ding,' and the masks fell down in front of my face,'' said Joe Sivertsen, 21. ``I woke up and said, `Oh, that's nice, now what's happening?'' ``It was handled very well by the flight crew,'' Turk said.

DOC.HEAD: Times of London Reluctantly Enters Modern Era With Style Changes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The venerable Times of London has bowed to the demands of a vulgar modern age, revising its Victorian-era style guide to include such brash and contemporary language as the title ``Ms.'' The 205-year-old newspaper _ whose readers tend to regard its eccentricities as a national treasure on the order of Big Ben _ introduced the usage changes in Tuesday's editions. Editor Simon Jenkins tried to break the news gently. ``The mirror that a newspaper holds up to the world is constantly smudged with jargon, bad usage and verbosity,'' wrote Jenkins, who took over in March. ``A style guide is a periodic cleansing of that mirror.'' The Times style guide, introduced at the turn of the century, was last revamped in the mid-1960s. There were regular updates but the guide remained ``terribly restrictive and quite Victorian,'' said literary editor Philip Howard, who helped write the new guide. Even so, he was quick to point out, it was ``very magnificent, with high standards.'' The old style guide was replete with arcane treasures such as The Times' singular spelling of Mikhail S. ``Gorbachov.'' Its rendering of the Soviet leader's name was based on its transliteration of the Cyrillic letters. ``Our Russian specialists know that our spelling is better, but if the rest of the world spells it another way, ours looks very odd,'' Howard said. ``We're right, but we're wrong.'' So from now on, it's Gorbachev. Under the old style, The Times referred to Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece as the ``Monna Lisa,'' a spelling that might seem to some as mysterious as the lady's smile. It will revert to ``Mona Lisa.'' ``The old Times style book said that one should always spell `Monna Lisa' with two n's to show that we are gents and that we know that it comes from Monna, which is derived from the Italian Madonna,'' said Howard. But that and other displays of erudition, he conceded, also ``came to look very odd.'' The Times is under siege from more than modern usage. Circulation dropped to 434,389 in daily sales this spring compared with 442,109 a year previously. A new highbrow newspaper, The Independent, was started 3{ years ago and is fast closing in on The Times with daily sales of 416,200. Under the new style guide, there were changes in courtesy titles for both men and women. From now on, ``Ms.'' will be automatically used in Times news columns for American women. For the rest of womanhood, it will be trotted out on special request. The Times is bracing for some flak over that one. ``When ``Ms.'' is used in the Times we get angry letters, often written by women, who want to know what is that vulgar new word and how do you pronounce it,'' said Howard, author of ``We Thundered Out: 200 Years of the Times 1785-1985.'' Howard thinks use of Ms. will make journalists' jobs easier, however. ``It is awkward for a reporter to have to go up to a woman after a lecture and ask her if she is married,'' Howard said. ``A younger woman is likely to tell them to mind their own business and they may get a clip around the ears with a handbag.'' The Associated Press Stylebook, style guide for many U.S. newspapers, prescribes using ``Ms.'' before a woman's last name if she prefers it. The Times is also dropping courtesy titles on first reference _ something certain to disappoint readers who enjoyed such prim designations as Mr. Ringo Starr. On subsequent reference, most people continue to get a title, except criminals, artists, athletes and the long dead. Some modern words introduced in earlier revisions of the style guide have now come to seem dated. The hippies of the '60s who gathered for summer solstice celebrations at the 4,000-year-old Stonehenge monument in southern England have become ``travelers'' in the modern Times. ``The words of a generation ago _ like `hippie' _ sound absurdly old-fashioned,'' said Howard. ``Newspapers have a duty to use the language of the current generation.'' The new guide also has a blacklist _ words that ``slip into journalese as a form of obfuscation and circumlocution and gobbledygook,'' he said. These include: problem, provision, very, issue, accommodate, crisis, interesting, and situation. Especially ``crisis situation.'' And ``probe.'' ``Words like probe should be confined to stories about surgeons,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Chanel Stages First-Ever Cruise Wear Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Tiny minis, brisk bike tights and beautifully cut jackets set the pace for the Chanel cruise wear shown in the original Rue Cabon salon where Coco herself once presided. It was Chanel's first show devoted to cruise wear ``though we have been making it for years,'' said Chanel's designer, Karl Lagerfeld. ``This was my idea, to have an intimate lunch show to launch the between-season clothes and set them off,'' he said at a catered champagne lunch after the show Tuesday. Top couture seamstress directors work better ``when they know they'll be admired by the press and a larger audience, not just in a showroom,'' he added. The line of clothes for ``cruising'' _ whether aboard a boat, in the street or at polo clubs _ looked like sharp versions of what Lagerfeld has been doing for a couple of seasons at Chanel, for whom he has been head designer since 1983. He topped most of them with beautiful, oversized boater hats. Neat and put together well, they looked angled to sell. They ranged from beautifully cut navy shantung jackets with patch pockets to little robin's-egg blue or tea-rose pink boucle suits. The details were sharply etched. The late-day wear featured some beautifully classic black-and-white outfits in crepe de chine and pleated shortie chiffon skirts, Lagerfeld's original vision of Chanel of yore. He also featured his current favorite shades of hot coral, peach and soft wisteria for next winter's sunny resort wear. For those with great figures, the skintight navy jersey sailor suits with middy-style tops were worn with gold-buttoned bermuda or corsair-length clinging pants. The only criticism was that it all looked terribly Junior Miss, even in beautiful boucle tweed suits featuring raspberry or lime plaids _ fine for young girls and older sophisticates like Audrey Hepburn, but perhaps a bit flighty for the likes of French politicians' wives, who often favor Chanel. ``Many women can wear these clothes,'' said Lagerfeld, hinting that perhaps a few skirts will come out longer in the boutiques. Lagerfeld himself wore a blazer and tie with a cameo tie clip, his usual ponytail, and dark glasses by Christian Dior. The little Chanel trapeze-line coats with their double-breasted gold button effects and the light pink poplin pants suits evoked luxury cruise liners in 1958, when Lagerfeld was a teen-ager learning design in Paris. But the traditional quality was there as well, and Chanel was proud to show it off up close. The cruise line wear is not cheap: Outfits will be in the $2,000-plus range, on a par with the ready-to-wear. With Lagerfeld at the helm, the world's most copied house is stil keeping a jump ahead of the rip-off artists.

DOC.HEAD: East German Christian Democrats Call For December All-German Elections
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's leading political party has called for both German states to elect a single government in December. The Christian Democrat caucus in Parliament said Tuesday that it would seek to have lawmakers vote on German unification this summer and that all-German elections should be held no later than mid-December. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany has been pressing for all-German elections in December in place of the West German elections set for Dec. 2. East Germany held its first free elections on March 18, ending four decades of Communist rule. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, the leader of the Christian Democrats, has been noncommittal about holding December elections. De Maiziere was on a state visit to the United States on Tuesday, but Guenther Krause, leader of the Christian Democratic faction in Parliament, said de Maiziere favored the proposal. Krause said the Christian Democrats would soon begin talks on the proposal with other parties in their governing coalition, which includes the left-leaning Social Democrats. The East Germany Social Democratic leader, Wolfgang Thierse, said his party opposes the elections because details of unification must first be worked out. Social Democrats in both countries favor a slower pace for reunification while the conservative Christian Democrats have been seeking to move the process as quickly as possible. Many analysts believe Kohl, the leader of West Germany's Christian Democrats, would make a stronger showing in an all-German balloting than in West German elections. East Germany's Christian Democrats enjoy a larger margin of support than their counterparts in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Jewish Leader Solomon Freehof Dead At 97
DOC.TEXT: Solomon B. Freehof, a rabbi who was considered one of the world's foremost Reform Jewish leaders died Tuesday of an undisclosed cause at Montefiore Hospital. He was 97. Freehof was elected president of the World Union for Progressive Judaism in 1959. He was the first American accorded that honor, which was seen as an acknowledgment of his stature in Reform Judaism. He also was president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis and as a member of the executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. He was honored in 1979 by the National Conference of Christians and Jews. A native of London, Freehof came to the United States in 1911. He was an honors graduate of Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati, where he later taught, and served as a Jewish chaplain for American soldiers in Europe during World War I. Freehof's first congregation was at the Kehillath Anshe Mayriv Temple in Chicago, which he left in 1934 to come to Pittsburgh. He served as rabbi at the Rodef Shalom Temple in the city's Shadyside neighborhood until his retirement in 1966. On retiring, he remembered his career this way: ``It's a happy profession provided that a man is suited for it, and to whom public life is not a trial. ``Religion brings out the best side of people and the minister represents the best,'' he said. ``The ministry has become a public service.'' Freehof is survived by his wife, Lillian. She is the author of more than 20 books of Jewish legend and children's stories.

DOC.HEAD: World's Most Expensive Decorator Dead at 71
DOC.TEXT: Valerian S. Rybar, known as the world's most expensive interior designer, has died of prostate cancer. He was 71. Rybar, internationally known for creating opulent rooms and extravagant party designs, died Saturday at his Manhattan home, said his partner, Jean-Francois Daigre. Rybar's clients included Nicholas and Genvieve DuPont, Samuel and Mitzi Newhouse, Pierre and Sao Schlumberger, Christina Onassis and Stavros Niarchos. He designed many of the furniture pieces and rugs he used, employing artisans from all over the world. He often chose opulent fabrics like satins trimmed with gold thread or red velvet. Mirrors and steel were Rybar signatures. ``The real luxury today is not that one incredible piece of furniture,'' he once said. ``It's perfect cooking and grooming facilities and perfect storage.'' The native of Yugoslavia began his career as a trainee at the Lord & Taylor department store in New York. Soon after he quit, he designed a headdress for an opera singer. Cosmetics company founder Elizabeth Arden saw it and ``took him under her wing,'' Daigre said. He stayed at Arden for three years, then began working on party designs and soon was hired by some of his clients to help them with their homes. Daigre joined Rybar in 1968. Their company had offices in New York and Paris. There are no survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Agrees to Shut Down Shelter While Settlement Negotiated
DOC.TEXT: A woman who angered neighbors and got in trouble with zoning authorities for taking in homeless mothers said Tuesday she would close down the operation and seek approval to run it as a shelter. In a letter to this southwestern Connecticut town's zoning enforcment officer, Donna Russell said she was ready to comply with the Dec. 15 order banning her from operating her lakefront home as a shelter. Russell wrote Donald Murray that she has agreed to go along with the order on the understanding that she and her 18-year-old son, Daniel, will not be fined and that no further action will be taken against them if she complies within a reasonable time. Last week, officials warned that Russell's son, the legal owner of the house, faced arrest on a misdemeanor charge of violating local zoning ordinances if the matter remained unresolved. Russell asked in her letter that she be given time to find alternate housing for the two women currently living in her home. The town issued its December cease-and-desist order after local officials concluded that Russell was operating a homeless shelter in violation of local zoning law. The law requires that three-quarters of the people living in a single family dwelling be related by blood, marriage or adoption. In her letter, Russell wrote, ``I still believe that the town's actions against me were unfair and unconstitutional.''

DOC.HEAD: Fortunes Turn for Texas, Massachusetts Banks
With BC-Banks-States
DOC.TEXT: Texas banks are back in the black after more than four years of steady losses, while once-thriving Massachusetts institutions have become the industry's biggest money-losers. Nationally, commercial banks earned $6.2 billion in the first three months of 1990, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Tuesday. The performance, except for a sharp earnings dip in the last half of 1989, was in line with bank profits over the past two years. But the overall performance masked dramatic turnarounds in some states. Texas banks, which lost $42 million during the first quarter of 1989, turned a profit of $164 million in the first quarter of this year. It was their first quarter in the black since the last quarter of 1985. Massachusetts banks went the other direction. They earned $202 million in the first quarter last year but lost $171 million in the January-March 1990 period, the worst loss of any state. The other states to post losses were New Hampshire and Rhode Island _ which border Massachusetts _ and Arizona. Economists said the reversal was telling evidence of the phenomenon of rolling recessions that have moved from region to region while the economy nationally has expanded for more than seven years. ``One of the characteristics of the 1980s was the rolling recession,'' said James J. McDermott Jr., an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a New York securities firm. ``Now we are having rolling recoveries as well. ``As banks in the Northeast experience pressure, banks in the Southwest are showing signs of stability and in some cases slight improvement.'' The problems in both Texas and Massachusetts stem from sharp drops in real estate values. But now Texas real estate is recovering as New England's declines. In Massachusetts, 9.22 percent of banks' real estate loans were delinquent in the first three months of 1990, up from 6.89 percent in the previous quarter. In Texas, the delinquency rate fell from 10.34 percent to 6.76 percent. The FDIC said much of the improvement in Texas, however, could be attributed to the agency's bank rescues. ``Absent government assistance, there are no indicators yet of a strong performance rebound by Texas banks,'' it said. Economists said tough action by regulators forcing New England banks to take losses this year could benefit them in the long run. ``1990 is going to be a down year for a lot of banks, but it's conceivable if we get through 1990 without a significant weakening of the economy that they could resume healthy growth,'' said Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, a Washington-based think tank. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman characterized bank performance nationally as ``not a bad result given all the publicity given to real estate problems.'' But analysts said it would take a downturn at only a few large banks to cause trouble for the insurance fund, which posted back-to-back losses in 1988 and 1989, even if most of the industry is healthy. ``The FDIC can still lose its shirt on the bottom 10 percent. In fact, it can lose ... everything it's wearing and everything in the house,'' Litan said. The percentage of banks losing money rose to 10.15 in the first quarter from 9.12 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: AG Said Within Law in Heading Clean Air Talks Despite Investments
DOC.TEXT: Government officials say Attorney General Dick Thornburgh acted within the law in heading discussions on revising the Clean Air Act even though 20 percent of his assets are in stocks affected by the legislation. President Bush granted ethics-law waivers to Thornburgh last spring so the attorney general could head Domestic Policy Council discussions leading to proposals to amend the Clean Air Act, administration officials said. Thornburgh needed the waivers because he held $149,827 in stocks and bonds in 12 major industrial and oil companies and a public utility, Alvin A. Schall, a Thornburgh aide, said Tuesday. These holdings amounted to 20 percent of the attorney general's assets of $722,083, Schall said. Federal conflict-of-interest law bars high-ranking government officials from participating in decisions that would affect them personally. But the law allows for granting waivers if the financial interest ``is not so substantial'' or was ``too remote or too inconsequential to affect the integrity of government officer's or employee's services.'' ``You probably could make a pretty good argument that it isn't even necessary to get a waiver, but just to be safe we did,'' Schall said. He said the clean-air waivers were sought even though there was only ``a very attenuated relationship'' between any action the council might take on clean-air issues and the value of Thornburgh's investments. The Office of Government Ethics did not object to the waivers, deputy director Donald Campbell said. ``The statute allows the appointing authority, in this case the president, to find that a financial holding is not so substantial and significant as to affect performance,'' Campbell said. ``If he was taking action that would specifically affect one of those companies, a waiver is not the way to resolve it,'' he added. Thornburgh obtained the clean-air waivers in May 1989 when the Domestic Policy Council, which he chairs, was considering acid rain, toxic emissions from factories and ozone pollution. The attorney general's investments covered by the two waivers included holdings in four oil companies _ Amoco Corp., Atlantic Richfield, Mobil Corp., and Shell Oil Co., _ and General Motors, General Electric and Westinghouse. The other affected holdings were investments in Wisconsin Public Service Corp., Arco Chemical Corp., Black & Decker Corp., PPG Industries, Inc., Procter & Gamble Co., and Eastman Kodak Co. The waiver for acid-rain covered the Wisconsin utility, in which Thornburgh has less than a $5,000 investment. The investments cited for a potential conflict-of-interest in discussion of toxic-emission issues amounted to 16 percent of the attorney general's assets. Holdings implicated by the ozone issue amounted to 4 percent of Thornburgh's assets, Schall said. According to the financial statement Thornburgh filed last month, those holdings were worth between $109,000 and $365,000, or 37 percent of an investment portfolio valued between $287,000 and $977,000. The financial disclosure law requires federal officials to report only broad ranges in the value of their stock and bond holdings. Schall provided the details on the value of the stock in oil and industrial companies at the time the waiver was granted 13 months ago. At that time, Thornburgh calculated the value of the affected holdings according to their current market value, Schall said. Thornburgh was also granted a waiver to participate in the drafting of legislation to ease antitrust restrictions to encourage the formation of joint-production ventures, Schall said. Thornburgh cited holdings in American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and International Business Machines Corp. as posing a potential conflict of interest. The attorney general's holdings in each of the two companies is valued between $5,000 and $15,000, according to his latest financial disclosure statement. The waiver to help write joint-production legislation was sought because both AT&T and IBM are involved in the research involving high-definition television, Schall said. Thornburgh has shunned involvement in a number of issues because of his financial holdings.

DOC.HEAD: Feminist Groups Angered Over Current Issue of Esquire Magazine
DOC.TEXT: Feminist groups announced a boycott Tuesday against Esquire magazine, saying they're outraged by the latest issue of the monthly featuring an article entitled ``Your Wife: An Owner's Manual.'' ``We find it to be literally an expression of the degradation of women,'' said Tammy Bruce, president of the local chapter of the National Organization for Woman. ``It puts us into a subhuman level, places women into a thing mode,'' Bruce said in a telephone interview. The June edition of Esquire devotes several articles to wives and lists ``The Twelve Virtues of the Perfect Wife,'' which describes the ideal woman as obedient, thrifty and reverent. NOW and The Feminist Majority urged members and supporters to mount a letter-writing and telephone campaign against Esquire. The groups also urged subscribers to cancel and advertisers to withdraw their ads. Calls to the New York-based magazine seeking comment were met with busy signals for hours Tuesday. In a news conference at a newsstand, the feminist groups demanded that Esquire's editor in chief, Lee Eisenberg, publicly apologize and devote an upcoming issue to a realistic view of women. ``We want an issue devoted to a positive view of women in society, that will look at violence against women and at the women's movement,'' Bruce said. ``We're not saying don't publish, we're saying balance it,'' she said. The current issue includes a special ``Owner's Manual'' pullout section that includes article on `` Her Handbag,'' ``Her Bra,'' and ``Her Medicine Chest.'' ``Her Plumbing'' shows a hand-drawn map of a wife's reproductive organs represented as pipes, valves and other various elements of household plumbing. Bruce conceded that some of the 17 articles in the issue are spoofs, but said the joke went too far.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Veto Sustained, But Democrats Have Second Chance
With PM-Hatch Act
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's string of successful vetoes remains unbroken, but Democrats are maneuvering for a second chance to force an Amtrak aid bill into law over his objections. Bush emerged Tuesday with the 11th veto of his term intact after Democrats failed by three votes to muster the two-thirds majority needed to override the president's veto of a bill to support the rail service. The president vetoed the $2 billion authorization bill last month because it also would have required that the Interstate Commerce Commission approve acquisitions of major freight railroads by non-railroad companies. Republicans promised during Tuesday's debate that Bush would support a substitute bill continuing support for the passenger rail service as long as the regulatory provision is omitted. ``If they send us the bill without the ICC provision, he'll sign it,'' White House spokesman Steve Hart said after the 64-36 vote. Sixty-seven votes were needed. Democrats will really only need to find two votes, however, since one of the 36 votes was that of Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Despite his desire to override the veto, Mitchell voted with 35 Republicans to sustain it. Since he was on the winning side, Mitchell is able under Senate rules to call for a second vote if Democrats can find the two extra votes needed to override. Those two votes will have to be Republicans, since all 55 Democrats in the Senate have come out for the override. There is no deadline for the second vote. Party pride was at stake, said Sen. J. James Exon, D-Neb. ``I hope that we can get back not to what's nice for the party, but what is right for America,'' he said. ``Overriding this veto is certainly right for America and its transportation needs.'' Despite the victory, it was the closest veto fight for Bush so far. In the House last week, 58 Republicans joined 236 Democrats in voting to override the Amtrak veto. It was the first time either chamber had voted against the president. A two-thirds majority is needed in both chambers to override a veto. Republicans have introduced bills in both chambers to authorize federal spending for Amtrak, but without the regulatory provision that prompted the veto. The Senate version was introduced on the floor Tuesday night by Sen. Conrad Burns, R-Mont. The Bush administration and the Reagan administration before it proposed to eliminate money for Amtrak from all their budget requests. The bill Bush vetoed was not a funding bill but rather an authorization bill. That means it gave Congress permission to appropriate funds later for specific purposes. The ICC already must approve any sale of one railroad to another. But supporters of the vetoed bill say the jurisdiction is needed over acquisitions by non-railroad companies to prevent against the dismantling of railroad assets to pay for the takeovers. ``What we want to avoid is a situation where people come in and buy the railroad and then just dismember it,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. In his veto message, Bush called the proposed ICC oversight ``an unwarranted regulatory roadblock to the financial restructuring of the railroad industry.''

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Allow Federal Workers in Partisan Politics
With PM-Amtrak-Veto Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Although they've been whipped in each and every veto showdown with President Bush, congressional Democrats are showing no inclination to stay down on the mat for the 10-count. As the Senate sustained Bush's veto of bill to authorize $2 billion for Amtrak rail passenger service, the House set up a veto fight with the White House over how much federal workers can participate in political campaigns. By an overwhelming 334-87 vote, the House on Tuesday rebuffed the administration's latest veto threat and sent Bush a bill to allow federal workers to take an active role in partisan politics for the first time in more than half a century. Ninety, or more than half of the House's 176 Republicans, including GOP Leader Robert Michel of Illinois, bolted from the administration in joining with 244 Democrats to approve the changes in the 1939 Hatch Act. The Senate passed the same bill by a potentially veto-overriding 67-30 vote last month. But GOP leaders there have expressed confidence they can persuade enough colleagues to change votes to sustain a veto. To win a veto fight, Bush must garner more than a third of the votes in either the House or Senate, as he did Tuesday with 36 of the Senate's 100 members voted to sustain his veto of the Amtrak bill. In an effort to avoid another veto fight over the Hatch law, which outlaws most political activities for 3 million civil service and postal workers, House leaders agreed to accept a Senate version less onerous to the administration but still opposed by top administration aides. Many supporters of the changes had expressed a willingness to yield even further _ such as maintaining the current prohibitions for employees of intelligence agencies _ if the administration would only negotiate with them. But Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a letter Tuesday that he and other senior advisers to Bush oppose any change in the 51-year-old Hatch law and would recommend that the president veto the bill. ``Such a reversal in the role of partisan politics in the ethic of public service would permit virtually unbridled partisan activities by federal employees,'' Thornburgh wrote. Unlike the original House bill last year, the measure that Congress is sending to Bush retains current prohibitions against federal workers running for partisan office or soliciting campaign funds from the public. If enacted, government employees could begin holding office in local, state and national political party organizations for the first time and solicit campaign funds from co-workers on behalf of federal employee union political action committees, but only when not working. The original House version approved by an overwhelming 297-90 vote in April 1989 would have allowed government workers to take leaves of absence to run for partisan office and solicit campaign funds from anyone. ``We are not advocating the grey masses ... rising up in a coup,'' said Rep. William Ford, D-Mich., a sponsor of the bill. ``We're only asking for the simple right to put up a yard sign, display a bumper sticker, send a check or stuff envelopes.'' The Hatch law was enacted at the height of the New Deal to protect a then-emerging professional civil service from being coerced by political appointees to contribute to or work on behalf of candidates. Opponents of changing the law argued that its protections against a spoils system are still needed.

DOC.HEAD: New Government Stirring Controversy With Stances on Settlements, Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: The new right-wing government says it will spend more on Jewish settlements in the occupied lands and won't promise not to settle Soviet Jews there, positions bound to set it on a collision course with Washington. Also Tuesday, a member of the Cabinet's defense committee said Israel should deport the leaders of the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Washington opposes both deportations and Jewish settlement in lands captured from Arab countries in the 1967 Middle East war. It also has urged Israel to show restraint in dealing with the uprising. In the latest uprising-related violence, Israeli troops pursuing Palestinian stone-throwers fired tear gas into a U.N. clinic in Gaza City Tuesday, and 66 infants and toddlers were treated for inhaling the fumes, the army said. In Jerusalem, a 17-year-old Jewish seminary student going to prayers at the Western Wall was stabbed twice in the stomach. He was reported in fair condition at a Jerusalem hospital. On the new government's first working day, it was criticized by Israeli newspapers across the political spectrum, as well as by Arab leaders. The coalition is made up of 10 rightist and religious factions and led by the Likud bloc of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Parliament approved the government on Monday. The independent Haaretz daily wrote that Shamir's proposed polices ``will only worsen Israel's international isolation.'' The left-leaning Al Hamishar said they would ``cause further incitement among the Palestinian population.'' The conservative Maariv daily wrote that ``no government in the country's history was born of greater sin than the present one.'' Shamir's coalition was built with the help of defectors lured by promises of Cabinet posts and money. In Cairo, the Egyptian government said in a statement that Israel has apparently begun ``to prepare for aggression and war.'' Official Cairo Radio said President Hosni Mubarak telephoned President Bush to discuss developments in the Middle East, but gave no further details. Egypt is the only Arab state to have signed a peace treaty with Israel. In Jordan, King Hussein called the new Israeli government a ``dangerous threat.'' And in Syria, Israel's bitter enemy, President Hafez Assad warned of a new war with the Jewish state and said such a confrontation would be bloodier than any of the previous wars. Relations between Israel and Washington have been troublesome since Shamir, prodded by Foreign Minister David Levy and fellow hard-liner Ariel Sharon, rejected a proposal by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for preliminary peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians in Cairo. Ties have also been burdened by the stepped-up settlement activity fostered by Shamir's outgoing caretaker government, despite sharp objections from President Bush. The Bush administration has demanded a halt to all settlements and specifically called for assurances that Israel not settle Soviet Jewish immigrants in the occupied lands. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has also hinted he might slow Jewish emigration unless Israel promises not to settle Soviet Jews in the occupied lands. More than 51,000 Soviet Jews have arrived since last year, and about 3,700 of them have settled in the West Bank and Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem, which were seized in the 1967 Middle East war along with the Gaza Strip. Sharon rejected the superpower demands Tuesday, saying Israel was a democracy and could not tell its citizens where to live. ``I don't think Israel has to make any declarations. Israel doesn't need any document of honesty,'' he said after taking office as housing minister and head of the ministerial committee on immigration. Levy, a hard-line Likud member and a key campaigner against U.S. Middle East peace proposals, said Tuesday that he would try to patch up strained relations with Washington, but he did not elaborate. Also, the director general of the Interior Ministry, Dov Kehat, met with Jewish settlers in the Gaza Strip and promised his office would allocate more money to expand the settlements. Ministry spokeswoman Tova Eilinson said the money would go toward improving the infrastructure in Gush Katif area, comprising 15 settlements for 3,500 people along the Mediterranean coast. Agriculture Minister Rafi Eitan, a member of the Cabinet's defense committee, told army radio that more Palestinians should be deported. ``I have said many times that the punishment of deportations is the most effective and most humane,'' he said. ``Instead of shooting at children, you have to deport those responsible, the inciters, the organizers.'' Israel has deported 60 Palestinians since the start of the uprising, drawing sharp criticism from the United States, which says the practice violates international human rights conventions. Since the rebellion began, 717 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 45 Israelis have also died in the violence. Eitan, a member of the ultra-rightist Tzomet faction, is a former chief of staff who led Israel's forces in the 1982 invasion of Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Differences Just Semantics, Bush Assures
DOC.TEXT: Is the Cold War over? Mikhail Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan say yes. George Bush suggests no. A difference of opinion? More like a ``difference of semantics,'' says Bush. Humpty Dumpty, in Lewis Carroll's ``Through the Looking Glass,'' tells Alice, ``When I use a word ... it means just what I choose it to mean, neither more nor less.'' Dumpty would fit right in as a speechwriter at the Bush White House, where words often mean only what the president wants them to convey. If they mean more or less to somebody else, he might dismiss the discrepancy as a matter of semantics. ``I see this glass not half empty, but half full and more,'' Bush said recently of U.S.-Soviet differences. Phrases like ``and more'' send aides scurrying to interpret, embellish, and put an official White House spin on the presidential remarks. So is the Cold War over or not? Gorbachev proclaimed after last week's superpower summit that the Cold War was indeed over. Even former President Reagan, who once referred to the Soviet Union as the ``evil empire,'' appeared to agree. In an Op-Ed page column in The New York Times earlier this week, Reagan wrote: ``Let us assume the Cold War is over, although that, in itself, does not mean we can afford to dismantle our defenses.'' Bush, however, was not willing to go even that far. He told a political audience in Des Moines, Iowa, that agreements reached at his summit with Gorbachev could lead to ``the beginning of the end of the Cold War.'' Does that mean that Bush thinks the Cold War is still being fought? And do he and Gorbachev disagree on so central an issue to U.S.-Soviet relations? ``I don't know,'' the president said. ``We've got a difference of semantics, don't we?'' Bush would not be pinned down on whether he thought the Cold War was over. For his own reasons, he was not joining Gorbachev and Reagan in their more upbeat assessments. ``We've got to wait and see how we can resolve all these problems out here,'' he continued. ``There are plenty of them around.'' Just what did Bush mean, a reporter asked recently, when he suggested that Gorbachev had shown ``willingness'' to peacefully resolve the Lithuanian crisis while saying officials of the rebellious Baltic republic had only shown ``some willingness to compromise?'' ``You're presenting me with some semantic difference that I did not intend to make,'' the president replied. In cases involving sensitive policy issues, Bush often chooses his words very carefully _ despite his reputation for fractured syntax _ either to clarify or obscure his meaning. Thus, the candidate who told Americans to ``read my lips: no new taxes'' was able to convene a budget summit with Congress by promising ``no preconditions.'' Surely that meant the administration was signaling it would consider tax increases. Or did it? Bush never did say, even though he once scolded: ``Read all the tea leaves. Listen to the nuances. It's out there very clearly.'' It was a matter of semantics, too, that enabled the president to defend his decision to send national security adviser Brent Scowcroft on a secret mission to China despite his own ban on ``high-level exchanges.'' Scowcroft's visit soon after the Tiananmen Square massacre that produced the ban was not an ``exchange;'' it was a ``contact'' and thus not covered by the edict, Bush said when the mission was disclosed last year. The president also redefines almost daily his rule against answering questions at ``photo opportunities.'' Bush cites his rule as grounds for ignoring questions shouted at him by reporters _ except when he wants to answer a question. Then he modifies the rule, recasts it or totally ignores it. On Tuesday, Bush added a new twist. ``No answers _ only those wearing hats get their question answered,'' he announced. It was his 66th birthday and some reporters wore children's party hats to a picture-taking session between Bush and congressional leaders. In the wonderland of presidential semantics, it's often up to chief White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater to bridge the gap between what is said and what is meant. For instance, on Monday, he was asked whether Bush was near a decision on cutting off talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization to protest the May 30 attack by Palestinian guerrillas on an Israeli beach. The president had ``no timetable'' for such a decision, Fitzwater said. But moments earlier, Vice President Dan Quayle had condemned the PLO and had told an audience of Jewish leaders that Bush would make the ``right decision'' and make it ``soon.'' ``Soon is totally consistent with no timetable,'' Fitzwater deadpanned.
