EDITOR'S NOTE: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows 49 Percent Believe Incurably Ill Have Right To Take Own Life
DOC.TEXT: About half the American people believe the incurably ill and those hopelessly wracked with pain have a moral right to commit suicide, according to a survey described as relevant to ``suicide doctor'' Jack Kevorkian's case. But an expert on the legal aspects of medical ethics says patients have ``absolutely no right'' to demand that a physician assist them in ending their lives. `` `Thou shalt not kill' still stands in this society, especially for doctors,'' Susan M. Wolf, a lawyer with the Hastings Center, a research institute that studies medical ethics, said in a telephone interview from Briaircliff Manor, N.Y.. The poll, conducted for the Times Mirror Center for The People and the Press, showed that 49 percent of the public believe a person with an incurable disease has a moral right to commit suicide. It said 55 percent believe in such a right for people suffering great pain with no hope of improvement. The telephone poll of 1,213 adults was conducted during the first week in May, about a month before Kevorkian touched off a furor by assisting in the suicide of a 54-year-old woman who had been diagnosed as being in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease. Diane Colasanto, a researcher for the Times Mirror Center, said the survey did not include any questions about physician-assisted suicide, but added, ``I think what we found is relevant to the Kevorkian case.'' Kevorkian, a retired pathologist in Pontiac, Mich., created an intravenous device that he hooked up to Janet Adkins of Portland, Ore., at her request. It allowed Mrs. Adkins to press a button that fed coma- and death-inducing drugs into her bloodstream. Kevorkian has not been charged, and prosecutors say it may take up to two months to get results of toxicological studies of the dead woman's brain to determine whether the Alzheimer's diagnosis was correct. In the meantime, Circuit Judge Alice Gilbert has ordered him to stop using his suicide machine and to refrain from doing anything else to help patients take their own lives. ``The Kevorkian case has demonstrated that there still is a lot of confusion among three very different things, one being the right of a patient to commit suicide,'' Ms. Wolf said. This question, she said, is distinct from ``whether a physician should be authorized to assist'' in a suicide and from ``the completely separate question of whether treatment should be terminated at the patient's request.'' The Supreme Court is expected to rule on the latter issue soon in the case of Nancy Cruzan, 31, of Carterville, Mo., who suffered severe brain damage in a 1983 automobile accident. Her parents, Joe and Joyce Cruzan, want doctors to remove a feeding tube from her stomach. ``The feeding tube removal presented by the Cruzan case has caused a lot of controversy in part because ... when you pull a feeding tube it is foreseeable often that the patient will indeed die,'' said Ms. Wolf. However, she said, ``When a clinician honors a patient's request to be free of an unwanted treatment, he is essentially letting nature take its course.'' ``There is a long history with ancient roots to the notion that people are entitled to be free of unwanted bodily invasion,'' she said. ``On the other hand people have absolutely no right to demand that a clinician assist them in suicide.'' The Times Mirror poll showed that eight of 10 Americans think patients should be allowed to die in some circumstances. Eight in 10 also approved of state laws allowing medical treatment for a terminally ill patient to be withdrawn or withheld if that is what the patient wishes. The poll was conducted May 1-5. The Times Mirror center, an arm of the Times Mirror publishing and broadcasting organization, said it was subject to a possible error of three percentage points either way because of sampling and other random effects.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Lags in Development of High-Definition TV
DOC.TEXT: The United States could be damaging its world position in high technology by falling behind in development of high-definition television, congressmen say. ``The message is clear: Congress and the administration, get moving,'' said Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif. ``We must recognize the huge significance of HDTV to our economy.'' A report issued Tuesday by the Office of Technology Assessment, a research arm of Congress, said the United States lags behind Japan in development of HDTV. ``Japan considers HDTV to be an important step into the future information society,'' it said. High-definition television promises motion picture-quality images and compact disc-quality sound. Proponents say its development could help re-energize the U.S. electronics and computer industries. New consumer electronics have long spurred advances in other fields, such as data storage and defense industries, said Levine and Reps. George Brown, D-Calif., and Don Ritter, R-Pa. Little work has been done in the United States on developing HDTV, the report said. Zenith is the only U.S.-owned company that still manufactures television sets. But the Japanese have been selling studio equipment for high-definition television since 1984 and are gearing up for large-scale production of HDTV sets for consumers, the report said. ``The little work done on HDTV in the United States has largely been by or for foreign-owned consumer electronics firms or by small, underfunded university programs and entrepreneurs,'' it said. A Pentagon agency charged with HDTV development, the High-Resolution Systems Task Force, received $10 million this year for advanced TV research. The task force wants $100 million a year. Brown, who requested the report, said at a news conference, ``We cannot afford to be left behind'' in HDTV development and the other technologies it can aid. ``By our refusing to mount a national HDTV effort we are assuring ourselves a dangerously diminished global economic position,'' Levine said. Ritter said he believed the Bush administration was starting to do ``a lot more listening'' to calls that it get behind HDTV development. The Federal Communications Commission has received a number of proposals by companies to set the national standard for HDTV broadcasts. The systems are to be tested for 12 to 18 months before the government chooses the standard in 1993. No one knows how well high-definition TVs would sell in the United States, the OTA report said, but the potential market value is large. The Electronic Industries Association estimates the market could total $12 billion a year, in 1988 dollars, by 2003 _ $4 billion more than the market would be for standard TV sets. Commercial and industrial uses also could be important, OTA said. Manufacturing technologies developed for HDTV would aid producers of computers and telecommunications equipment, it said. The government also would benefit, the report said, noting that the Federal Aviation Administration already has contracted with the Sony Corp. to buy high-resolution display screens to monitor air traffic.

DOC.HEAD: Bumper Harvest Expected to Replenish Low Wheat Inventory
DOC.TEXT: The nation's shrunken wheat inventory is expected to increase sharply as farmers move into a bumper harvest, according to the latest Agriculture Department forecasts. But the important 1990 corn crop is still being planted and it will be a couple of months before firm yield estimates are ready. Winter wheat production was estimated Tuesday at a nine-year high of 2.09 billion bushels. That was down fractionally from the May forecast, but still 44 percent more than last year's drought-battered harvest of 1.45 billion bushels. Figures released by the department's Agricultural Statistics Board showed the decline from the May forecast was only about 0.1 percent, or less than 2.4 million bushels. The average yield, based on indications as of June 1, was estimated at 41.2 bushels per acre, compared with 41.1 bushels indicated last month and the 1989 yield of 35.1 bushels. Farmers are expected to harvest fewer than 50.7 million acres, down from 50.8 million indicated in May. ``Wet conditions have caused yield declines in the (Mississippi) Delta area,'' the report said. ``Early harvested fields in Arkansas had low test weights, and diseases are a problem.'' The Missouri crop is developing late, with about 23 percent ``turning color'' in the ripening process as of June 3, approximately 10 days behind the usual pace, the report said. In Kansas, winter wheat production was estimated at 460.2 million bushels, unchanged from the May forecast and more than double the shriveled 1989 harvest of 213.6 million bushels. Winter wheat is planted in the fall and harvested the next year. It accounts for about three-fourths of the U.S. total wheat production. The remainder is planted in the spring. The USDA's first official estimate of 1990 production of all wheat will be issued July 12. The first estimates for corn, soybeans and some other major spring-planted crops are scheduled for Aug. 9, along with revised figures for wheat. No official estimates of total 1990 wheat output based on field surveys were included. However, department analysts in a related report did project ``highly tentative'' 1990 production of all wheat at almost 2.69 billion bushels, up from fewer than 2.04 billion bushels last year and virtually unchanged from the May projection. Projections for all wheat and some other crops were based on yield trends and an assumption the crop would have normal weather the remainder of the growing season. The 1990 corn harvest was projected at 8.1 billion bushels, up from 7.53 billion harvested last year and unchanged from May. Soybean production was projected at 1.925 billion bushels, also unchanged from last month and virtually the same as the crop of 1.927 billion bushels in 1989. According to the supply-and-demand report, the U.S. wheat stockpile was drained to a 15-year low of 452 million bushels on June 1, the beginning of the new wheat marketing year. But with the expected larger 1990 harvest, the wheat stockpile could be rebuilt to about 772 million bushels a year from now. The projected larger 1990 wheat harvest is putting pressure on market prices, which were indicated in both May and June in the range of $2.90 to $3.30 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with an estimated $3.71 last season. If corn production turns out at the projected level of 8.1 billion bushels, it still wouldn't be quite enough to match domestic and export demand, the report showed. Thus, the U.S. corn stockpile, which may be around 1.28 billion bushels next fall, could edge lower by Oct. 1, 1991. Corn prices were projected at $2.35 to $2.75 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with the current season's forecast of $2.35 to $2.40 per bushel. That was up 10 cents per bushel from last month's 1990-91 projection. Soybeans were indicated at an average of $6.25 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year that begins Sept. 1, compared with $5.70 this season. That was unchanged from May. Other June crop estimates included: _Oranges, 184 million boxes, up 3 percent from May prospects but down 12 percent from last season. _Peach production, including California clingstones, 2.13 billion pounds, down 9 percent from last year. The California clingstone crop, at 1 billion pounds, is up 1 percent from 1989. _Barlett pear production in the Pacific Coast states, 545,000 tons, up 4 percent from last year. _Sweet cherry production in the Western states, 131,000 tons, down 22 percent from last year. _Almond output, a record 670 million pounds, up 37 percent from last year. _Spring potato production, 23.8 million hundredweight, up 14 percent from the 1989 harvest.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Spreading Faster to Developing Countries
DOC.TEXT: With better reporting systems, international health experts have a clearer view of the AIDS epidemic as it spreads around the world, but they don't like what they're seeing in developing countries. ``The global balance of HIV infection is rapidly tipping toward the developing countries,'' said Michael Merson, director of the World Health Organization Global Program on AIDS. These countries currently account for about half of the 6 million to 8 million people worldwide infected with the AIDS-causing human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV. By the end of the decade their share will probably increase to 70 percent to 80 percent, and possibly to 90 percent in 2010, according to figures WHO released Tuesday. ``What's going to happen in this decade is that AIDS will continue to increase in Africa, primarily in countries that don't have large rates of infection now,'' Merson said in an interview. ``In addition, we're starting to see considerable increases in Asian countries and South American countries, and also in the Caribbean.'' Part of the reason for the faster-than-expected spread of HIV in these countries is that the limited data available previously made accurate predictions difficult and better reporting systems are now in place, said Dr. David Brandling-Bennett of the Pan American-World Health Organization. However, officials have documented an alarming increase in HIV infection in Thailand, and are unsure why it is spreading so quickly, he said. In that Asian country, the number of people who have been infected and their cases reported to authorities rose from about 1,000 in 1987 to 50,000 currently, Merson said. He added that only about one-third of actual cases get reported. Among prostitutes in Thailand, fewer than 1 percent were reported with HIV infection in 1987. Now, the rate is as high as 40 percent in some cities, Merson said. WHO had been projecting that by the end of the decade, 15 million to 20 million people worldwide will have been infected with HIV, but officials now say that is a minimum estimate. The forecast is expected to be pushed up by the startling increase of AIDS in the developing countries as well as by an increase in heterosexual transmission of the disease in industrialized countries. New projections will not be ready until late this year or 1991, Merson said. He declined to estimate how high the projection could go. The virus is spread mainly by sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood and blood products, and by pregnant women to their babies. In the United States, most of the people with AIDS have been homosexual men and intravenous drug users. However, Merson said that in industrialized countries _ such as the United States _ with inner-city poverty and high rates of intravenous drug use and sexually transmitted diseases, heterosexual transmission is increasing. About 60 percent of HIV infections worldwide have resulted from heterosexual intercourse, but by the turn of the century, that proportion is expected to rise as high as 80 percent, Merson said. In Africa, the virus is being spread primarily through heterosexual intercourse, and as many women are infected as men. An estimated 3.5 million sub-Saharan Africans have been infected with the virus, accounting for more than half the global total of HIV infection. Since the first AIDS cases were reported in 1981, more than 250,000 have been reported to WHO from more than 150 countries, but because of under-reporting and delays in reporting, agency officials believe that number is closer to 700,000. That number is expected to grow to about 5.5 million by the end of the decade. As of April 30, AIDS had been diagnosed in 132,510 Americans, of whom 61 percent, or 80,798, have died since June 1, 1981, according to the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Midol Manufacturer to Pay Fine for Unsubstantiated Ads
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest manufacturer of over-the-counter menstrual relief medicine must pay $375,000 to settle charges that it made unsubstantiated advertising claims. Sterling Drug Inc. reached agreement on Tuesday with the Federal Trade Commission concerning a 1985 complaint that eventually encompassed advertising for all but one of the company's products. The agreement ``is without admission of any wrongdoing,'' said Terry Kelley, spokesman for Sterling Drug Inc., which makes Midol brand products. We entered into the consent decree ``to avoid protracted, costly litigation.'' A court battle would have involved ``highly technical scientific issues,'' said Kelley, noting that the agreement ``does not involve our current advertising.'' ``Sterling will continue to manufacture and market the Midol brand products,'' he said, adding that all the questionable ads were halted by March. The FTC said Sterling had violated a 1985 order prohibiting product performance claims unless a company has ``competent and reliable evidence for those claims.'' The complaint said Sterling ran certain ads for ``Original Formula Midol'' and ``Maximum Strength Midol for Cramps'' from March 1985 to January 1986 and in April 1988 that claimed or implied one of the ingredients was a muscle relaxant for menstrual cramps that would quickly help relieve muscle contractions. ``The ingredient in question has been removed from the product,'' according to Sterling. Also cited were ads for ``Maximum Strength Midol PMS'' which claimed ``total'' or ``complete relief'' for the symptoms of premenstrual syndrome. The FTC also said the company had no scientific evidence that ``Original Midol Muti-Symptom Formula'' and ``Maximum Strength Midol Multi-Symptom Formula'' relieved menstrual water-weight gain. Advertising for Sterling's Midol 200 was not included in the complaint. Sterling is based in New York City and is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Co.

DOC.HEAD: Police Warn Record Stores Against Selling Rap Album
With PM-Florida Vice, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Record store managers pulled an album by the rap group 2 Live Crew from their shelves after police warned they risked arrest for obscenity. Detectives set out Tuesday to notify 84 stores that the lyrics of the 1.7 million-selling album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' are obscene, said vice squad commander Lt. Jerry Pittman. The action extends what had been a Florida-based campaign by anti-pornography crusaders upset by the album's references to sex acts and genitals. A federal judge in Florida last week declared the record obscene. Texas law requires that a defendant be aware material is obscene to be convicted of selling it, Pittman said. The maximum penalty is a year in jail and a $2,000 fine. Some record store managers and workers said they were asked by police to sign a statement saying they had been warned the lyrics are obscene. ``It's censorship, and they're starting it,'' said Greta Colbin, manager at a Hastings Records and Tapes outlet. ``It's a violation of our rights.'' She said stores in her chain don't sell ``R'' rated albums to anyone under 18. Another record store manager agreed with the police action. ``I'm not one of the people for censorship, but I think this music is ridiculous,'' said Mark Christy, branch manager of a Sound Warehouse. Pittman said a Bexar County assistant district attorney, Mike Schill, reviewed transcripts and listened to the lyrics before determining some of the words violate the state's obscenity law. The prosecutor wrote to Pittman May 29 that he was convinced the lyrics of ``Put Her In the Buck'' and ``Me So Horney'' were obscene but that his office would not issue a letter telling merchants to remove the album. ``We believe that such action might be considered `prior restraint' and unconstitutional by the appellate courts,'' Schill wrote. Police Chief William O. Gibson said removal of the records was voluntary, but that the district attorney's office has agreed to prosecute cases resulting from complaints by local anti-pornography groups. Schill said he would evaluate each case police bring him for prosecution. The Texas state courts would not be bound by the federal judge's ruling, which the rap group's attorney appealed Monday. In Florida, two members of the band were arrested on obscenity charges after performing material from the album, and a record store owner was arrested for selling the album.

DOC.HEAD: Plans to Curb Assault Weapons Move Forward A Notch
DOC.TEXT: Semiautomatic assault weapons made in the United States would be subject to the curbs already applying to the imported variety under a bill approved by the House Judiciary Committee. ``These are lethal weapons regardless of the country of origin,'' Rep. William J. Hughes, D-N.J., said Tuesday as the panel approved the bill, 21-15. The measure would require the Treasury secretary to issue a list of weapons that could not be sold because they lacked a ``sporting purpose.'' The bill also would ban magazines and other ammunition-feeding devices with a capacity of more than seven rounds, bar the manufacture of firearms to which silencers or bayonets could be directly attached and halt the export of assault weapons to governments that violate human rights or aid terrorists. People who already owned such weapons would be able to keep them. But the bill calls for fresh regulations governing their transfer to new owners. Manufacturers could still produce them for the military. The bill would double from five to 10 years the mandatory minimum penalty for using or carrying an assault weapon in a violent crime or drug-related crime. Opponents said the bill would not cut down on crime much because the weapons of choice among criminals are mainly shotguns and .38-caliber pistols. Rep. Bill McCollum, R-Fla., said that in some cases the statistics concerning assault weapons ``have been construed in a somewhat misleading fashion,'' making it appear they are the primary firearms of criminals. Supporters, however, pointed to multiple slayings in Stockton, Calif., and Louisville over the last 18 months by criminals armed with semiautomatic assault rifles. McCollum noted statements by authorities that there is ``no functional difference'' between traditional semiautomatic hunting rifles with their brown wooden stocks and military-style variants. Committee Chairman Jack Brooks, D-Texas, backed a McCollum amendment that would have made gun collecting and the ``plinking'' of tin cans and the like part of the definition of ``sporting purpose.'' Brooks said McCollum's amendment would ``give bureaucratic regulators a little more guidance'' about what Congress had in mind. But the proposal was rejected 20-16, with Hughes saying that ``my colleague from Florida, who I love dearly, is going to be considered a legislative grim reaper because he once again offers an amendment that would gut the bill.'' In the Senate, sponsors of an omnibus crime bill containing restrictions on nine semiautomatic assault weapons searched for a way to salvage the measure, which was withdrawn from the floor last week after lawmakers balked at cutting short a threatened filibuster. Senate Judiciary Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., fielded questions about the bill at a meeting of Democrats, aides said. But they said he also had to prepare for committee action in the wake of a Supreme Court decision throwing out the nation's law against flag burning.

DOC.HEAD: East German Living Standard Seen Rising to Western Level
DOC.TEXT: The East German prime minister is warning his countrymen against going on a shopping spree in their tender economy when they begin to enjoy the West German mark instead of their nearly worthless currency. ``They'll use the new money in the summer months to travel where they haven't been able to travel,'' Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere told the National Press Club on Tuesday. ``I hope their eagerness to buy will hold itself within bounds, because otherwise there would be serious difficulties for the economy,'' he added. De Maiziere addressed the club on his first trip to the United States, which may be his last as the formerly communist East Germany hurtles toward reunification in three weeks with West Germany, whose economy is quite healthy. He said unity would be costly to West Germany in the short run but that over a longer period it would bring an economic boom _ especially if West Germans invest in East Germany instead of just marketing their goods there. If West Germany saw its eastern neighbor only as new customers, it would lead to great social tensions and reproaches, he added. On July 2, the nearly worthless East German mark will be replaced by highly valuable West German marks. The exchange rate will be one-for-one. Under communism, East German black marketeers were willing to pay seven, or even 10, to one. Klaus Friedrich, former head of German affairs at the Federal Reserve, predicted that East Germany will achieve West German living standards in 10 years as a result of unification. Friedrich, now with the Institute of International Finance, also foresaw East German unemployment skyrocketing from 1 percent to 11 percent by the end of the year, robbing 1 million people of their jobs. He also predicted many formerly state-run factories, unable to compete in a capitalist marketplace, would close. But in a speech to the National Economists Club, Friedrich said German prices would remain fairly stable. ``I think that inflation, which currently runs between 2 and 3 percent in West Germany, will not be the dire consequence predicted,'' he said. ``Even if it doubles, which is unlikely, it will still be within a tolerable range.'' Generous West German social security benefits, to be granted to East Germans, are expected to cushion the effect of unemployment.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Chief Sees Major Military Layoffs if Budget Cut
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says significant cuts in President Bush's 1991 defense budget could force him to discharge more than 100,000 military personnel than already planned. Facing growing congressional opposition to Bush's $303.3 billion defense spending plan, Cheney told a Senate panel Tuesday that proposed reductions of more than $8 billion would cause ``great violence to our most important military asset _ our men and women.'' He estimated that if Congress adopts budget totals passed by the House on May 1, he would be forced to discharge 140,000 of the 2.1 million men and women now in uniform, about 103,000 more than in the current defense plan. ``The only place we can get those kinds of savings quickly in fiscal 1991 is our manpower,'' Cheney said. ``There's no other place to go. We'd have to run a lot of people off, throw people on the street, freeze promotions.'' White House officials and members of Congress are negotiating an overall budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 that would determine the amount of money for defense. The House approved a $1.2 trillion budget that earmarks $295.5 billion for defense _ $8.3 billion less than Bush has proposed. The Senate Budget Committee has approved a plan to cut his request by $9.4 billion. Cheney promised negotiators last week that by Thursday he would submit armed forces personnel projections for the next five years if defense spending is cut by 25 percent. The Pentagon chief provided a hint of the impact on Tuesday in testimony before the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on defense. Cheney said a 25 percent cut would result in a reduction of five to six Army divisions and five to six wings from the Air Force. Deputy Defense Secretary Donald Atwood, meantime, directed Pentagon personnel chief Christopher Jehn to coordinate a study on reducing the size of the officer corps in the 1990s in anticipation of a ``smaller force structure in light of changing world conditions and declining budgets. During the hearing, senators challenged Cheney's plan to buy 75 B-2 stealth bombers, which according to latest estimates could cost $860 million each. ``My view is that we probably ought to scrap the B-2 or just buy the B-2s in production,'' said Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark. Bumpers questioned whether the Soviets would be able to detect the radar-evading bomber if they develop a counterpart to the sophisticated Aegis radar that the United States has in its naval fleet. Cheney said the Air Force has not tested the B-2 against Aegis radar and that low observability testing of the bomber is scheduled to begin this fall. ``I'm confident the B-2 can do the mission that it's intended to do, but there's still a lot of testing to do,'' he said. Meanwhile, the Congressional Budget Office said that based on its inflation assumptions, the overall B-2 program of 75 planes would cost $64.9 billion _ more than Cheney's estimate of $61.1 billion and the Air Force's recent total of about $62 billion. The CBO figures that increase the cost of a single bomber from $815 million to about $860 million were included in a letter to Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., a B-2 opponent. The Union of Concerned Scientists and members of Congress on Tuesday kicked off a nationwide advertising campaign to end production of the B-2 bomber at the 15 currently in the pipeline. It called the bomber ``a mistake were cannot afford.''

DOC.HEAD: Morals Wave Washing Over Florida
DOC.TEXT: The crackdown on ribald rappers 2 Live Crew is part of a morals wave breaking across Florida's land of sand, sun and fun. ``It's a rising tide that is becoming increasingly difficult to contain,'' said Robyn Blumner, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Florida. Those supporting the crackdown argue that a tide of bawdy activity needed containment. Among the targets of their wrath: cheeky thong swimsuits, X-rated videos, nude bars and TV advertising for phone-sex services. U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez ruled here June 6 that the rap album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' is obscene. That was followed by the arrest two days later of a record shop owner who sold the album and the arrests in the wee hours Sunday of two 2 Live Crew members for performing songs from the record in concert. The crackdown has been attributed to politics, the influence of retirees and the increasing muscle of conservative groups. It has taken place mainly in tourist-driven beach areas associated with risque entertainment: _Gonzalez's ruling, which called the album with its graphic sexual content a violation of community standards in Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties, followed similar rulings by a local judge and grand juries in five counties. _In a four-county area that includes Daytona Beach, two video store owners were arrested and X-rated videos disappeared from most shops after 100 store owners were warned by State Attorney John Tanner against tapes deemed obscene. _In Sarasota, where charges earlier were dropped against a 19-year-old clerk accused of selling the 2 Live Crew album to a girl not yet in her teens, thong bikinis _ which have only a narrow piece of material covering the buttocks _ were banned. The state Cabinet on Tuesday approved a rule that swimsuits at state parks must cover at least half of a woman's breasts and everyone's buttocks. _In the Fort Lauderdale area, bars featuring nude dancing were banned last year unless they serve only non-alcoholic drinks. _In Palm Beach County, commissioner Ron Howard is seeking a ban on TV advertising for 900-number ``phone sex'' operations, in which callers are charged $10 or more to hear a woman talk dirty to them. Gonzalez called the 2 Live Crew case part of the continuing confrontation between anything goes and enough is enough. ``And anybody who lives in the land of `Miami Vice' as I do knows that just about anything goes down here,'' John Thompson, a Coral Gables lawyer who helped lead the fight against 2 Live Crew, said Monday on ABC's ``Nightline.'' But the days of ``anything goes'' appear to be going. ``I haven't seen anything like it down here. It reminds me of the McCarthy era. It shows that small minds aren't limited to small towns,'' said Woody Graber, a Miami Beach publicist who represents the Gold Club, an adult entertainment lounge that had to close because of restrictions such as requiring covering of nipples. It is operating now in compliance with the law. In not-too-distant days, Florida's beach areas were better known for wet T-shirt contests, spring break revelry and showings of porno flicks such as ``Deep Throat.'' But first Fort Lauderdale three years ago, and then Daytona Beach this year, toughened spring break standards, making arrest sweeps against drugs, drunkenness and lewd behavior. Ms. Blumner of the ACLU said such conservative organizations as the American Family Association have become well-organized in Florida in recent years. Ann Brittain, a University of Miami anthropology professor, noted that retirees make up nearly a fifth of Florida's 12 million residents. When they were raising their families, she said, they didn't want their children to watch Elvis Presley's undulating pelvis or listen to the Rolling Stones implore ``Let's Spend The Night Together.'' They may be shocked to hear of 2 Live Crew's raunchy lyrics, she said. ``The ones born in the 1905-1920 era, they see a L'eggs commercial, they get a little nervous,'' said Barry Freilich of Ormond Beach, a video store owner Tanner has charged with obscenity. Serial killer Ted Bundy, executed in Florida's electric chair in 1989, figures in some of the anti-pornography campaigning. Tanner, a born-again Christian, prayed with Bundy on death row and recounts that Bundy partly blamed his rape-murder rampage on hard-core pornography. Bundy discussed the effects of hard-core porn in his final interview, with radio psychologist James Dobson. Dobson's group, Focus on the Family, led Thompson to go after 2 Live Crew after Focus on the Family sent out transcripts of the album's lyrics. Blumner said Bundy is a pawn for the anti-porn groups. ``The fact of the matter is there are more sicko murderers who say God told them to kill than those who read Playboy,'' she said. She blames politics for the Florida push. Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, facing a tough re-election battle, spoke out early against 2 Live Crew. Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro, who ordered the 2 Live Crew arrests, has been accused by 2 Live Crew attorney Bruce Rogow and others of overzealousness. Civil liberties-minded politicians may find it hard to rush to the defense in such cases, Ms. Blumner said. ``They're hard issues for politicians to deal with in a constitutional way because the other side has commandeered the term pro-family,'' she said. ``They're easy issues for politicians who don't care about free expression rights.'' The governor defended his position this week, saying the 2 Live Crew album is ``audio pornography.'' ``Communities have the right to set a standard,'' Martinez said.

DOC.HEAD: City Employee who Prays for Mayor is Prospective Juror in Barry Trial
DOC.TEXT: A city employee who says she prays for Mayor Marion Barry is one of the prospective jurors at his cocaine and perjury trial. The woman was sent into the pool of 68 potential jurors Tuesday, along with nine other people. Meanwhile, top Barry aides said he would announce he was abandoning his re-election campaign plans. ``He will do it, but the only question left is when,'' one top Barry adviser said on condition of anonymity. ``We're all just waiting.'' . Barry told his top advisers and fund-raisers at a meeting Sunday that he would give up his plans for a fourth, four-year term. Several aides said the mayor was making that move in hopes of restarting stalled plea bargain talks in his drug case. Opening statements in Barry's trial are planned for early next week. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson plans to seat a jury on Monday. The prospective juror who said she has prayed for Barry in his time of legal troubles works in the District of Columbia's Department of Human Services. She said she didn't know any of the more than 50 potential witnesses in the case, including former human services department Director David Rivers. The judge said he is unable to conclude the woman was lying about the witness list. He also said her prayers for the defendant are not inconsistent with her assurances that she could be a fair and impartial juror. Barry is accused of 10 counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his alleged involvement with drugs. The three perjury counts are felonies.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Deserter Ready To Turn Himself In After 21 Years In Canada
DOC.TEXT: For the last 21 years, Ron Jacko has been afraid to cross the U.S. border. Now the Marine deserter has returned from Canada to turn himself in. Jacko, a native of Cleveland, left his Toronto home on Tuesday. He said he would present himself at the Marine base in Quantico, Va., this afternoon. Jacko, 42, said he wanted to make peace with himself and be free to see his mother. ``I wasn't able to go home for my father's funeral,'' he said. ``My mother's still alive, I'm an only child and she's about 74 herself right now. She just went through three operations in about the last six months. ``I don't want to be in a similar situation with my mom. I want to be able to be there.`` Jacko said he opposed the war from the outset, but decided to enlist in hopes of fulfilling his duty without going to Vietnam. He first tried to join the Navy, but flunked the entrance exam. The Navy recruiter then referred him to the Marine recruiter. The 21-year-old volunteer completed basic training and was assigned to communications school. That assignment persuaded him he was likely to be shipped to Vietnam, so while on leave he went home, said goodbye to his family and headed for Canada. ``It was a serious decision. It was a painful decision,'' he said. He's been living for 21 years in Toronto, where he married and worked as manager of a health food store. He said he didn't try to take advantage of amnesty programs during the Ford and Carter administrations because the first covered only draft dodgers and the second would have imposed a stigma and a status of ``clemency discharge.'' Looking back now, ``I wish I would have taken advantage of that program,'' Jacko said. Life as a deserter was never carefree, he said. ``It was eating at me, it was chewing at me.'' Finally, his mother's failing health persuaded him to turn himself in and try to tell the Marines that he deserves an administrative discharge, rather than a court-martial. He returned to the United States on Tuesday, and with a lawyer from the group Citizen Soldier, made the rounds of Washington news offices. Jacko and his attorney planned to talk today with the staff of Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio, and try to get meetings with Ohio's two senators before heading for Quantico. Oakar said Jacko had not made an appointment but letters from his attorney arrived Tuesday at her Cleveland and Capitol Hill offices. ``The letter says they want to talk to me. If they come, I want to talk to them,'' Oakar said. Jacko said he hopes attention from Congress and the public will help his case. ``Hope springs eternal, I guess. And naivete springs eternal, too.'' His wife, Nadia, did not accompany Jacko, but he said she would join him in his new home after his release.

DOC.HEAD: New FBI Policy Would Ease Weapons Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents would have more leeway to shoot at suspects under a proposed new policy, sources say. Agents could shoot fleeing suspects of violent crimes who are armed and considered likely to commit another crime, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Deadly force also could be used if the agent had a reasonable belief that the suspect could not be arrested without firing shots. Under current policy, FBI agents may use deadly force only in self-defense or to protect the life of another person. The new policy has been under study since 1985, when the Supreme Court held that police officers could shoot a fleeing, armed suspect if the officers believed the person posed a threat to public safety, said the sources. The increase in drug-related violence prompted the drafting of the new policy, said the sources. The FBI is awaiting clearance from Attorney General Dick Thornburgh before making an announcement of the policy change, said the sources. The bureau has also taken steps to replace its standard-issue .38-caliber Smith & Wesson revolvers with a 10mm automatic pistol, which officials say is in the process of being tested at FBI firing ranges. The new firepower was sought because FBI officials felt agents were outgunned on the nation's streets, officials say.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Engineer Nominated for MIT Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts Institute of Technology trustees vote Monday on their executive committee's choice of University of Michigan Provost Charles Vest to be the school's president. Vest, a 48-year-old engineer, would replace Paul Gray, who announced in March 1989 that he wanted to step down, MIT spokesman Ken Campbell said Tuesday. If Vest becomes the school's 15th president, it will end a yearlong search that frustrated officials at the prestigious private research university. MIT, founded in 1861, has 9,700 students. Initial front-runner John Deutch, then provost of MIT, withdrew after some faculty members bitterly opposed him. Another candidate, MIT biologist and Nobel laureate David Baltimore, was snapped up by Rockefeller University to become its president. Finally, Phillip Sharp agreed to take the job in February but changed his mind a week later, saying he would rather continue his teaching and cancer research at MIT. Vest has been at Michigan since his graduation from West Virginia University in 1963, except for a stint at Stanford University in the mid-1970s. He was dean of engineering at Michigan before becoming provost and vice president for academic affairs last year. ``They've picked a very good man,'' said Walter Harrison, University of Michigan spokesman. ``He's a very thoughtful, considerate human being who is a forceful and direct administrator. He is obviously a very well-known engineer, but he also has a deep commitment to the arts ... and humanities and social sciences.'' Harrison described Vest as a man of dry wit and deep interests that range from classical music to comic books. Vest did not return telephone calls to his office in Ann Arbor on Tuesday. The state-supported Michigan school has 50,000 students on three campuses.

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Criticizes Drug Czar for Cuomo Criticism
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan says ``tough guy talk'' used by national drug policy director William Bennett in a verbal attack on New York Gov. Mario Cuomo makes him wish he had blocked Bennett's confirmation. ``I have to say that if a year ago I had any reason to suppose that Dr. Bennett would use his office in this manner, I would have taken whatever measures necessary to see that he was not confirmed for it,'' Moynihan, D-N.Y., said Tuesday in remarks submitted to the Congressional Record. Bennett, in Albany, N.Y., last Thursday to meet with state drug officials, attacked Cuomo's drug fighting record and challenged the Democrat to run for president. ``Nobody's afraid of this guy,'' Bennett said. ``He's got a record to run on and the record on drugs, I have to tell you, is not what it should be.'' Moynihan expressed surprise at Bennett's choice of words. ``How does such a man come to refer to the governor of the state of New York as `this guy'?'' Moynihan asked. ``We recognize the idiom. It is so-called `tough-guy talk.' It can be learned from Hollywood movies, also from detective novels.'' Bennett declined to respond, according to spokesman Don Hamilton.
DOC.HEAD: Fast Food Chain Recalls Water Bottles
DOC.TEXT: A fast food restaurant chain is recalling 300,000 sports water bottles because the mouthpieces can present a choking hazard to children. Taco Bell Corp. began offering the bottles for 99 cents to customers at its 2,700 stores last Monday, but the promotional campaign was suspended three days later after the company ``received a report from a customer that his 21-month-old child had dismantled the bottle's mouthpiece and attempted to swallow it,'' the Consumer Product Safety Commission said. When a CPSC inspector tried to purchase a bottle last Friday he was told store managers had been instructed to pack them up and ship them back the day before, the agency said in a written statement. ``It's the fastest work on a recall I've ever seen,'' said CPSC spokesman Dan Rumelt. Consumers should return the bottles to the Taco Bell where purchased for a full refund.
DOC.HEAD: House Approves Program to Find Airliner Defects
DOC.TEXT: The House has approved a $10 million research program to develop new technologies and inspection programs to find defects in airplanes before they cause accidents. The bill by Rep. Tom Lewis, R-Fla., was passed on a voice vote Monday with no opposition. A similar plan is being considered in the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee. The legislation was prompted by the crash landing last July of a United Airlines DC-10 at Sioux City, Iowa, and an April 1988 accident in which part of the top was ripped off an Aloha Airlines plane during a short inter-island flight. The National Transportation Safety Board said both accidents could have been prevented through adequate inspection and maintenance programs.
DOC.HEAD: Officer Review Ordered
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's top personnel official has been asked to recommend cuts in the number of military officers needed in the coming years. Deputy Secretary of Defense Donald Atwood asked Christopher Jehn to coordinate the study in anticipation of a ``smaller force structure in light of changing world conditions and declining budgets,'' the Defense Department said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Says Warsaw Pact Can Play Useful Role
With PM-Soviet Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister of Czechoslovakia says the crumbling Warsaw Pact should be preserved in some form to prevent the Soviet Union from becoming dangerously isolated. ``For the first time, the Warsaw Pact is useful to us,'' Jiri Dienstbier said Tuesday in an interview with The Associated Press and two other news organizations. He said that as the Warsaw Pact moves away from its role as a military alliance it can still play a role in European affairs. The Warsaw Pact, created in 1955 to help the Soviets keep their Eastern European satellites in line, sent tanks into Czechoslovakia to crush the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' reforms. Now, Czechoslovakia wants to remain in the alliance so it can have a voice in negotiating disarmament and a new European security order, Dienstbier said. Dienstbier was considered certain to keep his post in the new Czechoslovak government. Parliamentary elections held last weekend were won by the pro-democracy forces that led last year's revolution. Recalling the isolation of Germany between the two world wars, Dienstbier said of the Soviets: ``We should do everything to pull them into Europe.'' ``We don't want to create any Versailles complex in Russia,'' he said, referring to the treaty that punished Germany at the end of World War I. ``It's even more dangerous because they have all those nuclear arms.'' Warsaw Pact members met in Moscow last week, and the Soviets agreed that the other six member nations should have command of their own armies. They had nominal command before but never exercised it _ with the exception of Romania' refusal to join the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia. The alliance's supreme military commander was always a top Soviet general or marshal. Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland want the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to make its headquarters in Prague. The 35-nation group includes the United States, Canada, the Soviet Union and all European countries but Albania. Under the three-nation proposal, a parallel center for arms control, verification and confidence-building measures would also be established in Berlin. The three east European nations want their idea discussed at a meeting of the Conference on Security in Vienna on July 10. That meeting is to pave the way for a Paris summit in December. Dienstbier and President Vaclav Havel of Czechslovakia have long advocated the eventual breakup of the Warsaw Pact and its Western counterpart, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Unlike Hungary's new leaders _ who want their country out of the Warsaw Pact _ Dienstbier and Havel say the East bloc alliance should break up only gradually. In the meantime, they want to remain members. Dienstbier said there are ``positive forces in the Soviet Union'' who want to work with Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland on transforming European security. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere told President Bush in Washington on Monday that NATO must be ``significantly changed'' to meet the Soviet Union's security concerns. The West is insisting that a united Germany be a full member of NATO. Moscow opposes exclusive military allegiance to NATO for a new Germany. The dispute has halted for the moment efforts to secure the removal from East Germany of the 380,000 Soviet troops stationed there.

DOC.HEAD: Former FBI Agent Pleads Guilty to Slaying Woman
DOC.TEXT: A FBI agent solved a year-old homicide by confessing he strangled a pregnant woman with whom he had been having an affair. Mark Putnam, 30, of Sunrise, Fla., was sentenced Tuesday to 16 years in prison after pleading guilty to manslaughter. His confession allowed authorities to find the remains of Susan Daniels Smith off a coal mine road in the eastern Kentucky hills. Putnam, who had used Ms. Smith as an informant in a bank robbery and auto theft case, is believed to be the first agent in FBI history charged or convicted of a homicide-related crime. Ms. Smith's family condemned the plea bargain because Putnam did not stand trial for murder. A sister of the victim was cited for trying to bring a concealed .38-caliber handgun into court before the agent's appearance. Commonwealth's Attorney John Paul Runyon said that without Putnam's June 4 confession, ``we had absolutely no evidence. Not one scintilla or shred or evidence to bring a charge or convict this man.'' In a signed confession, Putnam described the night of June 8, 1989, when he choked Ms. Smith, 27, ``in an act of extreme rage.'' A 27-year-old divorced mother of two, she was four months pregnant and insisted he was the father. According to her family, she wanted Putnam to leave his wife and two young children in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Their affair began in December 1988. Putnam, who resigned Friday, is eligible for parole in eight years. Ms. Smith's sister, Shelby Ward, 35, was ordered to appear in court June 26 after she was released for trying to enter court with a handgun, State Police said. Police gave no further details. ``This is the dirtiest county I've ever seen in my life,'' Ms. Ward said. ``I think they're covering everything up.'' Ms. Ward said she had no intention of using the gun in court. ``I always keep my pistol in my purse'' for protection, she said. ``But when I get in the car, I take it out and put it on the seat. This morning I forgot.'' Putnam, who was transferred to Miami in May 1989 after two years in Pikeville, was handcuffed and taken into custody. Terry O'Connor, agent in charge for the FBI in Kentucky, said Putnam received no preferential treatment. ``We had no role with any aspect of the plea agreement,'' he said. Earlier in the day, the victim's family filed a lawsuit against Putnam in alleging wrongful death. Attorney Larry Webster said the lawsuit would ask for millions of dollars, primarily to benefit Ms. Smith's 4-year-old boy and 8-year-old girl.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Leaves Presidential Residence in Marital Tiff
DOC.TEXT: In the latest episode in the saga of President Carlos Menem's marital troubles, the first lady moved out of the presidential residence rather than face legal eviction. Mrs. Zulema Menem, wearing a light blue jogging suit, stood Tuesday outside the high brick wall that surrounds the compound and demanded a showdown. ``If I can't go in, let the president and no one else tell me so,'' she said. After a fruitless wait, she drove with her two adult children to the couple's apartment in Buenos Aires' Recoleta neighborhood, leaving the 65-acre suburban estate in nearby Olivos vacant. Mrs. Menem had moved to the apartment on Monday. Menem asked his estranged wife to ``leave the residence and this was accomplished without any kind of violence due to the fact that she already had left,'' said Raul Granillo Ocampo, Menem's legal secretary. Air Force Brig. Andres Antonietti, chief of the presidential military staff, had gone to the residence to persuade Mrs. Menem to leave without incident ``and found that she already had left,'' Ocampo said. Menem himself moved out of the residence on May 8. By law, the president has exclusive power to say who may live in the luxurious residence. ``We're leaving because the president has thrown us out,'' son Carlos told reporters Tuesday, though Ocampo said the decree barring the wife's re-entry does not apply to the two children, Carlos, 21, and his sister, Zulemita, 19. In all, Menem and his wife have been apart for nearly as long as they've been together in their 24-year-old marriage. According to observers, a major factor in the discord is that Mrs. Menem wants a government post and her husband says no. Mrs. Menem, 46, told reporters last week she had no plans to leave the residence and hoped her husband would return home following a 12-day foreign trip. Menem, who arrived back in Buenos Aires on Sunday, instead went to his apartment. The couple's marital strife became news after Menem, 59, moved out of the residence amid reports he would seek a legal separation or divorce. While there have been reports of marital troubles for years, Menem has refused to discuss the situation with the media. Mrs. Menem has publicly accused her husband of being a ``womanizer'' and has assailed his social policies, his free-market economic plan and his staff. The presidential residence was donated to the government by a wealthy family in 1920 on condition it be used by the president. If the president fails to live in the house for six consecutive months, the donors have the right to request its return, according to a presidential decree. Menem, a former governor of the poor interior province of La Rioja, became president last July. He and his wife are of Syrian descent. While both are members of the labor-based Peronist party, since becoming president Menem has advocated the sale of money-losing state companies to help right Argentina's impoverished economy. Mrs. Menem has criticized this plan, which is anathema to hard-line Peronists.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Closes Higher
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,371.77, up 49.46 points, or 0.15 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Swinging Clubs, Police Clear Square Of Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of club-wielding police broke up a 50-day-old anti-government protest in central Bucharest early Wednesday, arresting more than 100 protesters. A reporter said several dozen were beaten. The demonstrators had put up a small tent city in University Square to protest what they consider the Communist domination of the governing National Salvation Front that has been in power since the December revolution. The raid Wednesday effectively cleared the square, which had been closed to traffic by the demonstration. On Tuesday, the Prosecutor's Office issued a communique saying ``profiteering, prostitution and gambling, theft and violence and drug abuse'' were practiced in the square where ``dangerous criminals sought refuge.'' It asked the government to ``take due measures in order to restore public order in keeping with the laws in force.'' Police moved in at 3:55 a.m. A woman who said she lived on the seventh floor of a nearby apartment building said: ``I first heard two men shout the warning ``Everybody flee,'' and then I looked out of my window and saw the police proceed very quickly. It all lasted less than 20 minutes.'' She spoke on condition of anonymity for fear of reprisal. About 300 police officers sealed off the area with trucks and buses. Demonstrators seeking shelter in the adjacent Intercontinental Hotel broke in through its glass door but were seized and removed by police. A photojournalist said several dozen demonstrators were clubbed by police. ``We arrested over 100, and among them were those who spat at us at the television station yesterday, as well as the one who imitates (deposed and executed dictator Nicolae) Ceausescu's voice,'' said a police officers with a blood-stained shirt sleeve. ``It's not my blood'' the policeman said proudly. He would not give his name. Police the film of an Associated Press photographer as he took pictures of them removing the tents, although they later allowed picture-taking as several trucks carried heaps of dirt left behind by the improvised camp.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Recovers After Morning Losses
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange recovered Wednesday afternoon from its morning losses and ended higher, and the dollar inched up against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 154.55 yen, up 0.15 yen from Tuesday's 154.40-yen finish. It opened at 155.08 yen and ranged between 154.40 yen and 155.08 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average regained 49.46 points, or 0.15 percent, ending the day at 32,371.77. The index closed the morning session with a 101.48-point loss before rebounding in the afternoon. Traders said the index's afternoon recovery was inspired by large-scale buying from major securities houses, which prompted other participants to buy. The index in the morning fell because market players were largely discouraged by the yen's weakness and the index's drops since Monday, said Tomoyuki Morimoto, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. The Nikkei fell 670.98 points on Monday and Tuesday together. In currency dealings, dealers said the dollar fluctuated around 155 yen in mixed trading as institutional investors bought the currency while exporters sold it. Most market players, however, remained reluctant to make major moves ahead of a series of U.S. economic data to be released this week, they said. Among the announcements are the nation's retail sales for May, April merchandise trade and May consumer and producer prices.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell: Poor Background Paved Road to Politics
With PM-Primaries Rdp
DOC.TEXT: State Sen. Theo Mitchell's roots lie in a poor neighborhood of Greenville, but his political branches now stretch toward the governor's mansion. The 51-year-old lawyer is hoping to become South Carolina's first black governor. On Tuesday, he became the first black in this century to head a major party ticket in South Carolina when he earned the Democratic gubernatorial nomination over freshman state Sen. Ernest Passailaigue. If successful, Mitchell would be the second black elected governor in the country, following L. Douglas Wilder's victory last year in Virginia. He enters the race an underdog to popular Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell. ``I don't think race will play any role,'' Mitchell said of the general election campaign, ``and I don't think race should play any role.'' Mitchell grew up during the era of Jim Crow laws in a poor family dominated by his mother. He played high school football with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has endorsed his bid for governor. He studied biology at Fisk University in Nashville, Tenn., hoping to become a surgeon, and transferred a year later to Howard University. He was the first member of his family to attend college and paid his tuition by working odd jobs. After working in cancer research for five years at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., he decided against medicine as a career and turned to law. Mitchell received his law degree from Howard in 1969 and returned to Greenville in 1970 to join a legal assistance program emphasizing poverty law. He now heads his own firm. In 1982, Mitchell was indicted on charges of illegally receiving $5,390 in food stamps, but a mistrial was declared when the jury could not reach a verdict and a retrial was never held. Mitchell has dismissed the case as political harassment. He has served in the Legislature since 1974, two years after he made an unsuccessful bid for Congress. After his first election, he was re-elected every two years until 1984, when he won election to the state Senate. Mitchell has made health and human resource development his main campaign issues, emphasizing help for the elderly and those in substandard housing. He also supports extending public transportation around the state and says he would repeal the sales tax on food over a five-year period.

DOC.HEAD: Arrests of Government Critics Reported in Somalia
DOC.TEXT: As many as 50 prominent people have been arrested in Somalia this week after signing a statement criticizing the government, Amnesty International says. Those detained included the East African country's former president, 81-year-old Aden Abdulle Osman, and members of the civilian government overthrown by Maj. Gen. Mohamed Siad Barre in a 1969 coup, the international human rights organization reported Tuesday. Amnesty said arrests were continuing as security police searched for others among the more than 100 signatories of the May 15 statement. ``We had information about the arrests from inside the country from a source which has proved highly reliable previously,'' Amnesty spokeswoman Serena Lim said. ``We were due to send a deputation to Somalia this week to discuss human rights with the government but the visit was postponed by the government at short notice.'' A news release said many of those arrested had been released earlier after long imprisonment without charge or trial. Amnesty said it was ``deeply concerned'' over the arrests of non-violent critics of the government. It said the May 15 manifesto expressed concern at the destruction, killings and flight of refugees in Somalia's civil war and attacked the government for purported violations of human rights, corruption and economic mismanagement. The manifesto asked that a committee be formed to prepare for a national conference of reconciliation and salvation aimed at ending the civil war. Civil war broke out in 1988 between the government and the Somali National Movement. At least 400,000 refugees have fled to neighboring Ethiopia.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Ordered Impounded After 260,000-Gallon Spill
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge impounded a tanker to ensure its owner and operator pay any damages resulting from a 260,000-gallon oil spill in New York Harbor caused when the vessel ran aground. U.S. District Judge Nicholas Politan signed an order Tuesday that blocks the BT Nautilus from leaving Bayonne, where it was docking when the accident occurred Thursday. New Jersey and New York state and city officials Tuesday had sued the owner, Nautilus Motor Tanker Co., and operator, Bulk Tanker Management Ltd., both of London. The lawsuit accused them of negligence and demanded impoundment. The tanker ran aground in the Kill Van Kull, a waterway that separates Bayonne and New York's Staten Island. The cause of the accident has not been determined, the Coast Guard said. The tanker's first mate, Gregory Frederick Geoffrey, 52, of New Marske, England, has been charged with operating a vessel while intoxicated. Charles Anderson, a lawyer for the owners of the 811-foot ship, characterized the impoundment as routine and said he expects the company's underwriters to post bond. He denied allegations of negligence. Officials said they wanted to send a tough message to polluters. The spill was the fourth major one in the Kill Van Kull and another nearby waterway this year. ``We're not going to just sit back. We will take every action available to guarantee that those who pollute don't stick us with the cost of cleanup,'' said Gov. Jim Florio. Hundreds of workers Tuesday continued to clean the shores and waters of the waterway.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Fundamentalists Defeat Ruling Party In First Free Elections
DOC.TEXT: A Moslem fundamentalist group defeated the party that has ruled Algeria since independence 30 years ago in the country's first multiparty elections, the interior minister said today. Interior Minister Mohamed-Salah Mohammedi said the Islamic Salvation Front was ``pre-eminent'' in local elections Tuesday for 1,541 municipal and 48 provincial council seats. The voting was marked by a low turnout because of a boycott by much of the opposition. Mohammedi said the fundamentalists were followed by the ruling National Liberation Front and the anti-clerical Rally for Culture and Democracy. He did not provide figures. Official results were expected later today. The municipal and provincial elections do not directly affect the national legislative body, the People's National Assembly. The National Liberation Front was the sole political party in the North African nation of 24 million people until constitutional changes in February 1989 opened the way to competing parties. Leaders of the centrist opposition had claimed the election was rigged because the National Liberation Front controls nearly all the media, has greater resources than other parties and has functionaries in local government offices where votes were counted. The Interior Ministry said earlier that only 55 percent of 13 million eligible voters participated in the election. The turn-out figures showed a considerable range, from 73 percent in the town of El-Tarf to approximately 50 percent in the capital and just 16 percent in the Berber town of Tizi-Ouzou. The turnout was lowest in districts dominated by the Berber movement, the Front of Socialist Forces, led by Hocine Ait Ahmed. He joined the left-leaning, populist Movement for Democracy, headed by exiled former president Ahmed Ben Bella, in urging voters to stay home. Police were deployed around the country as the nation's official media urged Algerians to vote in ``this first test of democracy.'' ``It is a great day which is being added to the realization of the Algerian revolution,'' President Chadli Bendjedid said before the election. The boycott, organized by Ait-Ahmed and Ben Bella _ the leading opposition figures among the nearly two dozen parties that have sprung up since pluralism was legalized last year _ left the highly organized fundamentalists to challenge the ruling National Liberation Front, which turned Algeria into a one-party state after winning a war of independence against France in 1962. Fundamentalist leader Abassi Madani, a philosophy teacher, declared in a widely reported speech last week that he expected his party to get 75 percent of the vote. The statement was denounced as a ``trouble-making provocation'' by several hundred fellow university professors and lecturers. For months, fundamentalist supporters have been accused of harrassing single women and disrupting nightclubs in the Algiers region, prompting denunciations from other political groups. In the Algiers suburb of El Harrach, the National Liberation Front withdrew from the elections, accusing the fundamentalists of ``exercising moral violence against the voters and committing serious violations against the election law.'' The statement did not elaborate. The official news agency reported several groups of Islamic supporters tried to overrun some Algiers voting stations, alleging the vote counting was influenced by the government. Numerous voters in the Algiers district were turned away from polling booths when they appeared without the necessary documents. Among those blocked were men who tried to exercise their right to vote on behalf of their wife _ or wives _ without written authorization. The National Liberation Front was forced to give up its monopoly on power after soldiers killed scores of people in October 1988 riots sparked by deteriorating economic conditions. Constitutional changes adopted in February 1989 legalized pluralism. The Islamic Salvation Front seeks to establish the Islamic legal code, the Sharia, as law and openly opposes the democratic process.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Passes First Press Freedom Law
With PM-Soviet Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Soviet legislature has passed the country's first press freedom law, which gives any Soviet citizen the right to found a newspaper and guarantees broad rights for journalists and publishers. The new law, which passed unanimously on Tuesday, intends to end decades of censorship of the Soviet media by the Communist Party, the government and a special agency established to kept the media under tight control. ``The press and other mass media are free,'' the law begins bluntly, and ``censorship of the mass media is forbidden.'' However, the law does not address how those who want to publish their own newspapers will obtain newsprint, which is often in short supply. The Soviet government controls all paper mills and the supply of newsprint and other materials needed to publish newspapers. It also controls all radio and television stations. After President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985 and introduced the policy of glasnost, or openess, political pressure on the Soviet media began to lighten, but there was still no legal protection from interference. Technically, freedom of the press is guaranteed by a declaration in the Soviet Constitution, but Tuesday's measure was the first law laying out detailed guarantees of press freedoms, the Tass news agency reported. The law establishes procedures for creating media outlets and specifies journalists' rights. They include the right to attend meetings and be present at the scene of disasters, the right to refuse to prepare reports that go against personal convictions and the right to interview officials. The provision giving any individual the right to establish a media outlet created the sharpest debate in the Supreme Soviet, Tass reported. ``However, it was agreed that the right to establish a publication is one of the main democratic freedoms envisaged in the international covenants on human rights which the Soviet Union has joined, and it is necessary to enforce them,'' the state-run news agency said. The law forbids publication of state secrets, but Tass said penalties would be imposed on the official who leaked them rather than the journalist who reported them. It also forbids slander and ``use of the mass media to interfere in citizens' private lives, infringement on their honor and dignity.'' Pornography, long outlawed in the Soviet Union, remains illegal, although Soviet media _ including television _ have begun showing nudity fairly often. The law, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press, does not specify the penalties for slander and other abuses of press freedoms, saying they can be established by the courts according to existing or future laws.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Closes Higher, Dollar Inches Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index closed higher today despite a morning setback, while the dollar kept inching up against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,371.77, up 49.46 points, or 0.15 percent, from Tuesday's close. The index was down 101.48 points at the end of the morning session. In the afternoon, however, four major securities houses _ Nomura Securities Co., Yamaichi Securities Co., Nikko Securities Co. and Daiwa Securities Co. _ made large purchases, said Katsumi Horikoshi, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co. ``That encouraged participants to pick up underpriced issues after the morning decline,'' he said. In the morning, investors had stepped off to the sidelines, discouraged by the yen's weakness against the dollar as well as the index's decline since Monday, said Tomoyuki Morimoto, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. The Nikkei fell a total of 670.98 points on Monday and Tuesday. Trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 450 million shares, down from Tuesday's 500 million. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 154.55 yen, up 0.15 yen from Tuesday's 154.40-yen finish. It opened at 155.08 yen, its high for the day, and ranged as low as 154.40 yen. The dollar has risen on 11 of the last 12 trading days, gaining 5.10 yen in all. Its higher opening today followed its overnight gains in New York, and life insurance and investment trust companies bought the dollar in early trading. But then it edged lower because of strong selling pressure a little above the 155-yen level, said Toshiaki Kanisaka, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. About $10.6 billion changed hands in spot trading, down from Tuesday's $13.98 billion. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.62 points as of 5 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT) from Tuesday's close of 87.45. The yield stood at 7.050 percent, down from the previous day's 7.085 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls in Midwest, Northwest; Fair Weather Prevails
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered over Upper Michigan, northern New York and the Northwest today, while fair weather prevailed much of the rest of the nation. Today's forecast called for showers over parts of Washington, Wyoming, North Dakota and Minnesota, and thunderstorms in bands from Wisconsin through Iowa, Illinois through Arksansas and along the southeastern coast of Texas. Rain fell early today in Buffalo, Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., and Seattle. Tornado warnings were posted over parts of Nebraska, Iowa, South Dakota, Wisconsin and Minnesota. A tornado touched down Tuesday near Massena, Iowa, but no injuries or major property damage was reported. Heavy snow fell in Yellowstone Park, Wyo., and snow and fog blanketed uplands in Idaho. The high temperature for the nation was 105 degrees at Bullhead City, Ariz., and Presidio, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Inmate Arrested in Boatmaker's Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A convicted killer who once was sprung from a Cuban prison by Jesse Jackson has been arrested in the 1987 slaying of Don Aronow, a powerboat builder whose customers included the Customs service and President Bush. Robert Young, 41, was jailed on murder charges here Tuesday, Metro-Dade police said Tuesday. Aronow, 59, designer of Donzi and Cigarette speedboats and a world champion powerboat racer, was shot several times shot by a motorist who waited for him at his marina on a stretch known as Thunderboat Row, authorities said. The slaying shocked Miami and the boat world, where Aronow was highly respected _ enough to have designed the Blue Thunder speedboats for the Customs Service to chase drug dealers speeding to Florida from the Bahamas. Investigators believed at least two people were in the waiting car, The Miami Herald reported today. Police and Gary Rosenberg, an assistant state attorney, released few other details. Asked if anyone else is being charged with the crime, Rosenberg said, ``Not today.'' Aronow had sold his fast boats to celebrities around the world, including Bush, who named his boat Fidelity. Also on his list of customers were King Juan Carlos of Spain, the former shah of Iran and ex-Beatle Ringo Starr. Young was in an Oklahoma prison serving a federal drug sentence when he was arrested, said his attorney, Virgil Black. ``He's been a suspect in the killing, along with everybody else,'' said Black. ``He finally said, `File it.' He's confident he'll be acquitted. He didn't do it.'' In May 1988, Miami police told the Metro-Dade department that a federal prisoner had given information that Young was involved in the Aronow slaying. Young was a passenger on a boat reportedly containing 300 pounds of marijuana and was held with another man by Cuban authorities until Jackson engineered their release for humanitarian reasons in 1984. Six months later, Young shot a crime figure after problems over a gun-running deal. Young is serving time in that slaying. In 1988, Young also was indicted in Oklahoma City on charges of taking part in a Colombian drug smuggling operation. He was later convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Early Education Helps Premature, Low Birth-Weight Babies
DOC.TEXT: A study of premature babies of below-normal weight shows their IQ can be boosted by special education in their first years. Loraine Stern, a pediatrician at the University of California at Los Angeles, said the study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association also showed the importance of parental involvement in a child's early years. ``You can't recapture what you lose in the first few years,'' she said. In the four-year study, one-third of 985 babies born in 1985 in eight states received educational help. Researchers visited the home, advised parents, provided educational toys and arranged visits to a child development center. Infants who weighed between 4.4 and 5.5 pounds at birth and received educational help and medical care scored an average of 98 at age 3, or 13.2 IQ points higher than children who had been in the same weight range at birth but received only medical care. The average IQ is 100. Infants who weighed about 4.3 pounds or less at birth and were given the educational help scored an average of 91 at age 3, or 6.6 IQ points higher than similar infants getting only medical care, wrote the researchers led by Dr. Ruth Gross of Stanford University. Arnold Sameroff, a psychologist who teaches at Brown University and practices at Bradley Hospital in Providence, R.I., said the children in the study got such multifaceted help, other researchers will find it hard to tell what made the difference. Almost 7 percent of babies born in the United States, or 250,000 a year, weigh 5.5 pounds or less at birth. Though these low-birth-weight babies have a much better chance of survival than in years past, they still are at risk of retarded development.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Cracked Wise About a Bomb
DOC.TEXT: USAir says it should have detained and questioned Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for joking as he boarded a plane that there could be a bomb in the luggage of a White House aide taking the same flight. Dukakis made the comment Sunday night at Logan International Airport. Also on the flight was Republican Ron Kaufman, an aide to President Bush, said Patricia Goldman, a USAir spokeswoman in Arlington, Va. Ms. Goldman said Monday that Dukakis joked about the possibility of a bomb in Kaufman's luggage. The supervisor on duty recognized the governor, determined the comments were made jokingly and ``let it go,'' she said. Ms. Goldman said allowing Dukakis to board was an error in procedure, according to Federal Aviation Administration rules. ``If he made a comment, even in jest, he should have been questioned. That is our procedure,'' Ms. Goldman said. The governor, asked about the incident by reporters in Washington, said, ``The humor of it was obvious to everyone who was there.'' Massachusetts Democrats have charged that Kaufman may have had a hand in a police union protest that disrupted the state Democratic convention in Springfield on June 2. ``After going through the experiences that the Democrats went through in Springfield, I can tell you we will always be concerned when Mr. Kaufman is around,'' the governor said. Kaufman, in a telephone interview, said of Sunday night's incident, ``Given the psychological terror people have of bombs and flying, it was irresponsible for a man in his position to joke about something like that.'' He said he did not hear Dukakis' comments when he was boarding.

DOC.HEAD: Blast Damages Mansion, Animal Rights Extremists Suspected
