DOC.TEXT: A explosion that tore through the front of a historic mansion was believed caused by a bomb, raising suspicions that animal rights extremists might be responsible, police said today. The 18th century West Green House in this village 55 miles from London was unoccupied when the blast tore out brickwork and blew in windows shortly before midnight Wednesday. Police said no one was hurt. The mansion, owned by the state-aided National Trust, was until last month the home of Lord McAlpine, a building construction millionaire and former deputy chairman of the governing Conservative Party. McAlpine, whose interests include a zoo in Broome, Australia, was attacked by animal rights extremists five years ago, Hampshire County police said. They gave no further details. ``We are looking closely at the animal rights angle, but have not ruled out any group or organization,'' said Hampshire police Inspector Barry Jakeman. ``We think the blast was the result of a bomb ... in all probability it was the result of a terrorist attack,'' he told reporters. McAlpine, 48, lived in West Green House for 10 years and spent millions of dollars restoring it, the National Trust said. He moved out last month, and also resigned then as treasurer of the Conservative Party. On Sunday, a bomb planted by animal rights extremists in the southwest England city of Bristol blew up the car of a veterinary surgeon whose research work involves animal experiments. The scientist was thrown clear but a 13-month-old child in a stroller on the sidewalk was injured. A shadowy group, the Animal Liberation Front, claimed responsibility. Main stream opponents of animal experiments denounced the attack as damaging their cause.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnappers Want Pesos, Not Dollars
DOC.TEXT: South American guerrillas holding an American hostage rejected the $60,000 ransom payment because they want it in Colombian pesos, not dollars, his family says. They also are doubting the family's plea of poverty. Heavy rains also have contributed to delays in obtaining the release of Scott Heimdal, and negotiators must now wait a few days while the ransom is changed into pesos and the weather cooperates, Heimdal's family says. Heimdal's mother, Marge Heimdal, said Tuesday a new date has been set for another jungle meeting along the Colombia-Ecuador border with a go-between and the guerrillas. She would not disclose the date for security reasons. Roy Heimdal, the man's father, said the kidnappers are doubting the family's claims of poverty after seeing TV coverage of their efforts last week to raise the ransom. ``They saw pictures of our house,'' Heimdal said of the modest, wood-frame bungalow. ``Our house is no mansion. But by their standards it is. I guess they figure anyone who eats three square meals a day has $60,000 laying around.'' Scott Heimdal, a 27-year-old employee of an Americann gold mining company, was abducted while working in Ecuador on April 28. He was believed to have been taken hostage by guerrillas of the Popular Liberation Army. The kidnappers initially demanded $1.2 million but lowered the figure, and the money was raised by donations that poured in to the Heimdals, including waitresses' tips and proceeds from nursing-home bake sales. ``The intermediary had problems getting up the river because they've had heavy rain and the river is swollen,'' the elder Heimdal said. ``Then the guerrillas got upset because the ransom money came in U.S. dollars instead of pesos. When they tried to exchange it, they had trouble finding enough pesos. So things aren't going so smoothly.'' Heimdal said the unidentified go-between was trying to convince the kidnappers the working-class family is financially strapped. The family says its savings were wiped out by medical bills after Mrs. Heimdal was seriously injured in a 1983 car accident.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Claim To Have Skeletons Of 30 Americans Killed In Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Nine Vietnamese boat people have given police the skeletons of 30 people, stuffed in seven barrels, that they claim were from Americans killed in the Vietnam War, officials said today. Paul Blakeburn, charge d'affaires at the U.S. Embassy, said he doubted the bones were those of Americans missing in action: ``It is possible, but it is not likely to be true.'' Embassy press officer Meg Gilroy said Malaysian authorities would hand the bones over to the embassy soon. She said an official from either the Joint Casualty Resolution Center in Bangkok, Thailand, or the U.S. Defense Department Forensic Laboratory in Hawaii would take them to Hawaii for tests to determine if they belong to U.S. troops. She said the embassy did not know yet how the Vietnamese obtained the bones, which Malaysian officials said had been handed over to police in the Kota Tinggi district, 150 miles south of Kuala Lumpur. The Kota Tinggi police station, contacted by telephone, said some Vietnamese had landed Monday with skeletons at a beach 40 miles to the east but could not provide further details. The newspaper New Straits Times said today that police had found metal tags on the skeletons. It quoted Deputy Superintendent of Police Roslan Dolah as saying, ``The tags had the names and unit numbers and addresses of the dead men, believed to have been killed during the Vietnam War.'' The refugees' 52-foot boat had the words ``USA Remains in my Boat'' and ``This Boat Have USA Army Remains'' written on its sides, the paper reported. It also quoted Roslan as saying the nine Vietnamese, aged between 18 and 56, told police they had left Vietnam on May 30 and had to land Monday when their boat sprang a leak. The refugees were sent to a refugee camp in nearby Mersing. ``We are investigating the reasons for the refugees bringing the skeletons with them. ... We have not come across such cases before,'' the paper quoted Roslan as saying. It added, ``It is understood the refugees were en route to Singapore to hand over the skeletons to the American Embassy. By doing so, the refugees not only hoped to gain refuge to the U.S. but also to get some monetary reward in exchange for the skeletons.'' Singapore is about 60 miles south of where they landed. The United States now lists 2,303 Americans as missing from the Indochina War. These include 1,678 in Vietnam. Refugee officials said this was not the first time Vietnamese refugees had claimed to have brought bones of American soldiers. But the presence of metal tags would make this case different, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in early European trading today, rising against most currencies but falling against the strong British pound and the Swiss franc. Gold prices fell. Dealers said the pound continued to rise on rumors that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government plans to link sterling to the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System later this year. The system links all the currencies of the European Community except those of Britain, Portugal and Greece. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.15 yen to a closing 154.55 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 154.65 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6952 West German marks, up from 1.6920 _1.4343 Swiss francs, down from 1.4367 _5.7055 French francs, up from 5.6950 _1.9090 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9045 _1,245.00 Italian lire, up from 1,242.35 _1.1715 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1713. In London, the pound's rise against the dollar took sterling to $1.7043, compared with $1.7020 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $353 a troy ounce, down from $356.25 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $353, unchanged from the opening bid. Dealers said the price was depressed by selling in New York. In Zurich, the bid price was $353.50, down from $355.65 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.66 to close at $355.16. Silver was quoted in London at a bid of $5 an ounce, compared with $5.06 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: More Troops Rushed East, Fighting Continues
DOC.TEXT: The government rushed 3,000 more soldiers today to the east coast, where Tamil rebels were attacking military camps and scores of people were believed to have been killed, government officials said. Military officials said they feared the rebels had killed more than 100 police among 600 taken prisoner in eastern Batticaloa district on Monday. In addition to the policemen, residents and rebels in the east said as many as 90 people have died in the violence, the worst confrontation between troops and rebels since peace talks started in May 1989. The officials cited a report from an injured policeman, who was among the 600 captured when rebels took command of 11 police stations in the east. They said the policeman escaped the rebels and reached a military camp on Tuesday, reporting that 115 of his colleagues had been shot to death by rebels. There was no independent confirmation of the alleged killings since government troops have been restricted to their camps and communication lines to the east are down, officials said. Tamil rebels have been fighting for more political autonomy in Sri Lanka since 1983. They claim they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese. Tamils form 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, while Sinhalese make up 75 percent. Military officials today could only confirm that 16 soldiers were killed and 12 injured in the fighting up to 6 a.m. this morning. They said rebels were burning the bodies of soldiers and police officers. The new attacks today on the camps at Kiran, Kalavanchukudi and Kalmunai, all in Batticaloa district, came hours before a cease-fire was to take effect, the officials said. The cease-fire was supposed to begin at noon, but fighting was still going on as the deadline passed. Throughout the night, rebels seized an additional seven police stations, seizing arms and ammunition. Reinforcements of government troops were rushed to the area. The 3,000 fresh troops comprised three battalions, military officials said. The battalions were an addition to four companies, totaling 1,200 soldiers, that had been deployed Tuesday to regions where fighting has raged for three straight days, officials said. The fighting apparently broke out when a Tamil man told rebels of the dominant Tamil militia, the Tigers, that he had been assaulted by a Sinhalese policemen at the Batticaloa police station on Sunday, officials said. The Tigers on Monday ordered policemen out of the station and took command. The Tigers took virtual control of the country's northeastern districts after Indian peacekeeping forces withdrew in March. President Ranasinghe Premadasa's government, which has been negotiating with the Tigers for the past year, requested the Indians' departure. At least 11,000 people, including 1,200 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the Tamil war since it started in 1983. Another 6,000 have been killed since 1987 in a backlash to Tamil demands whipped up by ultranationalist Sinhalese guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: Operation Successful to Replace Woman's Torn-Off Scalp
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose scalp was torn off from the eyelids to the nape of her neck, exposing the skull, had her scalp sewn back on in a 14-hour operation. ``She going to be just fine,'' the lead surgeon said. A team of five surgeons worked with high-powered microscopes to replace the woman's entire scalp, small blood vessels and other tissues torn from her head last week in a vineyard accident in Napa Valley. ``She was an attractive woman before...she will be an attractive woman when it's over,'' said Dr. Alfonso Oliva, who conducted the surgery at Ralph K. Davies Medical Center. The 33-year-old vineyard manager, whose family asked that her name not be released, was working in the field at Domaine Chandon on June 4 when her hair caught in the rotor of a sprayer crankshaft, the hospital said Tuesday. Though horrified, the woman's co-workers had enough presence to preserve the scalp. The woman was sped by ambulance to a nearby hospital in Napa, and then 50 miles to San Francisco, where the operation was done within 12 hours of the accident. Oliva said his team reconnected two of the major arteries to the scalp. Three veins in the exposed skull were rejoined using vein grafts from the woman's feet, and eight blood vessels, some ``as small as the width of lead in a mechanical pencil,'' were rejoined. Oliva said despite the severity of the accident, the woman will recover with little outward sign of the ordeal. Most of the scars, he said, will be covered by natural skin folds and hair. ``The actual suture line is just above the eyelids, right where you would cut for a routine eye lift,'' he said. ``The scars at the nape of the neck and above the ears will be covered by her hair.'' Oliva said that during her recovery the woman cannot recline or place her head against a pillow. ``Two days after the surgery, she was sitting there joking about sleeping in a `Buddha position,''' said Oliva. ``This woman is going to be just fine.''

DOC.HEAD: Radical Group Vows To Fight For Closing of American Cultural Center
DOC.TEXT: The fugitive leader of an outlawed radical student group vowed today to continue to fight to close a newly opened U.S. cultural center in the provincial city of Kwangju. Song Kap-suk of the National Council of Student Representatives also accused U.S. Ambassador Donald P. Gregg of meddling in South Korean politics and demanded his recall. Song made the comments at a hastily arranged news conference at Seoul's Hanyang University. He was surrounded by student bodyguards with masks over their faces and armed with metal pipes and firebombs. Song, a student at Kwangju's Chonnam University, is wanted by police for allegedly plotting a firebomb attack on a U.S. diplomatic building in Seoul last month. The cultural center in Kwangju, 156 miles south of Seoul, was reopened earlier this week after being closed for 13 months due to repeated violent attacks by radicals. The students claim the center is a front for CIA activities and represents an imperialist government. On Tuesday, hundreds of radical students wielding firebombs and rocks tried to attack the cultural center but were repelled by riot police firing tear gas, news reports said. ``Shutdown U.S. cultural center!'' students yelled, ``Yankee go home!'' Ambassador Gregg, a former CIA station chief in Seoul in the 1970s, was national security adviser to then-Vice President George Bush during the Reagan administration. Song called for the withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea, saying their presence hinders unification talks on the peninsula. He also demanded that American nuclear weapons, allegedly kept on the peninsula, be withdrawn. Both demands have been made by Communist North Korea. Washington never has acknowledged the presence of nuclear weapons in Korea. Song also demanded anew that the United States apologize for its role in South Korea's bloody suppression of a civil uprising in Kwangju in 1980. Anti-American sentiments are strong in Kwangju and many residents believe the United States condoned the suppression. No South Koreans have been held accountable. By official count about 200 people were killed and more than 1,700 injured. Citizens in Kwangju say the numbers are much higher. In a recent reply to open letters from Song's group and another dissident organization, Gregg denied any U.S. responsibility for the Kwangju suppression.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Proposes Union of Sovereign States, Softens Position on Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th pvs, `President Vytautas...' with Ryzhkov comment on progress on Lithuania. Picks up 8th pvs, `Gorbachev met...'
DOC.TEXT: Faced with a splintering empire, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is proposing to counter secessionist drives by transforming the Soviet Union into a looser federation of sovereign states, officials say. The Soviet leader has also significantly softened his position on German reunification, saying a united Germany could be an ``associate member'' of the NATO alliance while at the same time joining a new pan-European security order. He did not define exactly what ``associate membership'' would entail, but the Kremlin up to now has opposed a new Germany whose sole military allegiance is to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Gorbachev made his proposal about the Soviet republics on Tuesday, the same day the parliament of the huge Russian republic approved a resolution declaring its laws to carry more weight than federal statutes. Also Tuesday, Gorbachev met with the presidents of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia after refusing for weeks to negotiate with the secessionist Baltic republics unless they agreed to abide by the Soviet constitution. President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania hinted that the Kremlin might soon end the economic embargo imposed on his republic. Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who attended the session, said today that it produced definite progress on the impasse over the Baltic states' independence declarations. He said if the Baltic republics went ahead and accepted the Kremlin proposal that they suspend their independence moves and begin negotiations, ``great possibilities for future talks will be opened.'' Ryzhkov was scheduled to meet today with Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene to discuss ``practical steps'' toward better relations, he said. Ryzhkov said he was confident that ``the Lithuanian question is finally getting off the ground.'' Gorbachev met with the Baltic presidents after a session with the Federation Council, an advisory body consisting of the presidents of all 15 Soviet republics. He said he had summoned the council to begin work on ``realizing the key idea of deeply re-forming our federation.'' Gorbachev proposed that the country's republics agree on a new, looser union of ``sovereign states,'' officials said after the meeting. The 59-year-old Soviet leader has pledged repeatedly since last fall to work out a new union treaty. Some reformers would like to transform the Soviet Union into a confederation of independent countries, like the European Community or the British Commonwealth. Tuesday's proposal for a union of ``sovereign states'' is the closest that Gorbachev has come to publicly considering such a radical change. The Russian resolution has no immediate legal effect. But if it takes hold, it could bring a dramatic reduction in Gorbachev's authority because Russia includes 52 percent of the Soviet Union's population and three-quarters of its land mass. The Russian Congress of People's Deputies, under the leadership of radical reformer Boris N. Yeltsin, voted 907-13 for the declaration. The statement was weaker than originally proposed, because it says Russia's sovereignty _ and the priority of its laws ver national ones _ will be worked out in a new Russian constitution and union treaty. Any new treaty that keeps the Soviet Union as a single country would be likely to shift substantial powers from the federal government to the republics. Gorbachev has promised repeatedly that a new federation structure would solve the republics' grievances, but independence activists have dismissed his assurances in the past for lack of a concrete proposal. Some reformers have suggested that the central government retain control over foreign policy and defense. Others have added control of some industries, overall economic planning and other duties to the list. Landsbergis, asked whether Gorbachev would lift the economic embargo imposed on Lithuania in April, said, ``The blockade will not be canceled tomorrow, but the day after tomorrow, we shall see.'' Gorbachev cut off shipments of oil and restricted supplies of natural gas and other raw materials to Lithuania after the republic refused to repeal laws stemming from its March declaration of independence. The other two Baltic states have taken a less rapid course toward secession, declaring indefinite transition periods to independence. In an hourlong address to the Supreme Soviet legislature, broadcast live on Soviet TV, Gorbachev said ``huge results'' were achieved in arms control at his Washington summit with President Bush. He reported on his talks with Bush on a united Germany joining NATO. West Germany now belongs to the Western military alliance and East Germany to Warsaw Pact, an instrument of Soviet domination in Eastern Europe until last year's string of revolutions. Gorbachev said, ``Our position is thus: We could agree to the joining, if you accept associative participation, the principle of blocs coming together in conjunction with the unification of Germany in the process of which mutual obligations are not changed, neither from the side of West or East Germany, and if simultaneously the blocs are reformed in natural connection with Vienna and the all-European process.'' He did not spell out what associate membership for Germany would entail. Vienna is the venue for arms reduction talks and the Europe-wide Conference on Security and Cooperation aimed at reducing tensions. Later, official Radio Moscow said: ``It might be possible to agree with Germany being in NATO as an associated member provided there are changes in the nature of the military alliances, both NATO and the Warsaw Treaty organization.'' The Soviet president seemed to be demanding that a united Germany fulfill East Germany's obligations to the Warsaw Pact only during a transition period.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Names Veteran Diplomat As Envoy to United States
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Agostino Cacciavillan, a veteran Vatican diplomat who has worked in Africa and Asia, was named today as papal envoy to the United States. Pope John Paul II appointed the 63-year-old Italian to succeed Archbishop Pio Laghi, recently transferred to Rome as head of the Congregation for Catholic Education. Cacciavillan has been serving as papal nuncio, or envoy, to India and Nepal. He has also served in Kenya. Among the key tasks of a nuncio is to advise the pope on the appointment of bishops.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first graf in BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.-dated item to CORRECT spelling of Procter sted Proctor; SUBS 2nd graf of NEW YORK-dated item to CORRECT name of hotel to Barbizon Hotel sted Barbizon Plaza Hotel.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Actor Martin Sheen urged a supermarket chain to boycott Folgers coffee to persuade Procter & Gamble to stop buying beans from war-torn El Salvador. Sheen joined a demonstration Tuesday by about three dozen people outside a shareholders meeting of the Arden supermarket chain. The boycott was started in November by peace organizations to protest the slayings in El Salvador of six Jesuit priests. Salvadoran military officers have been implicated in the killings. ``My country should not be funding the killers of the Jesuit priests with our tax dollars or our consumer dollars,'' Sheen said. An Arden spokesman, Ernest Klinger, said the company would continue to stock Folgers to give consumers a full selection. Don Tassone of P&G, which makes Folgers, called the boycott ``preposterous.'' He said P&G buys coffee from at least 30 countries, and the Salvadoran product amounts to less than 2 percent of the coffee in Folgers.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also is moving on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Cal Ripken is in second place behind Lou Gehrig on baseball's Iron Man list, having notched his 1,308th consecutive game. Ripken moved past Everett Scott on Tuesday when he started at shortstop for the Baltimore Orioles, as he has every game since May 30, 1982. He needs 822 more games to match Gehrig's record for consecutive games played. ``I try not to think about what has transpired and what could possibly transpire,'' Ripken said before the game with the Milwaukee Brewers. ``I think I'll be proud of the accomplishment but I don't think there will be a real big, special feeling that comes over me.'' Scott's streak began in 1916 with the Boston Red Sox and ended in 1925 with the New York Yankees. His fragile knees just wouldn't let him continue.

Cajun fiddler-singer Doug Kershaw spent a few hours in jail before posting $132,000 bail to cover alimony he allegedly owes his ailing ex-wife. Kershaw, the 53-year-old ``ragin' Cajun'' best known for his 1961 song ``Louisiana Man,'' was jailed Friday after performing at the Tennessee State Fairgrounds. A contempt hearing was set for July 18. Kershaw's former wife, Elsie Griffin Kershaw, 72, is destitute and in ill health, said her attorney, Jack Norman Jr. According to a petition filed by Norman, Kershaw had avoided payment of $750 a month in alimony when the couple divorced in 1975 after seven years of marriage. Kershaw was the featured entertainer at halftime during this year's Super Bowl in New Orleans.

Georgette Mosbacher, wife of U.S. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, was robbed at gunpoint at a hotel but was not hurt, police said. The socialite was getting off an elevator on the 20th floor of the Barbizon Hotel on Tuesday when a man with a gun confronted her, and took her wedding ring, watch, earrings, two other rings and $400 in cash, police said. Mrs. Mosbacher, a guest at the hotel, is president of her own cosmetics business, La Prairie, and is well-known in New York and Washington social circles.

Sen. Robert Packwood is filing for a divorce from his wife of 25 years, Georgie. A statement from the Oregon Republican said a separation begun in January had not helped the couple resolve their problems. A spokeswoman, Julia Brim-Edwards, said the divorce papers were filed Tuesday in Oregon. Since the separation, the 57-year-old senator has kept an apartment in Washington. Mrs. Packwood lives in a Maryland suburb of the capital. They have two children, a son, Bill, 22, and a daughter, Shyla, 19.

DOC.HEAD: Top West German Terror Suspect Arrested in East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with comment from West German authorities. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Last Wednesday...'
DOC.TEXT: East German police have arrested one of West Germany's most wanted leftist terror suspects, the second such arrest of an alleged Red Army Faction member in a week, the government-run news agency said today. ADN said Inge Viett, 46, was arrested late Tuesday in the East German city of Magdeburg. She is accused of taking part in the murder of prominent West Berlin Judge Guenter von Drenkmann in 1974 and the kidnapping a year later of West Berlin Christian Democratic leader Peter Lorenz. In recent days, West German wanted posters had appeared in Magdeburg, with names and pictures of Ms. Viett and nine other accused, fugitive terrorists, according to ADN. The posters asked East Germans who may have seen the suspects to notify authorities. Ms. Viett's arrest raised speculation that other members of the notorious Red Army Faction terror organization will be found in East Germany, which is in the process of reunifying with West Germany. There has already been speculation that the once-dreaded and now disbanded East German secret police were involved in harboring West German terrorists. Willi Fundermann, a spokesman for the West German federal police in Wiesbaden, said Ms. Viett had lived in Magdeburg for more than two years under the name of Eva Schnell. Before that, she had lived in Dresden, Fundermann told The Associated Press. Another federal police spokesman, Willy Terstiege, said it is difficult to say whether other West German terrorists are in East Germany. ``There is the possibility that others are there,'' Terstiege told the AP. ``It's also possible that because of the arrests, any who may have been there are now trying to leave the country. I don't know.'' On Wednesday, East Berlin police arrested Susanne Albrecht, another suspected Red Army Faction member. She was wanted for the 1977 murder of prominent West German banker Juergen Ponto. According to the Morgenpost newspaper of Dresden, suspected West German terrorist Silke Maier-Witt lived for years in that East German city. She is suspected of having taken part in the 1977 kidnapping and murder of prominent West German industrialist Hanns Martin Schleyer. There was no official comment on the report about Ms. Maier-Witt. ADN said West German police were involved in tracking down Ms. Viett. East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel called Ms. Viett's arrest an example of ``success in German-German cooperation'' that had already worked in Ms. Albrecht's capture. East German law enforcement authorities, speaking to The Associated Press on the condition of anonymity, say the tip leading to Ms. Viett's arrest came from her neighbors. According to the sources, the neighbors traveled to the West German city of Braunschweig, about a half-hour's drive from the East German border, and notified police there. The West German officials then notified their East German colleagues, according to the sources. Ms. Viett allegedly first became active in leftist terrorism in 1972, when she is accused of having taken part in a bombing in Berlin that killed one person.

DOC.HEAD: Eureka! That's Some Heartburn!
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Or `maybe...', to CORRECT name of university to Northeastern sted Northeast.
DOC.TEXT: A study of what's eating Americans has crowned Eureka, Calif., today as the nation's heartburn capital. The National Rolaids Heartburn Index blames that searing sensation on sociology, not spices. It says Eureka is full of newcomers with a burning desire for economic success. El Paso was named the most heartburn-free city in America, despite its Tex-Mex cuisine. The reason: a stable population and a rebounding economy. Or ``maybe they're stoics,'' said Jack Levin, sociology professor at Northeastern University in Boston. However, his heartfelt study points to other factors. ``I think there is a tendency on the part of Americans to blame heartburn on spicy foods _ Mexican or Szechuan, for example,'' said Levin. ``From a sociological standpoint, it appears heartburn levels can be easily linked to the amount of population growth that a city is experiencing.'' To reach his conclusions, Levin digested sales figures for various antacid brands, tablet and liquid, from 197 metropolitan areas. Then, he ranked the nation's heartburn hotbeds. While the sales statistics were not revealed, he found that, on average, Americans experience heartburn twice a week. In contrast, the 25,000 folks in Eureka are plagued an average of four times a week. Other Americans left their heartburn in San Francisco; Chico, Calif; Santa Barbara, Calif.; Sacramento, Calif.; Boise, Idaho; Reno, Nevada; Fresno, Calif.; Bakersfield, Calif., and Seattle. The happiest tummies were found in El Paso; Fort Smith, Ark.; Ada, Okla.; Colorado Springs, Colo.; Columbia, Mo.; St. Joseph, Mo.; Lubbock, Tex.; Panama City, Fla.; Springfield, Mo.; and Albany, Ga. ``The most startling result in this analysis was that the Northeast region did not have high heartburn on the Rolaids index,'' said Levin. New York City ranked 135th. ``These results say heartburn occurs wherever there's `gold rush fever,' where you get large numbers of newcomers, transients, rootless people, who move to an area to make their fortune, for a new beginning or a last resort.'' Perhaps to prove a point, Levin and company officials planned to belch forth their findings at a luncheon of chicken marinaded in tequila, shrimp marinaded in chilli, salad with cilantro dressing, tacos and refried beans. As a hedge, there'll be ``Rolaids for everyone, if necessary,'' said spokeswoman Ann Forster. It wasn't clear whether Eureka citizens were pained by the study results. However, the mayor planned to be at the luncheon. To the 40 million Americans who sometimes suffer from heartburn, Levin offered this advice: ``Avoid a lot of important changes in their lifestyles all at the same time. Even the most positive changes, like getting married, moving to a nicer neighborhood, getting a better job, can create heartburn.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Now 148 in Kirghizia
With PM-Soviet-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic clashes in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia this month have left 148 people dead, the Tass news agency said today. Meanwhile, a top Interior Ministry official said that in two years of civil strife throughout the Soviet Union _ primarily ethnic clashes _ 24,000 people have been arrested and 4,000 firearms and 500 explosive devices seized. No new outbreaks of violence were reported in western Kirghizia, where clashes between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks began June 2 over a land dispute. Because the situation has stabilized in recent days, members of search and rescue teams have been able to make a better accounting of the dead and injured, Tass said. They said 148 people were killed and 885 injured in the unrest, Tass reported. Of the injured, 748 were hospitalized, the agency said. In addition, authorities confiscated 230 firearms and 23 incendiary bombs in the region, Tass said. The violence stems from a dispute over the allocation of land to ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks, both Sunni Moslems, in the densly populated region where housing is scarce. It was the latest in a series of bloody civil conflicts to trouble the government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In Moscow, the Interior Ministry official said on Tuesday that the ministry's troops were used in 13 regions over the past two years to quell such outbreaks of violence, the news agency said. Maj. Gen. Alexander Grienko, chief of the ministry's Political Department, told Tass 16 soliders were killed, four were reported missing and more than 1,000 were wounded. He did not say how many civilians were killed or injured. Besides this month's unrest in Kirghizia and Uzbekistan, ethnic violence also has occurred in Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Tadzhikistan.

DOC.HEAD: A Dozen Bakers Win $25 Million Lotto Grand Prize
DOC.TEXT: As workers on the hard-roll line at the National Baking Co., James Street and his friends are used to lots of dough, but not the kind they won in the Illinois State Lottery. The 12 bakery workers _ one shy of a baker's dozen _ stepped forward Tuesday to claim a grand prize of $25 million. Calling themselves the Blessed Dozen Partnership, they had pooled $60 for tickets in Saturday's drawing. ``I liked these numbers,'' said Street, 43, who organized the group about a year ago. ``The numbers just came to me to play. I knew we'd win.'' Lottery spokeswoman Julie Lively said the group will receive $1.25 million annually for 20 years. The big bread means some of the dozen will be saying goodbye to hard rolls. Baker Katy Mae Warren, 67, said she would be retiring soon, as she already had planned. ``I've been there 30 years,'' she said. Marshall Guthrie, 36, a dough mixer, remembers dancing around the baking line when he heard the news. ``Our boss at the bakery said no one can play the lottery anymore,'' said Guthrie. Edgar Harris, 58, who underwent open heart surgery in March, wasn't even sure he was in on the pool at first. He's been on sick leave. ``They put the money in for me. I know I have two good friends,'' he said. Street, head of the hard-roll production line, said the 12 began by contributing $2 apiece each week but increased their weekly ante to $5 in mid-May.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Six Cambodian Officials Held For Trying To Form Rival Party
DOC.TEXT: Authorities in Cambodia have arrested at least six senior government officials and army officers for trying to form a rival political party, a U.S. human rights group said in a statement. The group, Asia Watch, said the officials, who included a Cabinet minister, were arrested between May 21 and May 25 on suspicion of trying to set up the Liberal Social Democratic Party. Cambodia's one-party Communist administration was installed by a Vietnamese invasion of the country in late 1978. It continues to fight three guerrilla groups backed by China and other countries. The statement, dated Tuesday, said the executive director of Asia Watch, Sidney Jones, was in the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh at the time of the arrests. ``This is a major new development in Cambodia,'' it quoted him as saying. ``Up until now political arrests have been largely linked to the resistance factions based in Thailand.'' ``These men were apparently trying to take advantage of a changed political climate and move Cambodia towards a multiparty system. It looks like they may have jumped the gun,'' he said. The statement said the six men were thought to have been among a group that included 15 to 40 other people. They six were held in a villa in the capital, it said. More than one villa in the elite Tuol Kork district of the capital was known to house political prisoners, it said. The statement identified those arrested as Ung Phan, the minister of transport, communications and posts; Nou Saing Khan, the chief of planning and statistics at the same ministry; Kan Man, the deputy director of the European and American bureau of the Foreign Ministry; Thun Saray, acting director of the Institute of Sociology; Col. On Sum of the research department of the Defense Ministry; and another officer, Lt. Col. Kay Mathury. Nou Saing Khan was reported to have drafted the party charter, which called for a multiparty system, the statement by Asia Watch said. It said Ung Phan was considered a protege of Prime Minister Hun Sen. Ung Phan was a cabinet minister in 1983 and in 1988 was vice chairman of Cambodia's only law school, the report said. It said that on May 23, an official close to Hun Sen told Asia Watch that the arrests were a ``mistake'' and the men would be freed once Hun Sen returned from a visit to Vietnam. However, it said, the men remained in detention while Hun Sen went to Japan for peace talks with guerrilla leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The talks were held June 4-5 and Hun Sen returned to Phnom Penh on June 10 after stopovers in Moscow and Hanoi. Authorities in Phnom Penh have substantially eased political restrictions in recent years and said they would support a government along Western democratic lines when peace is achieved with the guerrillas. The Asia Watch statement said the debate over a possible change to a pluralistic system was thought to have split the government between a reformist group, led by Hun Sen and one of pro-Vietnamese hardliners.

DOC.HEAD: Remainder of Berlin Wall Begins Falling Down
DOC.TEXT: Workers began tearing down the remainder of the Berlin Wall today, starting with a street split down the center that symbolized the city's 29-year division. A huge crane smashed into a section of wall built into the fronts of houses on Bernauer Street in August 1961, when the wall was put up. Bernauer was the scene of the most escapes in the early days of the wall. Scores of East Germans tumbled through windows and off rooftops as the wall was gradually built higher and windows were cemented shut. ``I am full of hatred for that symbol of division,'' said East German Building Minister Ekkehard Kraft as hundreds of people gathered to watch the ceremonial start of the destruction. The decision to begin final demolition of the wall came Tuesday, in the first joint session of the city councils of both Berlins. ``We are already now one city,'' said East Berlin Mayor Tino Schwierzina, who was elected in East Germany's first free local balloting in May. One section of wall is to remain standing as a memorial to the people who were killed trying to flee from East Germany to the West. The demolition is to be completed by July 2, when the two German states are to merge their economies in the major step to full unification. The meeting of the West Berlin Senate and the East Berlin Magisrat was the first involving local officials from both Berlins since 1948, after Germany and its capital were both carved in two by the victorious World War II Allies. The two councils, which meet individually each week, plan to meet jointly every two weeks until full unification takes place and a single government is chosen in new local elections. East Germany's former Communist government was toppled by mass protests in October and the wall was opened in November. Since then, Germans have been able to pass back and forth between the cities and the two nations. Border crossings still are staffed by guards on both sides of the wall and cursory passport checks are made. Foreigners can pass only through two points. Some of the most famous stretches of the Berlin Wall have already been demolished, but most of the wall still snakes around West Berlin. Berlin was divided into four sectors following World War II, with the Soviets in control of the East and France, Britain and the United States in control of the West. East Berlin is the capital of East Germany, but West Berlin is still technically under military occupation and not part of the territory of West Germany. The four Allies are expected to negotiate an end to their direct involvement in the cities during the series of ongoing talks that also are dealing with the future strategic allegiance of a united Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Block Downtown Traffic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with more results, detail on demonstration. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `Traffic was...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators halted traffic in much of the capital today to protest the apparent victory of the heirs to the long-ruling Communists in Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years. The protesters formed barricades with benches, blocking traffic on main thoroughfares, including an intersection demonstrators had blocked for several hours Tuesday night. Some threatened drivers who did not honk their horns. Honking has become a common expression of protest over the past few days against the Socialist Party, known until April as the Communist Party. With half the official results tallied, the Socialists appeared to have won the first round of voting on Sunday, but final results were not expected before tonight, an election official said. Runoffs are being held Sunday in 81 constituencies where no single candidate received the required majority. Analysts said that based on the known results and projections by West German and Bulgarian groups, it was still possible that the opposition could gain a slight edge after the second-round voting. But the official BTA news agency said the opposition would have to win nearly all the seats at stake in the runoffs. Half of Parliament's 400 seats are being filled by direct election, the other 200 based on the percentage of votes each party receives. Supporters of the 16-party opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, and of an anarchist group say Sunday's elections were manipulated, but most foreign observers said they saw little or no wrongdoing. The opposition pledged Tuesday to rally behind candidates not associated with the Socialist Party in the runoffs in 81 constituencies, in a last-ditch bid to gain control of Parliament. According to final results for the individual constituencies released by the Central Election Commission today, the Socialist Party won 75 seats outright in the first round. Union of Democratic Forces candidates won in 32 constituences and the mostly ethnic-Turkish Movement for Rights and Freedoms won in nine more, state radio reported. Three more seats went to an independent and one each to two small opposition parties. On Tuesday, students began a three-day protest strike at Kliment Ohridski University, protesting the authorities' delay in releasing election returns. But the students distanced themselves from Tuesday's demonstration at the intersection. Traffic was halted today on the entire 2.5-mile Lenin Boulevard, the main artery leading into downtown Sofia. Angry citizens had to walk for miles to get to their jobs. The demonstration Tuesday night lasted into the morning hours, when police pushed the demonstrators back and a heavy downpour reduced their numbers. ``Long Live Anarchy, Long Live Freedom,'' shouted the crowd. Many of the demonstrators were of high school age. The late-night protest extended to nearby television headquarters, where protesters claimed that TV director Pavel Pisarev had manipulated election coverage. Socialist leaders say they would like to share power, but may be faced with forming a single-party government. The party then would have to tackle alone the country's deepening economic crisis, including rising inflation, a $10 billion foreign debt and consumer shortages. The Union of Democratic Forces favors faster reforms toward a Western-style market economy than the Socialists' cautious approach. The strong Socialist showing seemed due in part to its near-century as a political presence in Bulgaria. Another possible factor was the popularity of some current Socialist leaders, who figured prominently in ousting hard-line Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov last November and initiating reform in the country _ one of Moscow's closest allies during the Brezhnev era.

DOC.HEAD: Mail-Order Bride Business Outlawed in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino today signed a bill banning the ``pernicious trade'' in mail-order brides, which she said insults national pride and breaks the hearts of young women and their families. Mrs. Aquino hailed the new law's prohibition of the ``commerce in women under the guise of legitimate marriage.'' The measure outlaws the ``solicitation or inducement'' of Filipino women to become members of any club or association whose objective is to match women for marriage to foreign nationals _ either on a mail-order basis or through personal introductions for a fee. It also bans the printing and distribution of material promoting the practice. Violators could face up to eight years in jail and $870 in fines. ``The mail-order bride (business) is a relatively new phenomenon in our society, but its perpetrators are many,'' said Mrs. Aquino. ``They are able to carry out their pernicious trade through the use of the media ... for personal profit.'' Mrs. Aquino said many poor young women from remote villges are lured ``through sweet talk and grandiose promises'' by the mail-order bride businesses. ``Although we come by success stories every so often, most of the feedback is devastating not only to individual persons and families but also to our national pride,'' she said. Sen. Ernesto Maceda, the chief congressional sponsor of the new law, said he was spurred to action by the ``alarming rate'' of battered Filipino wives married to foreign nationals through the mail-order bride business. Any foreigner convicted under the new law faces the same fine and jail time, plus deportation afterward. Violators are barred permanantly from returning to the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: US Training of Lebanese Military May Resume
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is prepared to resume a military training program for Lebanon once that country pays off more than $8 million in overdue loans to the United States, U.S. officials said today. John Kelly, assistant secretary of state for Near East and South Asian Affairs, outlined the U.S. position last week at a meeting in Egypt with Lebanese President Elias Harawi, the officials said. Under law, Lebanon is ineligible for U.S. assistance because of the repayment arrearages. The suspell ahead of the schedule set in a U.S.-Soviet treaty signed during the superpower summit. The agreement signed by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev requires each side to reduce its stockpile to 5,000 tons by 2002, although the Soviets have no active facility for destroying their weapons. The United States says it has about 25,000 tons of chemical agents; the Soviets say they have 50,000 tons. The two nations are the world's largest holders of such weapons. Destruction is supposed to begin by Dec. 31, 1992, but doubts have arisen over the Soviets' plans because the government last summer shut down its only destruction facility, at Chapayevsk on the Volga River, because of environmental protests. The GAO report raises serious questions about whether the United States will meets its goal. ``As we try and rid ourselves of this dangerous legacy, we learn that the Army is behind schedule and over budget by billions,'' said Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., one of three lawmakers to request the GAO report. ``In short, with this effort the environment loses, the federal budget loses and the American taxpayer loses.'' The Army said late Tuesday it had not seen the report and had no immediate comment. The GAO said the Army believes it will fall short of the April 30, 1997, deadline due to problems at the Johnston Atoll facility. The agency also cited growing community opposition as a factor in delaying the Army's schedule. The Johnston Atoll plant in the Pacific Ocean was built to meet a 1985 congressional requirement to destroy all existing U.S. chemical weapons by 1997 as a condition for approving a Pentagon program to produce a new generation of such weapons. The Army announced in 1988 that it planned to build similar disposal facilities at each of the eight chemical munitions storage sites in the continental United States. The sites are Tooele, Utah; Anniston, Ala.; Pine Bluff, Ark.; Umatilla, Ore.; Pueblo, Colo.; Newport, Ind.; Lexington-Blue Grass, Ky.; and Aberdeen, Md. The GAO report said the Army did not expect restrictions imposed by a Utah environmental permit that require the service periodically to operate the disposal plant at 50 percent capacity while environmental test data is analyzed. In addition, purchasing of equipment for the Utah plant was delayed by a $37 million shortfall in funds for fiscal 1990. Meanwhile, the GAO found that at Johnston Atoll,``operational delays at the initial plant have adversely affected the Army's ability to incorporate lessons learned at this plant into the design and construction plans for the continental U.S. disposal facilities.'' The GAO also said the Army will likely face obstacles in obtaining environmental permits, and community opposition in Indiana, Kentucky and Maryland will put the Army's disposal schedule in jeopardy. The GAO said the Army received information in March 1988 that showed the total disposal program will cost $3.4 billion _ double the October 1985 estimate for destroying the weapons at the eight storages sites and Johnston Atoll. But the GAO report said the total cost likely will increase because ``current construction, equipment and personnel requirements are at least $300 million greater than estimated in March 1988.'' Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, said the ``great irony here is that we developed these weapons because they promised deterrence on the cheap, but we never took into account the clean-up, disposal and environmental costs incurred by manufacturing these weapons.'' Rep. Earl Hutto, D-Fla., chairman of the House Armed Services subcommittee on readiness, also requested the report. Glenn is chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee while Conyers is chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Fundamentalists Defeat Ruling Party in First Free Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Islamic leader demanding early legislative elections, comment from Iran. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An Islamic fundamentalist leader demanded today that the government dissolve Parliament and hold early national elections after his followers beat the ruling party in local balloting. Abassi Madani, president of the Islamic Salvation Front, thanked the government for allowing Algeria's first multiparty elections since independence in 1962. But he said Parliament, in which every seat is held by the ruling National Liberation Front, should be dissolved to clear the way for legislative elections within three months. There was no immediate government response. By midafternoon today, no official results had been announced, but Interior Minister Mohamed-Salah Mohammedi said Madani's party won a majority of the 15,000 seats at stake Tuesday on 1,541 municipal and 48 provincial councils. About 13 million people were registered to vote. The voter turnout was about 60 percent because of a boycott by several parties opposed to the government and the fundamentalists. In a constitutional referendum last year, the turnout was 76 percent. Mohammedi said the fundamentalists were followed closely by the National Liberation Front and the anti-clerical Rally for Culture and Democracy. In France, Algeria's former colonial ruler and home to hundreds of thousands of Algerian immigrants, Youth and Sports Minister Roger Bambuck indicated the results would cause alarm in government ranks. ``It's with great sadness that I see the rise of fundamentalists in Algeria,'' he said in a radio interview. ``Every time one sees dogmatism on the rise, whether political or religious, it's liberty that is in danger.'' He said the results ``will be a source of worry for Algerians and will create difficulties for our Algerian friends living in France.'' In Iran, state-run Tehran Radio said the results were ``part of the wave of Islamization that has gripped northern African nations simultaneously.'' ``The development of Islamic feeling in these countries is similar to Algeria, but it is suppressed by the ruling regimes,'' the radio said. In Tunisia, one of Algeria's neighbors, the main Islamic group was barred from nationwide local elections Sunday. Algeria's National Liberation Front was the sole political party in the nation of 24 million people until constitutional changes in February 1989 opened the way to competing parties. Centrist opposition leaders had feared the election would be rigged because the National Liberation Front controlled nearly all media, had greater resources and had functionaries in local offices where votes were counted. Madani, a 59-year-old philosophy professor, thanked the public and government for the ``high level of political maturity'' that led to his party's majority. The electorate ``knew how to choose its destiny by showing a profound confidence in us,'' he said. The Islamic Salvation Front seeks to establish the Islamic legal code, the Sharia, as law. But Madani said he was prepared to cooperate with other factions and did not favor a one-party state. ``We guarantee the freedom of all who have ideas on Algeria's future,'' he said. ``The Algerian people are not stupid. They can tell truth from error.'' For months, fundamentalist supporters have been accused of harassing single women and disrupting nightclubs in Algiers. In the Algiers suburb of El Harrach, the National Liberation Front withdrew from the elections, accusing the fundamentalists of ``exercising moral violence against the voters.'' The statement did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Baptists Elect Fundamentalist President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Vestal's comments today. Picks up 11th graf pvs: `Chapman said ...'
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest Protestant denomination is firmly in fundamentalist hands after moderates were easily defeated in what many considered their last chance for the presidency of the Southern Baptists. The Rev. Morris Chapman of Wichita Falls, Texas, the fundamentalist candidate, won 58 percent of the vote Tuesday in defeating the Rev. Daniel Vestal of suburban Atlanta, 21,471 to 15,753. ``I trust that after 12 consecutive years, we can consider the issue settled. For a lot of us are weary,'' said Chapman, who won by the largest margin will happen in most churches is a kind of general attrition'' of support for the national denomination, said the Rev. Dan Scott of Fort Oglethorpe, Ga. ``I call it a return to localism.'' The Southern Baptist Alliance predicts there will be greater support for their plans for a moderate seminary in Richmond, Va. Hastey said the group has raised about $600,000 of the $1 million it needs to open.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Says His `Life and Reputation'' Are at Stake
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; new material and editing throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger made an emotional plea to the Senate ethics committee today, saying his ``life and reputation'' are at stake and asking for compassion in their judgment of his financial dealings. In an intensely personal statement, the Minnesota Republican said repeatedly he was ``deeply sorry'' for financial deals that he admitted violated Senate rules. The committee's special counsel, Robert Bennett, recommended Tuesday that the Senate publicly denounce Durenberger for ``reprehensible'' actions that brought ``dishonor and disrepute'' on the Senate. ``His conduct was clearly and unequivocally unethical,'' Bennett told the committee after describing allegations that Durenberger broke Senate rules and federal law through a book promotion deal and transactions involving his Minneapolis condominium. Durenberger made no reference to the proposed sanction in a 13-page statement prepared for the committee today. Repeating that he was sorry for his actions four times, Durenberger described how he had thrown himself into his work because of the emotional trauma from his first wife's death and the ``daunting challenge'' of raising four young sons. ``My life and reputation are at stake, and I believe each of you will combine both good judgment and compassion in your decision,'' Durenberger said. Durenberger said he would not challenge the committee's recommended punishment, but he appeared to rule out resigning from the Senate. ``When this is done, I intend to serve this body and my home state with a renewed conviction to exemplify the servant in public service,'' he said. Durenberger's attorney, Jim Hamilton, told the committee today that Durenberger's conduct was not ``reprehensible'' and the senator does not deserve a sanction as harsh as a resolution denouncing him. He said reprehensible conduct ``conjures up venality'' and ``Dave Durenberger is not an evil, reprehensible man.'' He told the committee that Durenberger was undergoing ``personal strain and impaired judgment'' during a number of the questionable financial transactions, including marital problems, chemical dependency of two sons and severe financial strains. Hamilton told the panel Tuesday that ``Durenberger feels that some sanction is appropriate because he was inattentive and unwise.'' Only the full Senate can decide to punish one of its members. If the committee and the Senate followed the counsel's recommendation, a resolution would be passed denouncing Durenberger's conduct, but his position as a senator _ at least until his next re-election campaign _ would not be affected. A less-severe penalty, such as admonishing or reprimanding Durenberger, would not require Senate approval, Bennett said. Bennett reminded the panel it could consider stripping Durenberger of his seniority and committee assignments as well as order him to make restitution. He said the most serious punishment, expulsion, traditionally has been reserved for senators guilty of serious violations of the law. The counsel said Durenberger was guilty of a ``pattern of misconduct.'' Hamilton portrayed Durenberger as a victim of mistakes and sloppiness who relied on a ``bevy of lawyers'' to handle his finances. There were no ``venal motives'' or a ``grand conspiracy'' to violate the rules. Bennett accused Durenberger of making fake promotional appearances in 1985 and 1986 for his two books so he could keep more speaking fees than allowed. The speeches were ``a gimmick'' to ``magically'' turn honoraria earned from appearances before trade groups into book promotions, allowing Durenberger to make $100,000 above his Senate salary, Bennett said. Durenberger received the money from a Minneapolis publisher, Piranha Press, in return for having trade groups he addressed send their speaking fees to Piranha. Piranha earned $248,360 from the speeches but only $15,560 from sales of the two books. ``This very hungry fish, Piranha Press, was allowed to engage in a feeding frenzy'' to make money, Bennett said. Durenberger, he added, ``allowed himself and his office to be used as the bait and he got $100,000 for his trouble.'' Durenberger's attempts to change ownership of his Minneapolis condominium were part of a convoluted scheme to collect $40,055 in Senate travel reimbursements improperly from 1983 through 1989. He knew he would have been ineligible for the payments if he had owned the residence outright, Bennett said. Bennett also said Durenberger showed a ``pattern of insensitivity'' when he accepted free limousine rides in Boston from people interested in legislation. Durenberger used the limousine service to get to regular appointments with a local marriage counselor.

DOC.HEAD: Police End Party With Gunshot to Beer Keg
DOC.TEXT: Police wanted to pull the plug on a party of underage drinkers, so they pulled the trigger at their keg. ``Better to do that than leave it full and have 35 to 40 juveniles running around drunk,'' Police Chief Dennis Robertson said Tuesday. Police were called Sunday about a keg party involving minors in this town of 3,300 near Kansas City, Kan. Just two officers were on duty and they had two other calls which they had to respond to, Robertson said. ``There was nobody around and nobody to get hurt,'' Robertson said, and because of the other calls, an officer decided to fire his gun into the keg of beer, draining it. No arrests were made. If the officers had had time, they would have taken the keg to a chapter of Mothers Against Drunk Driving, so the group could get the keg deposit, Robertson said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Government Revamps Economic Reform Plans
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government said today that it would postpone unpopular bread price increases, but lawmakers were considering a plan to speed up other elements of a radical economic reform plan. Bread prices will be raised, but ``of course, not by July 1'' as originally planned, a top official said. When plans to raise the price of bread and other food and goods were announced last month, they set off a wave of panic buying. The official _ Yuri Maslyukov, chairman of the government agency that plans the centralized economy _ spoke with reporters during a break at a session of the Supreme Soviet legislature. Lawmakers were debating a resolution on the economic program presented last month by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. The resolution calls for faster and more radical steps to make the switch from central planning to a market economy. ``We can't stretch the elastic..., we have to begin work now,'' Alexei Boiko, chairman of an economic reform commission, told parliamentary deputies, urging the speeding up of the program. The draft resolution would instruct the government to cut spending immediately on the military and the state bureaucracy. It would also give the government until September to make concrete proposals for faster economic reforms, including drafting laws on creation of a stock market, commercial banks and credit and a federal reserve bank. But opposition surfaced during debate, and the resolution was likely to change drastically by day's end. Ryzhkov, the economic plan's architect, told reporters he supported the resolution. ``The project was worked on by commissions and is fairly objective, and allows us to work further,'' he said. But he said it would be difficult to complete all the laws and practical measures by the autumn deadline. Today's proposal did not address the Ryzhkov plan's price increases for most consumer products, which are due to take effect in January. The Ryzhkov plan was criticized for raising prices without freeing enough goods and prices from government control to allow a true transition to a market economy. Particularly unpopular was the proposal to at least double the price of bread, the staple of the Soviet diet. Currently, bread is extremely cheap at about 30 cents a loaf. Ryzhkov admitted he was surprised at the swell of sentiment against the price increases. He said he knew it would be difficult, but ``to tell the truth, I thought society was more prepared.'' Maslyukov said the plan for bread prices increases, which would be linked to compensation for the public, needed more work. But he said nine of the 15 Soviet republics had already agreed to raise their bread prices on August 1, with compensation beginning about two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Main Suspect In Libyan Scandal Says he Helped Build Rabta Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with quotes, details on transaction, case continuing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A West German businessman testified today that the company he once ran helped build a chemical weapons factory in Libya, West German television reported. Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, former director of the Imhausen-Chemie company of Lahr, also said at his trial that the Rabta plant in Libya was built to make poison gas, the television news said. According to the news report, Hippenstiel said the company ``participated in construction of the Rabta factory,'' delivering production plans and equipment. Hippenstiel said the project began in 1984 when a ``middleman,'' whom he did not identify by name, contacted him to build a chemical plant to make ``pharmaceuticals and insecticides.'' A short time later he was made aware that the $136.4 million project was intended to be set up in Libya, Hippenstiel said. He said he had suspicions that the project ``would be in conflict with export laws,'' but that he had purposely not checked it out because he ``didn't want to lose the business.'' Hippenstiel apologized that he had caused West Germany what he called ``diplomatic problems,'' because of the deal with Libya. ``The responsibility and overall management was in my hands,'' Hippenstiel said of the project. The television news said: ``Hippenstiel's statements also confirmed that poison gas was to be produced at Rabta.'' Hippenstiel said he did not pay taxes on $11.7 million on profits from his transactions. He said, however, that he used the money for the Rabta project to ensure it would be completed.He did not elaborate. The Libyan plant scandal broke in December 1988, with allegations of West German assistance in construction of the plant south of Tripoli. West German government officials at first denied any of the country's companies were involved, but later acknowledged the allegations were true. Libya says the plant was built to make pharmaceuticals only. Hippenstiehl-Imhausen headed the company that allegedly was the key supplier of equipment and expertise. The 49-year-old defendant was held in prison for 14 months until his trial began Monday in Mannheim District Court. A 100-page indictment alleged that Hippenstiehl-Imhausen played a leading role in the project from 1984 to 1988, when he headed the Imhausen Chemie chemical company. In opening arguments, prosecutor Hans-Heiko Klein said Hippenstiel-Imhausen had delivered plans and documents, as well as providing material valued at $12 million. The primary allegations against the defendant revolved around violations of West German export laws, designed to hinder any participation in such illegal projects abroad. Next week, the court will hear witnesses called to testify in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush Endorses Call for Flag-Burning Amendment
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush today endorsed her husband's call for a constitutional amendment against flag burning, but retired Supreme Court Chief Justice Warren E. Burger took an equivocal position. President Bush is pressing for a 27th amendment to the Constitution to make flag-burning a crime. The Supreme Court has overturned laws against flag desecration, ruling they violate the First Amendment's protection of free speech. The first lady, asked her view on amending the Constitution, said, ``I'm with the president on that. ... You're darn right, I'm always with the president. I'm glad you noticed.'' Reporters then tried to get an opinion from the 82-year-old Burger, who led the high court in 1969-1986 and has often cautioned against adding amendments to the Constitution. Burger and Mrs. Bush were meeting on the White House lawn with students who won a poster contest honoring the Constitution. ``Retired justices shouldn't have any thoughts as to what present justices should do, but I won't wrap myself in that flag because I might be afraid to get burned,'' Burger said. When a reporter pressed for an explanation, Mrs. Bush interjected, ``That's a pun, you dummy.'' ``I don't have a vote anymore. ... '' said Burger. ``Last year's coach shouldn't be telling the football coach how he should run the team this year.'' Burger is chairman of the Commission on the Bicentennial of the U.S. Constitution, which honored several dozen students from three schools for drawing historical maps of colonial America. More than 6,000 schools entered the contest. When reporters asked the students if they believed flag burning should be allowed, they chorused, ``No!'' No one disagreed. ``Thataway!'' said Mrs. Bush. The winners were 35 fifth graders from the King's Academy in West Palm Beach, Fla.; 20 seventh and eighth graders from St. Andrews School in Tipton, Mo., and Be Do, 16, a junior at Long Beach High School in Long Beach, Miss. Ms. Do and her family fled Vietnam in a small boat in 1979 when she was 5 and later emigrated to the United States. Her father is a shrimper in Biloxi, Miss. The teen-ager said she spent most of the month of December drawing her map, ``The Growth of a Nation,'' which featured colorful geographical and historical pictures inset in each of the original colonies. ``I remember the first time I left Vietnam that I didn't want to leave it,'' the teen-ager said. ``I kept on saying, `I want to go back! I want to go back!' But since I've been here I've regretted ever saying that. It was such a big change.'' Mrs. Bush held up her map and asked, ``You did that by yourself? Beautiful.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins in Rape-Attempted Murder Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with four grafs to UPDATE with jury selection under way. Picks up 5th graf,`They and...'.
DOC.TEXT: A judge has decided against allowing live TV coverage of the Central Park rape trial, which began today with jury selection. On Tuesday, Justice Thomas Galligan also banned audio coverage, citing the ``lewd and scandalous matters'' to be dealt with, witnesses' apprehensions, the ages of the defendants and the opposition of both prosecution and defense. Lawyers in the trial of three teen-agers accused of raping and nearly killing a jogger believe it will be impossible to find potential jurors who have not heard of the highly publicized case. About 500 prospective jurors were expected to go through an initial screening process today at Manhattan's state Supreme Court. Lawyers will try to pick 12 jurors and six alternates to hear the cases against Antron McCray and Yusef Salaam, both 16, and Raymond Santana, 15. They and three other youths are charged with attacking an investment banker while she was jogging through the northern end of Central Park shortly before 10 p.m. on April 19, 1989. More than 30 youths had entered the park's north end together for what they called ``wilding'' _ a violent rampage. They split up into smaller groups and allegedly attacked two male joggers, a homeless man, and the female jogger, who was gang-raped and left for dead. The three youths are being tried as adults on charges of attempted murder, rape, sodomy, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot. If convicted they would be sentenced as juveniles and would face a maximum of three and one-third to 10 years in prison. The victim, now 29, suffered brain damage in the assault and cannot remember the attack or identify her assailants. After emerging from a coma and living at a rehabilitation center, she returned to work at Salomon Brothers and was recently named a vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Reportedly Kills 30 People, 50 Others Missing
DOC.TEXT: A tornado swept across a southern Philippine village, killing up to 30 people and leveling scores of homes made from coconut leaves, officials said Wednesday. More than 50 people were reported wounded. The twister roared ashore ``like a thousand barrels of water being poured into the village,'' said Ceasar Binghay, budget officer of Manukan, a village about 450 miles south of Manila. The tornado, which hit Tuesday, leveled 59 houses, mostly made from coconut leaves, and carried people, plants and animals to sea, Binghay said. He said at least 30 people were reported killed and 50 were wounded. Only nine of the dead have been identified, Binghay told reporters in Dipolog, a town about 15 miles from Manukan. The Red Cross and other relief agencies in Manila said they have not received any report about the incident. Sgt. Ramon Aucena of the military's Office of Civil Defense said his office has received a sketchy report about ``heavy flooding'' in the Manukan area but there was no mention of a tornado. The report said about 30 people were either reported dead or missing in the incident but his office is still verifying the report, Aucena added. Complete reports of natural disasters often take days or weeks to reach Manila because of the Philippines' primitive communications system.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Group Claims Killing of Former Police Official
DOC.TEXT: Two gunmen posing as mailmen on Wednesday killed a former police official in his home, the police chief said. An outlawed leftist group claimed responsibility. The killing was the second in 24 hours claimed by extreme leftists. Hamdi Ardali, the chief of Istanbul police, said the gunmen rang the doorbell of Muhsin Bodur's house. They told his wife, who answered the door, they had a personal delivery for him. When Bodur, a former police official turned private detective, came to the door they shot him and ran away, Ardali told reporters. Later, the killing was claimed in phone calls to newspaper offices by Turkish Workers and Peasants Communist Army, an extreme leftist gang involved in political killings in 1970s. Police officials who asked for anonymity said Bodur had tried to track down members of the leftist group before he left the force. On Wednesday, a retired military judge, Durmus Aksen, was shot and killed in his law office. The shooting was claimed by Dev-Sol (Revolutionary Left), another underground organization active during the 1970s. Police said Aksen served as legal adviser to the Istanbul martial law command during 1980-83 military rule. The military takeover followed a wave of political violence by extreme leftist and rightist gangs which claimed 5,000 lives in three years. The military declared martial law nationwide. About 250,000 people were imprisoned on charges of terrorist killings or affiliation with one of the terrorist groups. Most of those imprisoned have been released.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Accepts New Defense Evidence
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Supreme Court accepted new evidence Wednesday that the defense contends will support convicted Nazi war criminal John Demjanjuk's assertion that he was a victim of mistaken identity. Demjanjuk, a retired Cleveland autoworker, is appealing his April 1988 conviction and death sentence. The justices admitted into evidence two affidavits from a former guard in the World War II death camp in Poland in which he stated that another Ukrainian named Ivan Marchenko was posted with him there. A man named Ivan Marchenko also is on a list from the Main Commission for Investigation of Hitlerite Crimes in Poland containing the names of some Soviet prisoners of war who volunteered to join the Nazis as guards. The court also accepted that list. Demjanjuk's defense lawyer, Yoram Sheftel, contends Marchenko, not Demjanjuk, is ``Ivan the Terrible,'' a gas-chamber operator at Treblinka who tortured Jews as they were herded in to die. A week before the appeal hearing began May 14, the justices accepted testimony from a defense witness who identified Marchenko as Ivan the Terrible. The deposition came from Kaziemiez Dudek, a liquor store owner whose wife was a prostitute who slept with Ivan the Terrible. Dudek identified Ivan the Terrible from a 1942 photograph that prosecutors allege is of Demjanjuk but said his surname was Marchenko. ``These things are unequivocal. They speak for themselves,'' argued Sheftel. ``When they come and say Ivan the Terrible was Marchenko... the case is over.'' Marchenko is Demjanjuk's mother's maiden name, which prosecutors claim Demjanjuk used when visiting Dudek's wife. Demjanjuk Americanized his first name to John from the Ukrainian Ivan in 1958 when he became a U.S. citizen. A three-judge trial court agreed with the prosecution that Demjanjuk was the Treblinka guard. More than 850,000 Jews were murdered at the Treblinka death camp in Nazi-occupied Poland in 1942-1943. A Ukrainian native, Demjanjuk claims he is a victim of mistaken identity and says he spent those years in several German POW camps as a captured Soviet soldier. The 70-year-old Demjanjuk was extradited from Ohio to Israel in February 1986. Chief Justice Meir Shamgar pressed Sheftel on the significance of the different names in comparison with the identification by Treblinka survivors of photographs of Demjanjuk. Justice Eliezer Goldberg also questioned the importance of evidence coming more than two years after the trial ended. ``Today 100 witnesses could come here and tell stories,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Professor Elected League President
DOC.TEXT: Susan Sturc Lederman, a professor of political science at Kean College in New Jersey, was elected president of the League of Women Voters on Wednesday. ``Action on League issues nourishes the spirit,'' she told the organization on the last day of its annual convention. ``We are concerned about the environment. We are concerned about nuclear proliferation. We are concerned about a safer world. We are concerned about reforming campaign practices and registration laws. ... We are fighting for reproductive choice.'' Mrs. Lederman, who was born in Czechoslovakia and now lives in New Providence, N.J., was president of the New Jersey League of Women voters from 1985-89. She has been a member of the League since 1961. She was unopposed for the four-year term. Virginia deSimone of Arlington, Va., was elected first vice president; Jean Askham of Fullerton, Calif., second vice president; and Diana Winterhalter of Columbus, Ohio, secretary-treasurer.

DOC.HEAD: Military Officials Reportedly Involved In Bribery Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Authorities detained four people, including a relative of a presidential aide, in an alleged bribery scandal involving the sale of 2.5 million black socks to the army, officials said Wednesday. Another of the four detained, socks supplier Hsiao Chun-liang, claims he paid $190,000 in bribes last year to win the $1.82 million contract, authorities said. Hsiao also told investigators he paid about $218,000 to three officers of the Combined Service Forces, an agency overseeing military purchases, to accept a shipment of inferior socks. Hsiao claimed it is difficult for Taiwan factories to meet some military standards, including one that requires black socks not fade after soaking in hot water for 40 minutes. Newspapers report Premier Hau Pei-tsun ordered an inquiry into the case after opposition legislators accused the military of a cover-up. In addition to Hsiao, authorities have detained Chiang Chung-lien, a cousin of the chief of staff to President Lee Teng-hui, and Chiang's son, Ching-hsiung. Also taken into custody was Tsai Hsiung, head of the National Assembly's public relations department.
