Police allege the bribe money was shared by three of the detained men and other government and military officials.

DOC.HEAD: Restaurant Owner Killed While Watching World Cup Game on TV
DOC.TEXT: A masked gunman walked into a crowded restaurant and killed the owner, police reported. The assailant hit Pietro Rosselli, 59, with pistol fire, killing him instantly, police said. The gunman escaped in a motorbike. At the time of the shooting Tuesday night, the restaurant TV was showing the second half of the World Cup soccer match between Netherlands and Egypt, which was being played in Palermo. Police said they had no motive for the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Urges Halt to Forced Return of Refugees
DOC.TEXT: The forced return of Burmese refugees to their homeland was condemned Wednesday by a human rights group urging a halt to the deportations. The U.S.-based Asia Watch organization requested President Bush to demand an end to Thailand's repatriation policy. The group claims some Burmese returnees are unwillingly pressed into military service and could be used as ``human mine sweepers.'' Thailand's prime minister, Chatichai Choonhavan, is scheduled to meet with Bush on Thursday in Washington. Thai police and troops last week forced about 1,000 Burmese civilians living in northwestern Thailand to cross the Moei River back into Burma. Thai officials have said there is no danger for most refugees to return to Burma since democratic reforms were endorsed in the nation's first free elections in 30 years. But there are still doubts whether the military will abide by the May 27 election results. ``The Thai government appears to be cynically exploiting the results of Burma's elections in order to rid itself of a swelling population of refugees who have fled Burma in fear of their lives,'' said the statement, seen Wednesday in Bangkok. Several minority groups in the rugged northern frontier area have been fighting the central Rangoon government for autonomy for the past three decades. The Asia Watch statement said there was ``no evidence that army soldiers have halted their systematic violations of human rights.'' The group cited reports that Thai police had burned the homes and belongings of those deported. By late Friday, Burmese authorities had received 766 people repatriated from Thailand, said government spokesman Kyaw Sann. He said there were 27 camps along the border to receive the returnees, and those resettled would be given plots of land. But the Asia Watch statement said the returnees had been ``imprisoned in monasteries and temple compounds,'' and only those with identity cards and able to pay $150 were freed. Others were forced into military service, acting as porters or leading patrols through mine-filled areas, the group charges. ``Civilian porters compelled to serve as human mine sweepers for the army have offered numerous testimonies concerning the reckless disregard for human life routinely exhibited by the Burmese army,'' it added. Several human right organizations have accused the Burmese army of murdering and abusing those it has pressed into its service.

DOC.HEAD: `War Room' in Seattle Helps Oil-Spill Cleanup
With AM-Tanker Blast-Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Hours after oil began spewing from a burning supertanker in the Gulf of Mexico, scientists in a windowless ``war room'' 2,000 miles away scrambled to provide fast answers to salvage crews on the scene. Whenever poisonous, explosive or otherwise dangerous substances are released into the nation's waters, telephones start ringing at the Hazardous Materials Response Branch. ``We are by far and away the most experienced group in oil spill response worldwide. No question,'' said Dave Kennedy, chief of scientific support coordinators at the war room, which is the Western regional headquarters of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. As fires raged aboard the Mega Borg off Texas on Saturday, the research unit was already providing cleanup and Coast Guard crews with vital data predicting the course and effects of a slick from the Norwegian supertanker. Two oceanographer-modelers were sent to Galveston to study currents and meteorological factors; three experts from Columbia, S.C., assessed hazards to seafood, beachgoers and shipping, and two Louisiana State University chemists analyzed the makeup of the vessel's cargo of light crude. Tomes of information were being sifted by two information management specialists. And a media specialist was sent to Galveston on Tuesday to field questions from reporters. Before the research unit was formed 14 years ago, the Coast Guard and cleanup contractors were deluged with raw information ``and in many cases had no idea how to interpret it,'' Kennedy said. ``We're here basically to provide a formal mechanism for transferring scientific information to the operational response guys, the Coast Guard.'' The hazardous-response team must answer a vast array of questions: _ Where would oil go if the vessel broke apart or sank? How much would drift to the bottom? How much would stay at the surface? How much would be carried by currents beneath the surface? _ What threat would the oil pose to shrimp, oysters, mussels and fish? What would be the best way to minimize the damage? Would containment booms do any good? If so, where should they be placed? _ How much air pollution has occurred? What is the danger to Corpus Christi, Galveston and other populated areas along the coast? _ What should be done about shipping traffic in the area? While the threat of a catastrophic spill receded today, the research unit still had plenty on its mind, including spills in the Arthur Kill waterway between New York and New Jersey, Buzzards Bay in Massachusetts and the Connecticut River in Connecticut. The Seattle control room is equipped with nautical charts and topographic maps for every coastline and major inland waterway. There's a large map on one wall dotted with markings for offshore oil and gas drilling rigs, weather monitoring platforms and buoys, the latest location of the burning ship and the outer limits of the slick. On a nearby bookshelf is an atlas listing shellfish and wetland areas, industrial and shipping sites, bathing beaches and other shoreline assets. ``This is what we call our war room,'' Kennedy said. ``I worked about 18 hours yesterday. You worked, what, about 24 hours?'' he said to a woman poring over computer printouts. The unit has grown from 10 people in 1976 to 60 today, including about 35 specialists ready to fly out at any moment and eight regional coordinators stationed around the country. Practically every available staffer was assigned to Prince William Sound after the Exxon Valdez tanker hit a reef and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of heavy crude oil in 1989, Kennedy said. About eight staffers are still monitoring the cleanup. ``This spill is not on a level of intensity with the Exxon Valdez,'' Kennedy said. But his team learned from that disaster to anticipate the worst. ``We all said, `The weather is good, the currents aren't too bad, we ought to be able to keep the oil from reaching shore,''' he said. ``Then we had a windstorm come up and drive the oil not just to the shore but far beyond where the tide would normally reach.'' ``We've gotten more skeptical.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Briefs Chinese on Washington Summit
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Wednesday briefed China about the U.S.-Soviet summit, in the latest of a flurry of Chinese-Soviet contacts. Moscow and Beijing normalized relations last year during a visit by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The two Communist powers had split over ideological differences in the late 1950s, and came close to going to war after several bloody border clashes in 1969. The official Xinhua News Agency said the Soviet deputy foreign minister, Igor Rogachov, met with Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen to discuss the U.S.-Soviet summit in Washington at the beginning of June. The report quoted Qian as saying China supports efforts by Washington and Moscow to improse ties. Qian said China welcomed the strategic arms reduction agreement reached at the summit. The agreement, however, was little more than a statement of what had already been accomplished and was not considered a breakthrough in arms reduction talks. ``We ... hope that the Soviet Union and the United States will, as soon as possible, reach a detailed agreement and put it into practice,'' Qian said. The two leaders also discussed Sino-Soviet relations, Cambodia and other international affairs, Xinhua said. It said the two sides decided that the fifth round of Sino-Soviet border talks would begin on July 26 in Moscow. The two sides have been holding talks to resolve territorial disputes along the border since 1987. In February, Chinese and Soviet military experts agreed both sides should cut forces along the 4,300-mile frontier. Rogachov's visit is the latest in a series of recent Sino-Soviet exchanges. Last month, the Soviet Union sent its highest-ranking Communist Party delegation to China since the two nations normalized ties. Earlier this month, the Soviet National Defense Ministry's director of foreign affairs, Rear Admiral V. Hujokov, visited Beijing to increase contacts between the two armies. At the same time, the vice chairman of China's Central Military Commission, Liu Huaqing, was in Moscow. Soviet Chief of General Staff Mikhail Moiseyev said that during Liu's visit, the two sides agreed to begin ``building their military relations on a new basis,'' according to a Xinhua dispatch. Moiseyev said the two sides also agreed to establish economic relations, and added that improving military relations was a natural process.

DOC.HEAD: Rhode Island Governor Announces Re-election Bid
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Edward D. DiPrete announced Wednesday he plans to run for a fourth term by claiming credit for the rebirth of downtown Providence. The mayor is seeking the Democratic nomination. DiPrete, 55, made his announcement on the Statehouse front lawn with the city as a backdrop. ``The magnificent skyline of a city reborn'' resulted from his efforts as governor, he said. ``Preserving strong family values, promoting better schools, protecting our environmental heritage and enabling all Rhode Islanders to earn a good, decent living,'' were also part of his record, the Republican said. Surveys indicate that DiPrete faces a tough battle against whoever emerges from the three-way Democratic primary in September. That contest pits Providence Mayor Joseph R. Paolino Jr. against businessman and twice-unsuccessful gubernatorial candidate Bruce G. Sundlun and Warwick Mayor Francis X. Flaherty. DiPrete has no opposition for the GOP nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Mobilizes More Troops to Control Medellin Violence
DOC.TEXT: The government is dispatching more policemen and soldiers to the drug capital of Medellin, where cartel-hired assassins have killed more than 100 police this year, authorities said Wednesday. A Medellin police spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 220 men from an elite anti-drug police unit would join the 4,000-member police force already in the city. That follows word that another 350 soldiers would be sent to Medellin. Gen. Jesus Armando Arias announced that mobilization at a news conference Tuesday. Medellin, Colombia's second largest city, has about 3 million residents. Officials say 106 policemen have been killed in the city so far this year. Drug traffickers in April offered a $4,300 bounty for each police officer killed. The latest killings came Tuesday night in western Medellin. Three unidentified assailants opened fire with machine guns on a truck carrying the bodyguards of the regional police commander. A Medellin police spokeman told the Associated Press that two police agents were killed in the attack. The Medellin cartel boasted in a communique Tuesday night that it has killed even more police than officials say. The cartel, which calls itself The Extraditables, said the murder of policemen is a response to ``the sackings, the tortures and the murders of our companions and of innocent people in poor neighborhoods.'' It blamed police for violence that has left 107 people dead in Medellin. Authorities say most of the killings result from gang rivalry and score-settling among opposing drug factions. In their statement Tuesday, the Extraditables said officials they have managed to frighten many police officers into quitting. ``The Colombian people should be told the truth about the resignations and desertions and it would also be nice if the real number of deaths suffered by the institution were not hidden or diminished,'' the statement said. The drug traffickers have been pressuring the government to end its war on drugs, under which traffickers have been extradited to face trial in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Win in Arkansas, South Carolina; Atlantic City Mayor Ousted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 20-23, `North Dakota...', to UPDATE vote totals for North Dakota elections.
DOC.TEXT: Black candidates won primaries for governor of South Carolina and lieutenant governor of Arkansas, propelling them into uphill general election races against powerful opponents. In the Arkansas race, businessman Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris trounced Ku Klux Klan sympathizer Ralph Forbes by more than a 6-1 margin on Tuesday to win the Republican nomination for lieutenant governor. In South Carolina, state Sen. Theo Mitchell soundly defeated state Sen. Ernest Passailaigue in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. In one other election with racial overtones, the first black mayor of Atlantic City, N.J., James L. Usry, was ousted by a white challenger in a runoff. Usry was recently indicted on corruption charges. Voters also elected the first black mayor of Trenton, N.J., chose congressional candidates in Maine and rejected a sales tax increase in North Dakota. In Arkansas, Harris said his victory over Forbes showed that Arkansas voters had ``finally rejected the old tactics of the KKK and the neo-Nazis, and white supremacists' effort to deceive the public.'' In final, unofficial returns, Harris, a 36-year-old executive with a Little Rock hair products company, had 27,548 votes, or 86 percent, to Forbes' 4,432 votes, or 14 percent. Harris is only the second black candidate ever nominated for a constitutional office in Arkansas and hopes to become the first black elected to such an office. But he will be an underdog in November against a strong Democratic nominee, ex-Rep. Jim Guy Tucker. Forbes, a former member of the American Nazi Party who believes in racial separatism, insisted he had been robbed of the election. Told that he was losing his home county, Pope, by 68 votes to 8, he replied, ``I've got more than eight kids, for crying out loud.'' The county's total at the end of the night was 571-79. In South Carolina, with 99 percent of the precincts reporting, Mitchell had defeated Passailaigue by 116,922, or 60 percent, to 76,790, or 40 percent. ``I'm very humble,'' Mitchell said as he accepted the party's nomination. ``As a man of color, it shows that we are still fulfilling the promise of this great nation.'' Mitchell would become the state's first black governor if he defeated popular Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell in the fall. ``He's going to be the next governor of South Carolina,'' Passailaigue said of Mitchell. ``I'm convinced of that.'' In Atlantic City, Usry received 4,427 votes, or 38 percent, to Whelan's 7,244, or 62 percent. The mayor had been dogged by his indictment on charges of illegally accepting $6,000 last summer. Race played a role in the campaign. Usry, angered by a lack of white support in the May 8 election, refused to campaign in two predominantly white wards. He received 49 votes in those wards Tuesday, to Whelan's 4,522. Across the state, county Freeholder Douglas Palmer scored a close victory over Mayor Carmen Armenti, apparently becoming Trenton's first black mayor. Palmer received 12,933 votes to 12,636 for Armenti, who called for a recount. In Maine, a Democratic state senator and a Republican ex-congressman won the right to face off for the congressional seat of Democratic Rep. Joseph E. Brennan, who is trying to regain his job of governor. In a five-way Democratic race, state Sen. Thomas Andrews upset Attorney General James E. Tierney. With 89 percent of the precincts reporting, Andrews had 15,203 votes, or 37 percent, and Tierney garnered 13,955 votes, or 34 percent. Three other candidates trailed. On the Republican side, former Rep. David Emery defeated state Rep. John McCormick. With 68 percent of the precincts reporting, Emery had 15,486 votes, or 63 percent; McCormick had 9,214 votes, or 37 percent. North Dakota voters turned down an effort to raise sales taxes from 5 percent to 6 percent for a year to improve education. The sales tax lost, 74,011 to 52,592, a 59-to-41 percent margin. They also turned thumbs down on Labor Commissioner Byron Knutson, who had been accused of sloppy management. The two nominees, who will face off in November, were Craig Hagen, a political newcomer who won't reach the minimum age for the office of 25 until after the primary, and S.F. ``Buckshot'' Hoffner, head of the state Centennial Commission. Hagen had 60,740 votes, or 50 percent; Hoffner had 37,731, or 31 percent; Knutson had 23,097 votes, or 19 percent. One of two counties west of Bismarck rejected a non-binding measure to switch from Mountain to Central time. In Mercer County, 1,325 opposed the change and 1,171 were in favor. In Oliver County, 675 voted for the Central time and 295 were opposed.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Say Many Groups Still Planning Conference Boycott
DOC.TEXT: A White House move to ease immigration restrictions for an international AIDS conference has not swayed the more than 100 groups that plan to boycott next week's event, AIDS activists said Wednesday. The activists, releasing the American edition of an international study on AIDS discrimination, said the U.S. immigration limits are part of a worldwide pattern that's spreading fear ``as widespread and destructive as the virus itself.'' Martin Foreman, author of the Panos Institute report, said more than 100 groups are boycotting the conference despite a new 10-day visa the United States announced in April for AIDS-infected foreigners who want to attend the conference. Groups listed as boycotting the 6th International Conference on AIDS include the International League of the Red Cross, the European Community, the Canadian Public Health Association, the World Council of Churches and the Roman Catholic Church's charity group, Caritas International. The San Francisco meeting is June 20-24. ``One of the purposes of the conference, which is the free international exchange of information, has already been defeated,'' Foreman said. The Immigration and Naturalization Service had denied entry to the United States to anyone with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, one of a handful of diseases that bar entry to the country. Those applying for the new visa don't have to reveal whether they are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. But AIDS activists said the limited visa sends the wrong message to those already facing discrimination. Carol Wolchok, director of the American Bar Association's Immigration Law Implementation Project, said the ABA believes those who have the HIV virus should not be barred entry to the country. ``Leaving HIV on the list of highly contagious diseases is counterproductive,'' she said. ``It fosters a false sense of security that the United States can isolate itself from HIV.'' Foreman said that although many groups are officially boycotting the conference, some may send observers who won't attend in an official capacity. The London-based Panos Institute is a non-profit, international organization that studies environmental and development issues.

DOC.HEAD: White House Welcomes Soviet Actions on Baltics
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; INSERTS full Fitzwater quote in 6th graf, Fitzwater, referring...; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The White House today hailed Moscow's decision to ease its economic blockade against Lithuania. ``We welcome this announcement,'' President Bush's spokesman said. The statement was issued by Marlin Fitzwater after the Tass news agency quoted Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene as saying the Soviet Union agreed to restore some fuel and raw material supplies. The supplies were cut off two months ago to force Lithuania to drop its declaration of independence. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met in Moscow on Tuesday with leaders of the Baltic republics. Bush said today he hoped that meeting was the ``first step'' toward ending the crisis over the secessionist republics. Shortly after Bush made his comments at a news conference, Tass reported the easing the economic blockade. Fitzwater, referring to Tuesday's meeting and the easing of the sanctions, said, ``We welcome this announcement. Together with the beginning of the dialogue yesterday, these are positive steps.'' Bush opened a news conference with out-of-town reporters by applauding Gorbachev's meeting on Tuesday with the presidents of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia. ``I think it was good news. I don't want to overstate it. But I was very pleased to see this occur in the wake of what I think was a successful summit meeting,'' Bush said. Bush said Gorbachev's decision to meet with the three presidents represents ``a very significant change that's occured in the Soviet Union.'' ``We applaud President Gorbachev's meeting with the Baltic presidents,'' he said. ``I hope that what we saw yesterday is a first step in a dialogue that will lead to the self-determination that we strongly support,'' Bush said. The president also renewed his call for Moscow to lift its economic boycott against Lithuania. At the same time, Bush criticized Moscow for its continued support of Cuban leader Fidel Castro. ``The Soviets ought to stop spending $5 billion a year in Cuba,'' he said. ``I would not accept the idea that this is the time to change our policy with regard to Fidel Castro,'' Bush said. In a session that covered a range of subjects, Bush also promised again a decision within days on restricting oil drilling off the coasts of Florida and California. ``It's a very hot item,'' Bush said. He said he still had not gotten all the information he needs to make a final decision on the long-delayed administration policy on drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf. On another pending environmental issue, Bush said he was searching for a compromise that would result in protecting the northern spotted owl without ``throwing people out of work'' in the Pacific Northwest. The administration must decide this month whether to declare the owl an endangered species. Such a designation would shut off vast tracts of forest to timber operations. ``I am very much concerned about the potential loss of jobs,'' Bush said. Bush also underscored his policy against normalizing relations with Iran ``until all our hostages are out,'' Bush said. Six Americans continue to be held by pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon. The president also voiced optimism toward resolution of the crisis in the Baltics on Tuesday, both in a session with reporters in the Rose Garden and again at a Republican fund-raising dinner. The president praised Gorbachev's decision to discuss the impasse directly on Tuesday with Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis and with the leaders of the two other Baltic states. ``I hope that out of that comes a further step towards self-determination for the Baltics,'' Bush told reporters. ``I think that's a heartening development,'' Bush said. The audience of more than 4,000 at the annual President's Dinner _ which coincided with Bush's birthday _ stood and sang ``Happy Birthday Mr. President.'' Organizers said the banquet generated $6.9 million for Republican congressional candidates. ``I feel it in my bones, we can get the majority of the Senate,'' Bush said. The president took questions from reporters after a Rose Garden event to promote his campaign for a constitutional amendment banning flag-desecration. Bush said flag desecration is ``unacceptable and must carry a price'' and asked Congress to pass the amendment in the aftermath of this week's Supreme Court ruling striking down an anti-flag-burning law. On another subject, Bush said ``there's quite a bit going on behind the scenes'' but he wasn't ready yet to announce his decision on suspending talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization. The administration has called on PLO leaders to renounce specifically the May 30 attack on an Israeli beach by Palestinian guerillas and to punish those responsible for it. Bush said he had discussed the incident on the phone earlier Tuesday with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. ``I want to see that terrorist act condemned, and those who did it condemned,'' he added. The PLO issued a statement on Monday renouncing terrorism, but did not specifically renounce the beach attack.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Post Third Consecutive Monthly Decline
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales fell again in May, posting their first consecutive three-month decline since the last recession, the government said Wednesday. Analysts saw the report as a reflection of fading consumer confidence. ``Consumer confidence was down in May,'' said economist Sandra Shaber of the Futures Group, a Washington management consulting firm. ``Maybe the poor job market and very weak wage gains are having an effect.'' The Commerce Department said sales skidded 0.7 percent to a seasonally adjusted $146.84 billion after falling 0.9 percent in April and 0.4 percent in March. Sales had not fallen for three straight months since the fall of 1981. Sales were even worse in April and March than first reported. Commerce had said originally that sales were down 0.6 percent in April and 0.2 percent a month earlier. They were unchanged in February after rising 2.8 percent the previous month. Retail sales represent about half of consumer spending, which has been a driving force since the 1981-82 recession. Overall, consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. But most economists believed the economy would continue to skirt a recession, although its growth would be weak for months to come. ``This does not necessarily indicate that the economy is in a recession, or headed in that direction, since there are signs of buoyancy elsewhere, such as in exports and capital investment,'' said economist Gordon Richards of the National Association of Manufacturers. ``Nevertheless, the slackening of sales indicate a weak second quarter and probably an even weaker third quarter.'' Ms. Shaber also said the report was not ``the last nail in the coffin of recession'' and could lead to promotional activity such as lower prices. She said that would be ``good news for inflation.'' On the other hand, S. Jay Levy of Levy Economic Forecasts in Chappaqua, N.Y., said: ``It's an indication of a recessionary trend.'' His organization contends there is a 60 percent chance the economy will slide into a recession this year. Levy and Ms. Shaber both pointed to the weak job market, where most recent gains reflected temporary government hiring of census workers, while employment losses continued at factories and in the construction industry. Automobile sales, a major component of retail sales, dropped 0.6 percent after a 1.6 percent decline in April. The manufacturing sector, including the automobile industry, has been dampened by Federal Reserve efforts to keep interest rates high so the economy would not overheat and fuel inflation. But even excluding automobiles, sales were down 0.8 percent in May. In fact, sales were off in every sector except for clothing and, Ms. Shaber said, ``that was on sale.'' Apparel and accessory sales rose 2.4 percent. Overall sales of durable goods _ big-ticket items like cars that are interest-sensitive because they often are made through loans _ fell 1.1 percent after sliding 1.7 percent in April. Building materials plunged 4.2 percent and furniture and other home furnishings fell 1.1 percent. Non-durable goods such as food and clothing slid 0.5 percent, the same as in April. Declines were posted for general department and grocery stores, both down 1.0 percent; gasoline stations, down 1.6 percent; drug stores, down 1.3 percent and restaurants and bars, down 0.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged East German Spy Says He Had No Choice
With AM-Germany-Terrorist, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A German researcher hired 30 years ago by a French government scientific agency testified Wednesday that he had no choice but to become a spy for East Germany's secret service. Rolf Dobbertin is accused of passing on confidential information about nuclear research and other topics to East Germany for 20 years, ending in 1979. His trial on espionage charges began Wednesday. The case is expected to hinge on the issue of whether the information he divulged was genuinely top secret. Dobbertin, 55, said he came to France after being awarded a grant to study abroad. But he said he would not have been allowed to accept it unless the secret service approved. ``In our country, nothing could be done without the authorization of the security services,'' he said. ``Don't forget this was during the Cold War. They wanted to be able to contact me at any moment, and I had to learn how to code and decode messages.'' He said his handlers mistrusted him because he had married a West German woman while living in Paris. Judge Maurice Colomb asked if Dobbertin still considered himself a Marxist, as he was in his youth. ``Marxism doesn't have a big future in the East,'' Dobbertin replied. Dobbertin was unmasked in 1979 and held in custody for four years during complex legal proceedings before being released on bail in 1983. He has resumed his post at France's National Center for Scientific Research. A verdict is expected Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Air Traffic Controllers Strike in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Managua's international airport was closed today by striking air traffic controllers who want the government to reinstate an officer in the Sandinista-controlled army as chief of civil aeronautics. The controllers walked off the job Tuesday night. Hours earlier, they contacted the plane carrying President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and threatened to strike before her flight from Costa Rica could land. The workers eventually allowed the plane to land before their Sandinista-controlled union shut down air traffic. The controllers are protesting the removal of Alejandro Arguello, a major in the Sandinista-controlled army, as chief of civil aeronautics. The walkout represents the second time since Mrs. Chamorro's pro-U.S. government took over from the leftist Sandinistas on April 25 that the air traffic controllers have struck. The first time, in mid-May, was in support of other civil servants who walked off the job demanding higher pay. The strikes are occurring as Mrs. Chamorro is struggling to solidify her power and improve the nation's economy, which was devastated by a decade of fighting between the U.S.-backed Contra rebels and the leftist Sandinistas. ``She was about five minutes from landing when we transmitted the message to the pilot,'' controller Daniel Gonzalez said in a telephone interview. The message was that the air traffic controllers wanted to talk to Mrs. Chamorro. ``But she couldn't come (to the cockpit) because of her knee,'' he said. Mrs. Chamorro, who suffered a recent knee fracture, walks with a cane. Jorge Saballos, another controller, said the controllers read a communique protesting Arguello's dismissal and demanded the government abide by a May strike agreement promising not to fire public employees. He said the controllers spoke briefly with Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado by radio. They allowed the plane to land after being assured that government representatives would speak in person with the controllers, Gonzalez said. Once the plane landed, Hurtado and presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo spoke to the controllers, but nothing was resolved. Air traffic controller Orlando Ortega said passengers planes were allowed to leave Nicaraguan air space Tuesday. ``As soon as they all left, we proceeded to shut down the airspace, until talks start,'' Ortega said. The controllers want to talk with Construction Minister Jaime Icabalceta, who fired Arguello last week after Civil Aeronautics was transfered from the air force to the Construction Ministry. Ortega said the controllers let an Iberia flight land today because it carried medicine. Ortega said four flights that were supposed to arrive in Managua today had been canceled. Those flights were from Sahsa, Copa, Aeronica and Cubana airlines. Lacayo, Hurtado and Icabalceta reportedly were in a Cabinet meeting with Mrs. Chamorro.

DOC.HEAD: Plan to Exit Soviet Jews through Finland in Danger
DOC.TEXT: The president has indicated he might suspend a plan to route Soviet emigres through Finland unless Israel says it will not settle Soviet Jews in the occupied territories, newspapers said Wednesday. President Mauno Koivisto on Tuesday told 20 newspaper editors he had made the demands on Jewish settlement to Israeli President Chaim Herzog, who visited in May. Koivisto's remarks were printed in newspapers Wednesday. Koivisto said Israel had ``reacted somewhat inadequately,'' to his demands, the Uusi Suomi newspaper reported. The daily quoted Koivisto as saying negotiations between Israel and Finland over the plan had broken off. Finnish officials said in May they were completing a plan with Israel to be a transit point for thousands of Soviet Jews. President Mauno Koivisto had said the plan would go into effect in late May. ``Officially Finland has not linked the transit of Soviet Jews with guarantees from Israel but it is clear that the transfer can only begin when Jerusalem has changed its current superficial attitude,'' Uusi Suomi wrote. In Jerusalem, Iris Ben-Shahal, spokeswoman for a Jewish agency helping to settle Jewish immigrants, said the threat was significant because Finland is one of four major routes to get Soviet emigrants to Israel. The other three routes are through Hungary, Romania and Poland. ``The Israelis have said that Israel is a free country, which we don't particularly doubt, but we don't see that it concerns the occupied territories,'' Helsinki Sanomat, the leading daily, quoted Koivisto as saying. ``There is the possibility of interpreting this ... in such a way that Israel considers the occupied territories as belonging to them,'' the newspaper quoted Koivisto as saying. Since the reform initiatives introduced by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev record levels of Soviet Jews have left the Soviet Union under freer emigration laws. Many have chosen to emigrate to Israel. But Arab leaders have expressed concern that the Soviet Jews, expected to number 750,000 over the next years, will be settled in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank. The territories were taken from the Arabs in the 1967 Middle East War. At a recent superpower summit in Washington, President Bush and Gorbachev asked Jerusalem not to settle Soviet Jews in the territories, home to 1.7 million Palestinians and 700,000 Jewish settlers. Israel says Jerusalem has no policy of settling Jews in the territories, but immigrants can live where they choose. Israel's absorption minister, Yitzhak Peretz, said Wednesday that 43,128 Soviet immigrants arrived in Israel this year, joining another 13,000 who arrived in 1989. He said 318 have settled in the West Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Government Reportedly Easing Embargo on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 7th pvs, `Tass quoted...' to UPDATE with White House reaction. Pickup 8th, `On Tuesday...'
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's prime minister said today the Soviet government has agreed to restore some fuel and raw material supplies to the Baltic republic, easing an embargo imposed two months ago, Tass reported. Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene made the comment after meeting with Kremlin officials today, the Soviet news agency said. ``There are no doubts about the lifting of the economic blockade. This was stated quite explicitly,'' Tass quoted Prunskiene as saying after she met with Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Mrs. Prunskiene said she had reached an agreement with Ryzhkov on a partial increase of the supply of natural gas and raw materials to some enterprises in the republic, Tass said. She also said the Soviet government intends to review the question of renewing the supply of fuel for Lithuanian agriculture. Mrs. Prunskiene was quoted by Tass as saying her republic would ``carefully discuss the question of freezing the republic's March 11 declaration of independence for the duration of negotiations with the Soviet government.'' Tass quoted Ryzhkov as describing today's encounter as ``the beginning of a concrete dialogue on the question of future negotiations.'' The reported breakthrough in the impasse between Lithuania and Moscow was hailed today by the White House. ``We welcome this announcement,'' said a spokesman for President Bush, Marlin Fitzwater. ``Together with the beginning of the dialogue yesterday, these are positive steps.'' On Tuesday, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with the presidents of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia after having refusing for weeks to negotiate with the secessionist Baltic republics unless they agreed to abide by the Soviet Constitution. President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania hinted then that the Kremlin might soon end the economic embargo imposed on his republic. Ryzhkov, who attended the session, said earlier today there was progress on the impasse over the Baltic states' independence declarations. The republics want independence lost when they were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Latvia and Estonia have taken more cautious steps toward independence than Lithuania. Gorbachev stopped shipments of all oil, most natural gas and other raw materials to Lithuania on April 18 to pressure the republic into rescinding pro-independence laws. The embargo cut off all of Lithuania's oil and much of its natural gas and certain raw materials and put 26,000 citizens out of work. Before today's reported agreement, Lithuania had said it was willing to negotiate on rolling back its independence laws but steadfastly had refused to revoke its declaration of secession. The United States became involved in the standoff when lawmakers in Congress suggested they would not approve a trade pact signed during the superpower summit in Washington until Gorbachev opened negotiations with the Baltic republics and lifted the economic embargo he imposed on Lithuania. The trade agreement would expand opportunities for American companies wishing to do business in the Soviet Union by reducing red tape and providing greater protections against copyright piracy. The pact is important because it also could clear the way for the United States to grant most-favored-nation trade status to the Soviet Union, a benefit that could help Gorbachev in his efforts to reform the nation's economy. Congress has indicated it will not stand in the way of the Bush administration granting the improved trading status once the trade pact is approved and the Soviets pass laws guaranteeing Jews the right to emmigrate.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Talking With Congressional Republicans About NEA
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, faced with growing furor over what some consider offensive art, has begun talks with congressional Republicans on restricting grants awarded by the National Endowment for the Arts, a congressman said Wednesday. Rep. Paul Henry, D-Mich., said after a meeting with NEA Chairman Paul Frohnmayer that the administration had dropped its previous strong opposition to any type of content restrictions or standards in a bill to extend the life of the agency. The change comes as congressional concern is increasing over federal subsidies going to arts projects that some consider obscene, pornographic or sacrilegious. ``I think we've reached a point that if you're going to rescue the NEA, you have to speak forthrightly about what receives public support,'' Henry said. ``The members have gotten so much mail on this that they're tired of the political baggage of it.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he expected a bipartisan agreement on the issue and a House vote by mid-July. Both House and Senate subcommittees considering NEA bills sent the legislation to the full committees Wednesday without making a decision on restrictions. ``We will have to deal with this controversy in the full committee,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. ``It will not be swept under the rug.'' Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., said no agreement had been reached and that he understood the Bush administration continued to oppose writing new restrictions into law. ``All along, the White House, the NEA and a majority in the Congress have recognized the political reality that there will be some changes in the NEA,'' Williams said. ``What those are to be we don't know. And there's no agreement.'' The Bush administration originally proposed a five year reauthorization, or extension of the life of the NEA, without any restrictions on what types of art may or may not receive public support. Faced with growing Republican sentiment for some kind of restrictions, the administration last week proposed as an alternative an interim one-year to three-year extension while an independent commission studied the problem. Henry said the latest development was a recognition that leaving the matter to NEA officials would not satisfy Congress. He said Frohnmayer, representing the Bush administration, acknowledged for the first time that there is a difference between censorship and deciding that some art may be inappropriate for taxpayers' financial support. The NEA said in a formal statement that it would not comment on the deliberations or any proposals for content restrictions. Henry, a Republican moderate in the NEA debate, is a member of Williams' education subcommittee and has taken a leading role in recent days in negotiating between various factions. Henry declined to detail what he will propose but said he was continuing to talk with Frohnmayer in private. He said he hoped to come up with language that affirmatively states what types of art will be supported. He said neither the NEA nor White House had agreed to any specifics so far. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., warned the NEA that ``people over there had better understand the feeling of the American people.'' He said the public is ``sick and tired'' of ``promiscuous art.'' Some conservatives, led by Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calf., have been pressing for strong prohibitions on what they call anti-religious or ``morally reprehensible'' art. The controversy was triggered a year ago over the works of two photographers, one whose images depicted homoerotic scenes and the other showing a crucifix in a jar of urine.

DOC.HEAD: New Communist Platform Borrows from Right, Left to Avoid Split
With AM-Soviet-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party leaders are borrowing ideas from conservative and reform-minded challengers for a new platform they hope will prevent the first major split in ranks since Lenin, a Politburo member said Wednesday. But less than three weeks before the opening of the 28th party conference, many party members and observers expect more breaks in the party structure as it tries to control a rapidly changing Soviet society. ``We are trying to develop the broadest possible platform,'' Politburo member Vadim A. Medvedev told a news conference. Medvedev said the platform will include some reformist policies, but not totally break with orthodox Marxist-Leninist ideology such as social organizations and party cells among workers. Although he declined to outline the entire platform proposal, Medvedev said it will not accommodate the Democratic Platform's call to turn the Communist Party into a parliamentary body. He said separate structures in the party are unacceptable. ``If we are talking about such fractions, there is no sense in being in the party. It should splinter and set up its own party,'' he said. Democratic Platform, the main reform group within the party, is scheduled to meet this weekend to discuss strategy for the congress, which begins July 2. Democratic Platform leaders have predicted the congress will be dominated by moderates, and that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would not push through enough changes to recapture disenchanted party members. The group is demanding the party give up control of newspapers and property, and dismantle party cells in the army, KGB, the police and factories. It also opposes one person serving as both party chief and the nation's president, as Gorbachev now does. Party data released by Medvedev on Wednesday indicates 43 percent of the congress delegates chosen so far are members of the party apparatus, considered as among the most resistant to change because their jobs depend on the party's continued influence. Among the more than 4,000 delegates already elected to the 4,700-seat congress, the number of workers and farmers has dropped drastically from the last congress, Medvedev said. Forty-two percent of the delegates in 1986 were workers, and 9 percent were farmers, Medvedev said. This year's figures so far are 11.6 percent and 4.8 percent, respectively. He said an extra 350 representatives for workers and farmers will be invited to the congress, which will decide whether they may vote. Members of the apparatus likely will approve the proposed party platform obediently, said Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, a Democratic Platform leader and the rector of Moscow's Higher Party School. Shostakovsky, however, said he was pesimistic the congress would implement major changes. Democratic Platform leaders say they expect support from about 500,000 of the Communist Party's 18 million members. But they have only about 100 delegates so far for the congress. Philosopher Igor Chubais suggested Democratic Platform could hurt its own popularity by lambasting the increasingly unpopular Communists. ``An anti-communist mood is growing. This is a fact,'' he said. ``The attitude to the very idea of communism is very negative. ``I would appeal not for reform, but for distancing ourselves from the Soviet Communist Party.''

DOC.HEAD: Supertanker Blaze Under Control, But Oil Continues to Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with estimated spill at 3 million gallons but most gone, hole found in center tank, tar balls forming, Norwegian hearing under way. Picks up 10th graf, `This will....'. SUBS 17th graf, `Once the...', to DELETE outdated reference to foam. Norway hearing has opened but lead prospects uncertain; procedural matters were dealt with first.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: At least 3 million gallons of oil leaked from the fire-ravaged supertanker in the Gulf of Mexico, but most of it has burned or evaporated, the Coast Guard said today. Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said crews found a hole in a center tank in the 886-foot Mega Borg. ``A minimum of 3 million gallons has left the cargo tanks and I'm presuming that most of that has gone into the water,'' Greene told reporters. ``I don't see any risk of losing cargo from the other tanks.'' He said between 12,000 gallons and 40,000 gallons remained in the waters of the Gulf of Mexico today. Greene said an oil sheen stretching 12 miles from the Mega Borg had begun forming into tar balls. He said he expected the balls to wash ashore, but could not determine where they might land or how soon. Salvage boats and Coast Guard ships were skimming the water and using floating barriers to try to corral the slick. The Norwegian ship was loaded with 38 million gallons of light crude oil when it was rocked by a series of engine-room explosions early Saturday. Official said they were not sure if flame-smothering foam would be used as planned. On Tuesday, firefighters spraying water on the searing deck boarded the ship and declared the fire controlled nearly four days after the first of a series of explosions ripped through the vessel 57 miles southeast of Galveston. ``They're smothering the fire,'' Petty Officer Gene Maestas said today. ``There are occasional flareups on board and there is some steam coming from the water being pour on it. But they are not using the foam yet and I'm not sure they will.'' The blasts on Saturday and fire left the ship with one deck awash, and crews had feared it would break up or sink with its cargo. In gaining the upper hand on the blaze, firefighters solved one problem but may have created another. ``What appears to be happening, that since they are getting the fire under control, is it's not burning up as much oil and more oil is getting in the water,'' said Coast Guard Lt. j.g. Robert Garrott. The Norwegian government opened a hearing today in Galveston to interview crew members who were aboard when the tanker exploded while transferring cargo to a smaller vessel. Two of the 41 crewmen died, two were missing and presumed dead and 17 were injured, none seriously. ``This will be purely fact finding,'' Norwegian Consul General Erik Leikvang said. The cause of the explosion is unknown. Five fireboats and a hose placed on the deck by firefighters continued dousing the burning stern. Aircraft dropped about 9,000 gallons of oil dispersant. Pemex, the Mexican government oil monopoly, said that at the U.S. government's request, it sent the 146-foot vessel that sucks up oil and water at the rate of 84,000 gallons an hour, separates out the oil and stores it. Thick gray smoke and steam surrounded the hulk, replacing the balls of flame and towering columns of black smoke that had risen from the vessel. Ted Hoskins, who heads the salvage operation, boarded the ship with a crew Tuesday and declared the fire under control, Greene said. ``Our latest videos we got, I can see no fire visible,'' Greene said Tuesday. He said there were still flames beneath the deck. An 825-foot British-registered tanker stood by to begin receiving the remainder of the Mega Borg's cargo. Greene said that operation could be dangerous because the ship is listing and crews might have to pump water into the holds to keep the vessel balanced. The ship's rear has dropped more than 60 feet and remained awash today. ``We're feeling fairly confident at this point, but we're not going to really breathe easy until the oil is back in a terminal,'' Petty Officer Todd Nelson said. The Mega Borg carried more than three times as much oil as was spilled by the Exxon Valdez off Alaska in March 1989 in the nation's worst oil spill. Coast Guard officials said the light crude would disperse more easily than the Exxon Valdez's heavy crude, but environmentalists said they still fear the oil will reach bays and estuaries where it will be toxic to birds and shellfish. Currents and winds were expected to push escaping oil toward a 200-mile stretch of coast between Freeport and Corpus Christi. But the Coast Guard said the currents also were expected to keep the spill from coming ashore. The tanker, operated by Mosvolds Shipping of Farsund, Norway, was bound from Palanca, Angola. It was scheduled to travel to Aruba after Galveston. Elf Trading Inc., a Houston subsidiary of a French oil and gas company, owned the cargo and said it would participate in the cleanup.

DOC.HEAD: German Businessman Admits Helping Build Alleged Chemical Weapons Plant
DOC.TEXT: A West German businessman accused of helping build an alleged chemical weapons plant in Libya testified Wednesday that he was involved but didn't know the factory would make arms. Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, ex-director of the Imhausen-Chemie company, said he had suspicions the project ``would be in conflict with West Germany's export laws'' but did not investigate because he ``didn't want to lose the business.'' West German prosecutors, government and security officials have said they have proof the plant in the Libyan desert was made to produce poison gas. Libya denies it. Hippenstiel, 49, whose trial began Monday in Mannheim District Court, is charged with violating West Germany's export laws and evading taxes in connection with the $136 million project. Reading from a prepared statement, Hippenstiel said the project in Rabta, Libya, south of Tripoli, got its start in 1984 when a ``middleman'' contacted him about building a chemical plant to make ``pharmaceuticals and insecticides.'' Hippenstiel said that as head of Imhausen-Chemie, located in Lahr in southern West Germany near Mannheim, he ``participated in construction of the Rabta factory'' by delivering production plans and equipment for the project. The former company manager said he was sorry he had caused what he called ``diplomatic problems'' for West Germany because of the deal with Libya. ``The responsibility and overall management (of the project) was in my hands,'' Hippenstiel said. West Germany's national television said Hippenstiel's statement appeared to confirm that he was aware poison gas could be produced at the Rabta plant. However, Hippenstiel did not admit that in his statement. The trim, bespectacled Hippenstiel faces tax evasion charges in connection with payments for helping build the plant. Hippenstiel admitted not paying taxes on $11.7 million on profits from his transactions. He said however, that he did not keep the money for himself, but used it to ensure the project in Rabta would be completed. The Libyan plant scandal first came to light in December 1988, when the United States government charged that West German companies were providing massive assistance for construction of a chemical factory capable of producing poison gas. West German government officials at first denied any of the country's companies were involved but later acknowledged the allegations were true. Hippenstiel headed the company that allegedly was the key supplier of equipment, construction plans and technical expertise to develop the project. A 100-page indictment alleges that Hippenstiel played a leading role in the project from 1984 to 1988, when he headed the chemical company. In opening arguments, prosecutor Hans-Heiko Klein said Hippenstiel had delivered plans and documents, as well as providing material valued at $12 million. The primary allegations against the defendant revolved around violations of West German export laws, designed to hinder any participation in such illegal projects abroad. Hippenstiel has been held in prison for the last 14 months awaiting the start of his trial. More than 60 witnesses are expected to be heard at the trial, which is not expected to be completed until sometime in September.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Win in Arkansas, South Carolina; Atlantic City Mayor Ousted
With AM-Primaries-Glance
DOC.TEXT: A black businessman who gained the GOP nomination for lieutenant governor during a runoff against a Ku Klux Klan sympathizer said his victory shows how far the South has come since 1957. Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris on Tuesday drubbed Ralph Forbes, a former American Nazi who wound down his campaign with an appearance at a KKK rally Saturday. Another black candidate, South Carolina state Sen. Theo Mitchell, soundly defeated state Sen. Ernest Passailaigue in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. Mitchell would be that state's first black governor, if he defeated popular Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell. In one other election Tuesday with racial overtones, the first black mayor of Atlantic City, N.J., James L. Usry, was ousted by a white challenger in a runoff. Usry was recently indicted on corruption charges. Voters also elected the first black mayor of Trenton, N.J., chose congressional candidates in Maine and rejected a sales tax increase in North Dakota. After his triumph in Arkansas, Harris said: ``Everybody wants to live in '57, but '57's dead. This is the 1990s.'' Federal troops were sent to Little Rock in 1957 to ensure the safety of nine black students who were admitted to Central High School under a federal court order. Harris, nonetheless, is an underdog in his effort to become the first black elected to such an office in Arkansas. His opponent in the Nov. 6 general election is Democrat Jim Guy Tucker, a former congressman and attorney general. ``I'm glad that the election came out the way it did,'' Tucker said. ``We need to send a message that the vote for Mr. Forbes wasn't representative of the people of Arkansas, and that's good.'' Two weeks ago, Forbes got 46 percent of the 71,000 votes in a three-way race. Harris got 36 percent to force a runoff and Robert Breaux of Little Rock got 18 percent. The final breakdown Tuesday was Harris 27,548; Forbes 4,432. Harris gained 1,876 votes in 14 days; Forbes lost 28,753. About 38,000 fewer voters turned out for the runoff than for the May 29 primary. ``We have finally rejected the old tactics of the KKK and the neo-Nazis and white supremacists' effort to deceive the public,'' said Harris, who became the state's second black in the 20th century to be nominated for a constitutional office. The 36-year-old former University of Arkansas defensive back is a property-management executive with JM Products Inc., a Little Rock company that manufactures hair-care products for blacks. ``I believe Arkansas' future is secure by the wisdom of her public, God-fearing people who understand that our destiny should not be dictated by hatred, power politics or one-party domination, but by the competent ideas of leadership,'' said Harris. Even Forbes said Wednesday that his loss had a lot to do with the fear of some voters that Arkansas' image would be tainted if a Ku Klux Klan sympathizer won a statewide race. ``I think that's part of it,'' he said. ``People fell for that Arkansas image stuff. We as a state have a real problem with self-image. I was hoping to counter that on the issues.'' Forbes refused to concede, and threatened to challenge the election. ``I'll never concede,' he said. ``I feel like a winner.''

DOC.HEAD: White House Says Bush Will Attend Dedication of Nixon Library
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will join former Presidents Reagan, Ford and Nixon in Yorba Linda, Calif., on July 19 for the dedication and formal opening of the Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace, the White House announced today.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Primary Voting
With AM-Primaries Rdp
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are highlights of primary voting Tuesday in five states:
ARKANSAS= Lieutenant Governor: Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris, a black executive, defeated Ralph Forbes, a Ku Klux Klan sympathizer and former member of the American Nazi Party, in a runoff for the Republican nomination. Harris will face former Rep. Jim Guy Tucker, the Democratic nominee, in November.
MAINE= Congress: Both parties held primaries to fill the House seat being vacated by Rep. Joseph E. Brennan, who is running for governor. State Sen. Thomas Andrews upset Attorney General James E. Tierney in a five-way Democratic race. Former U.S. Rep. David Emery defeated state Rep. John McCormick in the GOP race.
NEW JERSEY= Atlantic City Mayor: Incumbent James L. Usry, under indictment on charges of corruption, lost a runoff to City Councilman Jim Whelan. Trenton Mayor: County Freeholder Douglas Palmer scored a close victory over Mayor Carmen Armenti to become Trenton's first black mayor. Armenti demanded a recount.
NORTH DAKOTA= Ballot measure: Voters defeated a proposal to raise sales taxes from 5 percent to 6 percent for one year to improve education. At least one of two counties west of Bismarck rejected a non-binding measure to switch from Mountain to Central time. Labor Commissioner: Incumbent Byron Knutson, accused of sloppy management, lost to S.F. ``Buckshot'' Hoffner, head of the state Centennial Commission, and Craig Hagen, a political newcomer. Hoffner and Hagen will face each other in November.
SOUTH CAROLINA= Governor: State Sen Theo Mitchell defeated state Sen. Ernest Passailaigue in a Democratic primary, winning the right to challenge Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell. Mitchell hopes to become the state's first black governor.

DOC.HEAD: Militant Black Group Says ANC Is `Selling Out'
DOC.TEXT: A black militant leader on Wednesday called African National Congress talks with the white-led South African government premature and a ``sellout.'' Bennie Alexander, general-secretary of the Pan Africanist Congress, said the government must agree to a one-person, one-vote democracy before meaningful discussions can take place. ``If the government says it is against the principle (of majority rule), then there is no basis for talks,'' Alexander told a group of foreign journalists. ``We do not see a democractic solution in the very near future.'' President F.W. de Klerk's government held preliminary talks last month with the ANC in a bid to resolve obstacles to full-scale negotiations on a new constitution and ending apartheid. The ANC is country's leading black opposition group. ``There is a perception among the masses that to talk to the government now is selling out,'' Alexander said. ``The radical youth consider it a sellout.'' Asked if he agreed, Alexander said: ``Yes.'' De Klerk says he wants the 5 million whites and 28 million blacks to share power. He opposes outright black majority rule, saying it will replace white domination with black domination. He envisions a mechanism that will give whites veto power on major policy decisions. The government has said it is ready to negotiate a new constitution with the ANC and other black opposition groups. However, the ANC has set preconditions for formal negotiations that include the release of some 3,000 activists convicted of politically motivated crimes and the return of an estimated 20,000 exiles. The Pan Africanist Congress broke away from the much larger ANC in 1959 and is considered more militant and ideological, although the policies of the two groups are similar. Both favor a one-person, one-vote political system, socialist-oriented economic policies and both wage largely ineffective guerrilla campaigns. The Pan Africanists draw much of their support from black intellectuals and radical youths. Their supporters often chant, ``One settler, one bullet'' _ a reference to whites whom the organization considers colonialists. Youthful supporters of the two groups have battled each other in several townships recently. The organizations reached a peace agreement Tuesday in the Vosloorus township east of Johannesburg.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Ships to Visit San Diego
DOC.TEXT: Two guided missile destroyers and an oiler from the Soviet Navy's Pacific fleet will visit San Diego as part of the ongoing exchange between the U.S. and Soviet military, the Pentagon said Wednesday. About 800 members of the Soviet Navy will be aboard the three ships, which will begin their five-day visit at the San Diego Naval Station on July 31, the Pentagon said in a statement. Adm. Charles R. Larson, commander of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, will be host to his Soviet counterpart, Adm. Gennadij Alexandrovich Khvatov, commander of the Soviet Pacific Ocean Fleet. The Soviet ships designated to participate are the guided missile cruisers Adm. Vinogradov and Boyevoy, and the oiler Argun. Larson and three U.S. Navy ships will visit the Pacific port of Vladivostok in September, the Pentagon said. Last summer, three Soviet Navy ships visited Norfolk, Va., and U.S. Navy ships visited the Black Sea port of Sevastopol in the first round of the naval exchanges.

DOC.HEAD: Press Freedom Guaranteed, But Limited without Paper
DOC.TEXT: Press freedom has been enshrined for the first time in Soviet law, but doubts remain about whether the long debate was worth it and whether it means much in a country that cannot produce enough newsprint to ensure it. The Supreme Soviet legislature on Tuesday approved a law that places in the legal code a key element of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's glasnost policy: the media's freedom from any kind of censorship. ``The press and other mass media are free,'' the law says. ``Censorship of the mass media is forbidden.'' Strict control of the media was a hallmark of Soviet rule for decades. A journalists' role was first to be an agitator for Communist Party policies and second to be a source of information. The limited reports of the state- or party-run media defined what millions of people knew about their country and the outside world. Despite wide approval in the legislature, the bill took months to be approved. One prominent veteran of the dissident movement questioned publicly whether it even was necessary in an era of reform. ``I'm afraid that my writing brothers will beat me with stones, but is a law on the press necesary?'' asked Elena Bonner in a recent edition of the weekly Moscow News. Mrs. Bonner, widow of human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov, said press freedom could be guaranteed through changes that will be made in the Soviet Constitution. In that case, disputes can be settled by Soviet courts in much the same way they are settled in the United States, which guarantees freedom of press in its constitution. The law guarantees the right for Soviets to start their own publications. But as Soviets are finding in other cases, the country's poor economic condition places practical restrictions on their new legal rights. Production of paper and printing plants still are part of the state-run economy. The economy cannot produce enough newsprint. In the past couple of years, subscriptions to many national newspapers and magazines have been restricted because of a lack of newsprint. Scores of unofficial papers have sprung up, reflecting the country's new thirst for poltics and debate. Their publishers must scramble to reach agreements with state-run printing houses to supply the paper they need. Rabochaya Tribuna, one dail newspaper, said Wednesday that shortages of newsprint ``place in question the single unarguable success of perestroika _ glasnost.'' Perestroika is Russian for restructuring and glasnost means openness. The newspaper visited a factory near Gorky, about 200 miles east of Moscow where Sakharov was exiled for almost seven years, that produces about a third of the country's newsprint. It said the factory was built more than 60 years ago with foreign help, and that foreign help is once again needed to modernize it. But it accused the Soviet bureaucracy of preventing the factory from keeping enough of the hard currency it earns to buy spare parts or new equipment. ``Wouldn't it be just to allow us to keep half of the hard currency we earn, rather than 2 percent, as is now done?'' asked the factory director, V. Lapukhin.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Army Won't Make Deadline For Disposing Chemical Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tooele, Utah, in 16th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: The Army expects to miss an April 1997 deadline for destroying chemical weapons even though the Bush administration says disposal of the arms will begin ahead of schedule, a report released Wednesday says. The General Accounting Office said in the report that the Army's disposal program has encountered several obstacles, including environmental limitations, community opposition and a shortfall in funds. The investigative arm of Congress found also that the projected cost of destroying the weapons has doubled from a preliminary estimate of $1.7 billion to $3.4 billion and will likely exceed the latest figure. ``Since current construction, equipment and personnel requirements have continued to rise, total program costs will increase even more,'' the GAO report said. The agency attributed the cost increases to incomplete information the Army used in its preliminary estimate and program changes to ensure safety. The Army said Wednesday it had not reviewed the report and had no immediate comment. The report came less than two weeks after a U.S.-Soviet agreement to reduce superpower chemical weapons stockpiles and the administration's announcement that it would begin destroying the weapons by the end of this year. Administration officials said the target date for the program is well ahead of the schedule set in the accord signed by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev during their U.S. summit, which ended June 3. That pact requires each side to reduce its stockpile to 5,000 tons by 2002, although the Soviets have no active facility for destroying their weapons. The U.S. and Soviet Union hold the world's largest supplies of the weapons, which can blister the skin or disturb the nervous system. The United States says it has about 25,000 tons of chemical agents; the Soviets claim to have 50,000 tons. Destruction of the arms is supposed to begin by Dec. 31, 1992. The administration said destruction of the weapons, now stored in West Germany, would begin at the Johnston Atoll plant on a remote Pacific Ocean island by the end of the year. The plant was built to meet a 1985 congressional requirement to destroy all existing U.S. chemical weapons by 1997 as a condition for approving a Pentagon program to produce a new generation of such arms. However, the GAO said that due to a ``nine-month delay in the start of operational verification testing at Johnston Atoll, the Army believes that the overall program has slipped and that therefore the complete disposal of the chemical weapons stockpile by April 1997 is improbable.'' In addition, the Army announced in 1988 that it planned to build similar disposal facilities at each of the eight chemical munitions storage sites in the continental United States. The sites are Tooele, Utah; Anniston, Ala.; Pine Bluff, Ark.; Umatilla, Ore.; Pueblo, Colo.; Newport, Ind.; Lexington-Blue Grass, Ky.; and Aberdeen, Md. The GAO said community opposition and environmental requirements could delay the construction of the additional sites. In addition, purchasing of equipment for the Utah plant was delayed by a $37 million shortfall in funds for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, 1989. The GAO said also that the Army faces community opposition in Indiana, Kentucky and Maryland that will put the Army's disposal schedule in jeopardy.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Police Shoot at Demonstrators in Bucharest; Two Reported Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with police shooting demonstrators, unconfirmed report of two people killed. Pickup 9th pvs, `The government...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XBUC1,5,7
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers shot at anti-government demonstrators in central Bucharest tonight after the protesters occupied state-run television and stormed and burned police headquarters, witnesses said. One witness reported seeing at least two bodies after the shooting, but this could not be immediately confirmed. The most serious violence in the Romanian capital since December's revolution that toppled the Ceausescu regime was caused by a pre-dawn police raid that ended a 53-day anti-Communist protest in University Square. Demonstrators clashed with police during the afternoon in the square, then fanned out to police headquarters, secret police headquarters, the TV station and Victory Square, headquarters of the governing National Salvation Front. The shooting occurred outside the secret police headquarters, where the late dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's hated Securitate force operated. Before the buildings were attacked, President-elect Ion Iliescu issued a communique calling on all ``aware and responsible people'' to surround government buildings and state TV to ward off ``extremist groups'' and to save Romania's democracy ``earned with so much difficulty.'' Scottish free-lance photographer Jeremy Sutton-Hibbert said he saw soldiers shooting from inside the Securitate building in downtown Bucharest. He said he saw the body of a man in his 40s who had been shot in the head. He said other photographers had seen at least one more body near the building, which was ringed by half a dozen armored personnel carriers. State-run television, scene of fierce fighting during December's revolution, was stormed by the protesters who occupied one of the main studios. An announcer said they might not be able to transmit any longer. Minutes later, the picture was cut and shortly afterward the sound was also cut. Demonstrators carrying gasoline cans got into headquarters of the regular police this evening and set fire to cars and trucks nearby. About 1,500 people stood outside, watching the right wing of the building burn. Some civilians working in the headquarters leaned out the windows, looking panicked and coughing. Every few minutes, there were minor explosions, apparently from gasoline in the vehicles set ablaze. People who thronged the streets booed as helicopters flew overhead surveying the situation. The demonstrators say Communists still dominate the National Salvation Front, which has been in power since the December revolution and which won last month's free elections by a landslide. The government said more than 260 people were detained when steel-helmeted police moved in before dawn to break up the sit-in in University Square that had blocked the capital's main thoroughfare for 53 days. Witnesses said the police clubbed several protesters. Casualty figures were not immediately available, but officials said one policeman was injured in the clash with an estimated 1,000 people supporting the demonstrators. About 20 hunger strikers were among those camped in a small tent city in University Square. Police took the fasting demonstrators, some of whom had gone without food for a month, to the hospital. The protesters supporting the hunger strikers freed two people detained in a police van then overturned the vehicle and set it on fire, witnesses said. Several buses and trucks were also reported on fire. The attack on the police headquarters occurred several hours later. A government communique issued soon after the square was cleared said 263 people were detained for investigation. It accused protesters of attempting to resist the police with violence and said some arms were confiscated. Brindusa Muresan, who had been on a hunger striker since May 9, said some of her colleagues were clubbed by police in the lobby of the nearby Intercontinental Hotel. She said they were taken to a police station, fingerprinted and photographed and sent to the hospital for tests. Protesters, their ranks sometimes swelling to as many as 10,000 by day, had blocked traffic in the central square since April 22, dubbing the area a ``Communist-free zone.'' The protesters have pressed for a 10-year ban on former Communists officials _ such as Iliescu _ holding office. The demonstrators also demanded independent and private broadcast media. Government officials who met with the hunger strikers for the first time on Monday pledged their support for establishing such stations.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Guerrillas Battle Government Troops, Ignore Cease-Fire
DOC.TEXT: Tamil guerrillas battled government troops in northern and eastern Sri Lanka on Wednesday, ignoring a cease-fire, residents and military officials said Wednesday. Unconfirmed reports reaching Colombo said the Tamil Tiger rebels massacred at least 125 policemen who were among 600 officers captured when the Tigers overran 11 police stations Monday. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said the report ``seems to be authentic, but we have to double-check.'' He characterized the situation as ``war.'' In addition to the reported massacre of policemen, as many as 90 government soldiers, Tamil Tigers and civilians may have been killed since Monday, according to reports compiled by residents, military sources and the Tigers. Officially, the government has confirmed only the deaths of 16 soldiers. The violence is the most serious since Indian peacekeeping troops left Sri Lanka in March after an unsuccessful, 32-month-long effort to disarm the Tamil Tigers. It also raised the specter of a return to the all-out war between the Tigers and government forces that prevailed before the Indians' arrival on July 30, 1987. Wijeratne said reports of the police massacre came from one policeman who survived and escaped. He quoted the policeman as saying the Tigers killed 150 of his colleagues. Military officials in Colombo said the death toll could be between 125 and 150. One of the officials quoted the policeman who escaped as saying the Tigers on Tuesday told him and his colleagues they were going to be released. They then were taken by trucks into the jungle where they were forced to lie on the ground, sprayed with machine gun fire and shot in the head, the official said. The policeman who escaped suffered a bullet graze on his head and apparently was left for dead, the official said on condition of anonymity. The accounts could not be independently verified because telephone communications broke down Wednesday between Colombo and the eastern Batticaloa region as the fighting spread to the northern Vavuniya and Mannar regions. A cease-fire announced late Tuesday by the government and the Tigers was to take effect at noon Wednesday. But military officials in Colombo, speaking on condition of anonymity, said fighting continued past the deadline. The officials also said about 3,000 soldiers were rushed to the east coast on Wednesday to reinforce the 1,200 soldiers sent on Tuesday. Residents in Vavuniya, 135 miles northeast of Colombo, said the Tigers were still attacking police stations and army camps, and government troops were returning fire. The residents spoke on condition of anonymity. The government and the Tigers opened negotiations in May 1989 in an effort to end the 7-year-old Tamil revolt against the Sinhalese-dominated government. The latest fighting began Monday when the Tigers took control of police stations in the Batticaloa and Ampara districts along the east coast, 135 miles across the island from Colombo. On Tuesday, the Tigers spread their siege to four army camps in the east. At the same time, the government's chief negotiator, Justice Minister Shahul Hameed, was in the northern town of Jaffna for negotiations with top Tiger political leaders. Tamils comprise 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Tamil rebels demand an independent nation, claiming their community is discriminated against by the Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of the population and control the government and the military. At least 11,000 people, including 1,100 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the Tamil insurgency.

DOC.HEAD: Satellite Owners Agree to NASA Rescue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Endeavour is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The owners of a communications satellite that fell into a useless orbit said Wednesday they will pay NASA to send up astronauts to repair the $157 million spacecraft. NASA tentatively set the rescue mission for the 1992 inaugural flight of the space shuttle Endeavour. The rescue of the unisured satellite is expected to cost Intelsat more than half of the $146.5 million price for a non-government shuttle mission. ``NASA has the technological know-how to reboost the satellite, and we want to take advantage of NASA's expertise so we can boost the satellite and it will have a 10-year lifespan,'' said company spokesman Tony Trujillo. Intelsat's board of governors authorized the rescue attempt during a weeklong meeting in Barbados that ended Wednesday. The satellite is orbiting at about 345 miles above Earth, 22,000 miles lower than intended. It was even lower when it failed to separate properly from a Titan 3 rocket on March 14, but Intelsat ground controllers managed to boost it.
