The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said last month it would try to save the satellite if Intelsat paid for the mission. Last week, the federal Office of Management and Budget approved NASA's proposed $130 million pricetag _ in 1988 dollars _ for non-government shuttle flights. That amounts to $146.5 million for fiscal 1990. Intelsat will cover a ``sizable fraction'' of the expense since other cargos will be on board, said NASA payload manager William D. Green. The plan calls for Endeavour to carry a 20,000-pound motor that will be attached to the satellite in the payload bay by space-walking astronauts. The motor will contain a safety device to prevent it from firing until the shuttle is at a safe distance. Intelsat ground controllers will send a command that will ignite the motor and boost the 5-ton satellite to its proper stationary orbit. The February 1992 date would not disrupt other shuttle flights, Green said. ``Generally speaking, the reason we're doing it is we're in the business of providing space services when people ask for it,'' he said. NASA has twice repaired satellites in space _ in 1984 and 1985 _ and brought back two other disabled spacecraft. ``For this to be practical, a satellite that's in trouble has to be within the reach of the shuttle, in the altitude region,'' Green said. Discovery's flight in April with the Hubble Space Telescope set a record altitude _ 380 miles _ for a shuttle. A shuttle probably could reach 400 or so miles without any cargo, Green said. Intelsat, a Washington, D.C.-based consortium of 119 countries that operates a global communications satellite system, was not interested in having the satellite returned to Earth for repair because of the expense and delay in getting it back up. The Intelsat VI satellite was to have replaced two older Intelsat satellites over the Atlantic. Once in proper orbit, it will be capable of transmitting three TV channels and up to 120,000 telephone calls simultaneously. Intelsat's service will not be disrupted by the three-year delay, Trujillo said. Fourteen Intelsat satellites currently are in orbit, and a Titan 3 is scheduled to carry up another one later this month. Martin Marietta Corp., which makes the Titan rockets, said the engineering design error that led to the failed launch in March has been corrected.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Bill to Restrict Logging in Tongass National Forest
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted unanimously today to restrict logging in Alaska's huge Tongass National Forest. The bill would set aside 673,000 acres as permanently protected wilderness areas, modify two long-term harvesting contracts to pressentially the same as those on which Mrs. Helmsley, 70, was convicted in federal court last year. Mrs. Helmsley is appealing the federal conviction and sentence of four years in prison and $7.1 million fine. A state indictment charges Mrs. Helmsley and her billionaire real estate developer husband Harry with tax and business fraud. Most counts alleged they renovated, furnished and operated Dunellen Hall, their estate in Greenwich, Conn., while charging those personal expenses to their businesses. Harry Helmsley was found unfit to stand trial in the federal case. State charges against him remain since the double jeopardy rule does not apply. One of Mrs. Helmsley's lawyers, Sandor Frankel, asked Bradley to order Mendez to give the defense a ``bill of particulars,'' which specifies exactly what she is accused of doing, for the remaining eight counts. ``What is the crime?'' Alan Dershowitz, another Helmsley lawyer, asked outside court. ``What did she do wrong? They keep telling us, `You'll find out at the trial.''' Mrs. Helmsley, in a white Chanel knit suit and white patent leather pumps, again protested her innocence. ``We paid our taxes,'' she said. ``It isn't fair. It's an outrage. It's a shame. It's a disgrace.'' Bradley said he will rule on June 20 on the various applications, including a defense petition to dismiss four of the eight remaining counts. He said he also will decide, after receiving physicians' reports and the lawyers' papers, whether he will hold a hearing on Harry Helmsley's mental and physical fitness to stand trial.

DOC.HEAD: Genscher, Shevardnadze to Meet Again On NATO Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and his Soviet counterpart, Eduard Shevardnadze, plan to meet in West Germany next week to try to resolve a dispute over a united Germany's military status. The two will meet on Monday in the northern city of Muenster, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement. Genscher and Shevardnadze held talks on the issue in the Soviet city of Brest on Monday. The Soviets reject NATO's insistence that a united Germany belong to the Western alliance. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has suggested as a compromise solution that a merged Germany have ``associate'' memberships in NATO and the Warsaw Pact, but that has been rejected by both Washington and Bonn. In Muenster, in addition to the NATO dispute, the two men will discuss the ``long-term perspectives of German-Soviet relations,'' the Foreign Ministry statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Elusive Rooster Nabbed in Dark of Night
DOC.TEXT: After a year on the loose, a rooster that evaded traps and tranquilizer darts was finally captured by three pursuers working under the cover of darkness and armed with a flashlight and a fishing net. Henry the rooster's owners moved away a year ago. During the past few weeks, animal control officials intensified their efforts with traps and the tranquilizer guns because Henry's droppings were suspected of infecting a child at The Playhouse day care center. Monday night, day-care center director Geri Moton, and her son-in-law, Kevin Pike, took matters into their own hands. Joining them was Russell Burkett, grandfather of a child who was recently enrolled at the center. ``This was their first day at The Playhouse and Mr. Burkett said, `Honey, I'll help you get that rooster but we'll have to do it at night,''' Moton said. They found Henry in a tree. Taking advantage of roosters' poor night vision, Pike climbed up and knocked Henry to the ground. The pesky bird made a dash for freedom, but Moton nabbed him with a fishing net. ``He's gone and this morning I sang the Hallelujah chorus,'' Moton said Tuesday. Burkett is keeping the rooster as a companion for his grandson, Raymond Shollanbarger. ``I didn't want him shot,'' Moton said. ``I'm just glad the rooster found him a good home.'' She said Henry's owners moved last year and left him behind. Gaston health officials wanted the bird removed because stray animals are a violation of day-care health standards. The health department became involved two weeks ago when a pediatrician reported a case of campylobacter infection, a bacterial disease that causes flu-like symptoms. Animal feces is one source of the infection and officials said the illness might have come from the rooster.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Wins UNESCO Prize
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel of Czecholovakia on Wednesday won the 1990 Simon Bolivar Prize from UNESCO for his long struggle to lead his country to freedom, the organization said. The prize, awarded every two years by the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, recognizes those who contribute to the liberty, independence and dignity of a people. Havel fought for democracy at the price of his own liberty, the jury ruled. The dissident playwright jailed by the Communist government before his release and rise to lead a new non-Communist government last year. The prize carries an award of $25,000. It is named after the South American patriot who liberated much of the continent from Spanish rule in the early 19th century.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Circus Stars Say Show Must Go On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `The 55 ...' to CORRECT that lion cub was not yet born; Also moved for PMs
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX1
DOC.TEXT: They've been kicked out of motels, forced to live on charity and lost their animals. But members of the Great Circus Bim Bom, who say a U.S. business sabotaged their tour, still want to perform for the Americans who have opened their homes, hearts and checkbooks to the stranded Soviet performers. ``We want to perform for you, but we cannot get our equipment, our animals,'' said Emil Kio, a magician known for his acts with fire. ``That is a pity.'' The 115-member circus, named for two famous turn-of-the-century Russian clowns, came to the United States for a two-year tour in March. The group signed a contract with International Showbusiness Inc., a newly formed company in Clearwater, Fla., with financing from Kuwaiti investors. It brought the troupe to the United States and scheduled performances. The venture starting losing money because of poor publicity, circus director Yuri Turkin said. The circus came to Atlanta, where its trucking company is based, to regroup and assess its plight, only to be kicked out of a series of motels for not paying bills. Finally, the tour was canceled May 9 after only 12 performances. ``Lies, lies, lies, that's all they told us,'' a bitter Leonid Gordon, technical director for Kio's magic act, said of International Showbusiness. ``We waited two months for them to do something. They didn't tell us anything until we were in trouble. Now we have nothing.'' Thirty performers stuck with ISI and got lodging at a West Virginia ski resort but no work. Turkin severed ties with ISI and is frantically trying to arrange performances in Kentucky before Friday morning, when the troupe must leave its latest home, Atlanta's Oglethorpe University. To perform, the circus must pay to free its equipment and animals. Night Moves Transfer of Atlanta is owed about $165,000, and vice president Winfield Ward said he must have a large percentage of the money before he will release the equipment. ``I'm not a bank, I'm a trucking company,'' he said. The 54 animals _ including a pregnant lion whose cub that Kio said the circus wants to donate to Atlanta's zoo when it is born _ are being held by the Alex Nichols Agency in Newburgh, N.Y. Federal officials, meanwhile, are threatening to seize the animals because wildlife declaration documents weren't filed when they entered the country. ``We know our Soviet laws but we don't know all you Americans require,'' Kio said, blaming ISI for not providing documentation. ``This is not our debt. This is International Showbusiness debt. Because they won't pay, we are here.'' ISI attorney Robert Bauer Jr. did not return calls seeking comment. The company's president, Nikolaj Vissokovsky, has in the past blamed a Kuwaiti father and son for withdrawing financial support. But Brooks Savage, a lawyer for Waleed A.A. Ahmad and his father, Khoorsheed Ahmad, said the investors gave the circus a loan and never intended to back the whole tour. The performers have been biding their time at Oglethorpe University, which offered free housing during a student break. Most are frustrated that they can't practice. Vechislav Anokhin, who juggles large steel balls, misses working with his own equipment. ``I must stay strong for my work. Every day I go to the gymnasium, but it is not the same,'' he said. They try not to appear ungrateful to Atlantans who buy them food and spend time with them, despite the language barrier. Some, like trainer Kalachov Yevgeni, are making good friends. ``He's teaching me Russian and I'm teaching him English,'' said 7-year-old Ryan Haroldson as the two practiced boxing. ``He's my `droog,' friend.'' ``Ryan tells us what's happening,'' Yevgeni said in Russian. But the Soviets are tired of waiting. They want to send in the clowns. ``We wait and hope, wait and hope,'' said musician Mikhail Kolotovkhine. ``There's nothing else.''

DOC.HEAD: Michigan State University Tears Down Shanties; Five Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Michigan State University tore down several plywood shanties that were erected on campus to promote various causes, and campus police arrested five students who protested the move. Administrators had let the students keep the shanties up for several months, university spokesman Terry Denbow said. He said students violated an agreement that they not sleep inside the shanties. ``We do have an ordinance to enforce. We have gone along with these groups who have violated a university ordinance all spring,'' he said. Denbow said eight different groups _ which had erected the shanties to raise awareness on issues including racism and homelessness _ had agreed to remove them on Monday. Three complied, but five didn't, so the university took action Tuesday, sending in 15 campus police officers. They ordered out eight students in makeshift beds and dismantled the structures. ``It was an act of cowardice for the university to take down the shanties after all the students have left and before the press was awake,'' said Albin Rose, one of the eight forced out. Kenneth Overton, 21, was arrested after climbing atop an A-frame shanty to prevent groundskeepers from toppling it. He later was released. He was arrested again later in the day along with four others for allegedly violating the school's camping regulations _ a misdemeanor. All five pleaded innocent and posted bond.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Georgette Mosbacher, socialite wife of the U.S. secretary of commerce and head of a cosmetics company she owns, was robbed of $30,000 in jewelry and cash outside her hotel room by a man with a submachine gun. Mrs. Mosbacher said she gave the robber her jewelry and handbag, then escaped when an elevator opened and she jumped in. ``I was screaming and yelling and leaning on the buzzer,'' Mrs. Mosbacher said after the Tuesday robbery. ``When I got to the lobby, I ran to the desk. I was hoping they could lock off the stairs and catch him.'' The robber fled. No arrests have been made, police said Wednesday. Mrs. Mosbacher said the well-dressed robber covered her with the small submachine gun and told her to open her door. She said she told him the key wouldn't work, but he got it open. ``I told him `I'm not going there. I'm not going to shout.' ``I took off my earrings and said, `There's a bench over there and I'm going to sit.' I said to myself, `I'm not going to live,' but I thought I'd have a better chance in the hallway,'' she recalled. The gunman's hands were occupied with jewelry and Mrs. Mosbacher's bag when the elevator door opened and Mrs. Mosbacher took her chance to get away. The robber got her wedding band, two other rings, a watch, $400 in cash and the earrings, she said. She said the valuables were worth $30,000. Mrs. Mosbacher was staying at the hotel while the couple's apartment is being renovated.

Ted Turner apologized on his own Cable News Network for calling Christianity ``a religion for losers.'' Turner, appearing on CNN's ``Crossfire'' program Tuesday night, said he was speaking off the top of his head when he made the comment. ``I want to officially apologize to all the Christians for saying that,'' Turner said. ``That was a very uncalled-for statement. At one time or another, I've offended just about everybody. I was making a talk off the cuff when that just popped out, and I feel very sorry for it.'' Turner met earlier in the day with Chinese student leader Shen Tong, 21, who was offended by something Turner said last month. Shen said he was unable to persuade Turner to lend support to his country's democracy movement. ``He don't want to be involved. He don't want to contribute,'' Shen said. Shen sought the meeting after Turner said the Chinese government ``felt forced'' to quell democracy protests with military strength that left hundreds of demonstrators dead. Turner's remark about Christianity was first made last year and repeated last month at a convention of the American Humanist Association, where he was named Humanist of the Year. Despite his apology, Turner said Tuesday night he has problems with organized religion because of what he perceives as its inflexibility. ``The thing I don't like about all organized religion is, I've never seen one yet that didn't think they were right and it was the one true way,'' he said.

Itinerant Grateful Dead fans are going to have trouble finding spots to rest their heads around the time of the group's July 8 concert at Three Rivers Stadium. The city won't let them sleep in the arena's parking lot and a northern suburb adopted a resolution banning all camping for the first two weeks of July. The resolution adopted Monday by the Reserve Township Board of Commissioners bans all camping out, including sleeping in tents or any vehicle, in the township from July 1 to July 15. ``We don't want any problems,'' said Andrew Perlik, board chairman. ``The city has cracked down on their fans, which has forced them to the suburbs.'' At least 25 people were arrested when about 500 of the band's fans clashed with Pittsburgh police outside the stadium in April 1989.

The 1970s pop duo Seals and Crofts is putting together a record as a follow-up to their first concert tour in 10 years. The two, whose hits included ``Summer Breeze'' and ``Diamond Girl,'' did a concert tour in Canada last summer. ``It was such a success that everyone convinced them to work on another album,'' country music star Dan Seals, brother of Jim Seals of Seals and Crofts, said Tuesday. Dan Seals said the duo has eight songs finished for the album even though the two are not currently signed to a record label. Dash Crofts has lived in a Nashville suburb for the past few years. Jim Seals lives in Costa Rica, but visits Nashville often.

President Bush told guitarist Chet Atkins' wife that turning 66 ``doesn't hurt a bit.'' Bush, who celebrated his 66th birthday Tuesday, telephoned the country musician's home Wednesday morning to thank the musician for calling the White House a day earlier with birthday wishes. Atkins was away from home eating breakfast, but his wife Leona spoke to the president for about five minutes. Mrs. Atkins said Bush remarked about his birthday, ``It doesn't hurt a bit.'' Atkins, known as ``Mr. Guitar,'' joked later that his wife should have relayed the call to the restaurant where he was eating. ``I've got to train her differently,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Debate at Betsy Ross House on Constitution Change
LaserPhoto PX2
DOC.TEXT: At the Betsy Ross House, where Flag Day is a sacred holiday, those who celebrate the stars and stripes' creation have strong views about its destruction. But stitching an amendment onto the Constitution to stop people from burning Old Glory had some workers and visitors at the house knitting their brows with concern. ``Patriotism is in the heart and can't be legislated,'' said Seta Demurjian, 57, of Cherry Hill, N.J., a guide who escorts people to Philadelphia's historic sites. ``Once you start monkeying around with the Constitution you open up a lot of problems,'' said Ms. Demurjian, who suggested Congress had more pressing issues to worry about. Passion about the issue was re-ignited this week after the U.S. Supreme Court decided Monday that a federal law making it a crime to burn the flag violated free speech protections in the Bill of Rights. After the decision, President Bush renewed his call for a 27th amendment to the Constitution to make flag burning a crime. A big celebration is scheduled for Flag Day at the Betsy Ross House, complete with fife-and-drum corps and the reading of an essay by 14-year-old competition winner Katie Appleget of Princeton Junction, N.J., on ``What the Flag Means to Me.'' DOC.HEAD: The AP
Second Nuclear Test Detonated at Nevada Site
DOC.TEXT: A nuclear weapon with up to 11 times the explosive force of the atomic bomb that devastated Hiroshima was detonated underground Wednesday at the Nevada Test Site. It was the second announced test this year. Stephen Ledogar, the U.S. ambassador to the International Conference on Disarmament, joined test controllers and other Energy Department officials in viewing the test by closed-circuit television at a control point 32 miles from ground zero. The Energy Department announced Monday that the test would have an explosive yield of 20 to 150 kilotons of TNT. The bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945 produced a blast of 13 kilotons. Tests are announced in advance when they will reach near the upper limits. Managers of high-rises in Las Vegas are warned by the Energy Department not to have workers in precarious positions at the time of the blast. All tests are announced as being less than 20 kilotons, or 20 to 150 kilotons. The test was the first since March 10. Last year, 12 nuclear weapons were exploded underground at the desert site. In recent years, the Energy Department has tested an average of about one nuclear weapon a month. The test was the 701st since testing began at the site in 1951.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Find Genetic Defect Responsible for Albinos
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6 p.m. EDT; time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have discovered a specific genetic defect that causes the pale skin and white hair of people who are albinos. The discovery should help doctors tell parents before birth whether their babies are likely to have this inherited condition. Doctors from the University of Wisconsin studied a family in which four sisters were albinos, but their parents and brothers had normal skin color. They found that the sisters inherited two different genetic mutations, one from each parent. The defects were in a gene that makes a protein essential for skin color. The researchers screened 15 other unrelated albinos, but found that only one of them had the same defects. They believe that many different mutations in this gene may cause albinism. The research, conducted by Dr. Richard A. Spritz and colleagues, was published in Thursday's issue of the New England Journal of Medicine. Albinism results from defects in the gene that oversees the body's production of tyrosinase. Tyrosinase is needed to make melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin, hair and eyes. In the severest form of the disease, albinos have white hair, milky white skin and pale blue eyes. They are also likely to have poor vision. About one in every 17,000 people in the United States is albino.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Leaders Call for Dialogue with U.S. Administration
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of Israel's new right-wing government said Wednesday they are willing to make peace with the Palestinians, but first want a new understanding with the United States. Foreign Minister David Levy and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said they wanted American guarantees that Israel would not have to speak to the PLO or discuss any Palestinian state in U.S.-proposed peace talks. ``Deal with us as allies. ... First we have to reach an agreement on these things, and then other things can certainly be achieved,'' Levy said at a ceremony in Jerusalem formally installing him as foreign minister. The new Cabinet won parliamentary approval Monday, ending three months of political uncertainty that followed the collapse of the Labor-Likud coalition over U.S. proposals for Palestinian-israeli talks in Cairo. Shamir said he wouldn't talk to Palestine Liberation Organization representatives or Arabs from Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem on ending the Palestinian uprising, which began in December 1987. At least 717 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 45 Israelis have died in the violence. Levy insisted the new leadership would not ``torpedo'' peace talks. ``This is not an extremist government ... but you have to understand us. This is not an issue of experiments. There is no people that makes experiments concerning its survival,'' Levy said. Another major irritant in U.S.-Israeli relations is Jerusalem's insistence on expanding Jewish settlement in the occupied lands,which Israel seized in the 1967 Middle East war. About 70,000 Jewish settlers now live in the West Bank. About 750,000 Soviet Jews are expected to enter Israel over the next years as Soviet emigration laws loosen. So far, about 300 Soviet Jews have settled in the West Bank. Defense Minister Moshe Arens on Wednesday supported the government's controversial settlement policy by visiting the West Bank's two largest Jewish communities, Maale Adumim and Ariel. ``I think it's only proper that I should visit here on my first day of touring as defense minister,'' Arens told leaders of Maale Adumim, a settlement of about 13,500 just outside Jerusalem. ``Ensuring the security of the (settlers) is one of the most important objectives of our government,'' Arens said. But Shamir, in an interview published Wednesday in the English-language Jerusalem Post, denied his government would build new settlements in the occupied lands. ``The emphasis will be on the ... strengthening of the now existing settlements,'' Shamir said. Settlement leaders said Maale Adumim was expected to grow by 6,500 residents by 1992. Another settlement located south of Jerusalem, Efrat, was to grow tenfold to 20,000 people by the decade's end. Shamir also told the Post he would not discuss formation of a Palestinian state in any peace talks. Speaking of the United States, Shamir said: ``I want them to understand our intentions, and I want to make it clear that a dialogue between Israel and Arab representatives ... cannot succeed without prior agreement between the parties that the goal is to advance within the framework of ... autonomy.'' Shamir said Wednesday that peace talks with the Palestinians could not succeed unless the Arab world joined the dialogue. In the past, all Arab states except Egypt have refused to negotiate with Israel. The remarks by Shamir and Levy indicated that Israel's new government, like the last one, will refuse proposals made earlier by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for the dialogue in Cairo. Hard-liners in Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, including Levy, said the proposals were an attempt to bring the PLO to the negotiating table. In a May 1989 peace plan, Shamir called for elections in the occupied lands in which Palestinians would choose representatives to negotiate limited autonomy. After some years, the final status of the West Bank and Gaza Strip would be discussed.

DOC.HEAD: Texas, Oklahoma to Settle Boundary Question
DOC.TEXT: Texans and Oklahomans want to draw the line once and for all that determines an exact boundary of the Lone Star State _ and they'd rather do it Sooner than later. The Red River has served an official divider between the two since Spain and the United States signed a treaty in 1819 to set the southwest boundary of the Louisiana Purchase. But they've been wrangling in courtrooms and state capitals for years over which bank _ north or south _ sets the boundary along a 110-mile stretch of river. The U.S. Supreme Court tried to settle the question in the early 1920s by issuing four opinions, which set the boundary at the river's south bank, the Texas side. However, each time the course of the river's flow is altered, usually by flooding, new quarrels arise. The confusion has caused disputes over taxes, mineral rights and law enforcement jurisdiction. So once again, Texas and Oklahoma officials and the federal Bureau of Land Management will try to resolve the issue. The federal agency will present a proposal this summer to officials from both states, Paul Tanner, area manager for the Bureau of Land Management's Oklahoma City office, said this week. Tanner predicts the boundary will be fixed at a permanent spot on the Texas side of the river. If that happens, Oklahoma stands to gain acreage and increase its tax base, he said. The stretch is in the central part of the boundary and runs in Texas from about Byers to Oklaunion.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Leaders Endorse Proposed Ban On Strike Replacements
DOC.TEXT: Organized labor leaders urged Congress Wednesday to ban the replacement of striking workers, saying the practice has eroded the rights of employees to strike. But some lawmakers said such a law would unfairly tilt the collective bargaining process toward unions by leaving companies with no means of surviving a strike. ``Talk about a level playing field .... If this bill passes, one of the players won't even be invited to the game,'' said Rep. Cass Ballenger, R-N.C. ``They won't have a ticket to get in.'' Rep. Harris Fawell, R-Ill., complained that the hearing before a House Labor subcommittee was one-sided because the only witnesses were labor officials. Committee chairman Rep. William Clay, D-Mo., said opponents of the measure, which he is sponsoring, would be asked to appear later. Clay said he wanted corporate managers at Eastern Air Lines and Greyhound Lines Inc. _ two companies that quickly hired replacements at the onset of labor disputes _ to tell Congress ``why they would be so ruthless in replacing workers, some who have been with them 25 years.'' The House labor-management relations subcommittee is considering a measure that would bar companies from keeping replacement workers if union workers with more seniority wanted their jobs back after a strike was settled. A similar measure is pending before a Senate committee. Those testifying included Greyhound union president Edward M. Strait, who said the bus line's promise of permanent jobs for replacement workers was a ``major obstacle'' in the resolution of the 3-month-old drivers' strike. Strait's Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions represents the 6,300 drivers who walked off their jobs March 2 over wages and job security. He said the proposed change was needed to ``redress a fatal flaw'' in federal labor law that allows companies to replace workers who exercise their legal right to strike. Greyhound, which filed for bankruptcy protection last week, has been operating a reduced schedule with about 3,000 replacement drivers. In an interview from the bus line's Dallas headquarters, Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said the issue of replacement workers was a ``sideshow'' in the dispute. He said contract negotiations have failed because of unreasonable wage demands by the union. The hiring of permanent replacement workers, once considered taboo, has become more widespread in recent years. Many in organized labor trace the increase in permanent replacements to President Reagan's firing of striking air traffic controllers in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow To Speed Economic Reform, But Bread Price Rise Postponed
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature voted to further speed the nation toward a market economy Wednesday, but a government official told lawmakers that an threefold increase in bread prices would be delayed. Panic-buying has emptied many store shelves since late last month, when the Communist government proposed to cut many price subsidies by January. Prices on bread, the main staple of the Soviet diet, also will be raised eventually, but ``of course, not by July 1,'' said Yuri Maslyukov, chairman of the government agency that runs the centralized economy. Bread now sells for less than 30 cents a loaf. The Supreme Soviet, ordering the fine-tuning of a plan that drew widespread criticism as being too vague and tentative, instructed the Council of Ministers to have drafts of all the laws needed for the switch from a planned to a market economy by October. The measure also instructed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to issue a series of presidential decrees beginning July 1 to speed up progress on bringing new laws on ownership, leasing, farming and other key elements of a market economy into effect. ``The main thing now is that now we can begin to work,'' said leading economist and Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin. ``Three years ago someone who called for a market economy was pointed at _ `There's a man who's betraying the ideals of socialism!''' he said. ``Today everyone's talking about how to make the transition faster.'' Abalkin, speaking to reporters at the Supreme Soviet, said the government still intends to raise most prices on retail goods and raw materials in January as stated in its earlier plan, despite consumer outcry. The Supreme Soviet heard Maslyukov's proposal Wednesday to postpone the price increase on bread and was expected to vote on it Thursday. Maslyukov recommended the postponement largely because the plan for compensating the population for the extra money they would have to spend on bread still needed work. But he said nine of the 15 Soviet republics already have agreed to increase their bread prices Aug. 1, with compensation beginning about two weeks earlier. Wednesday's resolution did not reject outright the program put forth by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov late last month, which focused on price rises. But it demanded quick, concrete plans for creating a market and immediate spending cuts on defense, the government bureaucracy and construction to cut the budget deficit. ``We have to begin work now,'' deputy Alexei Boiko, who presented the resolution, told lawmakers. Ryzhkov and his government were forced to rethink the plan after it prompted panic buying and drew nearly unanimous criticism by economists around the world for raising prices without freeing enough goods and prices from government control to allow a true transition to a market economy. Wednesday's resolution set an October deadline for Gorbachev's administration to hammer out concrete reforms, including bills to create a stock market, commercial banks, credit and a federal reserve bank. Deputies changed the draft to remove the specifics of which laws were needed, but said the list still applied. Ryzhkov told reporters he supported the altered plan. ``The project was worked on by commissions and is fairly objective, and allows us to work further,'' he said. But he said it would be difficult to complete all the laws and practical measures by the autumn deadline. Ryzhkov admitted he was surprised at the swell of sentiment against the price increases. He said he knew it would be difficult, but ``to tell the truth, I thought society was more prepared.'' Asked about calls for his resignation due to the outcry, Ryzhkov said: ``It's not a question of who works on this program. I'm convinced this is the road we have to take.'' Opposition economist Gennady Filshin criticized Wednesday's proposal as a compromise among government economists unwilling to take the radical steps needed. His Inter-Regional Group, the opposition in the Soviet Congress, proposed much more radical measures, including liquidating all ministries and freeing up prices altogether. Other deputies took the floor Wednesday to blast the proposal as well, many speaking against the overall price increases. But the resolution passed nonetheless in a series of votes on each article. Boiko said the Parliament would keep a close eye on the government's fulfillment of the resolution, and if by fall it had not made satisfactory progress, ``we will be forced to make the corresponding verdict.''

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Says Bailout Agency Needs More Money from Congress
DOC.TEXT: The government's savings and loan bailout agency will run out of borrowing authority in the October-December quarter, bringing thrift rescues to a halt unless Congress provides more money, a top regulator said Wednesday. ``Obviously if we don't have any money, we can't continue,'' said L. William Seidman, previewing congressional testimony to be delivered Thursday by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Seidman is chairman of the Resolution Trust Corp., a 10-month-old agency responsible for closing and selling failed thrifts. Three weeks ago, Brady roughly doubled the Bush administration's estimate of the cost of bailing out S&Ls to a range of $89 billion to $132 billion. Brady's latest disclosure that the RTC soon will run out of operating funds, to be delivered to the House Banking Committee, lends new urgency to negotiations between administration and congressional leaders on the budget for fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1. It means Congress must provide substantial additional money in the budget or face a halt to thrift rescues within weeks of the start of the new fiscal year. Seidman, responding to reporters' questions at a news conference on an unrelated matter, indicated his agency has at least enough borrowing authority remaining to rescue another 95 to 120 S&Ls. That would leave as many as 500 failed institutions still open, but under government control. Since it began operating in August, the RTC has ``resolved'' 168 failed thrifts by paying off depositors or by selling the institutions to new investors. It plans another 45 resolutions by the end of June and expected to handle 50 to 75 in the July-September quarter, Seidman said. At the end of last week, the RTC had control of 295 failed S&Ls awaiting resolution. Thrift regulators have indicated at least another 299 institutions still operating independently appear headed for failure. S&L legislation enacted in August authorized the RTC to borrow $50 billion through long-term bonds to cover the losses in failed S&Ls. The resolutions through the end of this month should use about $30 billion of that money. The RTC has also been authorized to borrow an additional $45 billion in short-term working capital until it can sell the real estate, securities and other assets it is inheriting from failed institutions. Seidman said the agency had not decided how much working capital it will borrow in the July-September quarter. The total amount of short-term borrowing is capped by a complex formula in last year's law and Seidman indicated that cap would be reached before the end of this year. ``We will be out of funds enabling us to do transactions,'' he said. Senate Banking Committee Chairman Donald W. Riegle Jr. said Monday that Congress probably would have to act later this year to provide new money ``probably in amounts comparable'' to the $50 billion in long-term borrowing authorized by the law.

DOC.HEAD: East-West Teamwork Leads German Authorities To Second Terror Suspect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with another report saying more arrests expected, prosecutor saying possible PLO connection. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Ever since...'; SUBS 15th graf pvs, `The West...' to CORRECT spelling to Maier-Witt
DOC.TEXT: German officials in the East and West teamed up to capture the second top leftist terrorist suspect in a week, and news reports on Wednesday said more such arrests were expected. West German authorities hailed the joint effort that led to the arrest of 46-year-old Inge Viett, and East Germany's interior minister called it an example of ``success in German-German cooperation'' following decades of enmity. The East German minister, Peter-Michael Diestel, also promised to investigate the extent to which his country's former Communist government _ particularly its hated secret police _ had harbored West German terrorists. ``It's a perverse situation that in the past, terrorists were protected in the German Democratic Republic,'' Diestel told reporters in Bonn. The secret police, once virtually omnipresent, would have known the background of any West Germans resettling in East Germany. Many suspected the secret police, or Stasi, had provided the terrorists with new identities and other help. If so, Diestel said, it was a ``diabolical connection.'' The government-run East German news agency ADN said Ms. Viett, wanted in several attacks, was captured Tuesday night in the East German city of Magdeburg. It immediately led to speculation that other members of the Red Army Faction would turn up in East Germany, or that they once lived there. ``East Germany's chief prosecutor's office is optimistically looking forward to the speedy capture of other terrorists,'' said West Germany's ZDF television network. ZDF also said there are indications of ties linking East Germany's secret police and West German terrorists with Middle East terror groups. Law enforcement sources in Bonn, speaking to The Associated Press on the condition of anonymity, said there were indications that Ms. Viett had worked with Palestinian terrorists in the 1970s. Ever since the two Germanys started their rapid road to unification last fall, the question of terrorism has become increasingly important. Officials on both sides of the crumbling barriers have warned that East Germany could provide fertile territory for new leftist terrorist crimes. Joint efforts were stepped up to capture any Red Army Faction members who may have slipped across the border after a series of attacks that rocked West German industry in the 1970s and 80s. The West German federal police worked with their counterparts in East Germany to capture Ms. Viett unarmed in her apartment in Magdeburg, where she had lived for more than two years. Sources said Ms. Viett's neighbors notified authorities, after seeing West German wanted posters with her picture that had been put up throughout the city. East German police carried out the arrest, and West German authorities arrived in Magdeburg afterward. Ms. Viett's capture and the June 6 apprehension of another suspect, Sussanne Albrecht, represent some of the biggest successes against West German terrorists in years. The West German newspaper Bild said that officials in East and West were close to arresting terrorist suspect Silke Maier-Witt in East Germany. ``Every day, we are counting on seeing the news of her arrest,'' Bild quoted one unidentified West German official as saying. Bild is known to have close ties to government security officials in Bonn. Earlier, the Morgenpost newspaper of Dresden reported that Ms. Maier-Witt had lived in that East German city. She is suspected of having taken part in the 1977 kidnapping and murder of prominent West German industrialist Hanns Martin Schleyer. Ms. Viett's alleged involvement in terrorism goes back to 1972, when she was accused of taking part in a bombing that killed one man at a boating facility in Berlin. West German authorities have accused Ms. Viett of taking part in the slaying of prominent West Berlin Judge Guenter von Drenkmann in 1974. Ms. Viett is also wanted in the kidnapping of West Berlin Christian Democratic leader Peter Lorenz a year later, among numerous other crimes. In 1978, she allegedly took part in helping Red Army Faction member Till Meyer escape from a Berlin prison. Ms. Viett in 1981 allegedly shot a French policemen, after being stopped by authorities in Paris. The policeman was seriously injured. West German officials announced plans to seek the extradition of Ms. Viett, as they are doing in the case of Ms. Albrecht. Ms. Albrecht is wanted in the 1977 murder of prominent West German banker Juergen Ponto.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Training of Lebanese Military May Resume
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is prepared to resume a military training program for Lebanon once that country repays more than $8 million in overdue loans to the United States, U.S. officials said Wednesday. John T. McCarthy, ambassador to Lebanon, outlined the U.S. position last week at a meeting in Egypt with Lebanese President Elias Harawi, the officials said. Lebanon is ineligible for U.S. assistance because of the repayment arrearages. The suspension went into effect in 1988. Harawi told McCarthy he believes the debt problem can be resolved, paving the way for a resumption of the training program, said the officials, who spoke on condition they not be identified. U.S. military training programs normally are administered by the local American embassy. Because the embassy in Beirut has been closed, the officials said other arrangements would have to be made to train Lebanese troops when the program is restored.

DOC.HEAD: Mr. Universe Faces Steroid Charges
DOC.TEXT: The reigning Mr. Universe faces federal charges of conspiring to smuggle anabolic steroids into the United States, prosecutors said Wednesday. Matthew Dufresne, 24, of Hampden was indicted by a federal grand jury in Springfield on Tuesday on charges of conspiring to import steroids from Belgium and with possession of 5,000 doses of the drug. In October 1989, he was chosen Mr. Universe by the North Atlantic Body Building Association. He was only the second person to win that title in the same year he was named Mr. America. Anabolic steroids are used to build muscles and stamina, but can have dangerous side-effects and are banned by international athletic organizations. The indictment charges that Dufresne went to Belgium last October and gave $500 in cash to an unidentified individual. On Jan. 5, Dufresne ``removed a package containing anabolic steroids and labeled `X-mas gifts. Toys!''' from a post office box in Hampden, the indictment charges. Court officials said no arraignment date has been set for Dufresne, who faces a maximum sentence of 13 years in prison and fines totaling $260,000 if convicted, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Bertha D. Josephson. Dufresne did not return a telephone message left at his home Wednesday by The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Eureka! That's Some Heartburn!
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Eureka, Calif., on Wednesday sportingly swallowed his city's designation as the nation's heartburn capital. ``We'll long remember you and the occasion,'' Mayor Fred Moore gamely told company officials as he accepted a plaque placing Eureka at the top of the National Rolaids Heartburn Index. The Heartburn Index blames that searing sensation on sociology, not spices. It says Eureka in Northern California is Heartburn City because, among other reasons, it's attracting newcomers with a burning desire for economic success. ``Isn't this bonkers?'' said the mayor's wife, Madelon Moore. ``Everybody at City Hall went crazy.'' El Paso, Texas, had the lowest heartburn rate among 197 metropolitan areas. And how do El Paso residents perceive this great honor? ``With a certain bit of levity, probably,'' said City Councilman Gene Finke, who accepted his city's plaque. The study chalked up El Paso's tummy-taming qualities to a stable population and a rebounding economy. Finke also credited strong family values and friendliness. Finke swore that nary a twinge has been blamed on his city's spicy Tex-Mex cuisine. ``Maybe they're stoics,'' said Jack Levin, sociology professor at Northeastern University in Boston, who did the study for Rolaids. Actually, Levin's heartfelt, if theoretical, findings did finger factors other than food for the nation's 40 million heartburn sufferers. ``I think there is a tendency on the part of Americans to blame heartburn on spicy foods _ Mexican or Szechuan, for example,'' said Levin. ``From a sociological standpoint, it appears heartburn levels can be easily linked to the amount of population growth that a city is experiencing.'' He said there could be other factors, such as the October earthquake in Northern California. Levin digested sales figures for various antacid brands, tablet and liquid. Then, he ranked the nation's heartburn hotbeds. The sales statistics were not revealed. But, on average, Americans experience heartburn twice a week, he said. In contrast, the 25,000 folks in Eureka, 280 miles north of San Francisco, are plagued an average of four times a week. After Eureka, the most seething cities were San Francisco; Chico, Calif; Santa Barbara, Calif.; Sacramento, Calif.; Boise, Idaho; Reno, Nev.; Fresno, Calif.; Bakersfield, Calif., and Seattle. The least were in El Paso; Fort Smith, Ark.; Ada, Okla.; Colorado Springs, Colo.; Columbia, Mo.; St. Joseph, Mo.; Lubbock, Texas; Panama City, Fla.; Springfield, Mo.; and Albany, Ga. New York City ranked 135th. ``The most startling result in this analysis was that the Northeast region did not have high heartburn ...,'' said Levin. Levin also singled out Midwestern cities characterized by ``stability and tradition,'' like Springfield, Mo. (103); Green Bay, Wis. (184); Lansing, Mich. (181) and Sioux City, Iowa (186). Perhaps to prove a point, the results were unveiled at a lunch of chicken marinated in tequila, shrimp marinated in chili, salad with cilantro dressing, tacos and refried beans. As a hedge, there were post-dessert ``Rolaids for everyone,'' said spokeswoman Ann Forster.

DOC.HEAD: Recount Begins in Governor's Primary
DOC.TEXT: A recount began Wednesday in Nebraska's Democratic gubernatorial primary, nearly a month after election day. Unofficial returns from last month's voting gave attorney Ben Nelson of Omaha a 41-vote victory over Bill Hoppner of Lincoln, an attorney-businessman and former aide to U.S. Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb. The close margin forced an automatic recount, which is expected to take several days. ``What we're anticipating is that there have been some errors,'' Hoppner said. The winner will face Republican Gov. Kay Orr, the nation's first woman Republican elected governor, who is seeking a second term. There is no apparent record of such a recount in Nebraska history. Nelson spokesman Sonny Foster said the recount seemed to increase the interest of volunteers who wanted to serve as observers for the candidates at recount sites. ``We have about 150 people grumbling because they didn't get to participate in this historical process,'' Foster said. ``This is history in the making, a first for Nebraska, and they wanted to be a part of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Wall's Final Days B fall. More sections have been removed in
DOC.TEXT: recent months to alleviate traffic flow and make way for new developments. But most of West Berlin still remains surrounded by fortifications. The U.S. military in West Berlin said Wednesday arrangements are not yet complete for the removal of the famed Checkpoint Charlie through the Berlin Wall. The building had been scheduled to close Thursday. The Berlin governments chose Bernauer Street for the ceremonial start of the wall's final demolition because of the chilling images it gave the world. Shortly after the wall began going up, some occupants of nearby buildings jumped into bedsheets held open by West Berliners. A 77-year-old woman hung from a window ledge for 15 minutes while Communist Party functionaries tried to pull her back, at one point throwing a smoke grenade at the crowd below. They finally let the woman drop into a bedsheet. In 1964, some West Berliners dug a tunnel under Bernauer Street and 57 East Germans escaped. A 90-year-old church that straddled the border, which contained a plaque with the names of East Germans who died while trying to flee, was blown up by Communist authorities in 1985. They cited border security as the reason. Helmut Frankan ran a bar a block away when the wall was being erected. In the first few weeks, as the fortifications were still being built and strengthened, one of his waitresses used to climb over the wall to visit her mother in West Berlin. ``One day the guards caught her and punched her in the face. She spent a year and a half in prison,'' said Frankan, 66, as he kicked through the gravel where houses once stood. ``They tore down all of these houses. They even moved a graveyard.''

DOC.HEAD: IRA Suspected In Bombing Of Home Used By Conservative Party Figure
DOC.TEXT: A bomb blew a hole in the recently vacated home of a leading Conservative Party figure, and police said Wednesday that they suspected the IRA carried out the attack. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the explosion Tuesday night at West Green House _ an 18th century mansion in this southern English village _ was ``very disturbing.'' No one was hurt in the blast, and no organization immediately claimed responsibility. The Irish Republican Army, in a new offensive aimed mainly at British targets outside Northern Ireland, has killed seven people in the past few weeks and mounted half a dozen attacks in England. The explosion tore a three-foot hole in the front of the mansion, which until three weeks ago was the home of Lord McAlpine, a former deputy chairman and treasurer of the Conservative Party and major fund-raiser. McAlpine, 48, is a close associate of Mrs. Thatcher and neighbors said she has been a guest at West Green House, 55 miles from London. ``We are keeping an open mind,'' Hampshire police Detective Superintendent Alan Wheeler told a news conference. ``But because of the size of the explosion there is only one organization I know of which causes such explosions, and that is the IRA.'' McAlpine was on a target list of more than 100 prominent Britons, including judges, found in a police raid 18 months ago on a apartment used by IRA bomb-makers in south London. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule in the predominantly Protestant province of Northern Ireland and unite it with the republic of Ireland. Police said at first they suspected animal rights extremists, but they focused later on the IRA. McAlpine's interests include a zoo in Broome, Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Big Three Sales Slumped in Early June
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf, `Ford reported ...,' to CORRECT that 20.2 percent drop was in car, sted truck sales. A version also moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and trucks by the nation's Big Three automakers plunged 15.5 percent in early June, compared with the same period last year, the companies said Wednesday. The drop came as automakers tried to wean consumers from costly incentives. The number of vehicles covered by incentives and the amounts of rebates offered June 1-10 were lower than the same period were lower than during the same period a year ago. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said they sold vehicles at an average daily rate of 28,073 during the period this year, compared with an average of 33,223 during the same time in 1989. Car sales skidded 19.2 percent and truck sales dropped 9.3 percent. Through June 10 of this year, Big Three car and truck sales were running 7.7 percent behind last year's pace, dropping to a daily sales rate of 32,474 from a rate of 35,1273 a day last year. Car sales for the year were down 10.8 percent and light truck sales were off 2.6 percent. Chrysler's early-June vehicle sales were 18 percent lower than last year's. Car sales dropped 16.7 percent and sales of light trucks, which provide much of the company's profits, were off 19.1 percent. The company's vehicle sales so far this year declined 13 percent from last year; car sales dropped 18 percent and truck sales fell 8.2 percent. GM said its combined early-June car and truck sales were 16.7 percent behind last year's pace with car sales down 19.2 percent and sales of light trucks off 11.3 percent. So far this year, GM has sold 4.8 percent fewer vehicles than last year, with car sales down 7.5 percent and truck sales up a slight 0.8 percent. Ford reported a 12.4 percent drop in early-June car and truck sales, with a 20.2 percent decline in car sales blunted by a .5 percent increase in truck sales. Ford spokesman Joel Pitcoff said sales of the company's new Explorer sport-utility vehicle was the main reason for the increase in truck sales. Since Jan. 1, Ford's vehicle sales are down 8.8 percent, with car sales off 12.7 percent and truck sales showing a 2.8 percent decline.

DOC.HEAD: Wristwatch Pagers Not Just For Sleuths Anymore
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The Seiko ...,' to ADD introductory price. SUBS 5th graf, `Like Tracy's ...,' to CORRECT that similar service offered by other pager companies, sted radio stations. ADDS 1 graf with background on a similar pager to be offered by other companies.
DOC.TEXT: Dick Tracy, the comic book detective with a two-way wrist radio, would be pleased. A Japanese company says it plans to introduce a wristwatch with a pager capable of carrying short messages on a liquid-crystal display. The Seiko Receptor, which took four years to develop, is scheduled to debut next month in Portland, Ore., at an introductory price of $255 and may gradually appear for $275 in other U.S. cities, Hattori Seiko Co. spokeswoman Noriko Kuriyama said Wednesday. The company also is studying plans to expand sales to Europe and Asia, she said. Like Tracy's famous radio, the new wristwatch pager receives radio signals. The Receptor translates the radio waves into written messages up to 16 characters long. Many U.S. pager companies already provide similar services for beepers, but these devices aren't contained in a wristwatch. The wristwatch pager is manufactured by Seiko Epson Co., a Hattori Seiko subsidiary. It can store up to eight messages. The Receptor will be marketed in the United States through AT&E Corp., a San Francisco-based telecommunications company. In 1983, Seiko introduced a wristwatch-sized color television. But the TV required an auxiliary tuner about the size of a small cassette tape player. Seiko hopes to sell 1 million wristwatch pagers in the next three years, Ms. Kuriyama said. The Seiko model will have competition from a wristwatch pager that Motorola Inc. and Timex Corp. expect to introduce later this year. That model was announced last year by the two companies.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Deserter Turns Himself In After 21 Years In Canada
LaserPhoto WX21
DOC.TEXT: A former U.S. Marine private who fled to Canada after basic training ended 21 years of self-exile Wednesday and surrendered Marine authorities. Ron Jacko, a Cleveland native who has lived in Toronto since 1969, turned himself in at the Marine base in Quantico, Va., said Capt. Betsy Sweatt. Jacko, 42, said he would ask the base commander, Lt. Gen. W.R. Etnyre, to allow him to avoid a court-martial and leave the Marine Corps with an ``other-than-honorable discharge.'' If, after an investigation, Etnyre grants that request, Jacko could be free in a few weeks, Sweatt said. ``Every case is handled individually,'' the spokeswoman said. In the meantime, the Marines will check Jacko's background to make sure no other charges are pending against him. He will not be imprisoned but will be confined to the base, living in a barracks with other privates. ``He'll be treated as any other Marine PFC,'' Sweatt said. ``He'll be in what's called a casual status. He can see his civilian lawyer any time he needs to and a military lawyer will also be assigned to assist him.'' Returned deserters are no novelty at Quantico. ``We average about three a week,'' she said. Before heading for Quantico, Jacko met with the member of Congress who represents his old neighborhood, the west side of Cleveland. Afterward, Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio, said she would ask the base commander to consider Jacko's case ``justly, fairly, expeditiously and compassionately.'' ``He convinced me that it was a matter of conscience for him,'' said Oakar. Jacko said he considered returning for several years, and finally was convinced to turn himself because of the failing health of his mother, Marge, who still lives in Cleveland. ``She just went through three operations in about the last six months,'' he said. ``I want to be able to be there.'' Jacko married a Canadian woman and has supported himself by managing health food stores in Toronto. He had not tried to return before Tuesday, when he met a lawyer from the New York-based group Citizen Soldier and made the rounds of Washington news offices, trying to attract publicity and in turn improve his case. Jacko's wife, Nadia, did not accompany him, but he said she would join him in his new home after his release. Jacko said he opposed the Vietnam war from the outset, but decided to enlist in hopes of pulling an assignment in which he could avoid being sent to the Southeast Asian country. . Assignment to communications school convinced him he was likely to be shipped to Vietnam. He fled to Canada while on leave after basic training, but said he was never able to forget that he was a fugitive and was eager to put that behind him. ``It's not an easy feeling,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Months of Baltics Standoff
With AM-Soviet-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a glance at events in Lithuania since the republic's declaration of independence from Moscow three months ago:

March 11 _ The Lithuanian legislature elects the first non-Communist president of a Soviet republic, Vytautas Landsbergis, changes the republic's name and declares independence from Moscow. March 13 _ Mikhail S. Gorbachev declares Lithuania's move illegal. March 15 _ Gorbachev, elected the Soviet Union's first executive president, is given authority by the Soviet Congress to deal with the dispute with Lithuania. March 16 _ Gorbachev gives Lithuania three days to begin returning to the Soviet fold. Lithuania rejects his authority. March 21 _ Gorbachev gives Lithuanians seven days to turn in firearms. March 22 _ Soviet armor rumbles through Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, in a show of force. April 18 _ Gorbachev stops shipments of all oil, most natural gas and other raw materials to Lithuania to pressure the republic into rescinding pro-independence laws. April 21 _ Lithuania closes most factories to save fuel and raw materials. May 12 _ The presidents of the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia meet to forge a united front against Moscow to re-establish their independence. May 17 _ Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene meets with Gorbachev, who says Lithuania must suspend its declaration of independence, softening his demand that it be revoked. June 2 _ Lithuania is discussed by Gorbachev and President Bush at their Washington summit. The United States presses for an easing of the Moscow stance. June 12 _ Gorbachev meets with the presidents of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia after weeks of refusing to negotiate with them unless they agreed to abide by the Soviet constitution. June 13 _ Prunskiene says the Soviet government agrees to restore some fuel and raw materials to Lithuania, easing the embargo. Lithuania had said it was willing to negotiate on rolling back its independence laws.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Apoligizes; Committee Ends Hearings Early
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First 10 grafs new; picking up 5th graf pvs, But, Durenberger
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger apologized Wednesday to his colleagues and constituents, saying he takes ``full responsibility'' for ethical lapses even though he never set out to break the rules. Shortly after he spoke, the Senate Ethics Committee abruptly ended its trial-like hearing into Durenberger's financial conduct and accepted 23 volumes of evidence against the Minnesota Republican. The committee will now weigh a recommendation by its special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, that Durenberger be denounced by the Senate for financial improprieties. In an emotional, hour-long speech, the senator told the committee his ``life and reputation'' are at stake and said he would rely on the committee's ``good judgment and compassion.'' The committee had scheduled up to two weeks of hearings, but went along with a request from Durenberger's attorney, Jim Hamilton, to end the hearings early because a prolonged proceeding would cost the senator too much in legal fees. The panel's vice chairman, Sen. Warren B. Rudman, R-N.H., said the committee would have no problem making a judgment based on written documents and statements by Durenberger, his lawyer and Bennett. ``There is not a great deal of dispute about the facts,'' Rudman said. ``There's obviously a great deal of dispute about what those facts mean.'' A decision is not expected for several weeks. Bennett said it would likely take him two weeks to submit his formal recommendation. Durenberger, speaking softly in a voice that faltered but did not break, attributed his lack of attention to ethics rules, in part, to the ``strains and vulnerabilities in my personal life.'' Standing at a microphone and often looking straight at the six senators sitting in judgment of him, described the pain of raising four sons after his first wife died of cancer at the age of 31, and his marriage to his current wife, Penny, whose first husband had died in the Vietnam War. But, Durenberger said in his address to the hushed hearing room, these factors were ``not an excuse'' for breaking Senate rules. ``I ... accept full responsibility for errors which were made,'' he said. ``I recognize that real damage has been done by what has been perceived as my desire to push the limits and take advantage of the Senate, and for that I am sorry,'' he said. Durenberger combined his appeal for compassion with a defense that he had made mistakes but that ``all the key decisions'' had been taken with legal advice. As had been the case when Bennett made his case against Durenberger on Tuesday, the committee had no visible reaction to the senator's presentation. After he finished, Durenberger hugged his son Dan, his staff members and embraced fellow Minnesota Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz. Durenberger spoke on the second day of trial-like hearings in answer to Bennett's recommendation that he be denounced by the full Senate because, Bennett said, Durenberger had intended to break its rules and the law. The committee has found ``substantial credible evidence'' that Durenberger committed violations of Senate rules and the law. Bennett said Durenberger abused his office by: _Evading honoraria limits when he classified money earned from appearances before trade groups as his payment for promoting his two books. _Hiding his ownership in a Minneapolis condominium so he could collect travel reimbursements when he stayed there. _Accepting free limousine rides from special-interest groups in violation of a $100 annual gift ceiling from people or groups interested in legislation. Durenberger said he would not challenge the committee's recommended punishment, but he appeared to rule out resigning. ``When this is done, I intend to serve this body and my home state with a renewed conviction to exemplify the servant in public service,'' he said. If the Senate follows Bennett's advice, it would pass a resolution denouncing him for ``reprehensible'' conduct _ an action that would not effect his Senate standing or duties. Senators also could issue a mild rebuke, strip him of seniority, take away committee assignments or even expel him _ unlikely in a case without serious violations of criminal law. ``I acted in good faith and with no intent whatsoever to violate the rules of the Senate,'' Durenberger said. ``I know that in my heart to be the case.'' Bennett listened to Durenberger and began his rebuttal by stressing it was ``difficult to follow such an eloquent and touching moment.'' ``No human being in this room can feel good right now,'' he said. ``Certainly I don't. But let's get back to the facts.'' He then ripped into Durenberger's arguments, saying that the senator ``knowingly and intentionally committed acts that were unethical.'' Bennett, repeating an allegation he made Tuesday that Durenberger's speeches were honoraria appearances and not book promotions, told the committee: ``Sen. Durenberger knew when he spoke'' and didn't have any books with him ``this wasn't a book promotion. So let's keep our eye on the ball here. If there have been book promotions we wouldn't be here.'' Bennett said he asked Durenberger and his attorney, Jim Hamilton, to show him ``one event where the senator was asked to promote his book. I have not received that evidence.'' Political leaders in Minnesota, including state Republican chairman Robert Weinholzer, have said there could be pressure for him to resign if the Senate gives him a serious punishment.

DOC.HEAD: Science Minister Wants Mediterranean-Dead Sea Canal
DOC.TEXT: Science Minister Yuval Neeman on Wednesday proposed reviving a plan for a canal from the Mediterranean Sea to the Dead Sea that was shelved five years ago as impractical and too costly. Neeman, a physicist who headed a project to plan the route of the proposed canal in 1981, said the decision to cancel the project was made too hastily and ``without depth.'' ``The canal can solve the problem of the Dead Sea,'' Neeman told Israel radio. ``A big part of the Dead Sea is already desert.'' The plan to build the 70-mile so-called ``Dead-Med canal'' was announced in 1980. It caught the imagination of Israelis because Theodore Herzl, the visionary who conceived the modern Jewish state, urged building such a canal as early as 1902. The 1980 plan had two purposes: to generate electricity and to refill the evaporating Dead Sea, actually a lake laden with salt and chemicals through which runs the Israeli-Jordanian border. Electricity was to be generated by using the force of the water as it flowed down to the Dead Sea, which at 1,097 feet below sea level is the lowest point on earth. When the project was canceled in 1985, Energy Minister Moshe Shahal said the canal would be too expensive because falling oil prices had reduced the cost of generating electricity. Energy officials estimated then that the project would be feasible only if oil cost $32 a barrel. Today the price is about $15 a barrel. By 1985 the projected cost of the canal was estimated at $1.5 billion. The decision to stop the canal project also involved other considerations. Neighboring Jordan claimed the project would threaten its chemical works on the east bank of the Dead Sea. There were also fears that pumping ordinary sea water into the Dead Sea would change its unique quality that allows swimmers to float on the surface. The oily, chemical-laden water is also sought out by health enthusiasts who believe it has medicinal value in treating skin diseases.

DOC.HEAD: House Subcommittee Approves bill to End Antitrust Exemption
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee approved legislation Wednesday to scale back exemptions from federal antitrust laws the insurance industry has enjoyed for 45 years. On a 9-6 partisan vote, the Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on economic and commercial law approved a bill to subject insurance companies to federal court lawsuits for price fixing and other antitrust provisions. All Democrats on the panel voted for the bill and all Republicans voted against it. Insurance companies and their agents have enjoyed immunity from antitrust suits under the 1945 McCarran-Ferguson Act, which delegated regulation of the now $500 billion industry to state governments. The bill clearing its first legislative hurdle Wednesday was prompted by the 1985 insurance upheaval in which companies quit writing liability coverage for various occupations because of massive claims and judgments against them. A similar bill was approved by the subcommittee in 1988 but got nowhere because of intense opposition from the insurance industry. This time, however, Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, the full committee's new chairman, is determined to bring a bill to the House floor. Citing opponents' claims that the industry is so competitive that no antitrust laws are needed, Brooks said Wednesday, ``If that's so, then there is nothing to fear'' from the bill. In addition to price fixing, the legislation would, after a five-year transition, make other alleged abuses by insurance companies grounds for federal antitrust lawsuits. They include dividing up geographic territories among competing companies and ``tying'' requirements, such as forcing a buyer to purchase home insurance in order to get auto coverage. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, has introduced similar legislation in the Senate. However, the industry is counting on opposition from Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Howell Heflin, D-Ala. _ both, along with Metzenbaum, members of the Senate's judiciary committee _ to prevent its passage.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Seeks to Educate the Young
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Energy will use money that once financed scholarships for university nuclear engineering students to help schoolchildren improve science and math skills, an official said Wednesday. James Decker, acting director of the DOE's Office of Energy Research, told a House Science, Space and Technology subcommittee that the shift resulted from ``tough budget decisions'' made for fiscal year 1991. The administration decided to move about $6 million from university nuclear engineering research programs and scholarships to ``place greater emphasis on pre-college'' science and mathematics programs, he said. ``There is a growing consensus that one of the most serious problems facing the nation over the next 10 years is the declining number of young Americans, including women and minorities, interested in pursuing careers in science and engineering,'' Decker said. ``DOE is uniquely positioned to provide major assistance to the national effort to strengthen science and engineering education,'' he added. The Energy Department has traditionally supported science education at the graduate and postdoctoral levels. Its university research in fiscal year 1990 totals about $480 million. Richard Stephens, director of DOE's University and Industry Division, said the department had worked closely with 57 universities that have nuclear engineering programs providing degrees ranging from bachelor's to doctorates. There are 36 active projects with an average of three graduate students, each receiving the scholarships. Stephens stressed that none of the current scholarship recipients will be affected by the budget switch because for each of the three years of the program, three-year awards were granted. Besides developing pre-college mathematics and science education programs at the DOE laboratories around the country, Decker said there also will be a travelling museum-based science education program consisting of exhibits on major energy-related scientific programs, increased research appointments for teachers and minority high school students and an expansion of special engineering programs for middle school students. Decker said that special emphasis for the new fiscal year will be on the development of partnerships between DOE laboratories and inner-city and rural schools, mainly middle and high schools with high drop out rates.

DOC.HEAD: House OKs $4 Billion AIDS Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved a $4 billion AIDS bill that would provide emergency money for cities and states to deal with the deadly disease. The bill, approved on a 408-14 vote, is more expensive than the $2.9 billion Senate version passed last month. A conference committee will be appointed to work out differences. Bush administration opposes the House bill both because of its cost and the precedence set by passing legislation aimed at one specific disease. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., likened AIDS to natural disasters that have prompted Congress to appropriate money to local governments. ``This bill says to cities like New York, which has 25 percent of the total AIDS cases in the country, that we understand your problem ... (and) we are going to help,'' Schumer said. ``Hospitals are collapsing with the financial burden placed on them (by AIDS.)'' The House bill authorizes $400 million in each of the next five fiscal years for grants to provide a variety of AIDS preventative health services. Half the money would go to state governments, and the rest directly to health care facilities. It authorizes another $275 million a year for two years and ``such sums as may be necessary'' for the next three fiscal years to go directly to cities with the largest number of AIDS cases. Besides New York, other cities expected to receive emergency grants under the bill are: Atlanta; Boston; Chicago; Dallas; Houston; Jersey City, N.J.; Los Angeles; Miami; Newark; Philadelphia; San Diego; San Francisco; San Juan, Puerto Rico; and Washington, D.C. The bill authorizes smaller amounts for a series of other AIDS projects, including $20 million a year for research into helping pediatric patients and state grants to buy drugs for treatment of AIDS and related conditions. The House adopted amendments that scaled back the estimated five-year cost of the bill from $4.6 billion to about $4 billion, as estimated by the Congressional Budget Office. However, it rejected amendments that would have required states to test all citizens annually for the AIDS virus, and that would have required institutions that test for the virus to report to state health authorities anyone who tests positive. ``The bill's narrow disease-specific approach sets a dangerous precedent, inviting treatment of other diseases through similar ad hoc arrangements,'' the White House Office of Management and Budget said in a written statement. ``This approach also runs counter to the government's existing health care financing system, which will provide more than $870 million in federal Medicaid payments for HIV disease in 1991,'' it said. The administration statement said the bill's cost was excessive and doesn't target funds to the needy. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from infected pregnant women to their offspring. The 14 members voting against the bill, all Republicans, were: Philip Crane, R-Ill.; John Duncan Jr., R-Tenn.; Mickey Edwards, R-Okla.; Mel Hancock, R-Mo.; Clyde Holloway, R-La.; Duncan Hunter, R-Calif.; Jon Kyl and Bob Stump of Arizona; Ron Marlenee, R-Mont.; Carl Pursell, R-Mich.; Dan Schaefer, R-Colo.; Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y.; and Robert Walker and George Gekas of Pennsylvania. Ten congressmen did not vote. They were: Reps. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn.; Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif.; Joseph Kennedy, D-Mass.; New York Democrats John LaFalce and Charles Rangel; Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa; Romano Mazzoli, D-Ky.; Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill.; and Denny Smith, R-Ore. There are two vacancies in the House, and the speaker traditionally does not vote.

DOC.HEAD: White House Lauds Soviets on Easing Lithuania Blockade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with details of blockade easing, D'Amato, Mitchell quotes, subbing 7 grafs for grafs 6-10 pvs, After Bush ... photo session.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The White House on Wednesday applauded Moscow's decision to ease its economic blockade against Lithuania, and President Bush said he hoped the Soviet Union was beginning to defuse the crisis over the Baltic republics. Bush said it was ``good news'' that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had met Tuesday with the leaders of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which are trying to break away from the Kremlin's control. ``I hope that what we saw yesterday is a first step in a dialogue that will lead to the self-determination that we strongly support,'' Bush said at a news conference. He said the United States hopes for a ``peaceful resolution of this confrontation, one that will result in dialogue, negotiation ... in lifting of this economic blockade against Lithuania.'' The economic sanctions, imposed two months ago to break Lithuania's drive for independence, have been a stumbling block in U.S.-Soviet relations. After Bush spoke, the White House received news of an easing of Moscow's pressure on Lithuania. ``It's encouraging,'' said Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene was told by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov that 15 percent of the republic's natural gas needs would be restored, Rita Dapkus, a parliamentary spokeswoman, said. Ryzhkov made no promises on restoring other supplies, Ms. Dapkus said. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We welcome this announcement. Together with the beginning of the dialogue yesterday, these are positive steps.'' However, Sen. lfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., blasted Moscow. ``I think 15 percent is a slap in the face; you're trifling with people,'' he said. ``The embargo remains in place.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said, ``I am hopeful that the Soviet Union will lift its economic blockade against Lithuania and I welcome Soviet steps toward that end.
