Both sides should exert every effort to ensure that negotiations are conducted in an equitable and respectful manner.'' Bush declined to comment on the eported easing of economic pressure when questioned during an afternoon photo session. Earlier, Bush opened a news conference with regional reporters by praising Gorbachev's meeting with the Baltic leaders. He said it was a ``significant change that's occurred in the Soviet Union.'' He said, ``I don't want to overstate it but I was very, very pleased to see this occur in the wake of our _ what I think was a successful summit meeting.'' Reporters diverted the news conference to other subjects, and did not ask Bush any questions about Gorbachev and Lithuania. Two environmental subjects _ offshore oil drilling and the fate of the northern spotted owl _ were addressed by Bush. He said the long-delayed decision on restricting oil drilling off the coasts of Florida and California would be made within days. Bush said he wanted to make sure he had all the information he needs. ``We're still getting opinions,'' the president said. ``It's a very hot item, as you know.'' Bush said that protection of the northern spotted owl under the Endangered Species Act left him ``very much concerned about the potential loss of jobs.'' Vast tracts of forest would be shut to timber operations if the owl is deemed endangered, and the president said the law gives the administration ``very limited control'' in making such a determination. On other subjects, Bush said: _The Soviet Union should stop subsidizing the government of Cuba, which he said receives $5 billion a year. ``If that totalitarian and brutal society were not propped up by an enormous subsidy from the Soviet Union, I have every reason to believe that Cuban people would have a right to achieve the freedom that other countries have achieved.'' _The United States will not normalize relations with Iran until ``all of our hostages are out'' of Lebanon. Six Americans remain captive. On a related question, Bush said ``we aren't sure where the guilt lies'' in the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 that killed 270 people in December, 1988. _He was concerned about the financial problems suffered by Greyhound but said the problem of supplying transportation to rural American should be resolved by supply and demand, not federal intervention. One questioner said Bush's son Neil had contributed to the loss of $106 million by taxpayers through his involvement with a failed savings and loan and asked how the son should make restitution, Bush said, ``I don't accept your premise at all and I don't think the Congress does, either.'' Neil Bush was on the board of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver from October 1985 to August 1988. The Office of Thrift Supervision alleges that loans from Silverado to Bush's business partners were a conflict of interest for him. He has denied wrongdoing and is contesting an effort by the thrift office to discipline him. Silverado collapsed in December 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Police, Security Forces Accused of Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: A prominent U.S. monitoring group says police and members of the security forces are responsible for most human rights violations in Mexico, the official news agency Notimex said. Americas Watch said in a report made public Wednesday that the war on drugs is often used as a pretext for murder, torture and extortion. It said the special anti-narcotics division of the federal judicial police has one of the worst rights records, especially in the northern states of Sinaloa, Durango and Chihuahua. A spokesman for the Mexican Attorney General's office said Tuesday night it had no comment on the report, copies of which were released early. The federal judicial police are an arm of the attorney general's office. Americas Watch said that police and security force corruption and violence threaten Mexico's national security. The 115-page report, ``Human Rights in Mexico: A Policy of Impunity,'' also said some rights violations are political. It said labor strife, election disputes and land battles, which often pit the party that has ruled Mexico for 61 years against its opponents, have spawned assassinations, disappearances and illegal detentions. Americas Watch cited the cases of several journalists who have been murdered and said some of its informants had received threats from police officers. The report by the New York-based group criticizes the United States for ignoring Mexico's poor record on human rights. It blamed the indifference on a desire for cordial relations with Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President's Biblical Reference Angers Arabs
DOC.TEXT: The Arab League expressed anger Wednesday at Vice President Dan Quayle for calling Israeli-occupied lands ``Judea and Samaria,'' the Biblical names used by Israeli nationalists seeking to rule those territories. In a speech Monday to the annual convention of the American-Israel Public Affairs Committee, a major pro-Israel lobbying group, Quayle described two trips he took to Israel. On one, Quayle said, he was taken by helicopter to the West Bank of the Jordan River, an area which Israel captured from Jordan in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. ``From the hills of Judea and Samaria, you can see the land of Israel stretched out before you,'' Quayle said in his prepared remarks. He was referring to the strategic location of those hills, which command a view of Israel's most populated area and the Mediterranean Sea beyond. Israel cites the narrowness of the corridor between the hills and the Mediterranean as one reason why it needs to control the West Bank, whose Palestinian population wants independence from Israeli and Jordanian control. Clovis Maksoud, the ambassador of the 21-nation Arab League, said he had asked President Bush to clarify Quayle's remarks. Maksoud said he had asked whether the Bush administration now accepts the definitions of Israeli hardliners, such as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, for the occupied territories. U.S. officials generally refer to the West Bank, as well as to the Gaza strip which Israel captured from Egypt in 1967, as the occupied territories. The United States does not recognize Israeli sovereignty over those lands and urges negotiations on their future. It views Jewish settlements in those areas as an obstacle to peace. ``There has been no change in policy,'' said Quayle's spokesman, David Beckwith. ``The vice president was just using the Biblical names of those hills.'' ``If the U.S. administration is to hold the PLO responsible for any and all statements and actions by its representatives, we also hold the Bush administration responsible for statements made by its vice president,'' Maksoud said. The administration has demanded the Palestine Liberation Organization condemn an aborted May 30 raid by one of its factions on Israel's coast.

DOC.HEAD: Rap Obscenity: 2 Live Crew Prosecution A Case of Racism?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 6th graf, `Leland noted ...'
DOC.TEXT: The rapper says it's racism and the sheriff swears it isn't _ but the obscenity crackdown on 2 Live Crew is sparking a national debate about selective prosecution. ``This has nothing to do with racial overtones of any kind,'' said Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro, whose deputies have arrested two members of the rap group and a record-store owner on obscenity charges in connection with the album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' A third member, Mark Ross, was served with court papers Wednesday. The group, which was taping talk show appearances in New York, also has come under fire by authorities in Texas and Georgia. ``It's just an attack on my company and on me as a black guy,'' said 2 Live Crew's leader, Luther Campbell, who also owns the Miami-based group's record label. ``I think the role that race plays is really indirect and it might work in any number of ways,'' said John Leland, music critic for Newsday in New York. He was an expert witness at the federal trial in Fort Lauderdale that resulted in last week's obscenity declaration by U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez. Leland noted there were no complaints about the Crew's music until the group's first pop radio hit, ``Me So Horny,'' which brought them to the attention of mainstream audiences last fall. The sexually explicit album is the group's third. ``In order for something to be declared obscene it has to be declared lacking in serious artistic value,'' the critic said Wednesday. ``I think that what you have with 2 Live Crew is really a new art form that presents all sorts of creative possiblities that people who aren't sympathetic to the music aren't able to understand.'' He said the lack of understanding cuts across age lines as well as racial ones. ``Part of the reason 2 Live Crew has been singled out and persecuted is because they're relatively powerless,'' said Robyn Blumner, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Florida. ``This is an independent record company which is disaffected in part from the record industry establishment, so they're an easy target. Part of that is because they're a minority business.'' Leland agreed. ``The popular music industry left Luther Campbell and 2 Live Crew out to hang,'' the critic said. The group's raps have been criticized for sexist, prurient and violent references. Members of the black group and some of its supporters maintain that the songs spring from life as they've known it on inner-city streets. ``They're expressing resentment, they're expressing anger, fear _ emotions that are projections of their own culture,'' said Peter Thall, a New York attorney who represents entertainment figures. ``All artists write out of their experiences,'' said University of Florida media law professor Colleen Sullivan, who is writing a book on rock lyrics and the First Amendment. ``I think it's appalling that this is their experience.'' Navarro says his department has had no other complaints about the group, not even since last week's ruling, whose effects is limited to three south Florida counties. But in San Antonio, Texas, police this week began notifying 84 record stores that the lyrics of ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' are obscene, said vice squad commander Lt. Jerry Pittman. Police said no arests would be made for at least five days, but stores have begun removing the albums. In Gwinnett County, Ga., Police Chief Wayne Bolden said Wednesday he and about 15 officers will monitor two Thursday concerts by the group. ``(They're) talking about arresting us, the club owner and the managers,'' said Chris Lyons, one of the promoters. ``I don't think Gwinnett wants to fool with this. It's bordering on racism. ``Look at all the rock groups who get away with (slurs) of homosexuals and immigrants,'' Lyons said, ``and nobody says anything about that.''

DOC.HEAD: House Appropriations Committee Gives Super Collider '91 Funds
DOC.TEXT: The House Appropriations Committee on Wednesday approved the entire $318 million recommended by President Bush for the super collider particle accelerator. The money is contained in a $20.9 billion appropriations bill for federal energy and water projects in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 that should reach the House floor next week. The measure passed the committee on a voice vote with little discussion. The Energy Department is expected to make another estimate of the collider's cost, now put at $8 billion, later this summer. The House has voted to limit the federal share to $5 billion, and the department is seeking foreign contributions. The collider will be a 54-mile underground tunnel south of Dallas where proton beams are smashed into each other to probe the secrets of matter at 20 times the energy possible today.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney: U.S. Hid List of Secret Noriega Files
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf: `Jon May ...,' with two grafs to INCLUDE hearing on legal fees. Picks up 13th graf pvs: `The disputed ...
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government has illegally hidden from Manuel Noriega's lawyers thousands of secret intelligence documents seized in Panama, a defense attorney charged Wednesday. A five-page list found by a private investigator shows that during the U.S. invasion in December, the Army confiscated dozens of file cabinets, said Michael O'Kane, attorney for Noriega co-defendant Daniel Miranda. O'Kane said the file cabinets contained Panamanian G-2 intelligence files, weapons import-export records, confidential correspondence and files on Noriega foes who plotted a coup. The list is far more extensive than an inventory turned over to the defense by the U.S. attorney's office, O'Kane said. ``This (government) inventory is a fabrication,'' O'Kane said before he filed a motion Wednesday in federal court to force the government to hand over a revised list. He called the government inventory ``a coverup effectuated in Panama by unknown elements within the government of the United States.'' Noriega is being held on drug-smuggling charges. Attorneys for the ousted Panamanian dictator have insisted that many of his activities were sanctioned by the United States. They have said that U.S. and Panamanian intelligence records would show he cooperated with the CIA and the Drug Enforcement Administration. The prosecution's shortened list violates an order by U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff for the government to provide the defense with a complete list of documents seized during the invasion, O'Kane said. O'Kane said there was no indication the U.S. attorney's office in Miami knew its list was sanitized. He said prosecutors also may have been misled by U.S. officials in Washington or Panama. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the prosecutor's office, said she would not have any immediate comment on the motion. Jon May, an attorney for Noriega, said the general's defense was eager to examine the lists and documents when the question of their fees is resolved. The defense attorneys say the government must free Noriega's frozen funds to provide adequate resources for his defense. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler has scheduled a hearing for June 20 on the question of Noriega's legal fees. The disputed records are in the custody of the U.S. Southern Command's 470th Military Intelligence Group at a warehouse in Corozal, Panama. O'Kane said he sent a private investigator to the warehouse to rummage through boxes of documents listed by the government. ``We found wadded up in one of the boxes as garbage what we think is the real inventory,'' O'Kane said. The five-page list submitted with the motion included about 40 items taken to the warehouse. Most of the items were file cabinets apparently packed with secret documents, he said. ``The government inventory lists only one file cabinet,'' O'Kane said. He said it appeared some of the documents _ such as records of a coup attempt and Panamanian Defense Force payroll records _ were removed from the cabinets and submitted in a pile of evidence to the defense team. The defense never heard of thousands of other documents, however, he said. A file cabinet containing ``G-2 target files'' and another with ``G-2 interrogation detention reports'' were listed on the wadded-up inventory, but missing from the official government version, he said. Also missing were records of cabinets that included files of arms import-export and explosives companies, although the defense did get separate records of Israeli arms sales to Panama, O'Kane said. The attorney said many of the missing documents appeared to be essential records, not marginal items. ``From the label it seems these are sensitive things,'' O'Kane said. O'Kane's client, Miranda, is out on bond on charges of helping to fly drug money from Fort Lauderdale to Panama. If convicted, he could be sentenced to five years in prison. Noriega, confined at the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami, faces up to 145 years in prison if convicted of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a safe haven for U.S.-bound drugs.

DOC.HEAD: RTC Preparing For Second Property Sale
With AM-S&L Bailout
DOC.TEXT: The government is offering personalized computer lists of properties as it begins the second phase of its campaign to sell repossessed savings and loan real estate. Beginning Thursday, the Resolution Trust Corp. will accept offers on 35,908 properties valued originally at $14.9 billion. More than half the properties _ 19,067 with a value of $10.2 billion _ are in Texas. The rest are scattered through 45 other states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. The RTC, set up by the government to oversee the restructuring of troubled savings and loan associations is offering mostly residential parcels _ 29,977 propertlso listing 232 pieces of land and 5,699 commercial properties. ``We have everything available from a $15,000 pool hall in Houston to uranium mines,'' saies. But it is aid Lamar C. Kelly Jr., RTC director of asset and real estate management. The inventory being released Thursday is current through March 31. In January, RTC released its first list of 30,123 properties, current through Sept. 30. The agency has sold 13,200 of those, leaving about 17,000 to be carried over to its new list. The first list generated a huge response. The agency sold 180,000 sets of the bulky volumes. Kelly said RTC hopes a new marketing strategy computers can order CD ROM diskettes, magnetic tapes or floppy disks. Or they can tap into the RTC's main frame computer, 24-hours a day. Information on the computer versions of the inventory is available by calling 1-800-RTC-2990. The stepped-up sales effort follows mounting criticism that the agency isn't selling S&L assets fast enough. RTC has intensified the closing and sale of failed S&Ls, handling 96 since the first of April. However, the ``resolutions'' have left the RTC with large amounts of problem loans and distressed real estate. On other fronts, RTC is preparing to auction commercial properties, each worth more than $1 million, via international satellite hookup. It also plans to begin ``bulk sales'' of diversified portfolios. Buyers would get a mixed bag of assets valued at $500 million or more. ``We're open for business,'' Kelly said. ``We don't have any more poor quality real estate. We have opportunity investments that haven't been priced properly in the past.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Tells European Parliament EC Must Maintain Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with restaurant brawls, EC to continue aid to apartheid victims. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto STR2
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's call for continued sanctions on South Africa drew applause Wednesday from the European Parliament, but his visit also prompted a brawl among parliamentary members in the chamber's restaurant. The black nationalist leader, on a tour of Europe and North America, said ``profound and irreversible changes'' had not yet occurred in South Africa despite recent moves toward reform. He said even a partial lifting of sanctions would be disastrous. ``We ... commend this parliament for the role it has played in the struggle to isolate apartheid South Africa,'' Mandela said. Mandela also told reporters the African National Congress needs ``money in buckets'' to continue its bid to end South Africa's racial segregation policy. Mandela is deputy president of the ANC and many parliamentarians decorated their desks with the ANC's black, green and yellow flag. But not all the 518 parliamentarians heard Mandela's 45-minute address. Absenteeism was highest on the assembly's right-of-center benches, notably the Liberals, the Conservatives and extreme rightists. French rightists and Belgian Socialist Jose Happart later came to blows and name-calling in the members-only restaurant over Mandela's visit. Witnesses said Happart was first spat at by Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of France's far right National Front, then hit by Bernard Antony, another French far rightist. They said Happart replied by kicking Antony in the groin. The incident began when Luxembourg Socialist Robert Krieps commented to a table of ultrarightists on their absence from the chamber when Mandela spoke. Happart said later that Krieps wondered aloud if Mandela's speech had not ruined their appetite. One witness, French Socialist Bernard Thareau, said Le Pen did not recognize Krieps and asked a guard to remove him. Thareau quoted Le Pen, not a frequent attender of the parliament's monthly sessions, as asking about Krieps, ``Who is that dog?'' Happart objected and called Le Pen names. Le Pen then spat twice at Happart, who returned to the table he shared with Krieps and others. Thareau said Antony then came over, demanding Krieps identify himself. He said Happart replied that both he and Krieps were parliamentarians, at which point Antony grabbed Happart by the collar and hit him. ``So I kicked him in the groin,'' Happart told reporters. Antony was said to be short of breath for a while, but finished his meal. Mandela, who was freed in February after 27 years in prison, begins his U.S. visit next week. He was convicted of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white-led government. In Brussels last month, President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa was hopeful the 12-nations European Community will soon end its sanctions because of the ``dynamic'' changes occurring in his country. EC foreign ministers will discuss the issue next week. The European Parliament, whose members are elected by voters in EC nations, has little day-to-day power. In 1986, the EC banned imports of iron, steel and gold coins from South Africa and also banned new investments there. Since Mandela's release, Britain has unilaterally lifted the EC ban on new investment. The European Commission _ the European Community's independent executive with powers of proposal _ on Wednesday asked the EC to maintain and increase its program of aid to victims of apartheid in South Africa, but to adapt it to the changes now taking place there. The EC has spent $117.6 million on the program since it began in 1986. The Commission proposed to spend $50.8 million on it next year.

DOC.HEAD: Eighteen Tons Of Chicken Roll Recalled
DOC.TEXT: Charlie's Meat Products of Amarillo, Texas, is recalling 18 tons of deli-sliced chicken roll from three southwestern states because it may be contaminated with food poisoning organisms, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. The recall involves 36,000 pounds of ``Charlie's Country Smokehouse German Brand Breast of Chicken,'' officials said. The chicken roll is carried by ABCO and Safeway stores in Arizona, Homeland stores in Oklahoma, Kroger in Dallas and Fort Worth, Texas, and Homeland and Tom Thumb stores in Texas. Ronald J. Prucha, associate administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said no one is reported to have gotten sick but that consumers who may have bought the product should check with the store and return it if necessary. The problem was discovered by a USDA compliance officer who noticed ``a swollen package of the product on display at a supermarket deli counter in Cedar Hills, Texas,'' the agency said. ``Fifty cases subsequently examined in several stores and warehouses, all contained swollen product.'' Agency spokesman Jim Greene said tests had not been completed to identify the suspected organisms in the product. The chicken roll is sold to the stores in 7{-lb. plastic packages carrying the establishment number ``EST. 13301'' in the label's USDA inspection seal. The product is shipped in 15-lb. cartons containing two packages, the agency said. Consumers usually buy the product sliced at deli counters. Consumers with questions about the recall may call the toll-free USDA meat and poultry hotline at 1-800-535-4555 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EDT, Monday through Friday. Recorded information will be provided at other times. Callers in the Washington, D.C., area should call 447-3333.

DOC.HEAD: Sugar Consumption Expected to Outpace Production
DOC.TEXT: World sugar production in 1990-91 is expected to fall short of consumption for the sixth consecutive year, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Production for the year that will begin Sept. 1 was forecast at 107.2 million metric tons, raw value, the report said. That would be up from 1989-90 output, estimated in March at 105.2 million tons. But global sugar use in the coming year is expected to total 109.5 million tons, exceeding production by 2.3 million tons and indicating another draw-down of stockpiles. ``The fastest (consumption) growth is among the populous developing countries,''' the report said. ``India, China, Indonesia, Brazil and Mexico will account for 30 percent of global consumption, compared with 24 percent 10 years earlier.'' World sugar prices are ``relatively firm'' at this point, averaging 15.2 cents per pound in April, 14.6 cents in May and 13.5 cents in the first eight marketing days of June, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Ambassadors To Uruguay And Mozambique
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday selected new U.S. ambassadors for Uruguay and Mozambique. He announced his intention to nominate Richard C. Brown, 50, a career diplomat, to the South American post. He is currently special advisor for international security at the Defense Department and is a former deputy chief of mission at the American Embassy in Montevideo, Uruguay. He would succeed Malcolm Richard Wilkey. Bush announced he would nominate career diplomat Townsend B. Friedman Jr., 50, as ambassador to Mozambique, succeeding Melissa Foelsch Wells. Since 1987, Friedman has served as director of Southern European affairs at the State Department.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Asks $5 Billion to Stem Drug Use in Families
DOC.TEXT: The nation should pump $5 billion over the next five years into social services to stem drug abuse among pregnant women and to keep families in crisis from falling apart, a congressman said Wednesday. ``We cannot allow the budget crisis to overwhelm the crisis of America's families,'' said Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., acting chairman of the House Ways and Means human resources subcommittee. Downey said his Family Preservation Act, introduced with several co-sponsors, would build on existing programs to prevent drug abuse among pregnant women, help ``boarder babies'' left in hospitals by crack-addicted mothers and expand social services to help find ways to keep families together. He estimated it would cost $500 million the first year sounded undaunted by the intense competition over scarce federal funds. The timing of the bill, he said, was intended to take advantage of upcoming budget talks between congressional leaders and the Bush administration, to ensure that if taxes are increased, the money will not be used just to defray the budget deficit. The Bush administration's budget to fund the National Drug Control Strategy calls for about $350 million for prevention and treatment for pregnant women who use drugs and for their children, said Daryl Kade of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. Legislation co-sponsor Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., said the bill responds to problems unanticipated 10 years ago, such as widespread drug use, AIDS, child abuse and neglect, that ``have come together to overwhelm the child welfare system, to overwhelm the foster care and adoption system in this country.'' The announcement of the legislation coincided with the release of a congressional study requested by Downey called, ``The Enemy Within: Crack-Cocaine and America's Families.'' The report compiles findings of previously reported studies and notes that: _An estimated 375,000 children born each year are exposed to some drug while in the womb. _More than 100,000 cocaine-exposed babies were born in 1988 and studies have said that number could reach 500,000 to 4 million by the year 2000. _About 360,000 children were placed in foster care in 1989, a 29 percent increase over 1986, with the largest increases in cities hit hardest by crack. _Despite the publicity over boarder babies, the problem ``may not be as severe as the media coverage would indicate,'' affecting only certain hospitals in certain cities. In addition, studies have found that many mothers remain in contact with their children and are prevented by authorities from taking them home.

DOC.HEAD: Flag-Burning Amendment Clears First House Hurdle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead
DOC.TEXT: Reluctant Democrats pushed a constitutional amendment against flag burning past its first congressional hurdle Wednesday, just two days after the Supreme Court threw out the federal flag-protection law. Rep. Robert W. Kastenmeier, D-Wis., complained, ``It's unseemly that we're rushing to judgment'' as the proposed amendment whisked though the House Constitutional and Civil Rights Subcommittee. Supporters of the amendment called the flag a symbol of ``all that America stands for'' and deserving of special protection, while critics said that the plan would ``mutilate the Bill of Rights'' and the entire issue smacked of election-year politics. Both sides said if the House were to vote today on the amendment it would be close. The proposal would have to win two-thirds majorities in both houses and approval by 38 state legislatures to take effect. Wednesday's subcommittee session re-launched, in a fiery burst of congressional rhetoric, the proposed amendment that was set aside last year as Congress passed the statute overturned by the Supreme Court on Monday. The House panel voted 5-3 to send the measure to the full Judiciary Committee with an ``adverse'' recommendation _ a symbolic dark cloud that will have no effect on its chances of eventually being adopted. The three Republicans on the subcommittee, all of whom favor the amendment, voted no on the roll call because they wanted a ``favorable'' recommendation. ``You don't see that very often,'' said panel chairman Don Edwards, D-Calif., an outspoken critic of the plan. President Bush passed up a chance to restate the vigorous support of an amendment that he voiced on Monday _ after the court ruling _ and again on Tuesday. But his wife Barbara endorsed his views on the subject, saying ``You're darn right, I'm always with the president.'' Bush himself addressed a number of topics with a group of reporters but didn't bring up the flag. Retired Supreme Court Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, who often has cautioned against adding amendments to the Constitution, declined to give advice to his former colleagues or anyone else on the subject as he appeared with Mrs. Bush on the White House lawn along with students who won a poster contest honoring the Constitution. ``Retired justices shouldn't have any thoughts as to what present justices should do,'' Burger said. At the House subcommittee, supporters and critics alike said the final decision would be made on the House floor, most likely before lawmakers go on recess at the end of the month and perhaps much sooner. ``I don't think its going to be an overwhelming vote, but we will get the two-thirds,'' said Rep. James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., the ranking minority member of the panel. Edwards merely said it would be ``very close.'' The amendment would allow the federal government and the states to pass laws outlawing burning or other mutilation of the flag. The Supreme Court threw out last year's statute barring flag mutilation, saying it violated the right to free speech. Bush had urged a constitutional amendment last year and renewed that call after the court rejected the statute on a 5-4 vote. The first planned Senate action is a Judiciary Committee session tentatively set for June 21. Edwards was asked if Democratic critics of the measure were hurrying it to the floor before veterans groups and conservative organizations could mount lobbying campaigns. ``We ought to get it behind us so we can go on with the country's business,'' he replied. He said he was in the Navy in World War II and ``a lot of my friends were killed and I feel very strongly about it.'' He told of passing out copies of the Constitution to students in Prague on a recent trip and how eagerly those young people snatched up the document. ``I hate to think that I'd have to stand before the same students and say, yes, here's the Bill of Rights, but we've just weakened it, we've just mutilated it,'' Edwards declared. Sensenbrenner said, ``We all love the flag, we all love the Constitution, we all love the Bill of Rights.'' He scoffed at complaints about the amendment, saying, ``I don't believe it to be the outrageous attack on free speech that its opponents believe it to be.'' ``It doesn't restrict anyone from saying anything they want to say about an issue, about a public official, about a candidate for office,'' he said. Rep. Craig James, R-Fla., said the flag deserves special protection. ``The flag represents all that America stands for, it embodies all the America means,'' he said. But Rep. Pat Schroeder, D-Colo., said, ``For 200 years as a nation we have been mature enough to bite our lip when we saw flag burnings and cross burnings. ... One of the first things Hitler did was make flag burning a crime in Nazi Germany.'' Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., said that there was ``no line I know of anywhere in the United States waiting to burn the flag.'' ``This is about the politics of reelection, this is about the politics of hypocrisy, this is about manipulation of this symbol for political advantage.''

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Says Global Corn Prices Causing Concern
DOC.TEXT: There is growing uneasiness about global prices of corn and other coarse grains because of wet spring weather in the United States, an Agriculture Department report said Wednesday. ``While the outlook for the 1990 world wheat crop continues to be generally favorable, heavy rains across the major corn-growing areas of the United States have delayed corn planting,'' the report said. That is ``causing concern in the marketplace about prospects for the 1990 U.S. crop and _ because of the United States' dominance _ the world's coarse grain price outlook as well,'' the report said. In addition, analysts said there had been ``rather strong late-season import demand'' for coarse grains that ``will result in a large drawdown in world coarse grain stocks'' during the remainder of the 1989-90 season. On Tuesday, the USDA projected 1990 corn production at 8.1 billion bushels, up from 7.53 billion bushels harvested last year. Despite the increase in production, total exports and domestic use are even larger, meaning that the nation's stockpile will dwindle further in 1990-91. Also, the projections are highly tentative and were based on yield trends and planting indications derived from March surveys. Wet weather, however, has delayed spring planting and prompted concern about reduced yields and acreages. The department's first official corn estimate won't be released until Aug. 9, along with prospects for soybeans, sorghum, cotton and other 1990 spring-planted crops. Looking further at the global coarse grain situation, which includes sorghum, barley and rye as well as corn, the report said ``shifting trade patterns'' are beginning to affect the outlook for the 1990-91 marketing year. ``Crop shortfalls, especially in Brazil, are already influencing import patterns,'' the report said. ``In addition, foreign exportable supplies will be limited until new-crop output is available for export.'' Thus, it said, there will be continued greater reliance on the United States for coarse grain, particularly as the 1990 crops develop. According to the projections, corn prices at the farm may average in the range of $2.35 to $2.75 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year that begins Sept. 1. Prices in the current season are forecast to average $2.35 to $2.40 per bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher of Charleston Daily Mail Is Named
DOC.TEXT: Terry L. Horne, publisher of the Bluefield (W.Va.) Daily Telegraph, has been named publisher of the Charleston Daily Mail. Horne succeeds John F. McGee, who is retiring. Horne, 39, was appointed Monday. He has been publisher at Bluefield since January 1988. He is a native of Enid, Okla., and holds a bachelor's degree in journalism from Wichita State University and a master's degree in mass communications from Oklahoma State University. He formerly was co-owner, editor and publisher of the Atchison (Kan.) Daily Globe. He also worked for The Wichita Eagle-Beacon. McGee, 67, has been an executive of the Charleston Daily Mail since 1970. He remains as a director and a consultant to Thomson Newspapers Inc., which owns the Daily Mail and the Bluefield Daily Telegraph. McGee was an executive of the News & Courier-Post of Charleston, S.C., before becoming president and chief operating officer of The State-Record Co. of Columbia, S.C. He also served as president of Clay Communications of Charleston when it owned the Charleston Daily Mail. In 1987, Clay Communications sold its newspapers to Lincoln Publishing Inc. of Des Plaines, Ill., a subsidiary of Thomson Newspapers. McGee is a former director of The Associated Press, the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association and the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Officials Promise Faster Action on Great Lakes Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: A Bush administration official acknowledged Wednesday that Great Lakes cleanup programs have lagged and promised to quicken the pace. Skeptical senators said they had heard it all before. F. Henry Habicht II, deputy administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said a heavy workload and the complexity of developing and implementing cleanup programs for the polluted lakes were chiefly to blame for the lack of progress. ``We have to develop a long-term strategy that is based on good science and investment,'' Habicht said. ``It's a big undertaking.'' He told the Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management that the Bush administration opposes writing into law deadlines for getting cleanup initiatives under way. ``We do want to set goals for ourselves, but sometimes deadlines can have us focus on areas that may not be the top priority'' of agency experts, Habicht said. ``Our experience indicates that codifying deadlines does not assure high quality results and raises unreasonable public expectations.'' Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., the subcommittee chairman, said deadlines were necessary because of EPA's lack of progress in implementing the 1987 Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement between the United States and Canada. Levin is a sponsor of pending legislation that would set deadlines for the EPA to complete cleanup plans for 42 polluted areas of the lakes. The provisions are part of a comprehensive coastal protection bill that cleared the Environment and Public Works Committee on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Raunchy Rappers Meet Geraldo and Phil
With AM-2 Live Crew-Race, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: They're forbidden in Florida and taboo in Texas, but the leader of the 2 Live Crew was welcomed Wednesday for a fiery, foul-mouthed defense of their salacious million-selling album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' Luther Campbell, the front man for the Florida band, first went on the offensive during a taping of the ``Geraldo'' show. The rapper cursed at the sheriff who arrested him and questioned the credentials of the sheriff's legal adviser. ``He hasn't given more to the black community than I have,'' Campbell said of the adviser, then ripped into Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro, who was also on the show. He then headed from the Times Square taping to Rockefeller Center for a live bit on the syndicated ``Donahue'' show, where he was joined by previously censored performers Jello Biafra and Wendy O. Williams. ``I'm a little sick of the system,'' said Williams, who once wore only electrical tape above her waist at a show. ``What are we going to do next? What's Luther going to do next? What's Jello going to do?'' Campbell kept it clean for ``Donahue,'' although Bob DeMoss _ director of the conservative Focus on Family _ stunned Phil with an expletive that was heard in some markets where the show is broadcast live. ``I'd like to keep this job,'' Donahue said in asking his guests to calm down. DeMoss, sitting sheepishly, later apologized. The two TV appearances should keep fueling sales of ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' which are fast approaching the 2 million mark. A federal judge in Florida last week declared the album obscene. His jurisdiction is limited to three south Florida counties. San Antonio store owners pulled the record from shelves this week after they were threatened with arrest. Campbell's outburst will have ``Geraldo'' censors scurrying. He used, in several forms, one of the more popular obscenities from his album. Campbell also referred a half-dozen times to a song by rappers NWA that uses the same word. ``It will definitely be our most bleeped show ever. No question,'' said Jeff Erdel, the publicist for the show. Campbell and two other members of the band were arrested Sunday following a live show at a Florida club. While the judge has called the Crew's album obscene, Campbell and his supporters claim First Amendment protection and suggest they are victims of racism. ``A white man can say anything. How about Dice Clay?'' Campbell asked of comedian Andrew Dice Clay, whose material has been criticized for slurs against women and gays. Navarro denied the racism charges, as he has done repeatedly since the arrests. ``I'm not after anybody because of race,'' Navarro said. Luther didn't limit his anger to Geraldo Rivera's show; he brought a bit along for Phil, too. Campbell became involved in a shouting match with John Thompson, a Coral Gables, Fla., lawyer who helped lead the fight against 2 Live Crew. ``He's going to be disbarred because he's crazy. ... Why'd you single us out, man? Why don't you talk about other groups, man?'' Campbell shouted at Thompson.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Persuades Rail Workers to Accept Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa on Wednesday persuaded railroad workers in northwest Poland to accept a settlement in a pay dispute that prompted a weeklong strike in May. The workers agreed May 28 to end a weeklong strike that shut down Poland's Baltic ports after Walesa promised to help them achieve their demands. In talks between the Solidarity labor union, the Labor Ministry and the management of the state-owned railroads, the union won a $19-a-month pay increase, a significant raise for the workers who averaged about $79 per month. The workers had demanded a larger increase but approved Walesa's arrangement Wednesday. In Warsaw, officials said the raise had been planned and did not represent a retreat from the government's pledge not to increase pay under pressure of strikes. ``One should not treat it as a government concession,'' said Marek Dabrowski, deputy finance minister, at a news conference. Government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska added: ``It should not arouse hope that one can demand salary increases by means of strikes.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Believe Mussels Clean Polluted Water, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Could it be that the hated zebra mussel isn't all bad? Soviet scientists apparently think so, says an Environmental Protection Agency official who is planning to visit Moscow next month in search of ideas for battling the tiny mollusks. Officials are frantically searching for a way to prevent infestation of the Great Lakes by the pesky mussels, with their zebra-like stripes. Valdas V. Adamkus, the EPA's national program manager for the Great Lakes, said Wednesday he had received some papers from Soviet scientists who earlier notified him they had developed a biological method of attacking the pest. Zebra mussels breed rapidly and attach themselves to municipal water intake pipes. Much to his surprise, however, the papers said nothing about ways to eradicate the mussel, Adamkus said. Instead, they described the creature as useful because it can help control water pollution. ``They proved through their scientific work that zebra mussels can be a cleansing agent,'' he said. ``So instead of trying to reduce them, they are actually trying to ... increase their population. ``We were surprised,'' he said. ``We're trying to eliminate the zebra mussels and they are actually using them as an agent for purification of water.'' How the mussels could clean dirty water isn't clear, Adamkus said. But the report has made him all the more eager to visit the Soviet Union. ``I'm going to call on all the available scientists over there, meet with them, get any information or whatever scientific work or literature is available,'' he said. Last summer, the mussels clogged the water intake pipe of Monroe, Mich., restricting the flow through the 6,000-foot pipe by nearly 24 percent. Zebra mussels originated in Eastern Europe's freshwater seas and are believed to have entered the Great Lakes in the ballast water of oceangoing vessels. They showed up in Lake St. Clair in 1987 and rapidly infested Lake Erie. They have been spotted from Duluth, Minn., to New York. In a related development, the House Appropriations Committee voted Wednesday to spend $1 million for zebra mussel research at the Great Lakes Research Laboratory at Ann Arbor. Another $3 million for zebra mussel study was reserved, pending completion of legislation to authorize the Sea Grant program, said Rep. Bob Carr, D-Mich., a committee member. The panel also set aside $1.4 million to combat the sea lamprey, another Great Lakes pest.

DOC.HEAD: Former Northern Ireland Prime Minister Dead at 75
DOC.TEXT: Terence O'Neill, a former prime minister of Northern Ireland who attempted to reconcile Protestants and Roman Catholics in the 1960s, has died, the government said Wednesday. He was 75. O'Neill, who served as the province's prime minister from 1963-69, died Tuesday at his home in Lymington, Hampshire. Britain suspended Northern Ireland's parliament in 1972 in the the face of growing sectarian and political violence and instituted direct rule in 1973. O'Neill was named a lord in 1970, and spoke frequently in Britain's House of Lords on Northern Ireland. Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey said of O'Neill: ``He was a good man who meant well and, perhaps, if he had succeeded in the things he undertook, the whole course of events in Northern Ireland might have been different.'' Irish Deputy Prime Minister Brian Lenihan added: ``He will always be remembered as the Terence O'Neill in the 1960s who, with (Irish Prime Minister) Sean Lemass, initiated certain historic attempts at reconciliation between all Irish people.'' O'Neill was born on Sept. 10, 1914, into an aristocratic Anglo-Irish family. He fought with the Irish Guards during World War II and in 1946, entered Northern Ireland's parliament as a member of the predominantly Protestant Unionist Party. He succeeded Lord Brookeborough as prime minister in 1963. Soon after taking office, he introduced reforms aimed at accommodating the growing political aspirations of the Roman Catholic minority. He also worked to strengthen trade with Ireland. In January 1965, after a surprise visit by Irish Prime Minister Lemass to Parliament, angry Protestant extremists who opposed a rapprochment with the predominantly Catholic Irish Republic began an ``O'Neill Must Go'' campaign led by the Rev. Ian Paisley. In 1968, friction between Catholics and Protestants escalated into violent riots in Northern Ireland, convincing O'Neill of the need for reform. He faced opposition from his home secretary, William Craig, who demanded strong police action against civil rights demonstrators. O'Neill fired Craig and instituted a number of reforms to aid the Catholic community, including changes in local administration. Frustrated by critics who feared the loss of British sovereignty, O'Neill called a general election in February 1969. He managed to win leadership of his badly split party, but resigned two months later. Jack Lynch, Irish prime minister from 1966-73, described O'Neill as ``a man of courage and vision.'' ``It's a great pity that he was unable to bring the majority of his Cabinet along with him in his reforms. .... He clearly wanted to see the people of all Ireland, north and south, live in peace, friendship and economic well being,'' Lynch said. O'Neill is survived by a wife, the former Katherine Jean Whitaker, and a son and daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria Could Be World Bank Members by Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to RECAST; pickup graf 4 `World Bank....' INSERTS three grafs after 11th graf `A representative...' to UPDATE with World Bank granting Poland $300 million loan. Pickup pvs 12th graf `Conable also...'
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria have applied to belong to the World Bank and could become members of the U.N. loan fund by the fall, its president said Wednesday. World Bank President Barber Conable said he expected the two East bloc nations will ``doubtlessly be accepted by the time of the annual meeting,'' which is scheduled for late September in Washington. The World Bank, or International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, is a specialized agency of the United Nations set up to further economic development through guaranteed loans and to train member-state officials toward that end. World Bank officials meet annually with the International Monetary Fund. The IMF director, Michel Camdessus, said last month that he hoped Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia would become members of his organization this fall. Each of the World Bank's 153 members also belong to the IMF. The IMF promotes monetary cooperation, currency stabilization and trade expansion, and is charged with working out balance-of-payment difficulties in the international community. Conable, who attended an annual meeting of the Federation of West German Industries on Wednesday, met with West Germany's Minister for Economic Cooperation, Juergen Warnke, on Tuesday. He said Warnke told him that West Germany's plans for unification with East Germany haven't reduced the country's commitments to international development. Conable said the World Bank intends to actively take part in reconstruction of East European economies in support of democratic changes taking place there. He said the bank has earmarked $2.5 billion for economic development and environmental projects in Poland, and that an additional $5 billion was being made available in loans to Eastern Europe over the next three years. A representative office will be set up in Warsaw in July, Conable said. ``We're going to have a big program in Poland,'' he said. Also Wednesday, the World Bank and the Polish government reached agreement on a key $300 million loan to assist economic reform, a Polish finance ministry official said. The so-called ``structural adjustment loan'' provides not only funds but represents World Bank approval for the shock reform program undertaken by Poland's non-Communist government, Deputy Finance Minister Marek Dabrowski said. Final World Bank approval is anticipated by the end of August, Dabrowski. Conable also made general world debt problems a theme of his remarks. He said he hoped that the seven major industrialized country, the United States, Canada, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France and Italy, will decide on new ways to deal with world debt at their annual economic summit in Houston, Texas next month. ``No successful way of dealing with that has been found yet,'' the World Bank leader said. Another major issue at the Houston meeting includes funding to curtail ``environmental degradation,'' in the world, Conable said.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Arrested At Flag-Burning Rally
With AM-Flag Burning, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Scuffles erupted at a rally where American flags were burned to celebrate the U.S. Supreme Court ruling that overturned the federal flag-protection law. Police said 16 people were arrested. About 150 demonstrators and onlookers gathered for Tuesday night's hourlong rally at a post office, police said. About 20 counterdemonstrators waved Old Glory, sang the national anthem and chanted, ``No more burning.'' Officers ordered demonstrators to disperse after fights broke out, punches were thrown and some people were wrestled to the ground. ``I can't tell the fascists from the communists,'' said Gary Oules, 54, of Seattle, who had stopped to observe.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine President Irked his Marital Woes Now a Public Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Aides to President Carlos Menem said Wednesday the Argentina leader is uncomfortable that his marital strife has become a public scandal. Argentine newspapers gave more coverage Wednesday to Menem's decision to bar his wife from the presidential residence than to his shaky relations with the military; another devaluation of the austral; and even Argentina's World Cup soccer match against the Soviet Union. (Argentina won 2-0 Wednesday). ``Presidential Scandal,'' read the headline in Nuevo Sur. ``Marriage Crack!'' trumpeted Diario Popular. Pagina 12 changed its name on the front page to Radiolandia 12, a reference to a popular soap opera. Security guards refused to let Zulema Menem enter the 65-acre presidential compound in suburban Olivos on Tuesday. She didn't take that lightly. ``This is my home and that of my children,'' she told a crush of reporters and photographers. ``They are throwing out all of us.'' ``We're leaving because the president has thrown us out,'' son Carlos, 21, agreed. They angrily drove off with Zulema Eva, the Menems' 19-year-old daughter, to a private apartment Mrs. Menem maintains in the fashionable Recoleta neighborhood of Buenos Aires. The differences between Menem, 59, and his 46-year-old wife have been known for years _ they have lived apart for nearly half their 24-year marriage, each blaming the other for the long separations. ``Mrs. Menem wants to make a scandal and that is exactly what the president and we want to avoid,'' a presidential adviser _ not identified _ was quoted on Wednesday as telling the independent news agency Diarios y Noticias. Menem himself told the government news agency Telam, ``I love my family. I love my kids. But I'm not going to talk about a problem that has to do with my private life.'' Tuesday night, young Carlos appeared on a television talk show and said, ``It hurts me to lose my father.'' He added, ``This is even worse than a dictatorship. ... I'm going to fight it to the end.'' Mrs. Menem walked out of the presidential residence earlier this year, but returned days later. Menem walked out on May 8, returning _ alone _ for the first time Tuesday night. Mrs. Menem, whose family is wealthy, stood outside the presidential compound and complained, ``They didn't even let me take my things. I have only what I have on.'' Later, she issued a statement cautioning her husband to make sure her furniture and clothes are cared for. The children side with their mother and claim they also are barred from the compound. Menem, the former governor of the poor interior province of La Rioja, insists they can come and go as they please. Neither spouse has publicly taken steps to obtain a legal separation, or divorce _ which now is legal in this South American nation where Roman Catholicism is the state religion. Separation or divorce may soon take place. Justice Secretary Cesar Arias said Mrs. Menem apparently has consulted lawyers, and is ``reserving her rights in such a way it could be understood she could apply for a divorce.'' Menem became president last July.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Demonstrators Unblock Streets after Election Protest
LaserPhoto SOF1
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators tore down barricades that tied up traffic in downtown Sofia on Wednesday after an opposition leader said it was not the right way to protest election results favoring the former Communists. The leadership of the main opposition alliance _ the Union of Democratic Forces _ issued a statement asking that public order be maintained. It said such action as blocking main streets ``turns the citizens against the UDF.'' The 16-party UDF alliance trailed the governing Socialist Party, formerly the Communist Party, in Sunday's first-round voting for parliament _ Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years. Final results were expected Thursday, election officials said. Traffic halted in much of Sofia on Wednesday because of the barricades. UDF leader Zhelyu Zhelev appealed to protesters to unblock the streets and disperse, saying, ``Your reaction is not adequate to the situation. We ask you in the name of our political cause to remove the barricades.'' After about an hour the barricades came down and traffic resumed. Political analysts said it was still possible the opposition could gain a slight edge after second-round voting next Sunday, given the partial results from the first round and projections by West German and Bulgarian vote experts. Leaders of the UDF and of other opposition groups agreed to back each other's candidates in runoffs, to be held in 81 constituencies where no candidate received mpore than 50 percent of the vote. In other protest developments: _Television employees complained that state TV failed to accurately cover the elections and backed a student demand that the director of TV, Pavel Pisarev, resign, the state BTA news agency reported. Up to 300 people continued a protest near the TV station pressing demands for Pisarev's resignation. _Sofia University students kept up a sit-in strike begun Tuesday at the main university building, demanding publication of alleged electoral abuses. Exams were suspended as faculty joined students in demanding lifting of the ``news blackout,'' BTA said. It said students in at least three other cities supported the strike, as did the independent trade union Podkrepa. _Podkrepa asked its supporters to show their feelings about the elections ``by peaceful civic means ... by rallies, demonstrations and human chains.'' Bulgarian state radio reported demonstations in Yambol, Ruse, Veliko Tarnovo, Vratsa and Varna. BTA said about 30 people in Yambol went on a 24-hour hunger strike Tuesday. Varna protesters held up a banner declaring the Black Sea port ``A Zone Free of Communism.'' This was apparently a spinoff of the ``Communist Free Zone'' declared in University Square in Bucharest by anti-Communist protesters, who blockaded the square for 53 days before police roughly dispersed them early Wednesday. Half of Parliament's 400 seats are being filled by direct election, the other 200 based on the percentage of votes each party receives. The Socialists won 75 seats outright last Sunday, according to final results released Wednesday by the Central Election Commission. UDF candidates won 32 seats and the mostly ethnic-Turkish Movement for Rights and Freedoms won in nine, state radio reported. One seat went to an independent and one each to two small opposition parties. The Socialists apparently won easily in four of the 28 regional districts, and the UDF won in a fifth as well as in Sofia. Sunday's runoffs will mostly pit the Socialist Party against the UDF. The UDF favors more rapid reforms toward a Western-style market economy; the Socialists are more cautious. Some of the current leaders of the Socialist Party _ renamed from the Communist Party _ played a decisive role in ousting hard-line Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov last November and initiating reform.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped U.S. Miner May Not be Freed Because of Ransom Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with nine grafs to ADD quotes from Fino, father on how misunderstanding arose. Picks up graf 7 pvs, `This is...' Edits thereafter to trim
DOC.TEXT: A kidnapped U.S. gold miner may not be released because the $60,000 his family and community scraped together for what it thought was his ransom is only one-tenth what his captors are demanding. ``The last we know, the demand still stands at 350 million pesos, which is about $612,000,'' Jeffrey Fino, general manager of the IMINCO mining company in Ecuador that employed Scott Heimdal of Peoria, Ill., said Wednesday. Fino has been closely involved in negotiations with the Communist guerrillas who kidnapped the 27-year-old Heimdal in late April and took him to neighboring Colombia. He said the family had been under the impression if they paid $60,000, their son would be freed. However, the $60,000 that Heimdal's working-class family collected from community donations was money the guerrillas were demanding simply ``to guarantee his life,'' Fino said. The guerrillas have demanded the higher figure all along, said Fino, who added it was not clear how the family came to misunderstand the demand. The captive's father, Roy Heimdal, said Fino had not told him the guerrillas were demanding the higher amount, though they talked repeatedly. ``My understanding is the demand was brought down to $60,000,'' said Roy Heimdal. ``They said, `We want $60,000, or we will show you where the body is.'' He said he interpreted the threat to mean $60,000 would win freedom for their son. In comments Wednesday from Peoria, he also said there had been confusion throughout the negotiations and problems in translation. ``This is a complete surprise to me. It's just like a see-saw that keeps going up and down,'' Roy Heimdal said. His wife, Marge, said they could raise no more money for the guerrillas. ``We sold everything we had and had to get help from strangers to raise $60,000. We don't have anymore. I'm on the verge of losing my sanity.'' Fino, 39, said a meeting with rebels Monday where part of the $60,000 was delivered ended in failure. ``Their leader was not there. There were about eight guerrillas. There was no negotiator. They were yelling and screaming at our intermediary. Reaching an agreement is very difficult and dangerous under these circumstances.'' The guerrillas were upset because the go-between tried to deliver the payment in dollars instead of Colombian currency, even though they originally demanded dollars, Fino said. ``To make clear how irrational and unlogical these guys are, they told our intermediary to take the dollars from the middle of the jungle and be back within three hours with Colombian pesos or they were going to kill Scott. ``He had to get back in a canoe, go back to the little river port he had left from, grab a taxi and go into the main town of Lago Agrio. He cleaned out the town of pesos,'' Fino said. But there was not enough Colombian currency in Lago Agrio, a tiny Ecuadoran oil town 25 miles southwest of the rendezvous site, to make the full payment. The guerrillas set a date later this month for the balance of the payment. Fino would not reveal the date. ``At that time, we will demand Scott's release for that amount of money,'' he said. ``They need to understand that's all the money they're going to get.'' Heimdal had been working with IMINCO helping dredge river beds for gold deposits in the Ecuadoran jungle when he was abducted. Armed men wearing camouflage uniforms attacked a canoe Heimdal was aboard. The boat was traveling the Bermeja River in thick jungle about five miles from the Colombian border and 100 miles northeast of Quito. The boat's driver was killed in the attack. The attackers, who identified themselves as members of the People's Liberation Army, a Colombian guerrilla group, freed an Ecuadoran geology student also in the boat and sent him to Quito with the ransom demand. Fino described the latest contacts with the kidnappers in an interview in his one-room office in Quito, 9,300 feet high in the Andes. Spread across his desk were photos taken by the guerrillas at a camp inside Colombia. The photos showed Heimdal sitting in a hammock or beside a campfire beneath the jungle canopy. Close by were guerrillas pointing machine guns at him. He said in their first meeting the guerrillas demanded $1.5 million in ransom, ``then came down to $1.2 million in two minutes.'' ``We have been trying to convince them that they've got the wrong person,'' Fino said. ``The company is not wealthy. We have been running up a debt, not a profit. The family is not rich. ``They still believe there is money. If we could convince them that this $60,000 is all there is, we feel they would understand that and release Scott.'' Heimdal's friends in Peoria describe him as an adventurer. They say he saved up money from a job as a computer technician in Boston to go to South America. Heimdal, with IMINCO since October, operated electronic equipment that located gold deposits on the river bottom. He also was overseeing construction of a large dredge. Fino said he has received reports Heimdal was suffering from a problem with his feet and he thinks it most likely is an infection from flea bites. He sent in antibiotics and says the guerrillas promised to provide medical treatment for Heimdal. Fino says he remains distrustful of the kidnappers. ``One part of me is extremely optimistic,'' he said. ``But another part of me is extremely scared because these people are irrational. They're unpredictable. That makes them very dangerous.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Tells Israel to Call When It's Ready to Resume Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 14-17: ``Baker's public,'' with further reaction
DOC.TEXT: The United States will stop its efforts to set up Mideast peace talks unless Israel agrees to proceed without delay, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Wednesday. ``The phone number (for the White House switchboard) is 202-456-1414. When you're serious about this, call us,'' Baker said in comments directed to the Israeli government. Baker, testifying before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, urged the new government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to accept the U.S. plan for talks with Palestinians. Those talks could lead to elections among the 1.7 million Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. If the new government, which includes some of Israel's most hawkish politicians, puts unacceptable conditions for Palestinian participation in the talks, ``there won't be any dialogue, there won't be any peace,'' Baker said. The United States cannot get the talks going unless Israel shows willingness, he said. Meanwhile, Shamir and Foreign Minister David Levy said they wanted American guarantees that Israel would not have to speak to the Palestine Liberation Organization or discuss any Palestinian state in U.S.-proposed peace talks. ``Deal with us as allies. ... First we have to reach an agreement on these things, and then other things can certainly be achieved,'' Levy said at a ceremony in Jerusalem formally installing him as foreign minister. Baker's comments are expected to exacerbate tensions with the Israeli government, which already has embarked on a collision course with Washington by pledging to spend more on Jewish settlements in the occupied lands and by refusing to promise to refrain from settling Soviet Jews there. That issue will be raised in the next few weeks when the United States begins discussions with Israel about implementing a bill granting the Israelis $400 million in housing guarantees for the influx of Soviet Jews. Baker said he didn't know what assurances the administration would seek, except for the standard pledge to use U.S. money only in the lands it held before the 1967 Mideast war. The United States does not recognize Israeli sovereignty over land seized during the war. Shamir, in an interview published Wednesday in the English-language Jerusalem Post, denied his government would build new settlements in the occupied lands. ``The emphasis will be on the ... strengthening of the now existing settlements,'' Shamir said. Baker's public lecture was met with dismay by the Israeli Embassy and the powerful Jewish lobby. An embassy statement said the new government was willing and eager to promote the peace process, which it said was ``best served by direct communications between the U.S. administration and the new Israeli government.'' Seymour Reich, chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations, said Baker's remarks were both surprising and disturbing. ``The (Bush) administration has shown patience _ perhaps excessive patience _ with the PLO's refusal to condemn the attempted terrorist raid against the Tel Aviv beaches and to discipline Abu Abbas, who claimed credit for it. Similar patience with the new government in Jerusalem might have been a wiser course than conducting diplomacy in public, as Mr. Baker did today,'' Reich said in a statement. In February, Baker said, it appeared that 11 months of U.S. mediation were about to bear fruit with a historic Israeli-Palestinian dialogue. But Israel's coalition government refused to take the final step of accepting the formula for composition of the Palestinian delegation, leading to the March 15 collapse of the government. Baker told the committee that he had asked Israel to accept a list of Palestinian delegates made up of residents from the occupied territories, as well as some who had been deported from the territories and Palestinians with addresses both in East Jerusalem and the territories. The complicated formula was designed to appease Israel and the PLO, with which Israel refuses to negotiate. ``It's very hard for us to understand ... why we didn't get a `yes' answer,'' Baker said. However, he said the administration was willing to ``let bygones be bygones.'' ``The challenge for all sides is to try to put (the peace process) back on track ... and to see if we can't create a better environment for peacemaking,'' Baker said. For Palestinians, he said, it means ``looking beyond the tragic human losses that they have suffered and recommitting themselves to the political process.'' At least 717 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 45 Israelis have died in an uprising in the territories that began in December 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Chilean Army, Church Clash on Atrocities Issue
DOC.TEXT: Military leaders said Wednesday they should not be held responsible for atrocities following a 1973 coup, but the country's Roman Catholic bishops urged the courts to determine guilt. The clash over past human rights abuses intensified last week with the discovery of at least 20 well-preserved bodies in a mass grave in the northern fishing town of Pisagua, used as a detention camp for anti-government leftists in late 1973 and early 1974. An Interior Ministry subsecretary, Belisario Velasco, said Wednesday that of the 20 bodies, 17 had bullet wounds, two were mutilated and one was beheaded. He said 15 bodies have been identified and their remains will be handed over to relatives. Former military ruler Augusto Pinochet led the Sept. 11, 1973, coup that ousted an elected leftist government during a period of political and economic upheaval. His 16-year authoritarian rule was stained by charges of widespread rights abuses. Pinochet handed over the presidency to an elected successor in March, but retains command of the 60,000-member military. Pinochet sat in the front row, his face grim and brow lowered, when an army declaration was read at a gathering of the generals' corps Wednesday. ``Looking at things from the perspective of the peace we now enjoy, it may appear that the military reaction was exaggerated,'' it said. ``But this overlooks the fact that Sept. 11, 1973, was a military operation, that is a war action.'' It said Chile was being torn apart by ``an internal war, provoked by foreign ideologies.'' ``War is never bloodless, and always brings pains, hates, injustices and inhumanities,'' the army statement continued. ``Thus we demand respect for our institution and for those who carried out in our ranks the tough chores of war.'' While in power, Pinochet decreed an amnesty for all rights abuse that occurred before March 1978. A statement issued by Chile's bishops, released at almost the same hour as the army's, said that trying to elude responsibility for atrocities attempted to ``justify the unjustifible.'' ``It will be the job of the justice system to clear up events and determine guilt,'' the bishops said. ``The country needs to know what happened.'' They also said anyone with information on the whereabouts of missing victims should step forward. At least 700 people disappeared during the wave of political repression that followed the coup, according to rights groups. President Patricio Aylwin has created a special commission to investigate and report on the rights violations that occurred during Pinochet's rule. The army has expressed fears of a political witch hunt.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Opposes Compensation To Offset Job Loss Due To Owls
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he would oppose legislation providing federal payment for workers who lose their jobs in the Northwest because of efforts to protect the rare northern spotted owl. But leaders of the Northwest's timber industry came away from a meeting with Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. optimistic that plans are in the works to minimize the economic hardship on the region if the owl is listed next week as a threatened species. Bush said during a White House news conference he is ``very much concerned about the potential loss of jobs as a result of this spotted owl problem.'' The president said, however, his administration opposed a Senate amendment that would have compensated workers displaced by the Clean Air Act and would follow the same logic in the case of the owl. ``I opposed that and I would oppose a similar amendment,'' Bush said. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is expected to declare the owl as a threatened species by June 23. One panel of government scientists has estimated that timber harvests on federal lands in the Northwest will have to be cut nearly in half to save the owl from extinction, a move the government projects would cost more than 28,000 jobs by the end of the decade. ``I want those 30,000 families to understand that we care very much about that, but I cannot say that I would support the very kind of amendment that I opposed,'' Bush told reporters. ``But I hope that we can have a resolution of this problem that will not result in throwing 30,000 families out of work,'' he said. Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore., and a delegation of Oregonians representing the timber industry are scheduled to meet at the White House on Thursday to discuss the issue with Chief of Staff John Sununu and other presidential advisers. Sununu said Wednesday he is hopeful the Fish and Wildlife Service will issue a listing decision that ``doesn't gut the economic vitality of that region.'' The Oregon delegation met on Wednesday with Lujan, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and Forest Service Chief F. Dale Robertson.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Deplores EWxcessive Force in Romania
With AM-Romania a0676
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Wednesday it deplored the use of excessive force by police in clearing anti-government demonstrators from a square in the capital of Romania. The department urged all sides to exercise restraint. ``We deplore the use of excessive force by the authorities in clearing the square,'' said a department statement late in the day. ``We are concerned that this action by the Romanian authorities may set off a cycle of violence. President Iliescu and his government must now exercise restraint. We urge all Romanian citizens to avoid violence and use peaceful means to express their grievances.''

DOC.HEAD: White House to Try to Boost NASA at Budget Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf pvs, bgng: NASA would xxx, to CORRECT amount under House budget to $14 billion sted $13.4 billion
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will ask congressional negotiators at high-level budget talks to give special treatment to NASA, one of the president's chief domestic priorities, officials said Wednesday. The officials, who spoke on condition they not be identified, said the White House would propose that negotiators work out a specific spending figure for next year's NASA budget. In budget summits of past years, administration and congressional officials have agreed to a single spending amount covering thousands of domestic programs, including NASA. The budgets for individual agencies were then determined by Congress during the regular legislative process. President Bush would thus greatly enhance his role in determining NASA's budget if it is negotiated directly between White House and congressional negotiators. That would be important to Bush and NASA because Congress does not want to increase the space agency's budget by as much as the president would like. The administration's proposal to consider NASA separately would also leave the thousands of remaining domestic programs vulnerable to cuts that may be agreed to by budget bargainers. Negotiators, meeting Wednesday for a seventh time, are looking for ways to shrink next year's federal deficit by $45 billion to $60 billion. Many lawmakers would be likely to reject Bush's proposal to negotiate separately over NASA, said aides who asked to not be identified. They said Bush's idea would provide protection to his pet project while leaving their favorite programs exposed to potential spending cuts. In his budget for fiscal 1991, Bush proposed giving NASA $15.2 billion, a 24 percent increase over this year's $12.3 billion. That was the largest increase Bush requested for any of the government's major agencies. ``The exploration of space has benefits for the United States that go far beyond the quantifiable,'' Bush said in his budget, which he presented in January. Congress has so far been less generous with the space agency. NASA would receive $14 billion next year under a fiscal 1991 budget approved in May by the House. A separate spending plan approved by the Senate Budget Committee last month would give the agency $14.2 billion. Both congressional budgets were written by majority Democrats. Asked to confirm the administration's intentions, one official who spoke on condition of anonymity said, ``You can say administration sources wouldn't deny it.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Nation's Midsection
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms fell across the central United States from eastern Kansas to northern Lake Michigan on Wednesday, including a storm that downed power lines in an Illinois city. Summer snow fell in Oregon. In the northern Illinois city of Belvidere, winds hitting 69 mph downed electrical lines and started a fire at a downtown building. Up to 6 inches of snow fell overnight in some higher elevations of Oregon. A few showers and thunderstorms developed along the central and western Gulf Coast. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with clear skies across the southwestern quarter. A storm system developing along the California coast generated strong, gusty winds in sections of Arizona and Southern California. Temperatures dropped into the 40s in New England and the northern Plains. Readings were in the 30s and 40s in the Great Basin of Nevada and the northern and central Rockies. It was an unseasonably cool 44 degrees at Atlantic City's airport, tying the record for the date set in 1980. The low temperature for the Lower 48 was 30 degrees in McCall and Malad City, Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins in Central Park Jogger Attack Trial
DOC.TEXT: About 120 prospective jurors in the trial of three teen-agers accused of raping and nearly killing a Central Park jogger were given questionnaires Wednesday asking their attitudes on race and crime. All three defendants are black teen-agers who live in Harlem. The victim is a 29-year-old white investment banker. The 54-question, 17-page form was handed to those from a pool of 382 who told state Supreme Court Justice Thomas Galligan they would be able to stay for a six- to eight-week trial.
