The questionnaire asks if the prospective juror or his or her children attended an integrated school; whether the person has lived in a racially mixed community, and whether he or she has friends of a different race. It also asks whether the individual would prefer help from a police officer of his or her own racial or ethnic group if in need of assistance. The questions were agreed on by all parties in the case, said Michael Joseph, attorney for defendant Antron McCray, 15. Members of the Guardian Angels community patrol group marched in front of the Manhattan courthouse, passing out leaflets that said the case ``is not a question of black and white; it's about what's wrong and what's right.'' McCray and five other youths are charged with gang raping and beating the woman as she jogged through the Central Park the evening of April 19, 1989. The victim suffered brain damage in the assault and cannot remember the attack or identify her assailants. After emerging from a coma and being treated at a Connecticut rehabilitation hospital, she returned to work at Salomon Brothers and recently was named a vice president. McCray, along with Yusef Salaam and Raymond Santana, both 16, are being tried as adults on charges of attempted murder, rape, sodomy, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot. The other three youths are to be tried later, also as adults. If any in the first group were to be convicted, they would be sentenced as juveniles and would face a maximum of 10 years in prison. The questionnaire also asks potential jurors if they have a particular bias against people accused of sex crimes, whether they or any of their relatives jog, and whether they use Central Park often. In addition, there are the usual questions about whether the prospective juror has relatives in law enforcement or has been a crime victim. Jury selection was to continue Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: National Guard Jet Carrying Two Crashes in High Desert
DOC.TEXT: A California National Guard jet carrying two crew members crashed Wednesday in a remote part of the high desert. It was not known whether the crew survived. The F4-E Phantom II jet fighter from the 163rd Tactical Fighter Group out of March Air Force Base near Riverside in Southern California crashed about 60 miles west of Las Vegas around 1 p.m., said Maj. Bruce Roy, spokesman for the guard. The jet carried a pilot and a weapons system operator, Roy said. ``We do not know the status of the people in the aircraft, he said. Search helicopters were sent to the area. The crew members' names were withheld.

DOC.HEAD: Disposable Diapers Not A Major Environmental Threat, P&G Says
DOC.TEXT: Leaders in the disposable diaper industry said Wednesday that cloth competitors and consumer misunderstandings likely accounted for recent survey results indicating strong support for banning their product. ``It's not a simple issue of environment vs. paper diapers,'' said Scott Stewart, a spokesman for Procter & Gamble Co. The roughly 16 billion disposable diapers sold every year have become an environmental and health issue as local governments try to deal with mountains of used, bacteria-laden dirty diapers and rapidly filling landfills. Bans or taxes on disposable diapers are being considered in at least 20 states. Nebraska, for example, has generally banned the sale of new nondegradable diapers effective Oct. 1, 1993. A national Media General-Associated Press poll on environmental concerns found that 71 percent of respondents supported a ban on disposable diapers. In a recent Wall Street Journal-NBC News poll, respondents favored a ban on disposable diapers by a 3-1 ratio. In a Gallup Organization poll, 43 percent of respondents supported a ban, and 38 percent favored a tax. But Stewart said the criticism is misleading. He said disposable diapers account for only about 1 percent of trash in the nation's landfills. Furthermore, he said, cloth diapers were not necessarily environmentally safer because they take more energy to make and need water for cleaning. ``We don't get rattled about surveys because they don't tell us anything we don't already know,'' Stewart said. ``Our competition _ the cloth diaper industry _ has been relatively successful in painting this as an environmental problem. ``There's no dispute that disposables contribute to solid waste, but it's a relatively small part, and it's unfair to say it is a major contributor.'' Procter & Gamble says its Pampers and Luvs have about half of the nation's $3.5 billion-a-year disposable diaper business. The other major manufacturer is Dallas-based Kimberly-Clark Corp., which makes Huggies. Kimberly-Clark spokeswoman Jean Allen said it was unfair to blame disposable diapers for all landfill problems. She said consumers who used disposables simply weighed convenience against environmental costs. ``If you were to ban disposable diapers and use cloth, you would not come up with no environmental cost,'' she said. ``An individual has to balance that cost. Water is a limited resource; there are chemical and detergent wastes to be considered, and air pollution. ``This way the consumer has the right to weigh what they consider the best alternative against the environmental cost.'' Jack Mogavero, president of General Health Care Corp. of Piscataway, N.J., said his company delivers nearly 2.9 million cloth diapers a week in 14 states. ``I don't know anything about any poll, but I know what the consensus of the people is, based on the number of customers we serve weekly,'' Mogavero said by telephone. ``We've experienced tremendous growth, and I have to attribute that to the ecology issue.'' Mogavero said his company processes cloth diapers for softening and to inhibit bacteria growth. ``That, along with home delivery and the ecology issue, is turning the business around,'' he said. ``I think the public is extremely concerned with the ecology issue, not just diapers.'' The National Association of Diaper Services estimated in October that 750,000 households used cloth diaper services, a 38.5 percent increase in a year. Some hospitals are switching to cloth after years of using disposables. ``While well-intentioned, the perception that has driven that decision is that disposables are an environmental hazard, and they are not,'' Stewart said. Some small companies have developed disposables they say are degradable, but neither of the big producers have such plans. Both said actual disposal conditions tended to limit any breakdown of a ``degradable'' diaper over time. ``At this time, we don't see the so-called biodegradable diaper as a real solution,'' Ms. Allen said. ``Nothing degrades in a landfill; to say a diaper degrades in a landfill is a marketing claim. You can dig up a newspaper 25 years later and read it.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede MONROVIA
Liberian Gov't, Rebels Agree to End Killing of Non-Combatants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with rebels and government agree in Freetown talks to stop killing non-combatants, say peace talks progressing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Liberian government and rebel delegations met for six hours Wednesday and agreed to an appeal from Liberia's religious leaders to end attacks on civilians. A joint statement signed by both sides made no reference to church leaders' request for an immediate cease-fire in the 5{-month-old civil war. But it said an end to attacks on non-combatants ``will go a long way in enhancing the peace process now successfully under way.'' More than 1,000 people have been killed, many of them civilians, since the rebel National Patriotic Front moved into Liberia from the Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 and began a drive on Monrovia, the Liberian capital. Wednesday was the second day of talks mediated by the Liberian Council of Churches at a U.S. Embassy auditorium in the Sierra Leone capital. Talks will resume Thursday. Both sides signed the statement, which called for ``an immediate end to the killings, molestation and destruction of properties and innocent civilians and other non-combatants.'' It said the government and insurgents strongly condemned ``the killing, harassment and destruction of properties of unarmed civilians as such acts will not benefit any side, since there can be no winners in this fracticidal war.'' The statement also said negotiators approved an agenda for ``substantive talks leading to the peaceful resolution of the confict.'' No mention was made of the demand by rebel leader Charles Taylor that President Samuel Doe resign and leave Liberia before negotiations could proceed. The insurgents have charged Doe's government with human rights abuse, economic bungling and corruption in the 10 years since Doe seized power in a violent coup. Most fighting in Liberia appeared to have stopped Wednesday, a week after government troops retook a rubber plantation outside the capital from the rebels. But hundreds of Americo-Liberians fled their suburban homes Wednesday for Monrovia. They said soldiers accused them of being dissidents and supporting Taylor. Taylor and thousands of Liberia's 2.5 million people are the descendants of freed American slaves who founded the West African nation in 1847. They oppose Doe, whose coup ousted other Americo-Liberians. Diplomats said the fleeing Liberians are trying to leave the country by road or air for Ivory Coast, Guinea and Sierra Leone. ``They just want to get out and are worrying about getting to the United States later,'' said one Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A military trial began in Monrovia on Wednesday of three soldiers charged with killing four civilians. Although hundreds of civilians are believed to have been killed by soldiers since the insurgency began, it was the first known prosecution. A major and two lieutenants were accused of leading an attack Saturday on the Americo-Liberian settlement of Clay Ashland and killing the town's mayor and three others. Liberia's diplomatic corps on Wednesday condemned ethnic killings by both government troops and rebels. ``The diplomatic corps is dismayed that murders of innocent civilians are continuing to occur daily because they belong to certain ethnic groups _ Mano, Gio, Mandingo, Krahn, Americo-Liberians,'' the statement said. Human rights organizations accuse soldiers of killing Gios and Manos. Many rebels are of those ethnic backgrounds. Rebels retaliated by killing Krahns _ Doe is a Krahn _ and Mandingos, accused of supporting Doe. More than 1,000 Americans, mostly Liberians carrying U.S. passports, and hundreds of other European, Asian and Lebanese nationals remain in Monrovia. British and U.S. warships are stationed off Liberia, prepared to carry out a sea evacuation if necessary.

DOC.HEAD: State Prosecutors to Appeal Dismissal of Helmsley Counts
DOC.TEXT: A state prosecutor said Wednesday his office will appeal the dismissal of 180 counts of a 188-count tax fraud indictment filed against self-styled hotel queen Leona Helmsley. Assistant Attorney General Alfredo Mendez said the appeal will be filed Thursday with the state Supreme Court's Appellate Division. Mendez also filed a cross-motion seeking reinstatement of 27 charges. Justice John A.K. Bradley said last month he was dismissing the 180 charges on double-jeopardy grounds because they were essentially the same as those on which Mrs. Helmsley was convicted in federal court last year. Mrs. Helmsley, 70, is appealing the federal conviction and sentence of four years in prison and a $7.1 million fine. A state indictment charges her and her billionaire real-estate developer husband Harry with tax and business fraud. Most counts alleged they charged personal expenses from their Connecticut estate to their businesses. Harry Helmsley was found unfit to stand trial in the federal case. State charges against him remain since double jeopardy doesn't apply. One of Mrs. Helmsley's attorneys, Sandor Frankel, asked Bradley to order Mendez to give the defense a ``bill of particulars,'' specifying what she is accused of doing, for the remaining eight counts. Bradley said he will rule June 20 on the various applications, including a defense petition to dismiss four of the remaining counts, and will decide whether to hold a hearing on Harry Helmsley's fitness to stand trial.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used AM-Israel, a0638 of June 12, are asked to use the following story:
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press, in a story June 12 saying Israel's government will allocate more money to Jewish settlements in the occupied territories, reported erroneously that about 7,000 Palestinians live in the occupied Gaza Strip. The correct population figure is 750,000.

DOC.HEAD: International Radio Festival Awards Handed Out
DOC.TEXT: KCBS-AM of San Francisco won the Grand Award for best news program for its coverage of the 1989 earthquake at the International Radio Festival of New York awards ceremony Wednesday night. The British Broadcasting Corp. won 11 gold medals _ the most of any nominee. Westwood One Radio Networks and its NBC Radio Networks subsidiary were next with four. Capital Cities-ABC and the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. each received three gold medals. Capital FM in London, KYW Newsradio in Philadelphia and Radio Today in New York each got two gold medals. The Associated Press Radio Network won a gold medal. The ninth annual awards program received 1,775 entries in radio programming, promotion and advertising from 16 countries. Prizes were awarded in more than 60 categories. Radio programming and promotion entries were reviewed by program and news directors at radio stations around the country and, for the first time, in Australia, Canada, England, Ireland and New Zealand. Members of the festival's board of judges and advisors choose Grand Award winners. Radio advertising winners were chosen by a peer review panel in New York.
Eds: The data for the evening weather tables was delayed at the source, the National Weather Service. We now expect to receive the data shortly and to move the tables within the hour.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Bailiff's Sudden Death Shocks Murder-Trial Courtroom
DOC.TEXT: The defense called only three witnesses and rested its case Wednesday before the sudden death of a bailiff injected turmoil into the murder trial of a college student accused of strangling her romantic rival. Circuit Judge Michael Hoover broke into tears and defense lawyer Stephen Glynn openly sobbed as they and District Attorney Greg Grau met for an hour to determine what the jury should be told about bailiff Norman Block's death. Block died at his home Wednesday morning, apparently of a heart attack, Clerk of Courts Donna Seidel said. The friendly bailiff had been attending to the jury, which was sequestered at a motel. Hoover decided he would tell jurors about the death only if they inquired about Block's absence. At that point, he said, he would individually interview jurors to determine their ability to devote full attention to the trial. Closing arguments were scheduled for Thursday in the trial of Lori Esker, 20, of Hatley. She was Marathon County's Dairy Princess _ winner of a talent and leadership contest in agriculture _ until she resigned in October when she was charged with murder in the Sept. 20 strangulation of Lisa Cihaski, 21, of Birnamwood. The charge carries a mandatory life sentence on conviction. The prosecution contends Ms. Esker believed Ms. Cihaski had stolen away her boyfriend, Eland dairy farmer Bill Buss. In a fit of jealousy, prosecutors contended, she rented a car, drove 150 miles from the University of Wisconsin-River Falls, where she was a student, and strangled Ms. Cihaski with the woman's belt. The defense did not call Ms. Esker to testify. A statement she gave police admitting she strangled Ms. Cihaski in self-defense during an argument over Buss was adequate to tell the jury her version, Glynn said.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Shoot Romanian Demonstrators; Buildings, Cars Ablaze
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with higher official toll, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XBUC7,XBUC8,XBUC9,XBUC11; LaserColor XBUC27
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers shot demonstrators outside the Interior Ministry on Wednesday night after anti-government protesters stormed state TV offices and burned police headquarters, witnesses said. State radio reported four people killed and 93 hospitalized, four in a very ``grave state.'' Two of those killed were shot to death, the broadcast added, quoting the Health Ministry. The Soviet news agency Tass, in a dispatch from Bucharest, said ``many cars'' near the Interior Ministry and police headquarters were overturned and set ablaze and two buildings nearby were also on fire. The violence was the worst since the December revolution that ousted Communist dictator Nicolai Ceausescu, who was executed with his wife on Christmas Day. The Interior Ministry now occupies the building that was formerly the headquarters of Ceausescu's despised secret police. President-elect Ion Iliescu accused extremist elements of organizing an ``Iron Guard rebellion'' and trying to overthrow the government _ a reference to the pre-World War II Iron Guard party that supported the Nazis. The violence was touched off by a pre-dawn police raid that ended a 53-day anti-communist protest in University Square in downtown Bucharest. Police clubbed and dragged away protesters. The protesters were demanding that former high-ranking Communists like Iliescu be banned from holding public office for 10 years and that independent television stations be established. In Washington, the State Department said it deplored the use ``of excessive force by the authorities in clearing the square. ``We are concerned that this action by the Romanian authorities may set off a cycle of violence. President Iliescu and his government must now exercise restraint,'' the statement said. One witness said she helped carry 12 bodies from outside the Interior Ministry and another reported seeing at least two bodies but these reports could not be confirmed officially. Demonstrators halted broadcasts for about 45 minutes at state TV, scene of fierce fighting and dramatic on-air appeals for an end to Communist rule last December. The state news agency Rompres reported ``seriously wounded'' near the Interior Ministry, police headquarters and the TV station. Thousands of pro-government supporters thronged to government headquarters at Victory Square late Wednesday in response to Iliescu's appeal for ``responsible people'' to protect government buildings. Rompres said 5,000 miners and thousands of other government supporters were bound for Bucharest. An opposition leader, Liberal Party chief Sen. Radu Campeanu, said such action would only aggravate the situation. The rampage came weeks after Romania's first free elections in 44 years on May 20 _ tainted by allegations of campaign and electoral irregularities. The demonstrators say Communists still dominate the National Salvation Front, in power since December and the overwhelming winners of last month's elections. Demonstrators fought police in the afternoon in University Square, then fanned out to police headquarters, the Interior Ministry, the TV station and Victory Square. ``We are now facing an organized, planned attempt to overthrow through force and violence the leadership elected in a free and democratic way,'' Iliescu said in a communique Wednesday night. Iliescu, the first ex-Communist to win a popular presidential election in Eastern Europe, pleaded for support for the army and security forces ``to liquidate this Iron Guard rebellion and reinstate calm.'' A government communique said demonstrators stole weapons, ammunition and police uniforms from the Interior Ministry. It said a filling station near the ministry was attacked and gasoline stolen to make firebombs. Rebecca Doina Cercel said she and others helped carry 12 bodies to ambulances outside the ministry. She said the bodies were taken to the morgue. Mrs. Cercel's 4-year-old son was killed in December's revolution. She had been in University Square since the protest began in April. Mrs. Cercel, 25, told The Associated Press police clubbed her. She had bruises on her face and abdomen. Scottish freelance photographer Jeremy Sutton-Hibbert said he saw soldiers shooting from inside the ministry and the body of a man shot in the head. AP reporter Gabriel Paslaru said demonstrators who tried to force the main gate of the building were met with rifle fire or single shots. ``I saw one man with an injured hand who fainted before he was rushed into a car and another man who was hit in the neck. His face was a red mask of blood _ it is hard to believe he could survive,'' Paslaru said. Police said earlier about 260 people were detained. State television was stormed by protesters who occupied one of the main studios. An announcer said they might not be able to transmit any longer. Minutes later, the picture was cut and then the sound but the station went back on the air three-quarters of an hour later. ``A bunch of people who were drunk got into the TV and it is a grave situation which we hope will never again occur,'' said the television's director, Razvan Teodorescu. Earlier, demonstrators carrying gasoline cans, some armed with clubs, stormed the regular police headquarters in central Bucharest, then set fire to nearby cars and trucks and a wing of the building. Fire trucks arrived to fight the blaze. About 1,500 people gathered outside and booed when helicopters flew overhead. Some protesters marched toward Victory Square, headquarters of the National Salvation Front. The violence began before dawn, when police sealed off the central square with trucks and buses, then moved in on the sleeping demonstrators with clubs. Police ripped down the tent camp the protesters had built. Some protesters had been on hunger strikes. By midafternoon, steel-helmeted police were battling about 1,000 protesters who overturned a police van and freed two prisoners, then set the van ablaze, witnesses said. Fleeing demonstrators smashed glass doors to get inside nearby Intercontinental Hotel but were dragged away by police. Protesters hurled rocks at police, who hurled the stones back.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Confiscates Video from `Inside Edition' Crew
DOC.TEXT: Military police confiscated video from an ``Inside Edition'' television crew taping penned dolphins at a base where the mammals are trained as guards for nuclear submarines, the Navy said Wednesday. Reporter Craig Rivera, brother of talk-show host Geraldo Rivera, two other crew members and Richard O'Barry, best known as a trainer for the ``Flipper'' television series, were detained briefly Tuesday for allegedly crossing into a restricted zone at Key West Naval Station. ``They were warned off and in fact crossed the lines anyway,'' Ensign Robin Perkins said. ``They were apprehended because they were in a restricted naval area.'' No charges were filed, but she said a report on the incident will be referred to the U.S. attorney's office for review. ``They weren't booked on any kind of charges. The films were confiscated and they were escorted off base,'' Perkins said. The crew for the nationally syndicated tabloid television show and O'Barry were in a chartered boat ``about 150 yards away from the pens. ``There were no signs saying off-limits,'' O'Barry said. ``We were told to get out of there and then ordered to hand over the film. We were surrounded by 15 Navy frogmen.'' He said the same thing happened last week to a crew for ABC's ``20@20'' newsmagazine show. ``We stand behind our investigative reporter Craig Rivera, as he was within the parameters of the law and certainly within the parameters of journalistic ethics,'' said program publicist Marcy Baron in New York. She would not say whether efforts were being made to recover the tape. O'Barry has been arrested twice this year in protests at a Florida Keys resort where two recently captured dolphins were being held for a marine park. A pair of Navy-trained dolphins are in pens at the Navy base as part of a ``swimmer nullification program'' training the marine mammals in Key West, San Diego and Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii. The dolphins reportedly are fitted with nose guns and taught to kill enemy frogmen to protect submarines armed with Trident nuclear missiles. The Navy has used dolphins, sea lions and beluga whales in classified programs since the 1960s. The program was criticized in 1988 after several trainers charged the animals suffered physical abuse and that the program suffered from mismanagement, rapid employee turnover and pressure to expand.

DOC.HEAD: Rotting Herring Killing Lobsters
DOC.TEXT: In life and death, thousands of pounds of Atlantic herring have been eating up the oxygen in Block Island's Old Harbor _ and stinking up the local lobster industry. Local officials Wednesday sought state help for lobstermen who lost an undetermined amount of catch when the herring depleted the small harbor's oxygen supply. About 10-15 commercial lobstermen operate from the harbor. Restaurants on the tourism-dependent island also lost lobsters stored in tanks that circulate harbor water. Andrew Hunt, an aide to Lt. Gov. Roger Begin, said he was trying to arrange relief funds or low-interest loans for those affected. Experts believe a large school of small fish entered the harbor's inner basin, on the island's east side, on June 4. ``What we think happened is a school of Atlantic herring possibly was chased into the basin in the Old Harbor area by predators. It could be bluefish or striped bass,'' said Joseph Migliore, a scientist with the state Department of Environmental Management. The small fish has a fast metabolism and consumes a lot of oxygen. The school, estimated to weigh 15,000 to 50,000 pounds, apparently overwhelmed the seven-acre basin and its oxygen supply. Such fish kills are relatively common in enclosed bodies of water. But Block Islanders can't remember such a large kill on their isolated dot 12 miles off the Rhode Island coast. ``As far as I know, and I've talked to people who've been fishing out of that harbor all their lives, 15 to 30 years, this has never happened,'' said Chris Littlefield, harbor master for New Shoreham, the island's only town. First Warden Edward McGovern, New Shoreham's equivalent of a mayor, said the smell got really bad last week, but is improving. As the fish began dying, lobstermen collected about 50 barrels for bait. But most of the dead fish sank to the bottom and began to rot _ further depleting the oxygen. Unsuspecting lobstermen left their catch in cages filled with harbor water _for storage until shipment to market _ and some think the lobsters suffocated. Lobsters in restaurant tanks suffered similar fates. At least some eateries were seeking an alternative storing method until the harbor oxygen is restored. Experts could not estimate the extent of the damage or predict when the harbor would return to normal. Littlefield said some of the dead fish were beginning to be swept out with the tide, but most were staying on the bottom.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Passes New Law Making Drug Use a Crime
DOC.TEXT: Parliament has made drug use a crime in Italy in an effort to stem an increasing number of overdose deaths and narcotics-related crimes. Opponents said the new law infringes on personal liberties. Since 1975, Italy has had a much more permissive attitude toward drug use than most Western European countries. That law allowed possession of a ``moderate'' amount of drugs for personal use. It also left a loophole that permitted many sellers caught by the police to claim drugs in their possession were for personal use. The new law adopted by Parliament on Tuesday makes it illegal to use drugs in all amounts, though it remains lenient for those caught with no more than a ``daily dose.'' In the case of such small amounts, no penalties will be applied for those who choose to undergo rehabilitation. The precise amount of a daily dose will be defined later. If the user refuses treatment, however, his driver's license and passport can be suspended up to three months. Further abuse can bring jail up to three months. The new law also stiffens penalities for drug dealing. Those convicted of trafficking in heroin or cocaine can be sentenced to eight-to-20 years in prison and fined up to $420,000. The old law's maximum penalty was 15 years and $83,500. The new law was adopted to combat a wave of social problems related to drug use. Overdose deaths roughly doubled from 1987 to 1989. This year's total is expected to be even higher, about 1,000. Also worrisome has been the spread of AIDS through contaminated needles. Throwing a syringe away in a public place now can bring a fine of up to $835. Also under the new law, marijuana users caught for the first time will be issued a warning. The list of prohibited drugs includes heroin, cocaine, hallucinogens, marijuana and hashish as well as amphetamines and barbituates in amounts above medical doses. Opponents say the new law violates their civil liberties.

DOC.HEAD: Several Passengers Injured As Cable Car Suddenly Stops
DOC.TEXT: Seven people on a cable car were injured Wednesday when the trolley suddenly stopped while going up a hill, the city's Municipal Railway said. No other vehicle was involved in the accident around 5:20 p.m. Five passengers, the conductor and the gripmen were hurt, said a railway manager who refused to give his name. It was not known how badly they were hurt, but at least a few were taken to hospitals, he said. Railway investigators were on the scene.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief To Send Observer Mission To Occupied Territories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf `Arab states' to UPDATE with reaction from Arab League. Pickup 10th graf pvs, `Arab diplomats...
DOC.TEXT: U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Wednesday he will dispatch a delegation to the Israeli-occupied territories to investigate violence including alleged abuses of Palestinians. He said the group would go early next week. The U.N. chief's announcement came one day after Israel's new conservative government invited him to send a special envoy, but Perez de Cuellar said he was already planning to send a team. U.N. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the delegation might depart for Israel as early as Monday night. The group will be headed by Jean-Claude Aime, a director in the U.N. Secretariat. U.N. officials said the secretary-general had been planning for several weeks to send an investigative team to the West Bank and Gaza Strip, where violence has escalated recently. On Tuesday evening, Perez de Cuellar summoned Israeli Ambassador Johanan Bein to inform him of the plans. Bein told reporters beforehand that ``Israel would initiate an invitation'' to the U.N. team. He later said Israel would fully cooperate with the delegation. Perez de Cuellar told reporters the timing of Israel's invitation was ``a coincidence.'' Arab states had sought to dispatch a three-member team from the Security Council. Israel opposed the move, and the United States vetoed the plan in the Security Council. Arab League envoy Clovis Maksoud on Wednesday called the Israeli statement that the invitation was its own initiative ``a deliberate attempt to hijack the mission and rob it of its credibility and relevance.'' He also said the secretary-general's mission was independent of Arab efforts to convene an emergency session of the General Assembly or the Security Council on the deteriorating situation in the occupied territories. Arab diplomats said they wanted the Security Council to give its blessing to the secretary-general's mission and wanted to ensure that the council would take action on the mission's report. In the past, Arab diplomts complained, reports by the secretary-general on the occupied lands have not generated Security Council action. The invitation by Israel was the first action in the international arena of the new Israeli government. ``The government of Israel, on our own initiative, extends to the secretary-general an invitation to (Secretariat Director) Jean-Claude Aime to visit Israel as an envoy in the framework of a visit to the region,'' Bein told reporters. Arab nations have said the policies of the new Israeli government and the escalation of violence in the territories make it imperative that the United Nations take emergency action to protect Palestinians. The new government has said it will take tough measures to quell the 30-month-old uprising. The territories were captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East War and are claimed by the Palestinians as a future state.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say 148 Died in Kirghizia Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic violence killed 148 people and wounded 885 this month in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia, the official news agency Tass said Wednesday. Tass said 748 of the injured had to be hospitalized and said a search was continuing for a police officer who vanished June 7. No new outbreaks were reported in the region near the border city of Osh in western Kirghizia, where clashes arising from a land dispute began on June 2 between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks, both Sunni Moslems. The argument involves allocation of land in a densly populated region where housing is scarce. It was the latest in a series of bloody civil conflicts to trouble President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's government. Maj. Gen. Alexander Grienko, chief of the Interior Ministry's Political Department, said that in two years of civil strife _ mainly ethnic clashes _ in the Soviet Union, about 24,000 people have been arrested. He said in Moscow on Tuesday that ministry troops had to be used in 13 regions of the Soviet Union because of such outbreaks, Tass said. Grienko said 16 ministry soldiers were killed, four were reported missing and more than 1,000 wounded. Tass did not quote Grienko on how civilians casualties. The general was quoted as saying these conflicts ``were often accompanied by riots and pogroms, arson and massacre of innocent people, (and) complete or partial destabilization of the situation.'' Besides unrest this month in Kirghizia and Uzbekistan, ethnic violence also has been reported in recent years in Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Tadzhikistan.

DOC.HEAD: Air Traffic Controllers Cripple Plane Travel in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Striking air traffic controllers paralyzed flights nationwide Wednesday, but they went back to work after the government agreed to their demand that a fired Sandinista army officer be allowed to return to the job. The strike represented the latest confrontation between the U.S.-backed government that took office in April and its leftist Sandinista predecessors, who still control labor unions and the military. The walkout by the Sandinista-led union of air traffic controllers, which started Tuesday night, crippled Managua's international airport and closed all Nicaraguan air space to flights. Under Wednesday's settlement, Army Maj. Alejandro Arguello, who was fired as chief of civil aeronautics on Saturday, will be asked to return to the civil aeronautics department as adviser to his replacement, said union leader Manuel Garcia. His replacement was not announced. Jaime Icabalceta, the Construction and Transportation minister, also agreed not to fire any public employees from the civil aeronautics administration and to revise salary levels, Garcia said. ``We are now back to normal operations'' in the control tower, said Garcia after Wednesday's talks. An Iberia flight was the first passenger plane to leave Wednesday afternoon. Other airlines were checking in passengers who had been forced to camp out all day at the airport. The government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, which took over after defeating the Sandinistas in February elections, has been hobbled by a wave of strikes. In May, Sandinista labor unions struck for two weeks, nearly crippling the government. Air traffic controllers went on a sympathy strike at that time for 48 hours. Officials have accused the Sandinista Front of promoting the strikes to destabilize the government. The strikes are occurring as Mrs. Chamorro is struggling to solidify her power and improve the nation's economy, which was devastated by a decade of fighting between U.S.-backed Contra rebels and the Sandinistas and an embargo by the United States. The air controllers radioed their intention to begin the new strike on Tuesday to a plane carrying Mrs. Chamorro back from Costa Rica five minutes before it was supposed to land at Managua's international airport, said controller Daniel Gonzalez. However, the president's plane was allowed to land before controllers began shutting down air space 8 p.m. Tuesday. Mrs. Chamorro had been in neighboring Costa Rica for the funeral of former Costa Rican President Jose Figueres. Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado spoke to the controllers from the cockpit of the presidential plane, and the two sides opened the private formal talks Wednesday at the international airport. Representing the government was Transport Minister Icabalceta. Garcia, secretary general of the Civil Aeronautics Labor Union, represented the strikers. Arguello was fired after the Icabalceta moved the post of aeronautics chief from the military into the transport ministry. The controllers say the firing by the government violated an agreement reached during the earlier round of strikes not to dismiss civil servants.

DOC.HEAD: Algeria's Islamic Fundamentalists Demand Dissolution of Parliament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to ADD background on Islamic party; pickup graf 13 pvs `Madani thanked...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ALG1
DOC.TEXT: Islamic fundamentalists who won a majority of local council seats in Algeria's first multiparty elections demanded Wednesday that Parliament be dissolved so they can move to take national power. The victory by the Islamic Salvation Front in the nationwide local elections marks a stunning triumph for Islamic hard-liners and their 16-month-old party. A day after the vote, the fundamentalists called on President Chadli Bendjedid to hold national elections within three months instead of February 1992 as scheduled. The government had no immediate response. The National Liberation Front had been widely expected to win Tuesday's voting because of its grip on government machinery and the media, as well as its greater financial resources. It holds every seat in Parliament. But on Wednesday, before any official results were released, Interior Minister Mohamed-Salah Mohammedi announced the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front had won a majority of the 15,000 seats at stake on 1,541 municipal and 48 provincial councils. First official results released later Wednesday _ more than 24 hours after the voting ended _ showed the fundamentalists captured 327 of the 612 municipal council seats counted so far. The governing party won 208 seats, or 33 percent. The interior minister said the partial official returns indicated the anti-clerical Rally for Culture and Democracy had won 51 seats in Tuesday's voting, with independents and the tiny National Party for Solidarity and Development taking the rest. The interior minister said complications had delayed the count and full results would be unavailable before Thursday. The French news agency Agence France-Presse, citing sources, said the fundamentalists captured councils in Algeria's four largest cities _ Algiers, Oran, Constantine and Annaba _ and swept 45 of the 48 provincial councils. Abassi Madani, the philosophy professor who heads the Islamic Salvation Front, denied his movement wishes to turn the country into a one-party religious state. ``We guarantee the freedom of all who have ideas on Algeria's future,'' he said. ``The Algerian people are not stupid,'' added Madani, 59. ``The truth is the best way to answer all questions.'' Algeria's Islamic Salvation Front seeks to establish the Islamic legal code, the Sharia, as law. The party assigns women to a subservient role. None of the front's 12,000 candidates for office in Tuesday's voting were women. For months, fundamentalist supporters have been accused of harassing single women and disrupting nightclubs in Algiers. The fundamentalist party boasts 650,000 members. Many are drawn from the ranks of unemployed youth, attracted by its fiery mix of Islam and politics. Madani thanked the governing party for holding the elections, the first multiparty voting since the North African country won independence from France in 1962. The centrist Front of Socialist Forces headed by Berber leader Hocine Ait Ahmed and the populist, left-leaning Movement for Democracy led by former president Ahmed Ben Bella had charged that the governing party would rig the vote. From exile in Switzerland, Ben Bella on Wednesday called the fundamentalist win a vote of no-confidence in the governing party and urged ``really free'' elections for Parliament in the near future. Officials of all parties complained Wednesday of widespread irregularities, including multiple voting, missing ballots and interference at polling places by outsiders and election officials. The official APS news agency reported that about 40 percent of the voters had abstained, according to the partial count. About 13 million people were registered to vote. In France, Algeria's former colonial ruler and home to hundreds of thousands of Algerian immigrants, Youth and Sports Minister Roger Bambuck indicated the results would cause alarm in French government ranks. ``It's with great sadness that I see the rise of fundamentalism in Algeria,'' he said in a radio interview. ``Every time one sees dogmatism on the rise, whether political or religious, it's liberty that is in danger.'' In Iran, state Tehran Radio said the results were ``part of the wave of Islamization that has gripped northern African nations simultaneously.'' ``The development of Islamic feeling in these countries is similar to Algeria, but it is suppressed by the ruling regimes,'' the radio said. In Tunisia, one of Algeria's neighbors, the main Islamic group was barred from nationwide local elections Sunday. The official news agency reported several groups of Islamic supporters tried to overrun some Algiers voting stations, alleging the vote-counting was influenced by the government. A number of voters in Algiers were turned away from polling booths when they appeared without required documents. The governing party was the sole political party in the nation of 24 million people until constitutional changes in February 1989 opened the way to competing parties. The party was forced to end its monopoly on power after soldiers killed scores of people in October 1988 riots sparked by deteriorating economic conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Withdraws Venice as Fair Site
DOC.TEXT: Premier Giulio Andreotti said Tuesday his government was withdrawing Venice as a candidate for Expo 2000, a world's fair. The Bureau of International Expositions, headquartered in Paris, was expected to select the host city on Thursday. With Venice out of the running, the choice was narrowed to Hanover, West Germany, and Toronto. Critics cited the mess the tourist-swamped lagoon city was left with last summer after a Pink Floyd concert drew 100,000 young people to St. Mark's Square. They argued that the fair would further strain Venice, whose canals can't handle the sewage that spills out of hotels and restaurants. Under the proposal, Venice would have been the centerpiece of the international showcase of cultural and scientific exhibits. Other cities in the immediate region would have acted as host for some of the attractions. Last week, Andreotti went before Parliament to defend the candidacy and promised that Parliament would have the last word on the plan should Venice get the go-ahead from Paris. Andreotti's government, like Venice itself, was divided over the candidacy. Some argued that the fair would help relaunch the city, which has seen Venetians flee to solid ground, leaving Venice to tourists and real-estate speculators. Last month, the European Parliament voted overwhelmingly against the project and asked Italy to withdraw the candidacy. ``A senseless plan has failed and Venice can thus breathe a sigh of relief,'' said Italian Carlo Ripa di Meana, the European Community's environmental commissioner. On Monday, 300 members of the 630-seat Chamber of Deputies signed a petition against the candidacy following opposition expressed by 180 senators in the 324-member upper house. Andreotti announced the withdrawal in a meeting with Senate leaders. A communique from his office took note of the parliamentary opposition, but added: ``It goes without saying that the great problems of crowding, renewal and utilizing the abandoned quarters of Venice remain even leaving out the exposition.'' By the late 1980s, Venice had 80,000 people, compared to 175,000 in the 1950s. Butchers, grocers and plumbers have been closing their shops along the narrow, zigzagging streets of the carless city, and souvenir vendors are taking their spots. A study presented two years ago predicted there could be as few as 20,000 Venetians left by the year 2015. Many buildings are uninhabitable. The lagoon lapping at their ground floors and salty sea air wear away foundations and beams. The lagoon's black-green waters have also been plagued by bad-smelling algae, which feed on detergents and other chemicals dumped into the sea.

DOC.HEAD: Wife of Commerce Secretary Robbed in Hotel
DOC.TEXT: Socialite Georgette Mosbacher, wife of U.S. Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher, was robbed at gunpoint at a hotel Tuesday, police said. She was not hurt. Mrs. Mosbacher was getting off an elevator on the 20th floor of the Barbizon Plaza Hotel when a man with a gun confronted her, said Sgt. Ed Burns. The man, described as well dressed, took Mrs. Mosbacher's wedding ring, watch, earrings, two other rings and $400 in cash, then ran down the stairs, Burns said. Mrs. Mosbacher, who was a guest at the hotel, is president of her own cosmetics business, La Prairie, and is well-known in New York and Washington social circles.

Faced with a splintering empire, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is proposing to counter secessionist drives by transforming the Soviet Union into a looser federation of sovereign states, officials say. The Soviet leader has also significantly softened his position on German reunification, saying a united Germany could be an ``associate member'' of the NATO alliance while at the same time joining a new pan-European security order. He did not define exactly what ``associate membership'' would entail, but the Kremlin up to now has opposed a new Germany whose sole military allegiance is to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Gorbachev made his proposal about the Soviet republics on Tuesday, the same day the parliament of the huge Russian republic approved a resolution declaring its laws to carry more weight than federal statutes.
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Black candidates won primaries for governor of South Carolina and lieutenant governor of Arkansas, propelling them into uphill general election races against powerful opponents. In the Arkansas race, businessman Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris trounced Ku Klux Klan sympathizer Ralph Forbes by more than a 6-1 margin on Tuesday to win the Republican nomination for lieutenant governor. In South Carolina, state Sen. Theo Mitchell soundly defeated state Sen. Ernest Passailaigue in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. In one other election with racial overtones, the first black mayor of Atlantic City, N.J., James L. Usry, was ousted by a white challenger in a runoff. Usry was recently indicted on corruption charges.

President Bush's string of successful vetoes remains unbroken, but Democrats are maneuvering for a second chance to force an Amtrak aid bill into law over his objections. Bush emerged Tuesday with the 11th veto of his term intact after Democrats failed by three votes to muster the two-thirds majority needed to override the president's veto of a bill to support the rail service. The president vetoed the $2 billion authorization bill last month because it also would have required that the Interstate Commerce Commission approve acquisitions of major freight railroads by non-railroad companies. Republicans promised during Tuesday's debate that Bush would support a substitute bill continuing support for the passenger rail service as long as the regulatory provision is omitted.

Texas banks are back in the black after more than four years of steady losses, while once-thriving Massachusetts institutions have become the industry's biggest money-losers. Nationally, commercial banks earned $6.2 billion in the first three months of 1990, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Tuesday. The performance, except for a sharp earnings dip in the last half of 1989, was in line with bank profits over the past two years. But the overall performance masked dramatic turnarounds in some states. Texas banks, which lost $42 million during the first quarter of 1989, turned a profit of $164 million in the first quarter of this year. It was their first quarter in the black since the last quarter of 1985. Massachusetts banks went the other direction. They earned $202 million in the first quarter last year but lost $171 million in the January-March 1990 period, the worst loss of any state. The other states to post losses were New Hampshire and Rhode Island _ which border Massachusetts _ and Arizona.

Government officials say Attorney General Dick Thornburgh acted within the law in heading discussions on revising the Clean Air Act even though 20 percent of his assets are in stocks affected by the legislation. President Bush granted ethics-law waivers to Thornburgh last spring so the attorney general could head Domestic Policy Council discussions leading to proposals to amend the Clean Air Act, administration officials said. DOC.TEXT: And when is a freebie golf trip considered a gift? Only when lawmakers say so. In 1988, the Pennsylvania Manufacturing Association spent a reported $20,000 entertaining seven lawmakers at a Florida golf resort. Only one reported the outing, although three others said they went but didn't consider it a gift. Lawmakers can get free movie passes in Pennsylvania, free lift tickets at ski resorts in Utah, race track tickets in Maryland, college basketball tickets in Kentucky and all sorts of freebies to professional sports. Take a ticket in Wisconsin, however, and you'll be criminally prosecuted. Wisconsin is the only state that bars lawmakers from taking anything of value _ even a cup of coffee. Four Wisconsin senators were fined for accepting free lodging from a special interest while attending a Chicago Bears-Green Bay Packers football game. In a separate case, the Tobacco Institute was fined for giving tickets to a state senator for the Los Angeles Lakers-Boston Celtics basketball game during a legislative trip to Boston. Thirteen states set limits on the value of gifts a legislator can accept from a single lobbyist, ranging from a $10 per month in California to $100 per gift in West Virginia. But there's plenty of room for ambiguity. Despite Nebraska's limit of $25 per gift, a lobbyist onced hauled a senator around with a private plane until state officials intervened. Dannie Trautwein, executive director of the state's Accountability and Disclosure Commission, said the lobbyist was lectured on the intent of the state's lobbying law. But no one was prosecuted because of the vagaries of defining a gift. ``He looked me right in the eye and said the plane was just going in the same direction as the senator and anbyody could have gotten on it,'' Trautwein said.

Campaign Money Exerts Pressure on Lobbyists, Legislators
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The telephone message slips were piling up on lobbyist Loren Smith's desk. The callers were state legislators, and their message was written between the lines. They wanted money. Smith looked across the big wooden desk, across his spacious modern office and out the windows that framed the state Capitol gleaming in the sun. After 25 years as a lobbyist, he was troubled by what he saw. Like most lobbyists, Smith helps his clients dole out campaign contributions to legislators. It's a role that empowers lobbyists, guarantees their telephone calls will be returned and their faces remembered when they argue for their clients' interests. It can give them influence beyond that of the voters whom legislators ostensibly serve. But increasingly, it is giving them pause. Legislators' appetites for campaign funds are insatiable, and lobbyists say they can't fill the lawmakers' plates fast enough. ``I've never had to buy a vote in my life, nor do I intend to,'' said Smith, whose clients include such corporate giants as Dow Chemical and Pillsbury. And yet, he feels intense pressure to give money to legislators. The unspoken implication is that he'll lose his influence if he doesn't. ``The pressure for money doesn't come from us,'' he said. ``I'm not running over there'' _ he gestures toward the Capitol _ ``saying, `Can I give you some money for a vote?' I'm saying'' _ and now he slaps his forehead _ ```Oh God, another request!''' Other lobbyists say the same thing, and not just in Sacramento. Across the nation, legislative campaign spending is careening out of control and lobbyists can't _ or won't _ stop stoking the engines. ``The problem is that the legislators have gotten as greedy as the lobbyists,'' said state Sen. Julian L. Lapides of Maryland. The cost of running for public office has risen ever faster in the past decade, pulled by the lure of television advertising and pushed by the stick of competition. Legislative campaign expenses in California rose 180 percent between 1978 and 1988; the average race cost $610,000 by the end of that period. No other state is so costly, but campaign spending is the talk of statehouses from coast to coast. Campaign expenses rose 442 percent in Alaska between 1976 and 1988. Costs doubled in New Jersey between 1983 and 1987; quadrupled in Illinois between 1980 and 1988; and quintupled for Washington state Senate races between 1976 and 1986. ``It is out of hand. There's no question about it,'' said H. Donald Stewart, a New Jersey lobbyist who formerly served in that state's Assembly. When he first ran for office 25 years ago, $25,000 was considered a huge campaign warchest. ``Today, they make that on one fundraiser,'' Stewart said. ``And then they have a long way to go.'' In the trade route of campaign finance, moneyed interests are on one coast and politicians on the other. Lobbyists navigate between the two. They advise clients on how much to give and to whom, and they frequently deliver the money. Maryland lobbyist Bruce Bereano figures he'll have a hand in dispensing $150,000 in campaign funds this year. ``That's a conservative figure,'' he added. ``It depends on how the races shape up.'' Those with money aren't necessarily picky about who gets it. Frequently, lobbyists will recommend that clients give to both candidates in a close race _ just to make sure they help out the winner. ``It's like going to the racetrack and making a bet after the race,'' said Barry Kauffman of Pennsylvania Common Cause, which lobbies for open government and is critical of lobbyists' influence. Lobbyists in most states also buy tickets to legislative fundraising parties, which have become almost nightly events in most state capitals. In Sacramento or Albany, N.Y., tickets to fundraisers are frequently $500 or $1,000 each and lobbyists can be invited to as many as five or six in an evening. Richard Dugally, a lobbyist for Ford Motor Co. in Sacramento, figured he could have spent $105,000 in 1988 by buying one ticket to every fundraiser he was asked to attend. He bought none because it's Ford's policy not to do so. In some states, lobbyists are asked to do more than just buy tickets; they're expected to sell them, too. Lapides, the Maryland legislator, said some of his colleagues expect lobbyists to sell as many as 200 tickets each to fundraisers. ``A lobbyist can then become the prime fundraiser for a legislator,'' Lapides said. ``A legislator would find it impossible to view them, or legislation that the lobbyist has before that legislator, objectively.'' That gets to the heart of the issue: that lobbyists exert influence beyond that of an ordinary voter. Most say their influence derives from the interest groups they represent, not the money they spend. And at least some of the time, that's true. In California, environmental lobbyists exert a powerful influence, despite being outspent by wealthier opponents. In Delaware, legislators say the most powerful lobbyists are those who represent volunteer firefighters, whose ladders of influence extend to nearly every home in the state. Lobbyists say campaign contributions don't buy votes. They buy access, or a friendly relationship, or a sympathetic ear. Yet there is sometimes a fine line between access and influence. Last year, Oregon state Sen. Wayne Fawbush disappointed environmentalists by voting against a bill to protect a stand of old-growth trees _ a bill that Fawbush, considered a leading preservationist, had sponsored. Later, it was revealed Fawbush had received $12,000 in campaign contributions from the timber industry the previous election year. ``It tells us that the thousands of dollars he took from the timber industry counted when the chips were down,'' said Terry Nelson, the former executive director of Oregon Common Cause. Fawbush denied he had sold his vote, but conceded campaign contributions buy influence. ``If you have a large contributor, it's only human nature that you're going to listen to them,'' he said. ``But listening can't be equated to being bought.'' In New Mexico, state Sen. Shannon Robinson said he hadn't been getting contributions from oil and gas companies _ until he introduced a resolution calling on the state to study them. Right away, the money started flowing in, he said. ``I had to express an interest in an industry in order to get that industry's support,'' Robinson said. In that instance, the resolution didn't benefit the industry and had no binding effect. Robinson said he always has the best interest of voters at heart, and hasn't changed a vote because of the financial influence of a lobbyist. Still, he said, ``You get that kind of money and you think twice about the commitment those people made, and you try to help them with your vote when you can.'' Nevada Assemblyman Jim Banner said he cared deeply about what his constituents had to say. But constituents were rarely among his major campaign donors. And aside from a few zealots, he rarely heard from the people in his district. ``I like to feel clean about it,'' Banner said before he retired this year. ``But hell, a lot of times I push that button and I have no idea what my constituents want.''

DOC.HEAD: Door From the Legislature Leads to the Lobby
With PM-The Persuaders III
DOC.TEXT: There are no college degrees in legislative lobbying, no entrance exams and no written qualifications. But there is one sure way to become a lobbyist _ become a legislator first. In nearly every state, the ranks of the most successful lobbyists are filled with former legislators, former legislative aides and the occasional former governor or congressman. Just as those with money are attracted to the power of legislators, so are legislators attracted to the allures of money. It's hardly surprising. The highest paid legislators, those in New York state, earn under $60,000 a year; the lowest paid, those in New Hampshire, earn a token $100 a year. Good lobbyists in almost any state can earn more than $100,000 a year. In the biggest states, they can become millionaires. ``We resent it,'' said Alaska state Senate President Tim Kelly, who earns about $30,000 a year. ``The disparity between the legislator and the lobbyist is outrageous.'' But many legislators swallow their resentment and walk through the revolving door. There are more than two dozen former legislators working as lobbyists in Oklahoma, at least 50 in Texas, 35 in Illinois, 28 in New Mexico. When the North Carolina Center for Public Policy Research ranked lobbyists in that state according to their clout, six of the top 10 and eight of the top 15 were former legislators. In some states, such as Oklahoma and South Carolina, former legislators have at least one advantage over other lobbyists _ they are allowed onto the floor of the legislature during sessions. ``These other guys have to stay out there in the foyer,'' said South Carolina Rep. Herb Kirsh. ``These guys can come in, sit down, kneel by your desk and talk to you.'' Beyond that, former legislators bring a wealth of advantages to the lobby. They know the names and faces. They know how laws are made. They know how the political game is played. ``When hiring lobbyists, people ask who has special ins with the legislature,'' said Lester Brann, president of the Illinois State Chamber of Commerce. ``Well, former members of the Legislature have special ins with the Legislature.'' Few states have restrictions on how soon legislators can become lobbyists after giving up their seats, although some public interest groups support a cooling-off period between jobs. The most common path from legislator to lobbyist is the one followed by former Assemblyman Roger Bremner of Nevada, who became a lobbyist after running for the state Senate and losing. Bremner didn't go hunting for clients _ the news of his loss was as good as a ``Work Wanted'' ad. Although his background didn't guarantee success for his clients, it didn't hurt, either. ``I know a lot of the players,'' Bremner said. ``I know where the men's room is. I know how the system works.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-The Persuaders III
Campaign Limits Range Widely From State to State
DOC.TEXT: Nearly everyone complains about the high cost of campaigning, but state legislatures have been unable, or unwilling, to adopt regulations that would control the campaign arms race. Common Cause, among other groups, has argued that public financing is necessary if candidates are to be freed from the leash of special interests. That's because courts have ruled that states may not limit campaign spending unless they offer candidates public money. Yet only four states have any form of public financing of legislative races, and it hasn't put a lid on campaign spending in all of those states. Many people also worry about the propriety of legislators receiving contributions when they are actively considering legislation, but only six states bar candidates from receiving contributions during legislative sessions. States can limit the size of contributions, however, and many have. Twenty-seven have set a maximum on how much an individual can contribute to a single legislative candidate. These range from $220 per year in Arizona to $4,000-$9,092 per election for Senate candidates in New York. Seventeen states limit how much individuals can give to political action committees, ranging from $1,000 per year in Connecticut and Massachusetts to $150,000 per year in New York. California voters set a limit of $1,000 per contribution in 1988; that rule is getting its first test this year. Some fear it will put even more pressure on legislators to raise funds because they'll have to get more individual contributions to raise the same amount of money.

DOC.HEAD: The Political Pioneer Trail: From Washington to the Statehouses
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: If Ronald Reagan's New Federalism did nothing else, it taught Washington's lobbying corps that there is life _ and politics _ outside the Beltway. A surge of activity in state capitols has set off a political equivalent of the Gold Rush: Washington lobbyists flocking to lucrative diggings in Jefferson City and Juneau, Sacramento and Santa Fe, Boston and Baton Rouge. They have worked quietly, often unseen. But they have brought a new, sophisticated style of politics to state capitals, where old-fashioned shoe-leather lobbying is now augmented by television ad campaigns and computer-generated grassroots organizing. ``There's been a huge explosion of interest in the state level,'' said Paul Hallman, one of the founding partners of Multistate Associates, a lobbying firm with offices in Washington and Great Neck, N.Y. Multistate, which may be the largest firm of its type, maintains a roster of 1,500 local lobbyists in all 50 states. It hires them out to such clients as Apple Computer, Bristol-Myers, Citicorp, Johnson & Johnson, Metropolitan Life, Nabisco, Playtex, Procter & Gamble and Union Carbide. ``You can come to us and we can reach out anywhere in the country,'' said Steve Markowitz, the firm's other founding partner. Multistate, established in 1984, was among the first national lobbying firms to capitalize on the state legislative bonanza, but it is not alone. Hill & Knowlton, the huge public relations firm, recently entered the competition by buying out an established lobbying company, Hoog & Associates of Boulder, Colo. Tom Hoog, a former aide to Sen. Gary Hart who founded the firm, now works for Hill & Knowlton as a senior vice president. So far this year, he said, Hill & Knowlton has been active in 34 or 35 states and monitors legislation in all 50. He wouldn't name the company's clients. Hill & Knowlton has offices in only two state capitals _ Denver and Tallahassee, Fla. _ but Hoog said that will change soon. ``As I look down the road a couple years, I see us opening offices in 10 to 15 capitals, minimum,'' he said. Special interest groups and corporations, too, are sending their own lobbyists into the states in growing numbers. ``The states are the battlefield,'' said Florida lobbyist Lee Moffitt. ``The real power is in the legislature.'' The actual number of bills considered by legislatures has remained about the same the past decade _ it hovers around 200,000 a year for all 50 states, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. But the nature of the bills has changed. The issues are bigger, the stakes higher. Smoking. Abortion. Assault rifles. Toxic waste. Tort reform. AIDS. All are issues that once might have fallen solely under the purview of the federal government. Now each can be found on the agenda of nearly every legislature. Some credit President Reagan's New Federalism with stimulating statehouse lobbying by restoring power and responsibility to the states. ``By that yardstick, you'd have to say he was a major success, because issues did move to the states,'' said Hoog. Not that the federal government withered. It grew larger than ever in the Reagan years. But the Reagan administration certainly relinquished responsibility for some domestic tasks. And many critics say the Congress became a more difficult place to do business _ more politically charged, less open to consensus. Richard Gardiner, head of state government relations for the National Rifle Association, calls the New Federalism ``a lot of baloney.'' ``I think that the answer is that those who believe in more regulation have decided that the states are the next fertile field. The federal government can't do anything more. They've regulated so much, there's nothing left to regulate,'' he said. Gardiner speaks with some bitterness; his group has lost some tough battles over the right to own semiautomatic weapons. Still, the NRA can claim one of the most impressive track records of any lobbying group. It combines the tactical savvy of nine seasoned lobbyists with the grassroots clout of nearly 3 million members. The NRA's legislative lobbyists are the paratroopers of politics. There are seven in Washington, covering the eastern two-thirds of the nation, and two in Sacramento, Calif., covering the western third. They spend their days zooming from one capital to the next in a never-ending war against gun control. ``Our lobbyist for New England, for example, will go up to Albany (New York) for an afternoon, take a flight over to Portland or Augusta, Maine, spend the next morning there and then go down to Rhode Island ... that afternoon, and then zip over to Connecticut and come home,'' Gardiner said. NRA lobbyists are backed up by a grassroots organizing machine that is the envy of lobbyists everywhere. The NRA spends millions of dollars sending mail to its members, who respond with letters, telephone calls and personal visits to legislators. That kind of support is what other lobbyists are trying to cultivate. Once, ``grassroots'' suggested a brand of politics that was unsophisticated, unplanned and inexpensive _ a spontaneous movement on behalf of a candidate or cause. Now, with the help of the image-makers, grassroots lobbying can be slick, calculated and costly. Its aim is to persuade legislators that a lobbyist's position has popular support. The techniques can be as simple as a letter to citizens asking them to call or write their legislators. They can be as sophisticated as television commercials that subtly shift the public mood. ``I hate for anybody to refer to me as just a lobbyist anymore, because I don't think there's a market for just straight lobbying,'' said Hill & Knowlton's Hoog. ``I think you have to provide a base of support for your position.'' Gary Nordlinger is a specialist in drumming up that support. His Washington office is dominated by a large, wooden bookcase filled not with books, but with audio and video tapes. They represent his most tangible product. One videotape is a commercial produced for the Nevada State Education Association several years ago to bolster its clout at the legislature. Viewers were shown images of state prison inmates. The point: Nevadans could spend money on schools now or prisons later. ``It's now becoming increasingly common to do in a state capital what's been done in Congress, which is not only to use your lobbyist, but to rally public support, to run advocacy media, to do grassroots lobbying as well to get people to contact their legislators,'' Nordlinger said. ``Legislatures can be a lot more fun to work than the Congress, too. ... You know, if the Congress is a full-blown railroad, a state legislature is much more like a model train. Much easier to have a big impact.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: big impact.''
DOC.TEXT: Nordlinger's firm is just one of several that assist lobbyists nationwide without actually doing any lobbying themselves. They are an unregulated and potentially potent force that is one part of the future of legislative lobbying. Another glint of things to come shines in the 27th floor offices of TRW Inc. in Arlington, Va. From this steel and glass aerie overlooking Washington, Ernie Labelle shapes TRW's sophisticated approach to state legislative lobbying. Labelle, who directs state and constituent relations for the huge space and defense contractor, talks about government as a ``partner'' and says business must do more than respond to legislation _ it must shape it. TRW employs a ``vice president for public policy analysis'' whose full-time job, essentially, is to think deeply about important issues. It doesn't matter whether they have anything to do with TRW directly; the company sees benefits in the most tangential things. On a more down-to-earth level, TRW sends lobbyists into 15 or 20 states a year. It also has designed a computerized ``constituent network'' that allows Labelle to instantly tap into the company's 50,000-plus employees in the United States and get them on the phone to their legislators. ``It's a very structured, focused, disciplined, systems approach to grassroots lobbying,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: ``Way Of Cross'' Meditations Comfort Hard-Hit Farmers
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ``I fall and it is so hard to get up. I feel, `What is the use?' There are the drought of the land, emotional upheavals and spiritual droughts. I feel depression and sometimes despair. It hurts so much. Getting up is too much work. Now I am reminded how Jesus rose whenever he fell.''_ Floyd and Martha Hohman, McCutchenville farmers, from ``The Way of the Cross in Rural Life.''

When Seneca County farmer William Smith gets up at dawn, he looks out a window at his rich farm land and wonders about his family's future. In recent years, he's seen a soil-parching drought that withered crops in the field, and rains that left farm land a muddy mess, delaying planting and cutting yields. He has watched friends lose their farms, and helped comfort their families while their possessions were sold at auction. Through such uncertainty, Smith and his family find strength through Jesus and ``The Way of the Cross for Those in Rural Life,'' a 32-page religious pamphlet written by farmers and others involved in agriculture. ``We make mistakes and we fall. Jesus fell three times on his way to the cross and every time he fell he got back up. That's the way we look at trouble we've having on the farm. You have to pick yourself back up when you fall,'' the 39-year-old father of two said in an interview. This is the second year the pamphlet has been published by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Toledo's Rural Life Ministries, an organization that helps farmers and migrant farm workers. Sister Christine Pratt, ministries' director, said the booklet is popular with people engaged in agriculture. It is used in many rural parishes for devotional services. ``It is a spiritual walk with Jesus along the traditional stations of Jesus' trial, sufferings, death and resurrection, but includes meditations written by growers, dairy people, and others who are sensitive to the dependence on the growing cycles of nature,'' Sister Pratt said. The idea of publishing the pamphlet came to her in the summer of 1988 when a drought threatened the livelihoods of many farmers. Farm couples or individuals involved in food issues and migrant farm workers were asked to write their feelings, based on Scripture involving Jesus' walk to his crucifixion. The booklet is popular with farmers because the passages are written by people who understand the pain they go through, she said. ``They are written by our brothers, our sisters, our neighbors, our friends _ people who have been able to help us see how we can take the passion of Jesus and identify with it in a way that is close to our own experience,'' she said. ``I have given them to individual farmers, whether they be Catholic or Protestant. Many of them are in the middle of foreclosures and I give it to them to pray over, so they know that someone else is sharing what they're going through,'' she said. Smith and his wife, Jane, 37, wrote a passage for the booklet, based on when Jesus starts on his way to Calvary. ``Jesus silently accepted the rough wooden cross, though he had committed no wrong. Consider the farmer and the farm family who depend on variables out of their control. The weather, international trade and government policies have all affected the farmer,'' the Smiths wrote. ``As a result, many farmers or their spouses have been forced to find work off the farm to supplement their income. In dealing with this stress, some farmers withdraw from family and friends and face the loneliness that Jesus must have felt when betrayed by Peter.'' Mrs. Smith, 37, recalls when she and her husband wrote the passage. ``It was during the drought, when farmers were having so much trouble through a variety of things. I saw several friends experience anguish. I sat down and prayed about it, and this is what I thought of and decided to contribute,'' she said. Whenever the Smiths feel depressed about problems on their 800-acre dairy farm, they take solace in the pamphlet. ``It's beautiful because of the contributions from so many people. It helps us pray to the Lord. We can all associate with the sufferings of Christ,'' she said. Farmers in the past decade contended with foreclosures, land depreciation, inflation, low commodity prices, bad weather and shrinking markets. Agricultural experts say conditions should improve in the 1990s, but more for commercial farmers than the small part time or family farmer. ``It's rough for many farmers,'' Smith said. ``Some don't think things will get much better. But you always have to have hope. When you fall, you have to get up.''

DOC.TEXT: RICHMOND, Va. (AP) The world's Christian population grew by about 326 million during the past decade to an estimated 1.75 billion, says a noted expert on religious statistics. The Rev. David Barrett, an Anglican priest, editor of the World Christian Encyclopedia and now a consultant to the Southern Baptist Foreign Mission Board, cited the figures in the International Bulletin of Missionary Research. The new total amounts to about 33 percent of the world's 5.3 billion people, including 963 million Roman Catholics, 324 million Protestants, 180 million Eastern Orthodox and 54 million Anglicans, the ecumenical fortnightly, Christianity Today, reports. Another 232 million apparently were unclassified in those groupings.

A Christian monitoring organization says network television reduced the amount of sex, violence, profanity and anti-Christian stereotyping last year by 32 percent. The Rev. Billy Melvin, chairman of Christian Leaders for Responsible Television (CLeaR-TV), says some companies apparently were responding to the organization's activity in the shows they sponsor. CLear-TV is a coalition of about 1,600 Christian leaders from nearly every denomination, including top leaders of about 70 denominations.

Back from conferring with church leaders in the Philippines, the president of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod said basic elements remain of links to the Lutheran Church in the Philippines. The board of directors of that church voted in March to sever partner relationship with the the 2.6 million-member denomination based in Missouri. The Rev. Ralph A. Bohlmann, president of LCMS, said the talks convinced him that the ``basic component of our fellowship is intact. ... Given time to heal, this relationship can be salvaged and restored.'' However, he said, only the Philippine church can resolve problems at the root of the interchurch difficulty.

The American Jewish Committe has endorsed in principle electoral and constitutional reforms for the state of Israel, but says only Israeli citizens can determine whether and in what form such steps occur. AJC President Sholom D. Commay said: ``We believe that electoral reforms should be enacted, and protections of human rights should be more explicitly and firmly codified into the legal structure of Israel, so that the nation may better cope with its own unique and often perilous problems.''

Many church leaders were involved in recent protest demonstrations against the death penalty in Florida, Georgia and North Carolina. In demonstrations in Raleigh and Atlanta, a statement by Episcopal Presiding Bishop Edmond L. Browning was read, calling the death penalty ``an affront to God'' because all people are made in God's image. ``The taking of human life diminishes us as a people,'' he said, because ``we end up committing the very act we found so repugnant in the first place.''

Cross Currents, an influential quarterly journal which for 50 years has explored the implications of religion for modern life, is merging with another quarterly, Religion & Intellectual Life. Cross Current's founding editor Joseph Cunneen and associate William Birmingham will be co-editors along with Sister Nancy Malone of the Association for Religion and Intellectual Life. Name of the merged publications whose first issue appears in June: Cross Currents: Religion & Intellectual Life.
