DOC.HEAD: Water Complicates Turkey's Relations With Neighbors
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Arguments about water are complicating relations with Arab neighbors that Turkey spent a quarter-century building. A conflict over the waters of the Euphrates River has soured relations with Syria and Iraq. Reports that Turkey planned to sell water to Israel have angered the Arab world generally. Libya refuses to pay $250 million it owes Turkish construction companies, citing increased friendliness between Turkey and Israel, a diplomatic source said privately. Economists and scientists say rapidly growing populations in the Middle East could cause a disastrous water shortage. Turkey has plenty of water, much of it running unharnessed into the surrounding seas. It averted one dispute over the precious resource by backing off a proposed project with Medusa Inc. of Canada for moving water from the Manavgat River in southern Turkey to other countries, government and company official said. Medusa has developed a technology for transporting water in huge, balloon-like plastic containers pulled by ships. Italy showed interest in using the method to transport water to the islands of Sicily and Sardinia, and Israel also was looking into it, the officials said. Turkish officials described the project, requiring an investment of about $200 million, as a private venture with no political dimension. They said private firms would buy and ship the water for other countries. Arab nations apparently did not accept that explanation, which ignored the fact that the Turkish government would be selling the water, and Turkey did not go through with the deal. Medusa, worried about possible terrorist action, also was said to be having second thoughts. Foreign Minister Ali Bozer said in a recent statement that ``there is no project to sell water to Israel.'' He also said Turkey had not received a positive reply to a proposal to provide ``friendly Arab countries'' with water. His reference was to the ``peace pipeline'' proposal put forth several years ago by Turgut Ozal, then premier. Under it, a 1,500-mile pipeline would carry water from the Seyhan and Ceyhan rivers in the south to the Arabian peninsula. The project would require an investment of $21 billion. Shelving the water transport project may have averted a political crisis, but no simple solution is possible in a dispute over Euphrates water. Turkey blocked most of the river's flow in January to raise the water level in the reservoir of the Ataturk Dam, being built as the centerpiece of a huge irrigation and power project in southeastern Turkey. Syria and Iraq protested the action, which demonstrated Turkey's stranglehold on the vital waters. The Euphrates originates in the mountains of eastern Turkey and flows 1,460 miles through Syria and Iraq to a confluence with the Tigris River that empties into the Persian Gulf. The two rivers have been the lifelines of one of the cradles of world civilization. Water disputes have threatened to undo a generation of Turkish efforts to improve relations with the Arabs. Turkey has supported Arab causes in international forums, joined the Islamic Conference Organization and demoted relations with Israel from the ambassadorial to minister-counselor level. Syria and Iraq now demand talks with Turkey on an agreement to specify the exact amount of water each will receive from the Euphrates. Turkey has suggested a ministerial meeting in Ankara, but Turkish officials say privately they have no intention of accepting a quota system. There are no international rules to force Turkey into a sharing agreement, government officials say, and they describe the demands of the two southern neighbors as excessive. At a meeting last year, Iraq demanded 25 billion cubic meters of water and and Syria 14 billion from the average annual flow of 32 billion cubic meters, the Turkish officials said. Instead, Turkey has offered free electricity to Syria and joint irrigation projects to both countries.

DOC.HEAD: Justice System Accused of Delay, Favoritism
DOC.TEXT: Panama's justice system, once considered the lapdog of a corrupt military, now is accused of being a glacially slow institution whose prosecutors take bribes to bury cases. Of more than 5,000 cases received by the attorney general's office in the first four months of 1990, after the U.S. invasion that ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, none had gone to court by early June. Edgardo Molino Mola, a Supreme Court justice, told reporters more than 13,000 cases were pending in one judicial district where the number of judges was fixed by law at 53. Opinions on how to change the situation range from revising the law on judicial procedures to requiring that all judges have some legal training. Deputy prosecutor Rosa de Contreras told The Associated Press: ``The problem is not with the prosecutors ... but with the law that establishes court terms we must follow. ... The law has not been changed.'' Juan Materno Vasquez, former chief justice of the Supreme Court, said the law is fine, but complained of ``inexperience and a lack of technical preparation of appointed judges, some of whom have never even been lawyers.'' Molino Mola said more judges and courtrooms were needed. In San Milguelito, a working-class suburb of Panama City, he said, ``there are 1,200 cases pending before just one judge. As for justice, people are disgusted with notorious criminals going free on bond.'' ``They worry about the slow pace of the judicial process, the lack of prosecution of embezzlers and torturers and that, because of bungled prosecutions, the courts have had to free some people,'' he said in a statement. His remarks were published by the Civic Crusade, an organization of business and professional people that led the Panamanian opposition to Noriega. Some officials of the Noriega regime face specific charges of torture, but the public prosecutor's office has not said how many. They include Felipe Camargo, accused of torturing Crusade members. Military officers involved in unsuccessful coups against Noriega have said they and other conspirators also were tortured. The Civic Crusade declared: ``It is the responsibility of the attorney general and the prosecutors that the cases they bring .. . be careful and complete and meet legal requirements to avoid having them dismissed for lack of evidence or for defects.'' Molina Mola claimed the government of Guillermo Endara, which took over after the invasion, was allowing cronies of Noriega to go free pending trial. The general is in the United States, facing charges of drug trafficking. Ricardo Bermudez, a Crusade official, said: ``The justice system is the first national emergency the government should attend to. We are aimlessly turning criminals free, something that unnerves and angers people. ``If this continues, the democratic longings Panamanians fought so long for could be in danger because the will of the people will not be met.'' Former chief justice Vasquez, who supported Noriega's Democratic Revolutionary Party, said in an interview: ``In criminal justice, processes are slow. Justice has been interrupted. Judicial terms were interrupted from Dec. 21, 1989 (when the invasion began) until Jan. 29, 1990.'' ``The attitude of the prosecutors hasn't changed. They were on the take from the military and they are on the take from the people in office now,'' he said, referring to former supporters of Noriega who still are in the government and hope to avoid being charged. Eusebio Marchosky, in charge of recovering state property stolen by Noriega and his followers, has claimed publicly his investigations were being undermined by officials still still loyal to the ousted genral. ``There is interference in the investigations, attacks on depositories of goods considered to be ill-gotten, and there are political and economic links to the deposed Gen. Manuel Noriega,'' he said. Marchosky added that investigations were hampered by lack of evidence and ``the Americans still have 15,000 boxes of judicial documents.'' Return of the documents is one of several matters being discussed by the United States and Panama. The United States seized tons of documents during the invasion, hoping they would help track Noriega's alleged involvement in narcotics trafficking. What seems to worry Panamanians most, as revealed by letters to editors and comments on call-in radio shows, is balancing justice with the need to reunite the country. In suggesting solutions, Vasquez mentioned expelling offenders for a time, ``because a politician in exile is harmless,'' a practice followed in Brazil; the total amnesty Nicaragua used to bring Contra rebels back into society, or the Colombian method of collaboration among political groups. His own solution, Vasquez said, would be to separate the handling of serious and lesser crimes, ``ease tensions and bring about a climate of calm.''

DOC.HEAD: In India, There's a TV Epic to End All TV Epics
DOC.TEXT: In the United States, ``War and Remembrance'' lasted 39{ hours and was considered one of the longest miniseries ever. But how about one lasting more than 18 months? There is such a maxiseries. It's called ``The Mahabharata,'' and it's still running on Indian television. It won't end until July 8. Based on a mythological Hindu epic that is the longest poem in world literature, ``The Mahabharata'' is the country's hottest show, even though it airs at an hour that would amaze U.S. networks. Each one-hour episode of the Indian drama starts at 9 a.m. on Sundays. Despite that early hour, Doordarshan, the government department that controls India's only nationwide TV channel, estimates the show attracts an average audience of 90 million people each week _ or more than one-tenth of India's population of 880 million. The serial is in the Hindi language, but Doordarshan officials say its appeal reaches far beyond the northern, Hindi-speaking regions of the country. In the southern state of Kerala, for example, newspapers publish a transcript of each week's show in Malayalam, the local language. ``People here are highly involved in `The Mahabharata,' '' says I.G. Venugopal, a resident of Trivandrum, the capital of Kerala. ``They read the newspaper to get to know the outline and then watch the serial.'' ``The Mahabharata'' also appears to have transcended religious barriers in India, where 82 percent of the people are Hindu but there are large communities of Moslems, Sikhs and Christians. In one New Delhi house, two Moslem carpenters installing new windows threatened to take Sunday off unless they were given access to the television set. ``I watch the serial every week. If I miss an episode now, I won't understand anything,'' said one of them, Naseem Ahmed. His remarks would be familiar to American viewers of ABC's surreal, convoluted ``Twin Peaks.'' That series is set in a small logging town in the Pacific Northwest. ``The Mahabharata'' has a somewhat wider scope. It's a kaleidoscope of court intrigue and fierce battles between two sets of feuding brothers, tempered with religion, philosophy and the virtues and vices of princes and aspiring kings. Many Hindus learn the story in their childhood, when it is re-told as the victory of good over evil with the five good Pandava brothers defeating the 100 bad Kaurava brothers. But now, as the show begins to peak (the 99th Kaurava brother recently was killed in battle), several twists and nuances are beginning to come through. The Pandavas aren't pure: They have used every trick in the book to win. And some on the Kaurava side aren't totally bad. Their army chief, the illegitimate son of the mother of the Pandavas, is chivalrous in battle. And the guru of the Pandavas, another good guy, was on the Kaurava side until he died. ``Most of this we didn't know,'' says Shailendra Chopra, an employee of Indian Airlines and another avid viewer. ``It's like a crime thriller. What will happen next?'' ``It will take a long time for us to get another serial like this,'' said Abdul Sattar Tatari, the Doordarshan official in charge of television programs. ``Both in terms of audience appeal and revenue.'' Doordarshan plans to bring out a serial on Indian war heroes in the ``Mahabharata'' slot after the current epic ends next month, Tatari said. ``It definitely won't be as popular,'' he said. ``People seem to prefer going back to mythological serials, and we are also trying to get one of those for telecast within a few months.'' ``I have to feed my kids in front of the television set on Sundays,'' grumbled Gurmeet Kaur, a New Delhi housewife. When told of the program that will replace ``The Mahabharata'' next month, she said she doubted things would improve at home. ``War heroes?'' she said. ``I guess it's back to eating breakfast at the dining table.''

Elsewhere in television ... TED & FIDEL: Cable tycoon Ted Turner, not known as a journalist although he founded Cable News Network, this month taped an interview with Cuban leader Fidel Castro, whom he first met in 1982. The interview has been boiled down into a one-hour special, ``A Conversation with Fidel Castro,'' which CNN will air June 25 at 9 p.m. EDT. The program features Castro's views on a wide variety of matters, CNN says, from Cuban-Soviet relations to allegations of Cuban involvement in drug trafficking.

DOC.HEAD: Politicians Read Different Signals in California Tax Approval
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Looking for omens in California's vote to increase the state gasoline tax, politicians in both parties are reading the signals that suit them. They aren't checking the fine print, though. The administration sees the referendum vote for higher gasoline taxes as proof that President Bush's national transportation policy took the right route in recommending that state and local governments pay a bigger share of the cost of rebuilding roads, bridges and other facilities. Democrats, who had criticized that approach, said Californians showed that people are willing to accept higher taxes, so long as they know in advance that the money will be spent on real needs, and won't be wasted. That argument could be tailored to fit demands that the president renounce his campaign vow to block any new taxes, and tell the voters that it has to be done to deal with the budget deficit. An increase in the federal gasoline tax is among the options that budget negotiators are likely to consider. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, proposed boosting it sharply to help balance the budget and at the same time reduce U.S. dependence on imported oil. But deficit reduction is a general goal, not a specific one like the highways and bridges that are to be rebuilt with the proceeds of the California gas tax boost. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said that if the federal gas tax were to be increased from the current 9 cents a gallon _ a step he carefully avoided endorsing _ the money should be earmarked for the transportation infrastructure and nothing else. Skinner said the June 5 vote in California shows that state and local governments are willing to take on a greater share of transportation costs, and that the voters will back them, so long as new tax revenues are used for that specific purpose. He said people distrust the way governments spend money, but are less reluctant to accept tax increases when they know exactly how the revenues will be used. ``I think it validates one of the principles that has been somewhat contentious,'' Skinner said. ``It's time to act,'' Bush had said in presenting the transportation plan earlier this year, and promising the states more flexibility in the use of less federal aid. At the time, critics in both parties said it set national goals and assumed the states would pay the bill. ``Read my lips; raise your taxes,'' said Gov. James R. Thompson Jr. of Illinois, a Republican. Skinner said the states should be increasing their transportation taxes, that 18 have done so in the past year and 33 in the past two years. Until the voters agreed to raise the California gas tax from 9 cents to 18 cents a gallon over the next five years, the rate there had been held at bargain level. The California tax had been increased only 2 cents a gallon since 1963. While there is a tendency to look at the California vote as another bellwether from the state that began the tax revolt a dozen years ago, this time the message may be that there is none. The political circumstances are not going to be matched elsewhere. After an intensive campaign for the measure, the voters agreed by a relatively narrow margin to ease a state spending ceiling dating from the tax revolt, and to begin phasing in the gasoline tax boost. According to the National Journal, California ranks last among the states in per capita spending on transportation. Its gasoline tax was the fourth lowest in the country; the national average is 16.3 cents a gallon. Even with the increase, the tax won't pass the current national average for three years. Republican Gov. George Deukmejian and state Democratic leaders joined in support of the measure. So did interest groups, business to labor, unlikely allies, unanimous this time. About $6 million was spent to support the measure, in a campaign with no major, organized opposition. The freeway casualties of the October 1989 earthquake, and chronic gridlock on urban highways served to dramatize the problem. The revenues are tightly earmarked: $15.5 billion to build and improve freeways over the next decade. For all that, the referendum was approved with only 52 percent of the vote in a low-turnout primary election. ``The only significance I see is that Californians were smarter than I thought they were,'' said Sen. Warren B. Rudman, R-N.H. He said there was no national message in a state decision that higher gas taxes were preferable to hours-long traffic jams.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Big Trend on Campus _ Coping With Rape
DOC.TEXT: America's colleges, increasingly concerned about gang and acquaintance rape, are starting to teach students a more elemental lesson than English lit and Geology 101: that it takes two to say ``yes'' to sex. At campuses around the country, schools are sponsoring hotlines, courses and workshops to counter the widespread conviction that when it comes to sex, it's every man for himself. Many campus males feel ``you should always be ready to have sex, even if you don't want to,'' says Toby Simon, assistant dean of student life at Brown University. ``Don't ask a woman how far you can go _ just start making moves.'' Four years ago, Simon surveyed students to learn if they'd ever had sex against another person's will. Ten percent of the men _ at a school where students ``have a tendency to be politically correct'' _ admitted they had. ``That, to me, was a real trigger that we had to do something,'' said Simon, who also is director of health education. At the time, few schools admitted a problem existed. But Simon's efforts put Brown in the forefront of sex crime education. Now, slowly, other schools are following that lead and, as awareness grows, it appears more victims are coming forward _ and are being taken seriously. Bernice Sandler, director of the Association of American Colleges' Project on the Status of Women, has documented about 100 campus gang rapes nationwide over the past five years. ``For every one that's publicized, there must be easily more than a hundred that are not publicized,'' said Sandler. ``I've asked students, `Does this happen on your campus?' and I'm told, `Just about every week.''' Rape by solitary acquaintances also is common. Studies show 15 percent to 25 percent of all women undergraduates have been physically or psychologically intimidated into having sex against their will, Sandler said. ``I don't know if many more instances are occurring now than 20 years ago. It's just that the females are more willing and capable of speaking out and bringing charges _ which I think is good,'' said Durward Owen, executive director of the Pi Kappa Phi fraternity, headquartered in Charlotte, N.C. Pi Kappa Phi, which has 6,500 members at 142 colleges and universities, voted six years ago to take a stand against sexual abuse. Owen said a growing number of fraternities have begun discussing the problem in the past two years. ``We noticed so many instances of athletic team rapes and dorm rapes and date rapes being reported,'' he said. ``It appeared that many times, these things had gone on in the past and were accepted at face value.'' Pi Kappa Phi mails literature to its chapters and examines the issue at regional meetings. Its chapters often offer seminars with other campus groups. Colleges are taking many other tacks: _At Brown, victims can count on a campuswide help network, including 24-hour-a-day telephone counseling. Simon works to prevent both assaults and ``sexual misadventures: bad results that occur because people do not know how to talk about sex, because they do not make their needs known, and because they drink too much.'' Simon repeats the message at freshmen orientation and in a sexuality course. She addresses student groups, including fraternities, ``in extremely candid, graphic ways, using students to do role playing, using students' language.'' _In 1984, two women at Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania told a dormitory assistant that they had been abused by acquaintances. In response, students produced a consciousness-raising video to be shown to freshmen in dorms. Discussions follow. Since the tape was produced, Swarthmore has sold about 100 copies to other schools and organizations. _Awareness was heightened at the University of California-Berkeley in 1986 after a student said she was raped by four ootball players in a dormitory. No charges were filed and the football players were not suspended, but they were forced to move out of the dorm, do 100 hours of community service and write apologies to the woman, said university spokeswoman Pat McBroom. Amid the resulting uproar, a faculty-student task force investigated women's safety and the campus climate. In January 1987, Chancellor Ira Michael Heyman sent a letter to some 30,000 students, condemning sexual abuse and noting that ``No means no.'' Now, rape prevention workshops are held for various campus groups. There are indications that other schools will be following in the footsteps of Brown, Swarthmore and Berkeley. The Association of American Colleges has issued about 100 recommendations to its members on how to prevent rape, respond to victims and discipline rapists. In 1987, California's Legislature voted to suggest that the state's colleges and universities adopt codes prohibiting rape and setting penalties, including suspension or expulsion on conviction. The resolution also suggests rape prevention seminars for freshmen, fraternities and sororities. Building on the resolution, California Assemblywoman Lucille Roybal-Allard has introduced a bill requiring essentially all colleges and universities to follow specific procedures in the event of sexual abuse, including calling the police when the victim allows it. In New York, a report of the governor's Task Force on Rape and Sexual Assault has recommended the State University of New York and City University of New York develop strong prevention programs. ``Campus-based surveys have indicated that many students lack an understanding of, or deny, what constitutes a rape,'' said the report. Ignorance is only one aspect of the problem; mob psychology, peer pressure and alcohol abuse also contribute. Sandler, of the Association of American Colleges, said most gang rapists are fraternity brothers or team athletes. ``Very often, these men are simply raping for each other,'' she said. ``They'll do something they might not do if they were by themselves.'' Women who report campus attacks often are harassed by the rapists and their friends, Sandler said. Many drop out or switch schools after their attackers start using sexual slurs or other intimidation tactics. Shawn Johnston, a forensic psychologist at the University of California-Davis who treats sex offenders, said there are times, such as when alcohol is involved, when ``the line that differentiates the consensual, or voluntary, from a forcible act is fairly thin.'' That, say women's advocates, contributes to a ``blame the victim'' attitude, even by the victim herself. ``I don't care if a woman walks into the room raving drunk and stark naked: it's not an excuse to be raped,'' said Claire Kaplan, executive director of the Washington-based National Coalition Against Sexual Assault. Brown's Simon agrees, but still urges caution. She says booze can lead men to ``push themselves on women, misread the cues they're getting from a potential partner.'' Then, an inebriated woman might not be able to fight off an attacker. ``This attitude exists with men: `Give them enough to drink and they'll be easy,''' she said. ``I've had men tell me, `If she passes out, then we have sex, is that rape?' I say to these men, `What kind of a lover are you? Sex is something that happens with two alert, conscious people.''' Owen, of Pi Kappa Phi, said it took about 30 years to reach the ``obsession with alcohol'' that often triggers campus rapes. ``We can't do all that much to make it turn around in hurry,'' he said. ``But I think an amazing turnaround is starting to occur.''

DOC.HEAD: Odds Get Tougher For Stock Investors
DOC.TEXT: After the stock market bonanza of the 1980s, many savers and investors seem bound and determined not to miss out on the promise of the 1990s. In particular, they have been pouring money into stock mutual funds, both on their own and through retirement programs such as company-sponsored 401(k) savings plans. Their inspiration comes from many sources: the apparent end of the Cold War and the perceived triumph of capitalism over communism in many parts of the world; opportunities in fields like health care, technology and the environment; and, not so coincidentally, the recent rise of the U.S. stock market itself to record highs. Much of this optimism may prove justified, says a financial advisory firm long known as a staunch advocate of investing in stocks. But it also cautions that anyone hoping for a replay of the '80s in the next decade is bucking some long statistical odds. ``We are not doom and gloomers,'' says Norman Fosback at the Institute for Econometric Research, publisher of a series of newsletters on investing. But the percentage returns from stocks in the '90s, he declares, ``will almost certainly fall far short of those earned in the 1980s.'' While there are no absolute limits on the gains stocks can achieve, Fosback observes, ``there are a few constants'' that can be used in assessing their possibilities and probabilities. For starters, he notes, the 500 stocks that make up Standard & Poor's composite index produced a total return _ appreciation plus dividends _ in the 1980s at an average compound annual rate of about 18 percent. That ranks far above the historical trend rate, after all the booms and busts are figured together, of about 10 percent. Stocks and the economy, furthermore, began the 1980s at a very low point _ which Fosback says effectively magnified the opportunities for gains. In financial matters, he says, ``when there is a lot of room for improvement, and little room for further discouragement, the path of least resistance is to the upside.'' When Wall Street's bull market began in 1982, the stock of a typical company sold at a price about seven times its annual earnings. Today price-earnings ratios are more than double that, in the neighborhood of 15 to 1 or 16 to 1. For another doubling of P-Es to occur in the '90s, Fosback notes, they would have to soar to their highest levels in history. Similarly, he argues, there is less room for growth in business activity and corporate earnings with an unemployment rate around 5 percent starting the 1990s than there was in the early 1980s, when unemployment stood near 11 percent. ``It is likely that unemployment is already close to its lowest possible level right now,'' he says. ``This means that real national growth will probably increase 3 percent or less per annum in the 1990s, not the 4 percent-plus rates of the last eight years. ``Irrespective of political, social and economic forces, investors will probably earn a much lower return in the 1990s than the 18 percent per-annum total return recorded in the 1980s,'' Fosback concludes. ``Does all this mean that the Dow can't reach 3,000, 3,600 or 5,000? Of course not. At some point during the decade, the market will probably again sell at 20 times earnings. ``What our analysis does indicate is that long-term buy and hold investors will not find the stock market to be the sure thing that it was in the 1980s.''

DOC.HEAD: The Return To Long-Term Goals
DOC.TEXT: From time to time the economy goes through a phase in which long-term goals are abandoned, fundamentals are forgotten and only the next hour, day or week seems to count. The economy becomes volatile, stock prices gyrate, inflation erupts, quick killings are sought and often achieved in real estate and securities, get-rich-quick schemes abound and corporations wheel and deal. And then it all evaporates, although not until warning signs and omens _ bankruptcies, scandals, prosecutions _ become too numerous to ignore. The old ways come back. Basics are rediscovered; the vision is again long term. Like now. These phases of the cycle are never so sharply defined that they produce headlines; there are always frayed edges and exceptions to the generality, but still the pattern can be discerned: On Wall Street, for example, where analysts now talk about a company's price-to-earnings ratio rather than the possibility that it might be taken over by a larger company, with a sudden and spectacular rise in price. In the housing markets, where prices are more sensible than they were a year ago and where the buyer now buys a house as a place in which to live rather than a place in which to invest money for a big return. In corporations, where managers are fed up with the destructive practice of draining ever-higher short-term profits by refusing to ``waste'' money on research and capital improvements that make for a stronger future. And where boards of directors are withdrawing those management incentives tied to short-term profits and demanding instead that companies be made more competitive in the global marketplace. At the Federal Reserve, where economic manipulation is in disfavor and the goal now is to achieve modest, long-term economic stability, even if it means walking a tightrope over the chasm of recession before that goal is achieved. In organized labor, where workers join management to raise corporate productivity even if it means forgoing big wage increases, the notion being that a stronger company conveys greater long-term benefits. In consumer markets, where people have begun curtailing their propensity to borrow as if there were no tomorrow and are tending to save a bit more, forgoing purchases that once were almost automatic. These patterns can be discerned over varying lengths of time, and sometimes patterns of calm and then excitement occur within larger patterns. But in the marketplace, the past two decades certainly qualify as a period of volatility. The stock market erupted time after time, then collapsed in cold ashes. Rumors pervaded the market, and every day stocks with a story were promoted _ takeovers, buyouts, new products _ or demoted when they fell into debt. Fundamental analysis often was ignored; in the new marketplace there was no time for such things. Why settle for 7 percent annual dividends when you might make that in a day on price appreciation? Volatility and change invite creativity, new ways of doing things, short cuts: junk bonds, trading shenanigans, computer manipulations, tax-avoidance schemes. A new immorality arises _ until the culprits are caught. Enough of these culprits have been caught in the past couple of years to suggest that the easy way, the short-cut route, doesn't pay, either on Wall Street or in corporate management or among consumers. Indicative of this is an announcement from a large benefits consulting firm after it polled corporations on the types of incentives they were offering. It offered this report: ``Long-term incentive plans may be the way of the future, according to a recent survey. ... ``Findings revealed 28 percent of participating companies offered long-term incentive plans to executives in 1985, while 40 percent plan to offer such programs by 1995.'' Just as it used to be, back before all the short-term business began.

DOC.HEAD: Lost Causes and Hot Jazz Fill New Orleans Church
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It's fitting the little statue labeled St. ``Expedite'' should end up at Our Lady of Guadeloupe. The old Roman Catholic church on the edge of the French Quarter with its shrine to St. Jude has long been a haven to the homeless, the helpless and many of life's misfits. On a bright spring morning a young man kneels in prayer at the altar, an elderly woman lights a candle at the statue of St. Jude, and an old man in ragged clothes sits in a patch of sunlight by the door, his shopping bags around his feet. ``People come here from all over the city, but we have a lot of people who come from the French Quarter and here on Rampart Street and from the Iberville housing project directly behind us,'' said the Rev. William Zapalac, who has been at the church eight years. ``We see a lot of life in this location. Things are always hopping.'' Called the Mortuary Chapel for many years, the church was built in 1826 to handle the funerals of victims of the an outbreak of yellow fever. ``In those days they thought it was spread by the dead so they didn't want to have them in the Quarter,'' said Millie Brown, an 80-year-old parishoner. ``They'd bring them here and then zip them right across the street to the cemetery. They say there would be hundreds of wagons with coffins lined up on them outside the church.'' St. ``Expedite'' showed up about the turn of the century. Legend has it the statue arrived at the docks without paperwork or address. ``The only thing they saw was the word `Expedite' on the side of the crate,'' said Tom Finney, spokesman for the New Orleans Diocese. ``In those days there were a lot of first-generation Italians and Irish on the New Orleans docks and they didn't read English very well. They thought `Expedite' was the name of a saint so they delivered the statute to the church.'' Today it stands by the door, a cross in one hand and a sheaf of wheat in the other. The name on the statue is in quotes, St. ``Expedite.'' ``There really is a St. Expedite. I don't know if this is him or not, but he fits in here, anyway,'' said Zapalac. Four times a year the little church is host for a nine-day St. Jude Novena that draws 3,000 to 4,000 people a day. St. Jude, the patron saint of lost causes, spends the rest of the year dealing with a variety of people and pleas from the local community. There is no lack of work, Zapalac said. ``Being right here by the French Quarter we get a lot of the more unusual people from there. In New Orleans, I find people are much more tolerant of unusual people. Some places, people would be afraid of many of the people we really enjoy here,'' the priest said. Rampart Street, with its seedy hotels and cheap bars, has become a mecca for the homeless, Zapalac said. ``We're seeing more and more homeless people all the time. Some of them we get to know very well,'' he said. Some of them, like a mother and daughter who lived on the streets, are puzzles without solutions, he said. The church found housing several times for the mother, who was in her 50s, and her daughter, in her 30s, but they always returned to the streets, Zapalac said. ``I don't know what happened to them. They finally disappeared. I think they were afraid of being trapped somehow if they stayed in the housing we found for them,'' he said. Iberville, a vast collection of decaying brick buildings, is home for many of the city's poor, including many of the church's parishioners. But on Saturday nights it's not problems that are the focus of the early Mass, it's the city and its music that come to the forefront in the church's Jazz Mass. The Jazz Mass is the only one in the world, Zapalac believes. ``There's always piano and organ and drums and trumpet and sometimes other instruments, depending on who's here,'' he said. ``It's really something when we get going.''

DOC.TEXT: The world's Christian population grew by about 326 million during the past decade to an estimated 1.75 billion, an expert on religious statistics says. The Rev. David Barrett, an Anglican priest, editor of the World Christian Encyclopedia and now a consultant to the Southern Baptist Foreign Mission Board, cited the figures in the International Bulletin of Missionary Research. The new total amounts to about 33 percent of the world's 5.3 billion people. It includes 963 million Roman Catholics, 324 million Protestants, 180 million Eastern Orthodox and 54 million Anglicans, the ecumenical fortnightly Christianity Today reports. An additional 232 million Christians were not included in those groupings.

Cross Currents, an influential quarterly journal that for 50 years has explored the implications of religion for modern life, is merging with another quarterly, Religion & Intellectual Life. Cross Current's founding editor, Joseph Cunneen, and associate William Birmingham will be co-editors with Sister Nancy Malone of the Association for Religion and Intellectual Life. The name of the new combined publication is Cross Currents: Religion & Intellectual Life.

Many church leaders were involved in recent protest demonstrations against the death penalty in Florida, Georgia and North Carolina. In demonstrations in Raleigh and Atlanta, a statement by Episcopal Presiding Bishop Edmond L. Browning was read, calling the death penalty ``an affront to God'' because all people are made in God's image. ``The taking of human life diminishes us as a people,'' because ``we end up committing the very act we found so repugnant in the first place,'' he said.

The American Jewish Committe has endorsed in principle electoral and constitutional reforms for the state of Israel, but says only Israeli citizens can determine whether and in what form such steps occur. AJC President Sholom D. Commay said: ``We believe that electoral reforms should be enacted, and protections of human rights should be more explicitly and firmly codified into the legal structure of Israel, so that the nation may better cope with its own unique and often perilous problems.''

Back from conferring with church leaders in the Philippines, the president of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod said basic elements remain of links to the Lutheran Church in the Philippines. The board of directors of the Philippine church voted in March to sever its relationship with the 2.6 million-member denomination based in Missouri. The Rev. Ralph A. Bohlmann, president of the Missouri Synod, said the talks convinced him the ``basic component of our fellowship is intact. ... Given time to heal, this relationship can be salvaged and restored.'' However, he said, only the Philippine church can resolve problems at the root of the interchurch difficulty.

A Christian monitoring organization says network television reduced the amount of sex, violence, profanity and anti-Christian stereotyping last year by 32 percent. The Rev. Billy Melvin, chairman of Christian Leaders for Responsible Television, says some companies apparently were responding to the organization's activity in the shows they sponsor. The group is a coalition of about 1,600 Christian leaders from nearly every denomination, including top leaders of about 70 denominations.

DOC.HEAD: Sununu's Influence Still Felt Back in New Hampshire
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: John Sununu wields his clout in Washington these days but his influence still is felt in the state he governed for six years before being tapped as George Bush's chief of staff. New Hampshire's immediate past governor is seen as a smooth operator who does favors for his adopted home state but leaves few political fingerprints. Some state Republicans express concern that Sununu is meddling in local politics, but most consider his presence in the White House to be an asset for the state. ``Sununu makes certain New Hampshire's place on the political map is not forgotten,'' said GOP strategist Tom Rath. ``It was not an accident that the first place outside of Washington that the president visited was New Hampshire,'' Rath said, referring to a Bush stopover in Manchester not long after he became president. As New Hampshire's governor, Sununu sided early with Bush in the 1988 presidential race. He helped engineer a Bush victory in the state's earliest-in-the-nation primary and continued the national campaign with attacks against Democratic nominee Michael Dukakis, governor of neighboring Massachusetts. Sununu's political work continues even now. He had a guiding role in easing the White House's hands-off policy toward party primaries, putting the Oval Office behind candidates such as Rep. Bob Smith, R-N.H., who hopes to replace retiring GOP Sen. Gordon Humphrey. State GOP chairwoman Rhona Charbonneau wishes Sununu had stayed out of the primary race between Smith and Rye lawyer Tom Christo. ``It's good to have a friend in the White House rather than a foe,'' she said. ``But I truly wish they had kept out of the primary. I don't believe anybody, not even the White House, should be involved.'' Sununu, whose influence also can be seen in some state races, brushes off the criticism. ``We're not trying to pick candidates,'' he says. ``We're trying to help the process.'' His wife, Nancy, hasn't kept silent either. She said she considered challenging U.S. Rep. Chuck Douglas for the GOP nomination in New Hampshire's 2nd congressional district because she ``never appreciated his values and his morals.'' Sununu and his successor in the governor's mansion, Republican Judd Gregg, have what insiders consider a civil relationship at best. At a recent New Hampshire business dinner, Sununu sat next to Senate President William Bartlett, who was considering challenging Gregg. Sununu, 50, is described as Bush's right-hand man, part of a White House troika with Secretary of State James Baker and budget director Richard Darman. Many doubted the abrasive Sununu would last long in the White House job after an admittedly rocky start. But now even his critics have had to admit he appears to be effective and may wield more power than any other recent chief of staff. Most Republican politicians believe it is to New Hampshire's advantage to have Sununu in the White House. ``We may not get everything from the White House, but people at the White House have the ear of New Hampshire,'' said Bill Zeliff, a Sununu ally who is seeking the GOP nomination for Smith's congressional seat. Sununu is seen as helping to place New Hampshire operatives in federal positions, promoting the Seabrook nuclear power plant and ensuring that important promises are fulfilled. When the Navy threatened 1,000 jobs by canceling a $128 million submarine overhaul at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard, Maine and New Hampshire governors and congressional delegations won a pledge by the Navy to find replacement work. Humphrey credits Sununu with making the Navy deliver. ``When those promises started to filter down, the Navy bureaucracy was sidestepping it, so I called Sununu and he got them to do what they said they would do,'' Humphrey recalls. Humphrey said Sununu is clearing similar hurdles for a proposal the senator is championing to make a wildlife refuge out of some of the land to be abandoned when Pease Air Force Base closes. A string of people with New Hampshire connections have been appointed to federal posts since Sununu moved to Washington. Most recently, Wally Stickney, a Sununu friend and associate, was selected to head the Federal Emergency Management Agency. A highly placed Republican, who agreed to discuss Sununu only if not quoted by name, said Sununu is adept at maintaining a low profile in the state. ``He hasn't left any fingerprints or left anyone with a story that they can tell that `Sununu sidled up to me, and so on.''' Seabrook, the Republican said, falls into that category. Sununu, champion of the nuclear power plant when he was governor, ``didn't just go to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and say, `Give them the license,''' the source said. ``He's been very cautious. But Seabrook got the license, didn't it? He made sure his feelings on the topic were well known in the appropriate places.'' Sununu plays down his role in the licensing of Seabrook. ``I was a patient man,'' he said recently. ``I knew the right thing would happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Islamic Fundamentalists Gain Influence in Jordan
DOC.TEXT: Attacks by Sunni Moslem zealots on banks, breweries and night clubs underline the growing influence of Islamic fundamentalists in one of the most secular Arab states. In May, an Islamic court convicted journalist Ibrahim Abu Naab, 59, of apostasy, or abandoning Islam, and ruled that he be divorced from his wife and separated from his children. Abdullah Shamayleh, prosecutor-general of the Islamic Court, urged it during Abu Naab's trial to permit ``the shedding of his blood.'' That would not appear necessary, since anyone who kills an apostate is immune from prosecution under Islamic law. Jordan's civil law does not grant immunity, however, and the civil appeals court probably will overrule the Islamic tribunal's verdict. The ``crime'' Abu Naab committed was attending a meeting in Britain of the breakaway Qadiani sect, which is outlawed in many Moslem states, and allegedly converting from the mainstream Sunni sect. His case reflects the increasing strength of fundamentalists, who became the largest legislative bloc after the November parliamentary elections, Jordan's first in 22 years. The Moslem Brotherhood won 22 of the 80 seats and Islamic independents got 12. They have pledged to work for strict application of Sharia, the Islamic religious law, but have said they will work within the constitution and not challenge King Hussein. Arab leaders worry about increasing fundamentalism among the world's 1 billion Moslems. Recent moves toward greater democracy in some Arab states are largely an outgrowth of that concern. Khalil Abdulrahman Khalifa, a 28-year-old engineer, said: ``The Islamic tide is growing these days because the people have lost trust in their governments, which have not moved so far to solve the central Arab issue, the Palestinian problem. ``We want liberation and we want to have an effective role in the world. We want the Arabs to be respected, not ignored. The Islamic parties attract us because they match our outlook.'' Jordan's fundamentalists are not having it all their own way. A government ban on male hairdressers working in women's beauty salons, imposed in May because of Islamic pressure, was canceled in two weeks after strong public protest. The fundamentalists sought to enforce a Koranic law that a woman cannot be touched by a man who is not her husband or a relative. Even though the fundamentalists ultimately lost, many Jordanians are disturbed about the government of Prime Minister Mudar Badran bowing to the pressure in the first place. When the prohibition was imposed, the English-language Jordan Times declared: ``It is clear that such a ban will lead to other decisions that will limit the freedom of the individual.'' It said the sole purpose was ``to cater to the whims of some religious or conservative groups which do not represent the majority of the population.'' During street protests in May, after an Israeli civilian killed Palestinian workers in Israel, fundamentalists attacked businesses considered un-Islamic. Mobs raided banks, the Dutch-owned Amstel brewery and night clubs that serve liquor, causing damage worth millions of dollars. Charging interest and drinking alcohol are forbidden by the Koran, the Moslem holy book. Several Amman night clubs were attacked in February and March. State television has been affected. Scenes of actors kissing, or even holding hands, are deleted because the fundamentalists consider them lewd. Newspaper or poster advertisements showing scantily clad women have disappeared. Attendance at prayers on Friday, the Moslem sabbath, has grown considerably. The area covered by prayer rugs on the sidewalks around Amman's Husseini Mosque in the teeming bazaar district has been extended to accomodate more people. Fundamentalist strength is on the rise in the Israeli-occupied territories across the Jordan River, challenging the Palestine Liberation Organization. A movement called Hamas, or Zeal, has played a major role in the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising and made major gains in municipal elections in Israel's Arab towns. In Egypt, Moslem militants have attacked Christian churches and, in clashes with police this year, 34 people have been killed and more than 70 wounded. Fundamentalism is spreading in Tunisia. In Turkey, Moslem but secular, fundamentalist violence is increasing and several outspoken champions of secularism have been assassinated. Earlier this year, the Turkish government was forced to lift a rule against women university students wearing Islamic-style headscarves on campus.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Spy Agency Still Active Despite President's Pledge
DOC.TEXT: A secret security agency created by the military regime still operates five years after the generals relinquished power to civilians, despite the new president's pledge to abolish it. The National Intelligence Service, a sort of combined FBI and CIA, was synonymous with spying, torture, censorship and midnight knocks on the door under the military governments of 1964-1985. Its decline accelerated when agents were linked to terrorist bombings carried out in an attempt to forestall a return to democracy. When President Fernando Collor de Mello took office Mar. 15, he promised to dismantle the hated agency, known as the SNI, and burn its secret files. ``The security of the state cannot become the insecurity of the citizen,'' said Collor, who won Brazil's first direct election for president since 1960. He gave the agency a new name _ the Secretariat of Strategic Affairs _ and a new civilian director, but critics say it still collects information about citizens despite laws prohibiting it from doing so. ``In place of the SNI, the government created the embryo of a political police,'' said Walder de Goes, a political science professor at the University of Brasilia and an expert on the agency. ``The ideological archives were joined with financial information about individuals and their police records. Anywhere in the world, that's the beginning of a political police.'' Luis Eduardo Greenhalgh, a lawyer who represented political prisoners during military rule, said: ``The SNI was not extinguished, just modified. Some of its agents were returned to their military units, but most are still spying. ``If the government needs dirt on somebody, the agency gets it. Everything continues the same.'' In 1965, the SNI was created as a super-intelligence service to safeguard national security. It spied on citizens, tapped telephones and tailed alleged leftist opponents of the regime. As repression increased in the 1960s and early 1970s, the agency ran covert operations and collected damaging information about enemies of the ruling generals. Thousands of Brazilians lost their jobs, were imprisoned or had to flee the country because their names apeareed on the SNI list. The impunity enjoyed by SNI agents created disciplinary problems within the armed forces, and Gen. Golbery do Couto e Silva, who formed the agency and was its first director, said at one point: ``I created a monster.'' Brazil returned to civilian rule in 1985, But President Jose Sarney, chosen by an electoral college under military control, did not try to curb the armed forces' behind-the-scenes influence. Collor promised a change. During the 1989 campaign, the 40-year-old presidential candidate referred to the agency's director as a ``tin-pot general.'' The job job was a cabinet-level post. Once in office, Collor decreed the SNI abolished. Clandestine operations would cease, he said, SNI agents would return to the regular military and secret archives would be opened to the public and destroyed To replace ``the service,'' as insiders called it, Collor created the Secretariat of Strategic Affairs and turned it over to Pedro Paulo Leoni Ramos, a 30-year-old businessman and longtime friend. Its job was ``exclusively'' to provide the president with information for political and government policy, according to the official orders. The old agency did not die, however. Its files were not destroyed, and even grew fatter with data from the Federal Police and the Internal Revenue Service. Goes said the new Secretariat is more sophisticated than the SNI ever was. ``Information and intelligence now are a department of the Secretariat and continue under the aegis of the military,'' he said. The other departments of the new agency are Strategic Policy and National Defense. ``If a crisis were to develop, there are now authorities who could act like a secret police,'' Goes said. He complained of a lack of outside control over the agency, noting ``there is no congressional committee that checks its budget or personnel.'' Like his military predecessors at the SNI, director Ramos is highly secretive. He will not speak to the press and is rarely photographed or seen in public. Several requests by The Associated Press for an interview went unanswered. ``The job creates the habit,'' said Goes, who knows Ramos and described him as ``a very capable young man, in Collor's strictest confidence and one of the few with direct access to the president's office.'' In recent years, former members of the SNI have revealed some of the agency's inner workings and past mistakes. Retired Gen. Helio Lemos, 74, a former top official, said: ``The SNI had informants in every Brazilian embassy and consulate, but it still didn't even suspect that Argentina would invade the Falkland Islands in 1982.'' Lemos said the SNI did not foresee the oil crises of the 1970s or the Iran-Iraq war, both of which were of great strategic importance to Brazil, an importer of oil and exporter of arms. Adm. Maximiano da Fonseca, a former navy minister, recalled that ``we got our information from the newspapers.'' Some generals have grumbled publicly about Collor's decision to put a civilian in charge, but Goes said the armed forces and Secretariat now make up a new intelligence network. ``The military was worried at first,'' he said, ``but soon the spy services of the army, navy and air force were expanded and many files were duplicated, in the event of possible destruction.'' He described the combined network as ``a web so tangled that nothing and nobody can escape.''

DOC.HEAD: A Home for the Big Broadway Musical in the New Jersey Suburbs
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In the sprawling suburbia of New Jersey, nearly an hour's drive from Times Square, the big Broadway-style musical is alive and flourishing. It has found a receptive home at the Paper Mill Playhouse, a one-time summer theater that forsakes conventional straw-hat offerings for more innovative theater fare, produced on a yearly budget that now tops $10 million. The Paper Mill's prominence has risen steadily in the last few years, primarily because of its savvy mixture of musicals, both old and new. Among its productions were a revival of ``Mack and Mabel,'' a rarely seen Jerry Herman musical about movie director Mack Sennett and his star Mabel Norman, and a musical version of James Michener's ``Sayonara.'' But the show that gained Paper Mill a national audience was ``Show Boat,'' taped at the theater last summer for public television and then shown on ``Great Performances'' in the fall. The revival, which starred Richard White and Eddie Bracken, will be repeated later this year on PBS. During its current season, which ends June 24, Paper Mill produced an opulent revival of ``Fanny'' with George S. Irving and Jose Ferrer playing the roles originated on Broadway in 1954 by Walter Slezak and Ezio Pinza. And it took on Gilbert and Sullivan in a big-business reworking of one of the duo's most famous works, ``The Mikado.'' Rechristened ``Mikado, Inc.,'' it was the theater's final offering of a 10-month season. ``Mikado, Inc.,' which was conceived, directed and choreographed by Robert Johanson, the theater's artistic director, was loosely inspired by the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta. The words are all new. The music was largely reworked, for example, melodies sung by one character in the original are now given to another character. ``We try to do an eclectic year,'' says Angelo Del Rossi, the theater's executive producer and a 27-year veteran of the playhouse. ``We don't try to do things that are too similar. Those two shows are perfect examples. We have no philosophy. Whatever excites us is what we want to do.'' Paper Mill, which also does dramas and comedies, began mixing new musicals with revivals about five years ago. ``There wasn't really very much new out there _ think back to what Broadway was like then,'' Del Rossi recalls. ``We do musicals well and thought we were in a perfect position to develop new musicals.'' Out of their deliberations came Paper Mill's Musical Theater Workshop. It works like this: The theater does a reading _ two performances with script in hand _ of a new work. The public is invited and feedback is encouraged from both audience and staff. Paper Mill does six readings of new material a year. Its most recent reading, done in early June, was a musical version of the Jimmy Stewart classic ``It's a Wonderful Life,'' with music by Joe Raposo and lyrics by Sheldon Harnick. ``Out of those readings, we usually find one show that we like and bring it to the next phase, the workshop or laboratory phase,'' Del Rossi added. ``At the conclusion of the workshop, if we feel it deserves a main stage production, then we go ahead and do it. We've done that with `Sayonara' and `Mikado, Inc.''' Del Rossi and Johanson choose their revivals with care, looking for good shows that somehow have been neglected. ``I try to do things that haven't been done continuously, like `My Fair Lady,''' Del Rossi says. ``We breathed new life into `The Desert Song' and `The New Moon.' In fact, Beverly Sills saw both those productions and picked up our whole artistic staff _ our director, our conductor, our choreographer and our star _ brought them to City Opera and did both of those shows.'' ``I love shows that are romantic, have a beautiful love story and really have a book as well as something of an epic feeling to them,'' Johanson said. ```Fanny' certainly did. Plus it's fun to work on something that has no real history. People don't know the classic production of `Fanny' like they know the classic production of a `My Fair Lady' or `Fiddler on the Roof.''' The Paper Mill Playhouse originally was a paper mill, built in 1790. The long, narrow shoebox of a building was turned into a theater in 1938. It remained in operation until January 1980 when a fire destroyed the stage and auditorium. ``We were not quite sure we were going to come back,'' said Del Rossi about the dark days following the fire. ``I didn't want to come back as the old Paper Mill Playhouse. I wanted to return as a new theater with new ideas.'' Reconstruction wasn't easy. In 1980, the interest rate was 16.5 percent. The theater had no money and was surviving from show to show. It took a year for the trustees to approve rebuilding and then almost two years to actually do it. The final cost was nearly $9 million, much of the money raised by Del Rossi and his staff from corporations, foundations and from the state. From a meager subscription base that would vary between 2,000 and 6,000, Paper Mill today has 43,000 subscribers for its 10-month season. Plays run five weeks, and musicals are booked for six-week engagements. Paper Mill now has a permanent staff of 40 people who help put together each show. The scenery is designed and built there and although costumes are often rented, the theater is developing facilities to do its own costumes. Del Rossi encourages creators of new work not to be be intimidated by size. ``We are one of the few theaters, when we put the search out for new material, that say `Don't restrict yourselves because of size.' We want anything that is good and not to have authors afraid to send us something that has a cast of 24 people. Most of our musical casts at Paper Mill are 30 to 40 people.'' The theater is also commissioning new works for the stage. ``Mikado, Inc.'' was one such commission. Among other commissioned projects, which could turn up in a year or two, are a science fiction musical and a musical about the last princess of Hawaii. ``Next year we're thinking about doing an opera but not like the Met or the New York City Opera would do it,'' Del Rossi said. ``But we want to do it the way a musical theater would do it. We just take different approaches to things.''

DOC.HEAD: `Northern Exposure' _ Doctoring in Alaska To Pay Off Med School
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: So what's a nice young Jewish doctor doing in the wilds of Alaska? That's the premise of the CBS summer series ``Northern Exposure,'' in which Dr. Joel Fleishman, who financed medical school by promising to practice in the Far North for four years, arrives in Alaska and starts paying his dues. ``He's stuck in this little town in Alaska,'' said Josh Brand, co-writer and producer with John Falsey. ``He doesn't like the place. He doesn't feel comfortable. He feels he's been tricked, because they had promised him Anchorage.'' In the first episode, Fleishman, played by Rob Morrow, learns he's being sent into the wilderness. Other regulars in the eight-episode run, which starts July 12, are Barry Corbin, John Cullum, Janine Turner, John Corbett and Cynthia Geary. ``This isn't a medical show. This isn't about the disease of the week,'' said Brand, who also created ``St. Elsewhere'' with Falsey. ``This is about a fish out of water. It's a show about people.'' Brand and Falsey became partners as writers for ``The White Shadow.'' They also guided ``St. Elsewhere'' as producers in its first year. Later, they created and produced ``A Year in the Life.'' They also helped Steven Spielberg create the ``Amazing Stories'' series and were its supervising producers the first year. ``Northern Exposure'' had its origin in several sources, including Brand's doctor friend who suggested the original idea for ``St. Elsewhere,'' a series set in a teaching hospital. ``We'd read about the state of Maine paying for medical school to get doctors to practice in small towns,'' Brand said. ``The genesis of this series was the movie `Cry Wolf,' which was about a city man going into the northern woods to study wolves, and a script we'd written about a friend of mine who was a doctor and joined the New York Police Department. He now practices in rural New York.'' The show is being filmed on location in Roslyn, Wash., a small town about 60 miles east of Seattle, just off Interstate 90 east of the Cascade Mountains. ``It's a one-street town, a little farther out than we wanted, but it's great,'' Brand said. ``The mountains and the lakes are magnificent. The skies can be dark and filled with billowing clouds. It's very clear you're not in Los Angeles.'' Brand said they discovered a huge mural painted on the wall of a cafe in Roslyn showing a camel and a palm tree. ``We made up a story that it was Roslyn's Cafe and Roslyn had been one of the founders of the town,'' he said. The home for Corbin's character is a spectacular log cabin with 40-foot-high ceilings. A 15-foot-long buggy hangs on one wall. ``The idea of filming on location is fun, but you're always so busy you never have time to see anything,'' Brand said. ``I think I've been in to Seattle once. I'd love to get to the San Juan Islands, but there's no time. Working on location is a two-headed monster. No matter where you are, there's another place you need to be. We have to do all the post-production work in Los Angeles.'' ``Northern Exposure'' is one of a several summer shows the networks, particularly CBS, are mounting this year in hopes of retaining viewers until the fall season premieres, Brand said. The summer placement has has its advantages, he said. ``The networks have been losing viewers every fall,'' Brand said. ``They're hoping they won't lose as many this year if they can keep viewers over the summer. I think CBS is putting more money into this show than all the summer shows of the past few seasons. ``We get to introduce a new show without the intense competition of the regular season. If it catches on, it'll be back later.''
