DOC.HEAD: Leaders in Fight Against AIDS Meet in International Conference
DOC.TEXT: For the sixth time in the short history of AIDS, the top minds in the fight against the disease will gather to brief each other _ and the world _ about their triumphs and setbacks. The Sixth International Conference on AIDS, which opens Wednesday, will be a sort of AIDS marathon, five days of terse reports on almost every aspect of the disease. No dramatic breakthroughs are likely to be announced, but experts say the meeting should turn up signs of progress in medicine's effort to understand and defeat the virus. An estimated 11,000 doctors, scientists and other AIDS professionals will hear about 2,500 presentations, ranging from the results of experiments with new drugs and vaccines to reports on the spread of AIDS from mothers to children and from prostitutes to their customers. Such meetings are a staple of medical research, but ordinarily pass in peaceful obscurity. Last month, for instance, 7,000 doctors gathered in Washington for the American Society of Clinical Oncology, the major U.S. cancer meeting. About 100 reporters chronicled the proceedings. Twenty-four times more Americans die of cancer than of AIDS each year. But AIDS is clearly different. Organizers of the AIDS meeting expect 1,800 members of the news media to attend, drawn both by the newsworthiness of AIDS research and the possibility of demonstrations and other street drama in San Francisco, the city with the nation's highest AIDS rate. Some scientists might find the publicity unseemly, but many seem to relish the intense, if fleeting, attention. ``All of us recognize that we are in the business of dissemination of information, and there is simply no better forum in the world for doing that. It is unmatched,'' said Dr. Robert M. Wachter of the University of California at San Francisco, the meeting's program director. Inside the Moscone Convention Center, vaccine development is likely to be one of the hottest topics of discussion. ``At this meeting, you will see a lot more positive news about successes in the vaccine field, testing in chimpanzees and rhesus monkeys and perhaps some encouraging news in human beings, also,'' said Dr. David Ho, an AIDS researcher at the University of California, Los Angeles. While none of these reports is likely to suggest a vaccine is close to being ready for widespread use, they at least should hint that such a preventative measure is possible. ``In the first five years of HIV (AIDS virus) research, anything related to vaccine research has been very discouraging,'' said Ho. ``Over the past year, we have seen a lot more positive results.'' Much of this work still is at the most basic stages. Scientists will update their search, for instance, for vulnerable spots on the surface of the AIDS virus that a vaccine can exploit to attack and destroy it. Scientists also will report on the uses of AZT and still-experimental drugs by people who are infected with HIV but not yet sick. The goal of such treatment is to keep them healthy, but the new studies show people quickly grow resistant to the helpful effects of the drugs. Whether such treatment should be reserved for later stages of the disease, when victims might benefit more, is expected to be a major topic of the conference. Many reports also are planned on new AIDS drugs still in the test-tube stage of development. Researchers are creating these medicines to attack the virus at various points in its life cycle. ``It will be some time before they get to the clinic, but there has been a tremendous amount of progress in the past year in understanding the virus and translating that information into designing new drugs,'' said Dr. William Haseltine of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. While much of the research will be new information, a good deal also will be stale, at least to AIDS insiders. Because of the intense interest in AIDS, major developments rarely remain secret for long. ``We hear about events almost as they happen, rather than in the artificially contrived schedule of meetings,'' said Dr. Clifford Lane of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. ``The way communication goes these days, there's no time delay anymore.'' Other expected topics include the effect of AIDS on sexual practices, the risk of passing on the AIDS virus during pregnancy, AIDS hazards among health care workers, and the cost of paying for the epidemic. The conference will include about half as many presentations as last year's meeting in Montreal, largely because it will pay significantly less attention to social issues. Non-scientific subjects explored last year, but not this time, include erotica, AIDS coping strategies, AIDS in the arts, and the religious response to the disease. ``Montreal made a conscious effort to emphasize the social side of the epidemic,'' said Wachter. ``We heard from a number of scientists that they didn't get as much out of the conference as they would like. This encouraged us to be as sensitive to the needs of people working in the lab looking for new vaccines as we were to people working in the community.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, June 17

DOC.TEXT: The deficit in the broadest measure of U.S. trade shrank to a six-year low of $22.94 billion during the first three months of the year, the government reported. Analysts, however, cautioned that the good news may be temporary. The Commerce Department Tuesday credited a record level of American merchandise exports, increased spending by foreign tourists and higher U.S. investment earnings for the 14 percent improvement in the current account deficit compared to 1989's fourth quarter, when the deficit was $26.69 billion.

A New York Stock Exchange panel proposed new severe trading halts to curb wild price swings but said widely criticized program trading strategies didn't cause market volatility. The report released Tuesday capped a six-month study commissioned after the stock market plunged last October, driving away many individual investors already shaken by the 1987 crash and provoking an outcry against program trading. The group proposed that the NYSE install ``circuit-breakers'' to slow trading during wide market fluctuations.

A federal appeals court overturned a Securities and Exchange Commission rule preventing corporations from creating unequal voting rights among their stockholders. The three-judge appeals panel on Tuesday unanimously ruled in favor of an association of top corporations that contended the SEC had exceeded its authority by imposing a so-called ``one share, one vote'' rule. In an unusually sharp rebuke, the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said the SEC went beyond its congressionally mandated authority to regulate the financial markets.

American Express Co. announced plans to issue 27 million new shares of common stock, worth about $825 million at current market value, to help pay for acquiring the rest of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. American Express already owns 60 percent of Shearson, the nation's second-largest brokerage. American Express said Tuesday about $300 million worth of the stock will be bought by Nippon Life Insurance Co. The sale is intended to replace the Japanese company's stake in Shearson that is being sold to American Express in the buyout.

Profits at commercial banks bounced back to $6.2 billion in the first three months of 1990 despite spreading problems from sour real estate loans, the government said. That was a big improvement over the preceding two quarters, but still marked a 14 percent decline from a record $7.3 billion profit in the first quarter of 1989, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Tuesday.

Chrysler Corp. and French automaker Renault terminated a joint venture to build a small sport-utility vehicle, but Chrysler said it planned to continue developing the project. Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said Tuesday that the company, which saw its first quarter profit drop by 80 percent, decided the joint venture is no longer economically attractive.

Hardee's announced a new, leaner quarter-pound hamburger, but competitors said the fast-food company is playing catch up. The Rocky Mount-based company on Tuesday announced ``THE LEAN 1,'' a quarter-pound burger with an average of 18 grams of total fat that it described as the lowest-fat burger in the business.

Seven states sued Mobil Chemical Co. charging the company falsely claimed its Hefty trash bags and grocery bags would decompose. Mobil announced in March that it would stop referring to its Hefty bags as biodegradable because of confusion about what degradable means. Lawsuits were filed Tuesday by Massachusetts, Minnesota, Texas, California, Wisconsin, New York and Washington state.

Climbing the corporate ladder can plunge some people into depression, but an early diagnosis could spare middle managers a serious case of the office blues, researchers said. A study of 1,870 white-collar employees of Westinghouse Electric Corp. in Monroeville, a Pittsburgh suburb, showed 16.6 percent of female and 8.6 percent of male managers were clinically depressed in the year prior to the survey, which was taken in 1987 and 1988. The figures released Tuesday exceed the latest depression rate for all Americans, 4.4 percent in 1986, according to the National Institute of Mental Health.

Stocks advanced to near-record levels Tuesday, strengthened by a late-afternoon rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 40.85 points to 2,933.42, just below the record close of 2,935.19 reached June 4. Bonds declined slightly. The dollar was mixed against foreign currencies and gold fell. Gasoline futures soared, boosted in part by worries about the crippled oil supertanker Mega Borg off the Texas coast. Grain, soybean and precious metals futures were mixed; livestock futures fell and pork bellies advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Volatility Report Latest Salvo in Market Reform Debate
DOC.TEXT: A New York Stock Exchange report clears program trading as the major villain in market turmoil and gives ammunition to officials seeking a super-regulator for stocks and their spinoff products. The report is the latest study into wild price movements blamed for scaring off small investors. It was written by a blue-ribbon panel formed after the market plunged last October in a near-repeat of the 1987 crash. The panel's conclusion that the most popular program trading strategy, index arbitrage, is a ``natural feature'' in stock and stock-index futures markets is likely to reignite a simmering debate. The NYSE group was composed primarily of representatives of Wall Street, large corporations and big insitutional money managers _ which largely have opposed placing restrictions on program trading. ``It's simply an affirmation of the fact that the NYSE has surrendered all of their hopes and dreams to the institutions,'' said Charles Wohlstetter, chairman of Contel Corp. and a program trading opponent. In its main proposal, the panel supported coordinated ``circuit breakers'' in the cash, futures and options markets that would stop trading during wide market fluctuations. The system would place a 400-point cap on the possible daily rise or fall in the Dow Jones industrial average and allow for the stock market to close for nearly a full day in the case of rapid price movements. The average plummeted 508 points in the record crash of Oct. 19, 1987. General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger Smith, who led the 19-member panel, said the circuit breakers would provide ``a breathing spell in the market'' in chaotic times. The panel proposed halting trading for one hour if the Dow Jones average moves up or down 100 points from the previous day's close; another 90 minutes if it moves 200 points; and two hours each if it moves 300 points and 400 points. Stoppages would be coordinated with the nation's futures markets. But opponents have said such a measure, a less restrictive form of which already exists, would limit individual investors' ability to get out of the market during a downturn. There were no circuit breakers in effect at the time of the 1987 crash. The Big Board panel took the view that index arbitrage and other forms of program trading are here to stay. Index arbitrage involves rapid trading of stocks in New York and stock-index futures in Chicago to profit from momentary price discrepancies between the two markets. Critics blamed the practice for worsening the market's freefall during the 1987 crash and again last Oct. 13, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190 points. Many large Wall Street brokerages pulled back on program trading after last year's mini-crash, but their customers did not. In February, the NYSE proposed restricting stock-index arbitrage when the Dow Jones average is up or down 50 points or more. That proposal still is pending before the Securities and Exchange Commission and wasn't affected by the new report. At the time, the NYSE said program trading strategies ``may create excess volatility that undermines investor confidence in the fairness and orderliness of the securities markets, and may in fact constitute a threat to the viability of America's capital markets.'' But the blue-ribbon panel report, endorsed by NYSE Chairman John J. Phelan Jr., concludes that ``there is little evidence that index arbitrage causes an increase in volatility as usually measured.'' The closest the report comes to criticizing the practice is a statement that ``it is possible that program trading and index arbitrage exacerbate short-term volatility.'' The panel also called for creating a single agency to regulate the nation's stock and stock-index futures markets. That finding rankled the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which would be likely to lose authority under a super-regulator, and is sure to deepen the debate. The Bush administration already has endorsed legislation that would give the Securities and Exchange Commission control over the markets. SEC Chairman Richard S. Breeden said he was ``extremely pleased'' with the NYSE panel's recommendation. He said it ``in essence fully confirms'' the proposed legislation. But Chicago Merc Chairman Leo Melamed, a panel member, attached a dissent to the report. ``A majority of the panel simply mirrored a popular perception that consolidation of regulation seems desirable,'' it said. Some of the conclusions in the latest report overlap findings in more than a dozen studies undertaken following the 1987 crash, including the government's Brady Commission report that endorsed circuit breakers. The Brady Commission, however, placed more blame on program trading as a source of volatility. Phelan said the report would be voted on by the exchange's board and its recommendations discussed with other financial markets.

DOC.HEAD: United Brands Agrees to Let Fyffa Buy Honduran Bananas
DOC.TEXT: A three-month-old banana battle has ended with United Brands agreeing to let the Irish-English firm Fyffes buy Honduran bananas and gain a toehold in the Central American country for the first time. The agreement between New York-based United Brands and more than 600 independent producers affects about 1 million of the 47 million boxes of bananas Honduras exports annually. But the dispute ballooned to far greater proportions. United Brands, which had exported all of the bananas from the independent producers, will buy 60 percent until March 31, 1991, and let Fyffes buy the other 40 percent. After that date the independents, who wanted to accept Fyffes' higher prices, will be free to sell to the highest bidder. The agreement, announced Tuesday by the Economy Ministry, was reached on Sunday. The dispute arose in March after independent producers sold to Fyffes, which has 26 European subsidiaries. United Brands argued that the sale violated its exclusive contract with the producers, which expires in 1991. With a judge's consent, the company had employees go to the dock where a Fyffes shipment was waiting and throw tens of thousands of boxes of bananas into the sea, give them away to local people or stomp on them. United Brands, which has operated in Honduras since 1912, argued that it invests in the country while Fyffes wants only to buy. Over the past 50 years United has accounted for 60 percent of Honduran banana exports. San Francisco-based Castle & Cook exports the other 40 percent. The two companies also produce all but the 1 million boxes grown by the independents. United employs about 8,000 people and Castle & Cook 4,000 on their plantations. Honduras is the world's fourth largest banana producer after Ecuador, Costa Ricaand Colombia. As a result of the fray, the government said Tuesday it was studying the possibility of rejoining the Union of Banana Exporting Countries and would change its banana policy. The country withdrew from the marketing union four years ago, saying it could not pay the $500,000 dues. It owes the organization $1.2 million in back dues, half of which the union has forgiven. The union's seven members and Honduras account for half the world's banana production. ``The new Honduran banana policy will be directed toward protecting the national activity to impede the resurgence of monopolies, local as well as international,'' Assistant Economy Minister Ramiro Figueroa said at a news conference.

DOC.HEAD: UAL's Wolf Has `Cordial' Talk with Greenwald
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. Chairman Stephen Wolf and his would-be successor held a ``cordial and open discussion'' at their first meeting, and the airline company's No. 2 officer said he'll quit if employees pull off their buyout bid. The four-hour meeting Tuesday between Wolf and former Chrysler Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald reflected their stated desire for a smooth transfer of power in the event that UAL's employees succeed in their proposed $4.54 billion takeover of the company, parent of United Airlines. Lawrence Nagin, a UAL senior vice president for corporate and external affairs, said the private meeting at a hotel near O'Hare International Airport consisted of a ``cordial and open discussion.'' Nagin quoted Wolf as saying: ``Jerry Greenwald was gracious and forthcoming and well prepared for a discussion of United's future.'' Separately, John C. Pope, UAL's chief financial officer and executive vice president for marketing and planning, said he would leave UAL if the employee-led buyout goes through. Pope's announcement was not a surprise. Wolf told shareholders at the company's annual meeting in April that neither he nor Pope expected to remain in their positions after a worker buyout. Greenwald agreed last week to head the acquisition company formed by United's pilots, flight attendants and Machinists. He would become UAL's chairman and chief executive, replacing Wolf, should the union group secure financing to complete the $201-a-share buyout. Tuesday's meeting was the first face-to-face encounter between the two executives since Greenwald joined the buyout effort, said Steven Matthews, spokesman for the union group. ``I'm not even certain there was an agenda other than to sit down and say hello to each other,'' Matthews said. He added that the union group has not yet obtained financing. Greenwald reportedly received $5 million to join the buyout effort and is guaranteed to receive $12 million more in salary and fees over the next five years if the deal is completed. Meanwhile, Northwest Airlines announced Monday it had hired away the chief executive of Covia-Apollo, an automated airline reservation system half owned by United. Covia-Apollo CEO Barry A. Kotar's jump to Northwest is believed to be the first major defection from UAL since the union group proposed buying the nation's second-largest airline in April. Kotar will become executive vice president and chief information officer of Northwest, the company said in a statement. The proposed UAL buyout includes the likely sale of United's stake in the reservations system.

DOC.HEAD: Securities Industry Leaders Discuss Ways to Advise New East Europe Markets
DOC.TEXT: Top officials of U.S. financial exchanges and several major accounting and securities firms have joined forces with the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine the best ways of helping the new free market economies of Eastern Europe. In its first gathering Tuesday, the SEC's Emerging Markets Advisory Committee mapped preliminary strategy and planned smaller working groups. ``It is the right thing for the United States to give the benefit of our knowledge and our experience to these other countries,'' SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden told the blue ribbon panel. The group included Michael Minikes, senior managing director of investment bank Bear Stearns; American Stock Exchange Chairman James R. Jones; Joseph Hardiman, president of the National Association of Securities Dealers Inc., and Leo Melamed, head of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Breeden proposed setting up the panel in March and has sought an active role in helping Easter Europe emerge from decades of socialism. He will travel to Hungary later this month to speak at the official reopening of the Budapest Stock Exchange _ dormant since 1948 when the Communists came to power. He also has met with Polish, Hungarian and Soviet officials in recent months. Breeden noted that foreign officials who have sought SEC assistance and advice do not have time for lengthy reports and studies. ``They want assistance that is practical and concrete,'' he advised the panelists. Also addressing the group was Oscar Espinosa Villareal, president of Mexico's national securities commission, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. ``We must not only work to develop the markets that already exist, but we must also provide the necessary priority to the markets that do not yet exist; specifically, we must focus on the countries of Eastern Europe in their process of incorporation to a market economy,'' Espinosa Villareal said. A surprise guest was Wieslaw Rozlucki, an adviser to Poland's Finance Ministry, who was in Washington to attend a World Bank conference.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Overturns SEC's One Share, One Vote Rule
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission's attempt to prevent corporations from creating different classes of stock with unequal voting rights has been thwarted by a federal appeals court. A three-judge appeals panel in Washington ruled unanimously that the SEC exceeded its authority when it imposed a so-called ``one share, one vote'' rule. That supported the contention of The Business Roundtable, an association of the nation's top corporations, which claimed the SEC rule interfered with the traditional role of the individual states in regulating corporate governance. The SEC had contended that its federal mandate to protect investors in publicly traded companies gave it the right to impose the one share, one vote rule. But the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said the SEC went beyond its congressionally mandated authority to oversee the financial markets. ``Because the rule directly controls the substantive allocation of powers among classes of shareholders, we find it in excess of the Commission's authority,'' the panel said in a 21-page opinion written by Circuit Judge Stephen F. Williams. Concurring with Williams were circuit judges James L. Buckley and Harry T. Edwards. ``I was disappointed,'' said Richard G. Ketchum, head of the SEC's Division of Market Regulation. SEC officials will have to review the opinion before deciding whether to appeal, he said. The United Shareholders Association, a Washington-based stockholders' rights group founded by T. Boone Pickens, also bemoaned the decision as ``a major blow to America's 47 million shareholders and the entire free-enterprise system.'' USA Director Ralph Whitworth urged the SEC to appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court. The head of the Roundtable's corporate governance task force hailed the decision, though. ``American shareholders won an important victory today,'' said Bruce Atwater, who is also chief executive officer of General Mills. ``The court has resoundingly affirmed their right to determine for themselves what kinds of equities best serve their interests.'' The Business Roundtable argued that the SEC had overstepped its authority and was trying to regulate how companies are run, a traditional role of the states. The states of Ohio, Delaware, Kentucky, Michigan, Idaho, Pennsylvania, Wyoming, Nebraska, North Carolina, Missouri, Georgia and West Virginia had filed court papers supporting the group's stance. The Roundtable is an association of 200 companies that includes American Express Co., Xerox Corp., Citicorp and General Mills. ``It's a very important decision that limits the SEC's attempt to regulate corporate governance,'' said attorney Robert D. Rosenbaum, who represented the group in oral arguments last November before the appeals court. The appeals court found that SEC authority to compel full corporate disclosure to shareholders ``doesn't extend to what shareholders can decide,'' Rosenbaum said. The SEC rule in question, Rule 19c-4, was adopted in July 1988. It prohibited publicly traded corporations from weakening the voting power of existing stockholders by issuing new classes of stock with superior or ``supervoting'' rights. In filings with the appeals court last fall, the SEC claimed that without the curb, ``shareholders could be stripped of their ability to participate in management, and confidence in the securities markets could be impaired.'' Rule 19c-4 allowed the SEC to bar an offending company's stock from being listed on any stock exchange that it regulated or with the National Association of Securities Dealers stock quotation system, Nasdaq. The SEC claimed Congress intended it to have such authority to ensure that exchanges didn't lower their listing standards to attract more corporate stock listings. But the appeals court said that intent only concerned the SEC's authority to govern exchanges and quote systems _ not corporations. ``To argue that Congress's `equal regulation' mandate supports SEC control over corporate governance through national listing standards is to gamble that the court will accept a Commission spin on a statutory fragment without even a glance at its context,'' said the court, adding: ``Wrong court, bad gamble.'' The SEC's Ketchum said he did not think the ruling would cause the nation's stock exchanges to lower their listing requirements.

DOC.HEAD: To Issue 27 Million Shares To Help Pay for Shearson Buyout
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. plans to issue more than $800 million worth of stock to help finance its shoring up of troubled investment banking subsidiary Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. The travel and charge card company said Tuesday would issue 27 million shares of common stock, which would bring in about $825 million at current market prices before selling costs. Most of the proceeds will be used to eliminate $500 million in short-term debt American Express took on in March when it bought $750 million worth of Shearson preferred stock. American Express has injected more than $1 billion into Shearson in recent months and is taking full control in an effort to revitalize the struggling Wall Street house. American Express already owns 60 percent of Shearson, the nation's second-largest brokerage. The company said it expects to buy the remainder of Shearson in the third quarter. Nippon Life Insurance Co. will buy $300 million of the stock offering. The purchase is intended to replace the Japanese company's stake in Shearson that is being sold to American Express in the buyout, American Express said in a statement. After its purchase of the new stock, Nippon Life's total investment in American Express will be less than 5 percent of the company's nearly 447 million shares. Nippon Life plans to pay the lesser of the public offering price or $30.96 a share for not less than 9.69 million shares. American Express closed at $30.37{ Tuesday, down 25 cents, in New York Stock Exchange trading. The offering was announced after the stock market closed. The offering is subject to completion of the merger between American Express and Shearson and regulatory approvals. Officials expect the offering to be made in early July. Shearson lost $915 million in the first three months of the year, a record in the securities industry. It announced a restructuring earlier this month that will consolidate the firm into two divisions instead of four. The divisions will be Shearson Lehman Brothers for individual investing and asset management, and Lehman Brothers for investment banking and capital markets activities. The full firm will be known as Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. American Express began taking charge of its ailing subsidiary late last year. The changes have included replacing chairman Peter A. Cohen, who led Shearson through a large expansion in the 1980s, with Howard L. Clark Jr., a top American Express official. American Express also has pumped capital into Shearson and engineeried a major restructuring that has resulted in more than 2,000 layoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Company Suspends Crude Shipments to Most U.S. Ports Because of Liability
DOC.TEXT: Royal Dutch Shell Group, the world's biggest oil company, said it will stop docking its crude and fuel oil tankers at all but one U.S. port because of what it said were huge liability risks. ``The Exxon Valdez made it clear what happens when you have a spill and the enormous liabilities you can face,'' said Norm Altstedter, a New York spokesman for the Anglo-Dutch company. The decision has no relation to the fire on the Mega Borg supertanker some 57 miles offshore from Galveston, Altstedter said. ``It was made solely as a commercial decision,'' he said. Under the decision, shipments of crude and fuel oils in tankers owned or operated by the Royal Dutch Shell Group will be limited to the Louisiana Offshore Oil Port. About 80 percent of the company's U.S. shipments of some 180,000 barrels a day involve such oils, but only 40,000 barrels a day will be affected by the decision, Altstedter said. The rest of the shipments already go to the port about 20 miles offshore Louisiana, he said. The remainder of the company's U.S. shipments involve light oil products such as kerosene and gasoline and won't be affected by the decision, he said. The suspension came after a review of the risks and rewards to such trading in the United States, the spokesman said. ``The U.S. has not yet ratified the international conventions, which limit liability,'' Altstedter said. ``And there's no limitation on liability or the magnitude of legalities.'' Exxon Corp. was indicted in February on five federal charges stemming from the grounding of the Valdez in March 1989. The government said it would seek at least $700 million in penalties from the oil company under a law that allows recovery of twice the amount of proven losses. Exxon also has spent more than $2 billion to clean up the 11 million gallons of crude released in the nation's worst oil spill. The marine activities of Shell Oil Co. USA, the U.S. subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell, are not affected by the decision, officials said. ``We don't own ships,'' said H.R. Hutchins, Shell USA spokesman at the company's Houston headquarters. ``We charter everything from groups. Royal Dutch Shell is one of many groups we use. This will have little or no effect on Shell Oil USA.''

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler, Renault Scrap Joint Production Deal
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. may go ahead and produce a new small Jeep on its own after it and French automaker Renault backed out of a deal to jointly make the vehicle, a company official said. The automakers said Tuesday they were calling off a planned $500 million project to jointly develop the vehicles for European and North American production in the mid-1990s. Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said the joint project was no longer attractive economically. The collapse of the deal comes as Chrysler and other automakers worldwide eye economic developments in Western and Eastern Europe, which represent the world's biggest auto market. Analyst Chuck Brady said he was surprised by the announcement. ``I don't see what has changed to make it uneconomical,'' said Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. in New York. ``It doesn't make any sense.'' Last week, General Motors Corp. announced a joint venture with Volga Auto Works of the Soviet Union. GM executives said the project to provide fuel system components represented their entrance to a potentially huge marketplace. Although Houston said the planned joint venture was no longer attractive, he indicated Chrysler is considering developing the vehicle, code-named ``JJ,'' by itself or with another partner. ``Chrysler intends to continue with the `JJ' project and is reviewing various implementation alternatives,'' Houston said, declining to disclose details. The two companies said last February the vehicle would be produced in Valladolid, Spain, and that a North American site would be chosen later. Chrysler has been negotiating with public officials in Ohio and the United Auto Workers union over the fate of the company's Jeep plant in Toledo. There has been intense speculation that Chrysler wanted to transfer production of the Jeep Wrangler, now made in Canada, to Toledo and add ``JJ'' production later. On Monday, members of UAW Local 12 in Toledo approved by a wide margin a new labor agreement seen as key to bringing production of the ``JJ'' and the Wrangler to the Toledo factory, which is approaching 70 years old. Chrysler has been getting the lion's share of its profits from sales of its minivans and its Jeep line, which it acquired with the purchase of American Motors Corp. in August 1987. But recently, Chrysler's profits and sales have been falling. The company's profits fell 80 percent in the first quarter to $71 million, and its vehicle sales tumbled 12.8 percent in the first five months of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Game Allows Home Viewers to Get Involved in TV Football
DOC.TEXT: Home television viewers will be able to match wits with NFL quarterbacks and win prizes by calling plays in an interactive football game popular in sports bars, taverns and hotels. Interactive Network Inc. of Mountain View, National Football League Properties Inc. in New York and NTN Communications Inc. of Carlsbad, Calif., jointly announced Tuesday an agreement to make NTN's ``QB1'' game available to home TV viewers. David Lockton, president and chief executive officer of Interactive Network, said in New York that the game will cost $400 to $500 for the control unit plus a subscription fee of about $15 a month for access to a family of programs. The system will be available in Northern California in 1990 and will begin to be rolled out nationwide in 1991. He predicted that 400,000 to 500,000 homes would have the system in 1991 and that the market would grow substantially in future seasons. More than 1 million people have played QB1 in sports bars since its introduction four years ago, said NTN president Patrick J. Downs, and about 50,000 played it during this year's Super Bowl. The game is played on a cordless, wireless terminal with simulcasted data of the action. All the information required to play along is received by the FM receiver in the control unit, much like a stereo simulcast. Players watching the game on TV or listening on radio make judgments on whether the next play will be a pass or a run and get points for their decisions. They can gain extra points by predicting whether the play is to the left, right or middle, or whether the pass is long or short. A lockout signal is sent instantaneously to all players to prevent entering calls after the ball is snapped, then the correct answer is sent out by an NFL referee who sits at a computer console punching in the types of plays. As the players go along, their scores are continually updated after each play. At the end of the game, players can compare their scores to other players by plugging a phone to the back of the unit for a few seconds. The score is transmitted to Interactive Network's computer, ranked and rebroadcast over the FM. Within five minutes, even if millions of players are playing, Interactive Network will be able to tell who won the game, Lockton said. Since the game is considered one of skill, rather than luck, NTN and the game's sponsors are legally able to offer prizes, including trips to winners. The sports bars charge varying amounts to play, some offering the game for free to patrons who consume a certain amount of food or drinks. For home players, Interactive Network is considering a variety of awards to recognize winners. The game uses Interactive's patented technology, which was developed by Lockton in the early 1980s and licensed to NTN for the sports bar game. Interactive holds the patent on the only practical working technology that permits home competition and scoring without engaging the telephone line throughout the contest. ``Interactive Network's system not only adds a new dimension to television viewership, but it provides the television industry an opportunity to offer interactive advertising, couponing, sweepstakes and other promotional activities in conjunction with commercials run in this interactive environment,'' said Tom Rogers, head of business development for NBC and president of NBC Cable. Interactive Network has been testing a baseball game licensed with Major League Baseball Properties Inc., and has deals in the works with the NHL and NBA. In addition to contests based on live televised sports, the system will permit home television viewers to play along simultaneously with game shows, as well as interact directly with television news programs, educational programs and special event broadcasts.

DOC.HEAD: Delta, Singapore and Swissair Happy Together But Also Want Individuality
DOC.TEXT: The chief executive officers of Delta Air Lines, Singapore Airlines and Swissair say their year-old alliance is flying high with several new joint projects in the works. But the CEOs emphasized in a meeting with reporters Tuesday that the three airlines continue to maintain a certain distance, and that their relationship is not likely to evolve into anything more formal, such as a merger. ``Each one is proud of our own personality,'' said Cheong Choong Kong, chief executive officer of Singapore. ``No one seeks to tell the other parties how to run their airline.'' The three got together last year, joining through cross-equity investments for a number of projects. Cheong, along with CEOs Ronald W. Allen of Delta and Otto Loepfe of Swissair, said Tuesday that the alliance so far has produced such tangible gains as Delta's recent loan of 70 flight attendants to Swissair to help with a personnel shortage and an agreement between Delta and Singapore for blocked space on traffic between Singapore and Dallas@Fort Worth and New York. The three airlines also have joined in expanded frequent flier programs, coordinated global flight schedules and joint fares. The airline chiefs said Tuesday they are working on plans for joint purchasing, aircraft interchange flights, global tour packages and a global small package delivery service. Cheong said the three executives during meetings Monday and Tuesday in Atlanta ``accomplished quite a lot'' on the tour package project as well as joint fare and advertising plans. But he said the aircraft interchange will take more time to develop. Kevin Murphy, who follows Delta for Morgan Stanley & Co. in New York, said such alliances, which open international doors for airlines, ``are the order of the day for the 1990s.'' He said the strength of Delta's alliance with Singapore and Swissair is the compatibility of the three carriers' operating styles. ``As far as equality of service, if there are three airlines that should ... run like a Swiss watch, these are they,'' Murphy said. Murphy said it is notable that Delta established its global alliance during the heightened airline takeover activity of last summer, when the Atlanta-based carrier was frequently mentioned as an attractive target. ``They also act as white squires for Delta,'' Murphy said of Swissair and Singapore. Delta's Allen said the three airlines continue to be competitors, however friendly. ``We will all keep our individual identities. We will continue to be competitive with one another,'' he said. The success of the alliance, he added, ``doesn't preclude our (Delta's) continued expansion internationally ... nor does it preclude expansion by Singapore or Swissair.''

DOC.HEAD: Automakers: Rescuers Should Watch for Armed Air Bags
LaserPhoto DT2 of June 12
DOC.TEXT: Rescue crews working on air bag-equipped cars should disconnect the vehicles' batteries to assure the safety devices don't accidentally deploy, a fire official says. Automakers began installing air bags en masse late last year because of governmental regulation requiring passive restraint systems on 1990 and later model cars. The devices are standard equipment on all of Chrysler Corp.'s U.S. made cars, about half of Ford Motor Co.'s and about 15 percent of General Motors Corp.'s. This week, firefighters from around the United States and Canada are at the GM proving grounds west of Detroit using crash-test cars to practice roadside rescue techniques and learn about new technology in cars, including air bags. Some of firefighters said Tuesday there was concern about armed air bags deploying during rescue operations. ``You don't put yourself between an (undeployed) air bag and the victim,'' said Ken Jones of Owen Sound, Ontario, and a member of the Ontario Fire Marshal's Office. ``The information about the (new) technology of the cars hasn't been disseminated to us.'' The Big Three automakers have issued owner's and dealer service manuals describing how the devices work, precautions to take while working near them and disclaimers saying failure to follow directions could result in injury. ``If somebody is there with their nose against the bag and the thing goes off, I guess somebody might get injured,'' said GM spokesman Don Postma. The cardinal rule, automakers say, is to disable the car's electrical system, which powers the air bag. The device, designed to be used with manual lap and shoulder seat belts, is a large pillow flattened and stored in a steering wheel or dash board. It inflates in a tenth of a second and begins deflating immediately. Other passive restraint systems include an automatic shoulder belt on a track used with a manual lap belt, and an automatic lap and shoulder belt system. In a garage, disabling a car's electrical system along with the air bag is simply a matter of unbolting battery cables. At a crash scene, things are more complicated. If it is difficult to locate the battery or determine if its cables are intact, then automakers recommend mechanics and rescuers go under the steering column to disconnect the air bag.

DOC.HEAD: SmithKline Beecham Accuses Bolar of Dyazide Fraud
DOC.TEXT: SmithKline Beecham has filed a law suit accusing two competitors of lying to obtain government approval for generic versions of SmithKline's anti-hypertension drug Dyazide. Bolar Pharmaceutical Co., Inc., of Copiague, N.Y., and Vitarine Pharmaceuticals, Inc., of Springfield Gardens, N.Y., both manufactured and sold generic versions of Dyazide until the past year, when allegations of false reports to the Food and Drug Administration surfaced. The suit, filed in federal court Tuesday, accuses Bolar of falsifying evidence that its generic drug is Dyazide's bioequivalent _ that is, the generic drug achieves the same effect in the same dosage. The suit accuses Bolar of back-dating testing studies to make it appear the company's tests were performed on a batch of Dyazide when in fact they were performed on a batch that was not prepared according to federal procedures. Bolar took its generic version of the drug off the market in January after acknowledging that the company had faked lab tests to win FDA approval. Vitarine, when taking their version off the market in June 1989, admitted its substituted Dyazide for its product in tests required to win FDA approval. ``SmithKline was injured ... because those schemes and representations enabled (the companies) to obtain FDA approval ... to sell their generic versions of Dyazide to persons who otherwise would have bought Dyazide from (SmithKline),'' the suit claims. Dyazide is one of SmithKline's best-selling products, with annual sales exceeding $300 million in 1987, according to the suit. In 1988, after the generic substitutes entered the market, sales fell to $153 million. The suit characterizes the companies actions as a violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act and asks for unspecified damages. Also named in the 12-count suit are Bolar's president, Robert Shulman, and Port Washington, N.Y.-based Schein Pharmaceutical, Inc., the company that developed, marketed and sold Bolar's version. An assistant to Bolar's general counsel, who did not give her name, said she could not comment on the suit late Tuesday because the company had not received a copy of the complaint. Officials at Vitarine did not return a message left at their offices Tuesday afternoon. Smithkline Beecham PLC is the big pharmaceutical company formed last summer in the merger of Smithkline Beckman Corp. and Britain's Beecham PLC.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Off for Third Consecutive Month
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales slumped 0.7 percent in May, posting their first three-month decline since the last recession in 1981, the government said today. The Commerce Department said sales decreased to a seasonally adjusted $146.84 billion from $147.93 billion in April. After remaining unchanged in February, retail sales fell a revised 0.4 percent in March and 0.9 percent in April. That was worse than the 0.3 percent decline first reported for March and the 0.6 percent dip in April. Many economists had expected a slight improvement in sales in May. It was the first time since September, October and November 1981 that retail sales had fallen for three straight months. Retail sales represent about half of consumer spending, which has been a driving force for the economy during much of the last eight years. Overall, consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Retail sales had jumped 2.8 percent in January when automobile purchases spurted after cash rebates and low-interest financing were restored to attract buyers. Each of the automakers continues to offer incentives, but fewer cars are covered as companies try to wean consumers from the profit-eroding practice. Commerce said automobiles slipped 0.6 percent in May following a 1.6 percent drop in April. Through May 31, car sales had dropped 10.3 percent over the comparable period of 1989, manufacturers reported last week. Excluding autos, retail sales were off 0.8 percent in May after dropping 0.7 percent in April and 0.6 percent in March. The manufacturing sector including the automobile industry has been dampened by Federal Reserve efforts to restrain credit to avoid overheating the economy and thus fueling inflation. Economists also question the effect of a slowing job market and declining consumer confidence on future retail sales. Most recent job gains reflected temporary government hiring of census workers, while employment losses continued at factories and in the construction industry. Economists will be watching for Thursday's business inventory report to see whether any drawdown would be sufficient to increase production and thus create more jobs. Sales of durable goods _ usually costly items like automobiles which are expected to last at least three years _ fell 1.1 percent in May after dropping 1.7 percent in April. In that category, building materials plunged 4.2 percent after a 3.2 percent drop a month earlier. Furniture and other home furnishings were down 1.1 percent on top of a 0.5 percent gain in April. Sales of non-durable goods such as food and clothing slipped 0.5 percent, the same as in April. Gains were posted by only by apparel, up 2.4 percent and offsetting a 2.4 percent decline a month earlier. Declines included general department stores, down 1.0 percent on top of a 2.1 percent decrease in April. A survey focusing only on the country's largest chain department stores shows sales had generally been sluggish in May because of colder-than-normal temperatures and unusually heavy rainfall in some areas. Grocery stores sales were down 1.0 percent after rising 1.2 percent a month earlier. Gasoline sales were off 1.6 percent after falling 1.9 percent in April. Drug store sales were down 1.3 percent after rising 2.1 percent a month earlier. Sales at restaurants and bars slipped 0.5 percent after a 1.1 percent decline the previous month. For the three months from March through May, overall retail sales were off 0.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Sharply Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were sharply higher at midday Wednesday, boosted by Wall Street's strong close on Tuesday and a rise in the British pound. Traders said a spirited start to London dealings was led by professional investors who were inspired by the 40.85-point rise in the Dow Jones industrial average to 2,933.41 on Tuesday. DOC.HEAD: Examiner Appointed in Revco Bankruptcy Case
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Harold F. White has appointed Barry L. Zaretsky, a Brooklyn Law School professor, as an outside examiner to look into the 1986 debt-financed buyout of Revco D.S. Inc. Zaretsky, counsel to the New York-based law firm of Kelly Drye & Warren, said the appointment appears to be the first time an examiner has been appointed to review a junk bond-financed buyout during bankruptcy. Any decision could have a bearing, retroactively, on junk bond-financed LBOs as a way to buy companies, said Leonard Borrino, of Makovsky & Co., a New York public relations firm representing Kelly Drye & Warren. Zaretsky said he will be investigating whether Revco took on too much debt when it went from a publicly held company to a private one during a $1.5 billion, management-led leveraged buyout. Zaretsky, whose appointment was approved by the judge Tuesday, was ordered to file a preliminary report by July 16. The Revco buyout failed in 1988. Revco's was the first major debt-financed buyout to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Act. This year the suburban Cleveland-based drugstore chain, one of the country's largest, decided to sell more than 700 of its 2,000 stores in order to concentrate on eastern operations, where sales are strongest. In a leveraged buyout, the buyer borrows the purchase money with the intention of repaying it through earnings and asset sales. The appointment of an examiner was requested by U.S. Trustee Conrad J. Morgenstern, who supervised the Revco bankruptcy case.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Jewelry Store Chain Giant to Make Inroad to Japan
DOC.TEXT: The big U.S. jewelry store chain Zale Corp. will create franchises in Japan in collaboration with Japanese concerns, a spokesman for one of the Japanese companies involved said Wednesday. Zale's planned entry into the Japanese market coincides with Tokyo's efforts toward easing a rigid regulation which restricts the entry of foreign retailers. According to the spokesman at C. Itoh & Co., who spoke on condition of anonymity, the Texas-based jewelry store chain will open its first store in downtown Tokyo in September jointly with C. Itoh and a Japanese jewelry chain store named Tsurukame Corp. The action is the first inroad for the U.S. jewelry giant into the market, the spokesman said. Zale expects to expand to about 1,000 Japanese stores over the next decade, the spokesman said. As a result of the link-up, Zale will buy a one percent stake in Tsurukame. C. Itoh already holds an 11 percent interest in Tsurukame, which will acquire a one percent stake in Peoples Jewelers Ltd., Zale's parent company, the spokesman said. Zale is the world's largest jewelry store chain, with sales at about $1.38 billion in the fiscal year ended last March.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Varied in Europe, Gold Falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with closing figures; AMer planned by 5:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar closed mostly lower against the major currencies in European trading Wednesday but rose against the West German mark. Gold prices fell. Foreign exchange dealers said the main factor affecting the dollar was the unexpected decline of 0.7 percent in U.S. retail sales in May. The slide, which suggests U.S. economic growth is continuing to slow, sparked anxiety that the Federal Reserve may be tempted to lower domestic interest rates, which would make the dollar less attractive for investors. Two more U.S. indicators this week also may affect the dollar _ producer prices on Thursday and trade figures on Friday. Further signs of softer U.S. economic activity would send the dollar lower, dealers said. The dollar was firm against the mark because of continuing concern over the impact of the monetary union between the two German states in July. Investors and dealers say they are not convinced that the transition will be smooth, despite official assurances that it will be. The British pound continued to surge and at $1.7070, up from $1.7020 on Tuesday, hit its highest level since it reached $1.7090 on Feb. 23. Sterling was trading at $1.7107 at midday in New York. On top of continuing high interest rates that attract investments in sterling, there is growing expectation that Britain will join the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System later this year. Such a move would reduce the wide fluctuations of sterling in day-to-day trading. Other European late dollar rates compared with late Tuesday: 1.6925 West German marks, up from 1.6920; 1.4335 Swiss francs, down from 1.4367; 5.6880 French francs, down from 5.6950; 1.9045 Dutch guilders, unchanged; 1,241.00 Italian lire, down from 1,242.35; 1.1722 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1713. Gold bullion prices fell in busy trading at the end of the day after the failure of efforts Tuesday to push the price above $358 an ounce. Dealers said the outlook for gold was negative. The late bid price of gold in London was $350.15 a troy ounce, down from $356.25. The Zurich late bid price was $350.50, down from $355.65. DOC.HEAD: Resurrecting Black Entrepreneurship
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese laundry, the Italian produce stand, the Jewish delicatessen, the Irish bar are old cliches of American life. More recently, the Korean greengrocer has joined the list. Aspiring to business ownership, to be one's own boss, to be independent, to control one's destiny, to create a future for one's family all are deeply rooted in the American ethic. But what happened to black entrepreneurship? Blacks and Hispanics make up nearly 20 percent of the population, but they own less than 5 percent of the country's small businesses, and many of them are extremely small. But a report by the Business-Higher Education Forum, made up of chief executives of major American colleges, universities and corporations, suggests the opportunity for minority entrepreneurs now ``may be better than at any time since the turn of the century.'' They view the racial climate as having changed sufficiently, and the economic climate as now favoring small-businesses that can adapt to quickly changing markets. Meanwhile, the black middle-class market has swelled. Throughout the 87-page report, however, it becomes clear that still another factor might be at work: a new sense of urgency by the establishment, educators and executives included, that black entrepreneurship should get a helping hand. In tracing the history of black enterpreneurship, the report cites the work of Bart Landry, a Stanford University sociologist, who describes the existence of black-owned enterprises even before the Emancipation. After the Civil War such businesses flourished, the report states. ``Building on skills acquired during slavery, black entrepreneurs worked metal, repair harness and leathergoods, managed hotels and rooming houses, catered and operated grocery stores.'' But, it states, ``these enterprises were almost completely obliterated during the Reconstruction,'' or the period of economic and governmental rebuilding after the Civil War. Still, when the Fourth Atlanta University Conference on ``The Negro In Business'' met in 1898, more than 1,900 black businessmen participated. And two years later, Booker T. Washington founded the National Business League. But, the report relates, ``thrift and individual enterprise were weak reeds on which to rely in the year 1900.'' Black-owned business encountered selective white racism. And the North industrialized, while the South was held back. Only certain enterprises remained open to blacks. The report describes how ``Black business owners cut hair, provided meals, cleaned and pressed clothes, and buried the dead.'' All required little capital. Now, almost a century later, the Forum _ which many people will identify as the establishment _ believe the causes of the problem and its solution is clear. Minority business problems, it says, are often: ``...problems of access to financial institutions and to community networks that might provide financing to begin a business, finance an initial inventory, andf obtain equipment and space.'' Many ethnic minorities avoided some degree of these problems, even financial ones, because of strong family and community structures, and because of institutions brought from the old country. Blacks have not always had them. The Forum makes many important recommendations in educational and business areas, few of which seem more important than in the area of capital development. In particular, it suggests that corporations investigate three related strategies of capital assistance: 1. Creating partnerships with local banks and community developoment groups to bring business back to the inner city. 2. Depositing a small percentage of corporate assets in the banks that form the cornerstone of these venture, to be available for mortgage and business loans. 3. Investing for profit directly in the venture capital efforts of community development efforts. Every little bit will help, according to the report, signed by task force co-chairmen Steven Mason of The Mead Corporation and Clifton Wharton of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association. Indeed it might take very little. The report stresses ``that investing a very small amount of the capital controlled by major corporations _ a fraction of one percent _ can exert an enormous force for good in supporting these community based organizations.''

DOC.HEAD: Airline Sets Distance Record with Boeing 767 Flight
DOC.TEXT: A Boeing 767 set an unofficial world distance record for twin-engine commercial airliners by flying 9,253 miles non-stop from Seattle to Nairobi, Kenya, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said. The flight by a new 767-200ER was completed Sunday and lasted 18 hours, 29 minutes, Boeing said Tuesday. The plane was on the first part of a flight to the island of Borneo to deliver the airliner to the Royal Brunei Airlines, the national carrier of Brunei. There were 20 passengers aboard and a crew of four. The aircraft, the first Boeing 767 for Royal Brunei's fleet, continued to Brunei on Monday. Pending final verification, the National Aeronautic Association established the flight as a record, Boeing said. The previous record of 8,893 miles also was set by a 767. The 767-200ER model can seat 216 passengers and is designed to fly extra-long routes.

DOC.HEAD: Wristwatch Pagers Not Just For Sleuths Anymore
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The Seiko ...,' to CLARIFY that $225 is introductory price. SUBS 5th graf, `Like Tracy's ...,' to CLARIFY that similar service offered by other pager companies, sted radio stations. ADDS 1 graf with background on a similar pager to be offered by other companies. A version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Dick Tracy, the comic book detective with a two-way wrist radio, would be pleased. A Japanese company says it plans to introduce a wristwatch with a pager capable of carrying short messages on a liquid-crystal display. The Seiko Receptor, which took four years to develop, is scheduled to debut next month in Portland, Ore., at an introductory price of $255 and may gradually appear in other U.S. cities for $275, Hattori Seiko Co. spokeswoman Noriko Kuriyama said Wednesday. The company also is studying plans to expand sales to Europe and Asia, she said. Like Tracy's famous radio, the new wristwatch pager receives radio signals. The Receptor translates the radio waves into written messages up to 16 characters long. Many U.S. pager companies already provide similar services for beepers, but these devices aren't contained in a wristwatch. The wristwatch pager is manufactured by Seiko Epson Co., a Hattori Seiko subsidiary. It can store up to eight messages. The Receptor will be marketed in the United States through AT&E Corp., a San Francisco-based telecommunications company. In 1983, Seiko introduced a wristwatch-sized color television. But the TV required an auxiliary tuner about the size of a small cassette tape player. Seiko hopes to sell 1 million wristwatch pagers in the next three years, Ms. Kuriyama said. The Seiko model will have competition from a wristwatch pager that Motorola Inc. and Timex Corp. expect to introduce later this year. That model was announced last year by the two companies.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Company Announces Deals With Eastern Europe, Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Control Data Corp. has announced a $9 million letter of intent by Poland to buy a computerized energy management system. The computer company also disclosed further details of a technology cooperation agreement it signed with the Soviet Union when Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev visited the company June 3. In addition, it announced plans to install five small mainframe computers in East Germany beginning next month. The system being ordered by the Poles is expected to be financed by the World Bank, the company said. Under new export restrictions agreed to by the United States and its allies in Paris last week, the sale many not require an export license, said Dieter Porzel, vice president of Control Data's central Europe region. When Gorbachev visited the company, Control Data said it hoped to work out a joint venture to help the Soviets build their own computer workstations. On Tuesday, Jim Ousley, president of the company's computer products group, expanded on the technology agreement that includes that effort. The agreement calls for pilot projects in civilian nuclear reactor safety, petroleum exploration, electrical energy management and software development. But it calls for no further specific computer sales to the Soviet Union. Control Data is expecting to receive export approval soon for a six-computer, $32 million sale to the Soviets for nuclear power safety and already has U.S. approval for the sale of three smaller mainframes for oil exploration for $6 million. The East German deal calls for the installation of mainframes at five universities and government agencies in partnerships with existing West German customers.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Government Urging Quick Action on Tightened Export Controls
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. has asked West Germany to speed work on measures designed to tighten export controls, a top aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Wednesday. Allegations that a West German company helped outfit a factory in Rabta, Libya, to make poison gas prompted the legislation. U.S. Ambassador Vernon Walters sent a letter June 8 to West German Finance Minister Helmut Haussmann urging Parliament to pass the laws before the summer recess begins in late June, said Kohl aide Lutz Stavenhagen. The measures would increase sentences for violations, broaden the list of materials for which shippers must obtain government approval and reduce the number of countries that could receive sensitive exports without government approval. Stavenhagen appealed to Parliament to approve the proposed measures, despite calls by the opposition for even tighter restrictions. Stavenhagen said the proposed German measures were linked to Washington's good will regarding easing Cocom export restrictions on certain products for Eastern Europe, including East Germany. Cocom, or the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, agreed in Paris last week to ease restrictions on what goods could be exported to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. A U.S. Embassy official confirmed Walters had sent a letter to Haussmann, but called it ``very straightforward'' and denied there was any suggestion of quid pro quo between the Cocom decision and passage of the proposed new West German export laws. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States wanted quick passage because ``we're hoping to be able to stop the proliferation of dangerous technology,'' and because it feared the proposed laws could get bogged down in committee over opposition demands. The two Germanys are moving toward economic merger next month. The eased Cocom regulations will allow countries' access to previously restricted products such as machine tools, telecommunications or computer equipment that could help revitalize their economies.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Futures Sink On Profit-Taking After Report
DOC.TEXT: Corn futures prices fell steeply Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid profit-taking after a government report confirmed perceptions of a shrinking national corn stockpile. Most other grain and soybean futures finished slightly lower after hovering near unchanged for most of the session. In a report released after the close of trading Tuesday, the Agriculture Department raised its estimate of corn exports for the marketing year ending Aug. 31 by 50 million bushels and accordingly lowered its projection for the corn stockpile next September by 50 million to 1.28 billion bushels. Traders had anticipated the revision and took profits after the report confirmed their expectations, analysts said. ``The market made some very steep gains in the past week and some people made some very nice profits,'' said Katharina Zimmer, grains analyst for Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc. Corn for near-term delivery rose 14 cents a bushel in the week prior to the report, which also projected smaller soybean stocks and a smaller winter wheat harvest than the May report. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to 2 cents lower with July at $3.34\ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 4{ cents lower with July at $2.90{ a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 2{ cents lower with July at $1.43} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to to 2 cents lower with July at $6.06 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Down Sharply

DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended weaker Wednesday against most major currencies after a mixed performance overseas, while the soaring British pound continued to take center stage. Gold prices fell here and abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $352 a troy ounce, down $3.70 from late Tuesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $351 an ounce, also $3.70 lower. Currency dealers blamed the dollar's decline largely on technical factors, with traders selling the dollar to buy the West German mark and Swiss franc. But they said the dollar also was depressed by an unexpected 0.7 percent decline in May retail sales, which suggested economic growth was continuing to slow. The report sparked concern that the Federal Reserve may be tempted to lower interest rates, making the dollar less attractive to investors relative to other currencies, dealers said. Three more indicators this week also may effect the dollar: producer prices on Thursday and wholesale prices and trade figures on Friday. Meanwhile, high interest rates and growing expectation that Britain will join the European Monetary System later this year continued to shore up sterling. The pound rose to a nearly four-month high against the dollar, dealers said. It traded at $1.7070 in London, up from $1.7020 Tuesday, and at $1.7115 in New York, up from $1.7035. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.6865 West German marks, down from 1.6965; 1.4240 Swiss francs, down from 1.4382; 5.6720 French francs, down from 5.7090; 1,238.00 Italian lire, down from 1,245.00; and 1.17195 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17255. Late European dollar rates, compared with Tuesday, included: 1.6925 West German marks, up from 1.6920; 1.4335 Swiss francs, down from 1.4367; 5.6880 French francs, down from 5.6950; 1.9045 Dutch guilders, unchanged; 1,241.00 Italian lire, down from 1,242.35; and 1.1722 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1713. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 154.55 Japanese yen, up from 154.40 Tuesday. It traded at 154.80 yen in London, and at 154.75 yen in New York, up from 154.55 yen the day before. Gold bullion prices in Europe and Asia declined. The late bid price of gold in London was $350.15 an ounce, down from $356.25. The Zurich late bid price was $350.50 an ounce, down from $355.65. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $353.45, down from $356.55. Silver prices also declined. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.915 a troy ounce, down from $5.018. Silver fell in London to $4.95 an ounce from $5.06.
