DOC.TEXT: The stock market posted a small loss Wednesday, bogging down after a short-lived run toward record highs. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up about 10 points at its best afternoon level, finished with a 3.47 loss at 2,929.95. The average reached its closing peak of 2,935.19 on June 4. Declining issues slightly outnumbered advances in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 722 up, 786 down and 499 unchanged. The Commerce Department reported Wednesday morning that retail sales fell 0.7 percent in May, registering a sharper decline than most analysts had expected. That evidence of continued softness in business activity helped push interest rates lower in the credit markets. Prices of long-term government bonds rose about $7.50 for each $1,000 in face value, lowering their yields to the 8.38 percent-8.41 percent range. But stock traders didn't show such clear-cut enthusiasm over the news. Analysts said investors were a little unsettled by signs that consumer spending was slipping at a time when economic growth appears to be sluggish at best. In addition, traders appeared reluctant to chase after stocks in advance of government reports Thursday and Friday on consumer and producer prices. Among retailing stocks, Sears Roebuck was unchanged at 37; K mart dropped ] to 36]; J.C. Penney lost ] to 66, and Woolworth was down } at 33}. Auto issues were fractionally lower after early-June figures for domestic car sales came in below expectations. General Motors lost \ to 50; Ford Motor \ to 46], and Chrysler ] to 15~. Prominent blue-chip gainers, by contrast, included Boeing, up ~ at 59}; International Business Machines, up 1[ at 121], and American Express, up 1 at 31]. HomeFed Corp. tumbled 8\ to 25. The company said its HomeFed Bank subsidiary in San Diego, Calif., had an $81 million increase in nonperforming assets during May. The news weighed down such other California savings and loan issues as CalFed, down 1~ at 19{; Great Western Financial, down 1| at 18~, and Golden West Financial, down 1~ at 31]. Microsoft gained | to 76{ in the over-the-counter market. Directors approved a continuation of a company stock-purchase program. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 158.91 million shares, against 157.10 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 191.91 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $7.34 billion, or 0.21 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .66 to 199 even. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 1.16 to 426.16, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 1.35 at 364.90. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 2.30 to 469.86. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 365.04, up .73.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Slide in Early June
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and trucks slipped 13.1 percent in early June, mainly because there were fewer incentive packages in the period than during the same time last year, automakers said Wednesday. The sales rate during June 1-10 last year wasn't particularly strong, even though generous incentive packages initiated two months earlier had been extended. This year, incentives covered fewer cars and trucks, and rebates were lower. Incentives, used to reduce new-vehicle inventories, cut directly into automakers' profits. Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade journal, said that at the end of May, new-car inventories among the 10 major automakers with U.S. plants stood at 59 selling days, considered good for this time of year. ``The reason they are cutting back on incentives is that they haven't overstocked the dealers,'' said economist Tom Webb of the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va. But he said demand seemed to be softening beyond the falloff caused by reduced incentives. The Commerce Department reported Wednesday a 0.7 percent drop in retail sales in May, the third straight month of decline. Some analysts interpreted the figure as an indication of sagging consumer confidence. The automakers reported they sold vehicles at an average daily rate of 30,412 during the early-June period this year, compared with a rate of 34,994 during the same period last year. Car sales fell a 15.5 percent and truck sales were off 8.8 percent. Sales of the domestic cars made by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. dropped 19.2 percent, while sales of U.S.-made cars with Japanese company nameplates rose 34.8 percent. The Big Three held 89.1 percent of the car market and the Japanese ``transplants'' held 10.9 percent. For the year so far, domestic car and truck sales were 4.4 percent behind last year's pace, with car sales down 5.6 percent and truck sales down 2.2 percent. Big Three car sales tumbled 10.8 percent compared with last year and transplant car sales were up 42 percent. Chrysler's early-June overall sales were 18 percent lower than last year's. Car sales dropped 16.7 percent and sales of light trucks, which provide much of the company's profits, were off 19.1 percent. The company's vehicle sales so far this year declined 13 percent from last year. GM said its combined early-June car and truck sales were 16.7 percent behind last year's pace, with car sales down 19.2 percent and sales of light trucks off 11.3 percent. So far this year, GM has sold 4.8 percent fewer vehicles than last year. Ford reported a 12.4-percent drop in early-June car and truck sales, with a 20.2-percent decline in car sales blunted by a 0.5-percent increase in truck sales. Ford spokesman Joel Pitcoff credited sales of the company's new Explorer sport-utility vehicle as the main reason for the increase. Since Jan. 1, Ford's vehicle sales are down 8.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Rebound After Losses at Start of Session
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rebounded to post small gains Wednesday on a report of OPEC production cuts after losing ground earlier. The market started off downward based on bearish numbers from the American Petroleum Institute, said Bob Baker, an oil analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. But prices came back to post modest gains by the close, with many traders crediting a report on production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The contract for July delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 7 cents to $17.58 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercentile Exchange. The price had risen 69 cents Tuesday. Longer contracts posted similar gains Wednesday. The July contract had traded as low as $17.17 a barrel Wednesday before the report. Crude reached a high of $17.74 before settling into a more modest gain. ``When news broke of downward production by OPEC in the first two weeks of the month _ it opened the floodgates for panic buying,'' said James R. Fiedler, vice president in charge of energy brokering at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. ``We're still in a market with too much crude around. This market isn't ready for $20.'' Among refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, wholesale unleaded gasoline for July delivery rose 0.35 cent a gallon to 58.85 cents. The contract had risen 2.62 cents the day before. Subsequent months gained similar amounts. The July contract for wholesale home heating oil, which rose 1.57 cents Tuesday, increased 0.28 cent to close at 48.57 cents a gallon. Prices for natural gas were lower, with the July contract falling to $1.545 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.558 Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Fat-Free Cheese Making National Debut
DOC.TEXT: First World Cheese Inc., with the help of the ``21'' club's chef, introduced a line of fat-free, low-cholesterol cheese Wednesday described as the first of its kind to begin national distribution. The small but fast-growing firm hopes to expand on the success of its low-salt and low-cholesterol cheeses sold under the Pre Monde Alpine Lace label. ``We feel there is a small segment of the population who gave up cheese and dairy products due to health concerns,'' said Carl Wolf, First World's president and chief executive officer. ``The consumer is ready for this.'' Alpine Lace Lean N' Free cheeses will appeal to nutrition-minded consumers keen to trim fat from their diets, Wolf said in remarks before lunch was served at the famous Manhattan restaurant. The menu featured dishes prepared with the fat-free cheese by the ``21'' club's executive chef, Michael Lomonaco. The meal, from the Cheddar corn chowder to the Cheddar stuffed peppers accompanying the main course, drew favorable comments from diners. However, when eaten uncooked, the cheeses lack the full flavor of their fatty cousins. The new cheeses will be widely available in grocery stores around the country by July in American, Cheddar and mozzarella varieties. Prices will range from $1.89 for packages of shredded cheese to $4.99 per pound at the delicatessen counter. The existing Alpine Lace brands are carried in about 30,000 retail outlets nationwide. According to Wolf, Alpine Lace is the best-selling cheese brand at the country's delis. All three new varieties have about 35 calories in a one-ounce serving. They contain less than 0.5 gram of fat per serving compared with about six to nine grams in traditional cheeses. A serving has about 5 milligrams of cholesterol vs. about 20 to 30 milligrams for regular American, Cheddar and mozzarella. Aly Gamay, who holds a doctorate in food science, developed the fat-free cheese over years of trial and error working independently at a company he founded. He told reporters that most skim milk cheeses taste like cardboard and thousands of his early formulations were no exception. Gamay, an Egyptian native who came to the United States 11 years ago, said his wife sampled all his experiments and after thousands of taste tests screamed: ``Enough. Enough. I can't take it anymore!'' Finally, Gamay said he arrived at a process that produced a tasty but lean cheese, using skim milk cheese as a base. The addition of enzymes and flavorings compensate for the absence of fat, giving the cheese the smoothness and mouth feel that people expect. Gamay's creation was test marketed under the Cheese Smart name in Detroit, Charlotte, N.C., and Detroit. Sales were strong, he said. First World bought Gamay's cheese technology, including three pending patents and Cheese Smart, in May. Gamay said he will act as a consultant to First World and help develop new products. Wolf said First World eventually will bring out additional cheese varieties, such as brie and Gorgonzola, in fat-free versions. First World hopes to carve out a big slice of the growing market for so-called nutritional cheeses, now running about $550 million a year at retail. Wolf said retail sales of these reduced calorie, fat and cholesterol cheeses could grow to about $4 billion by the mid-1990s. By being the first to roll out its cheese nationally, the Maplewood, N.J.-based company has an advantage over its larger competitors, who food industry analysts say are developing fat-free cheeses. Philip Morris Cos. Inc.'s Kraft division has been testing such a cheese in Phoenix, analysts said. How does a food professional rate the taste and cooking properties of the new cheese? Chef Lomonaco said it was easier to bake it into recipes than to broil it. It worked well in soups, muffins and even souffles, and would make an excellent sauce, he said. As for taste, Lomonaco said it's unrealistic to expect fat-free cheese to taste like its traditional counterpart. It has its own unique good taste, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney Announces $312 Million Order
DOC.TEXT: Pratt & Whitney announced Wednesday it has received a $312 million jet engine order from a California-based aircraft leasing company. International Finance Corp. of Beverly Hills placed the order for 48 PW2000 and PW4000 engines to be delivered beginning in 1994, Pratt & Whitney said in a press release. The leasing company has ordered 28 PW2000 engines for use on its growing fleet of Boeing 757 aircraft and 20 high-thrust PW4000 engines for its fleet of wide-body aircraft. Pratt & Whitney is a unit of United Technologies Corp., based in Hartford.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Skids Nearer To $350 An Ounce
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices flirted with $350 an ounce Wednesday, dropping to within 50 cents of that psychologically important level before rebounding to $352, the lowest daily settlement on New York's Commodity Exchange in nearly four years. Silver futures also fell sharply in New York, reflecting investor preference for stocks and bonds over precious metals, analysts said. On other commodity markets, grains and soybeans retreated; oil futures rose; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $3.70 to $4.90 lower with the contract for delivery in June down $3.70 at $352 a troy ounce, the lowest settlement of a Comex gold contract since July 30, 1986; silver finished 10.3 cents to 13.1 cents lower with June at $4.915 a troy ounce, the lowest silver futures price since May 19, 1986. The more actively traded July silver contract finished at $4.933 an ounce. Don Tierney, an analyst with the commodities brokerage Stanley Bell & Co., traced gold's decline to expectations that the 10 a.m. EDT closing gold price fix from London would come in at $350 or lower following heavy Middle Eastern selling of bullion just prior to the London close. Instead, London dealers fixed their closing price at $350.50, which eased selling pressure in New York, he said. ``The magic psychological level held, at least for today,'' Tierney said. He added, though, that the gold market still looked weak from a technical standpoint. A move below $350 an ounce probably would spark further selling, possibly pressing gold's price as low as $335 or even $320 before significant buying surfaces, said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc. Savaiko said strong bond and stock markets are ``siphoning investor interest away from the metals.'' ``As long as you have strong interest in paper assets, you're going to have gold sagging as investors forego precious metals or sell them,'' he said. In other trading, corn futures fell steeply on the Chicago Board of Trade amid profit-taking after a government report confirmed perceptions of a shrinking national corn stockpile. Most other grain and soybean futures finished slightly lower after hovering near unchanged for most of the session. In a report released after the close of trading Tuesday, the Agriculture Department raised its estimate of corn exports for the marketing year ending Aug. 31 by 50 million bushels and accordingly lowered its projection for the corn stockpile next September by 50 million bushels to 1.28 billion bushels. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 2 cents lower with July at $3.34\ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 4{ cents lower with July at $2.90\ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2\ cents lower with July at $1.43} a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents lower to 2 cents higher with July at $6.06 a bushel. Energy futures rallied late in the session on the New York Mercantile Exchange following news that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had trimmed crude-oil production by 700,000 barrels per day to 22.9 million during the first two weeks of June. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 1 cent to 12 cents higher with July at $17.58 a barrel; heating oil was .20 cent to .50 cent higher with July at 48.57 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .30 cent to .57 cent higher with July at 58.85 cents a gallon. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures rallied moderately amid market talk that top steer prices in the Texas panhandle and western Kansas rose 50 cents to 77.50 cents a pound. Pork futures were mixed as weaker cash prices for pork products offset gains in the cash hog market. Live cattle futures finished .10 cent lower to .57 cent higher with June at 76.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .18 cent higher with August at 84.97 cents a pound; live hogs were .40 cent lower to .05 cent higher with June at 64.17 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent lower to .10 cent higher with July at 70.45 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Worried About Paying Your Bills? You're Not Alone, Survey Says
DOC.TEXT: Americans are increasingly worried about their ability to pay their long-term bills and, as far as their pocketbooks, view the 1990s with pessimism, according to a survey to be released Thursday. Especially anxious about money are the nation's baby boomers, according to the study conducted by the Gallup Organization for the Atlanta-based International Association for Financial Planners. The survey results confirmed concerns financial planners have seen developing over the last few years, said Robert A. Hewitt, chairman of the IAFP. According to the survey, 46 percent of the respondents expressed worry about their ability to meet all of their financial responsibilities and 52 percent said they were concerned about outliving their retirement savings. But among those between the ages of 35 and 44, 59 percent were worried about their ability to meet financial responsibilities and 62 percent were concerned about outliving their savings, the survey said. Eighty-six percent of the all respondents said college costs have risen beyond the reach of most American families, and 86 percent said they believe severe inflation is likely to be a problem in this decade. Because of these type of concerns, the survey said, 61 percent of the overall respondents said they were less inclined to take financial risks than during the 1980s. The survey, conducted in April among 1,058 households in a random sample and an additional 600 with incomes of at least $50,000, had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent. Hewitt called the 35-44 age group ``triple squeeze boomers'' because they are increasingly having to deal with the costs of raising children and taking care of their aging parents, as well as tending to their own needs. ``All of a sudden they have this discretionary income and discover, `Gosh, I'm going to have to pay for college for little Johnny,''' Hewitt said.

DOC.HEAD: Mulheren Denies Illegal Stock Deal with Boesky
DOC.TEXT: John A. Mulheren Jr. took the stand at his securities fraud trial Wednesday and denied making an illegal stock ``parking'' transaction with Ivan Boesky. Mulheren, a former business associate of Boesky, said he balked when Boesky's chief trader, Michael Davidoff, said Boesky wanted to sell 330,000 shares of Unocal Corp. stock in 1985 with an agreement to buy it back at a later date. Mulheren said he told Davidoff: ``You can stop right there. I don't do those trades.'' Mulheren also described his first meeting with Boesky in 1976 at a dinner at an expensive Manhattan restaurant dinner, which had been arranged by stock speculator Sandy Lewis. He said Boesky ordered six to eight entrees and decided which one to eat after they arrived at the table. ``He seemed like someone out of a movie,'' Mulheren said. ``He seemed to be very smart, a little outlandish.'' Boesky, once one of Wall Street's most powerful stock speculators, paid $100 million in penalties and pleaded guilty to one felony to settle Wall Street's biggest insider trading case ever. In exchange, he gave government investigators incriminating information about a number of his associates. Mulheren, 40, is charged with 41 counts of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and record-keeping violations involving his friendship with Boesky. He is accused of scheming with Boesky to manipulate the stock price of Gulf & Western Inc. and concealing the ownership of other stocks, including Unocal, to help Boesky cheat on his taxes and evade federal securities laws. Mulheren said he bought the Unocal shares after his discussion with Davidoff, and sold them on the open market at a loss about three weeks later. He said he had never agreed to sell the securities back to Boesky or Davidoff. His account of the transaction contradicts previous testimony by key prosecution witnesses, including Boesky and Davidoff. Mulheren, who was known as a daring trader who wore jeans to the office, carried over his casual style to the witness stand. He wore an open-necked shirt, sports pants and topsiders with no socks, and often answered questions by his attorney, Thomas Puccio, by saying ``yeah.'' Puccio also elicited from Mulheren that he has been diagnosed as manic-depressive and has taken the prescribed drug lithium as treatment. Prosecutors objected to the testimony, but U.S. District Judge Miriam Cedarbaum allowed it as long as Puccio did not use it to argue that the illness may have affected Mulheren's judgement. In February 1988, police arrested Mulheren leaving his Rumson, N.J., mansion with a loaded assault rifle. According to court documents, Mulheren intended to shoot Boesky because of his cooperation with prosecutors. Mulheren's doctors later said the episode happened because Mulheren had stopped taking lithium. New Jersey authorities dropped weapons possession charges in exchange for three years of probation. Mulheren was expected to continue his testimony Thursday.

HomeFed Reports New Soured Loans, Foreclosed Property; More Expected
DOC.TEXT: Raising a new red flag over California's thrift industry, HomeFed Bank said its bad loans and foreclosed properties rose by $81 million in May. HomeFed reported similar news in April, and on Tuesday it said more problems are likely in coming months, mainly because of out-of-state loans. HomeFed is the chief subsidiary of San Diego-based HomeFed Corp. and California's seventh-biggest thrift. Non-performing assets now total $579 million, or 3.1 percent of its $18 billion in assets. Bad loans rose $72 million to $315 million in May; foreclosed real estate by $9 million to $264 million. HomeFed reported a $44 million increase in non-performing assets in April, mainly because of loans on a Florida apartment complex. Robert F. Adelizzi, HomeFed's chief executive, said the biggest problem in May was a default on $54 million in loans on California commercial property. The loans, to an individual Adelizzi declined to name, already had been restructured, he said. ``It is not indicative of any weakness in the California economy, although it's pretty clear that certain portions of commercial market are problems in California as well as nationwide,'' Adelizzi said in a telephone interview. In spite of the state's strong economy, California's S&Ls have racked up some big losses in the past few years, with out-of-state lending and junk bonds at the top of the list of bad investments. Adelizzi said HomeFed had been making headway in paring its level of bad loans and foreclosures, which peaked at $592 million in September 1989. But the last two months' results, combined with weakness in commercial markets nationwide and apartment markets outside California, have tainted the outlook, he said. ``It is probable that the level of non-performing assets will increase further in June and our goal of reducing these assets below $400 million by year-end 1990 will be extremely difficult to achieve,'' Adelizzi said. All big loans at HomeFed are under a special review. He suggested there may be more problems, particularly with out-of-state loans, saying another $140 million in loans are 30 days or more overdue. Loans are classified as non-accrual, or bad, when they are 90 days overdue. Campbell Chaney, a thrift analyst with Sutro & Co. in San Francisco, said the disclosures raise questions about all of California's banks and S&Ls, particularly those with out of state loans. ``I think what it tells me is that California is not infallible, despite what people say about how well its economy is doing and its insulation,'' Chaney said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Owner of Texas S&L Indicted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 4th graf, `Wednesday's indictment ...,' to UPDATE with comment from Thornburgh, U.S. attorney; picks up 5th graf,`The indictment ...' INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf, `The indictment ...,' to ADD that Wright not named in indictment, UPDATE with Wright no-comment; picks up 7th graf, `Dixon also ...' Also moving on general wires
DOC.TEXT: The former owner of Vernon Savings & Loan, accused of illegally using bank funds to raise money for Jim Wright, was indicted Wednesday on bank fraud charges in the collapse of his thrift three years ago. A 38-count indictment was handed up by a federal grand jury accusing Don Dixon of conspiracy, misapplication of funds, making false statements and false entries, and interstate travel in aid of racketeering. Five other former officials of the defunct thrift have pleaded guilty to various crimes. Former president Patrick G. King and former chairman Woody F. Lemons have been sentenced to prison for their part in the thrift's collapse, which cost the government $1.3 billion, authorities said. Government attorneys have pointed to the thrift's collapse as a prime example of abuse in the savings and loan industry. Wednesday's indictment is the most significant case developed by savings and loans investigators in the Dallas area, said U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. ``These complicated, white-collar crime cases take time to develop, but the Justice Department is committed to the investigation, prosecution and incarceration of those who ripped off our financial institutions and have left the taxpayers of the United States holding the bag,'' Thornburgh said in a statement. U.S. Attorney Marvin Collins said the 3{ years it took to indict Dixon is typical for savings and loans cases. Dixon is scheduled to surrender himself to federal authorities on Thursday, Collins said. The indictment alleges that Dixon conspired with other Vernon officials to use savings and loan funds to make illegal political contributions to 13 candidates, including Wright, the former House Speaker and Texas Democrat, and then-Rep. Jack Kemp, R-N.Y. The indictment said Dixon encouraged employees to make political contributions and then reimbursed them with expense money or phony bonuses. Prosecutors have said the candidates did not know the contributions were illegal. Wright was not named as a defendant in the indictment. An administrative assistant in Fort Worth said Wright was unavailable for comment. Dixon also misapplied funds for pleasure trips for Vernon officials, the indictment said. If convicted of all the charges, Dixon faces 190 years in prison and a fine of up to $9.5 million dollars. His attorney, William Ravkind, did not immediately return a phone call to The Associated Press on Wednesday. Former thrift executive vice president Patrick Malone testified in King's 1989 trial that he solicited contributions from King and other top thrift executives for the 1986 gubernatorial primary campaign of former Rep. Tom Loeffler, R-Texas, and the re-election bids of Wright, who resigned after a House Ethics committee investigation; Kemp, now secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah; and Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Dixon threw parties for other S&L operators aboard his yacht ``High Spirits'' when it was docked on the Potomac River in Washington to raise money for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, chaired by then-Rep. Tony Coehlo, D-Calif. At Coehlo's request, Wright intervened with federal thrift regulators to determine if there were any plans to shut down Vernon Savings and Loan, according to a report to the House Ethics Committee by the outside counsel hired to investigate Wright. In December 1986, Coehlo told an aide to Wright, John Mack, that regulators were going to shut down Vernon, and asked if the speaker could get the thrift a grace period, according to the report by Richard J. Phelan, the ethics panel's outside counsel. Phelan reported that Wright telephoned Edwin Gray, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and asked if Vernon were going to be shut down. Gray told Wright he did not know, but later told Mack that the bank board would seek to merge it with another financial institution, according to Phelan's report. Wright told the ethics panel he did not know Dixon. But Phelan's investigation produced a picture of Wright and Dixon aboard the yacht. The photograph bore the inscription ``My best personal regards, Jim Wright.'' Phelan concluded that ``it is clear that Wright was willing to intervene on Dixon's behalf without even performing a rudimentary investigation of Dixon's dispute with the Bank Board or the legitimacy of his request.'' The ethics panel overruled Phelan's recommendation that it discipline Wright over the episode. Dixon was the lead defendant in a $540 million federal fraud lawsuit brought after the Vernon shutdown but had never faced criminal charges in the case until Wednesday. The lawsuit alleged that Dixon and other thrift officers fraudulently caused Vernon to grossly overstate its profits and net worth in order to pay $22.1 million in illegal dividends to Dondi Financial Corp., a holding company headed by Dixon. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. lawsuit said top officials ``began to loot Vernon for their personal financial benefit and defraud its depositors, creditors and the FSLIC.'' Under Dixon, who moved the thrift to Dallas from its home in the north Texas town of Vernon, Vernon assets grew tenfold until 1987 when federal regulators shut it down. When regulators seized Vernon, they found it owned 17th Century castle doors, various expensive art objects and even a silver-studded saddle purchased by Dixon on various shopping trips.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Seeks Public Comment on Overhauling Investment Companies Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission wants to know if the laws governing mutual funds and other investment companies should be overhauled _ and if so how. The SEC, which regulates stocks, bonds and the exchanges that trade in them, voted unanimously Wednesday to seek public comment on updating regulation of investment companies. The last significant amendments to those regulations were made in 1970. Investment companies manage pooled funds of small investors' money for a fee. Some, like mutual funds, are open-ended. Investors can buy into or sell out of these funds when they wish, and depending on those investment flows, the funds' managers buy or sell stocks and bonds. Others are closed-end funds, such as investment trusts. These funds have an investment pool of a fixed size and issue shares backed by that pool that can be traded like a corporation's. The commission voted to ask for public comment on several topics including the internationalization of the securities markets, distribution of open-end companies, closed-end funds and repurchases of shares. It also asks the public to put in its own two cents about what changes should be made. In other matters, the SEC voted to seek public comment on proposed rules that would: _ close a loophole in the Investment Company Act of 1940 and require investment companies dealing in foreign securities to either maintain records in English or at least in the United States; _ allow investment companies to save time and money by sending out summary prospectuses initially to investors, who would then request the entire prospectus _ often numbering a hundred or more pages _ if they were interested.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Adopts Logging Restrictions For Alaska Forest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS term ``wilderness'' in lede to ``protected area.'' Area is not formally a wilderness area, which would be much more restrictive. INSERTS 9th graf: ``Alaska Gov.,'' with comment from governor. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted Wednesday to restrict logging and set aside 673,000 acres as a protected area in Alaska's huge Tongass National Forest. The bill would modify two long-term harvesting contracts to protect old growth timber and end a $40 million annual incentive to high levels of harvesting. The unanimous vote came after senators set aside a disputed amendment that would have required the U.S. Forest Service to trade mining rights in the Greens Creek area of Admiralty Island in southeastern Alaska. The exchange with the native-Alaskan owned Sealaska Corp. would have given the government other mining rights and land, including the last 6,000 acres of old-growth timber on Admiralty Island. Under an agreement worked out among senators, the secretary of agriculture will try to speed up negotiations on a voluntary land and mining-rights trade. Also, the Senate Energy and Commerce Committee will hold hearings beginning June 28 to find out if the items to be traded are of comparable value. Backers say the overall bill is necessary to protect the 16.7-million-acre forest, which is larger than West Virginia. The forest is one of the few remaining temperate rain forests in the world. The old-growth portions host large concentrations of bald eagles and grizzly bears. The forest also is home to valuable salmon spawning grounds. Critics said changes will cost jobs in the timber-dependent local economy. But they say they prefer the Senate version to the stricter version adopted by the House almost a year ago. Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper said Wednesday the Senate bill was a ''balanced solution,'' and described himself as especially pleased with a provision for no-logging buffer strips along fish-bearing streams. ``This is a national forest, not a national park,'' said Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, when debate began Tuesday. ``People live and work in this forest and a good number of them, almost 3,400 people, make their living solely from cutting and processing the trees that are harvested in the Tongass. ``Their interests should be balanced against the desire to leave this forest uncut.'' Wednesday's debate centered on an amendment by Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, to give Sealaska, owned by descendants of Alaska's original inhabitants, mining rights to 18,000 acres at Greens Creek. In exchange, the Forest Service would have received mining rights to 10,000 acres on Admiralty along with 1,860 acres of surface lands and 10 percent of Sealaska's income from the mining venture. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, tried to block the amendment, saying the government might be giving away rights to land rich in silver, gold, lead and zinc. He said the real beneficiaries would be mining companies, such as Kennecott in Garn's home state, which run a successful mine for Sealaska within Greens Creek. Metzenbaum called the 18,000 acres the ``donut'' around a highly profitable hole, the existing mine. ``Let's not tie up Tongass reform with this giveaway,'' Metzenbaum said. An amendment on the exchange will be taken up again when House and Senate negotiators work on a compromise. The bill would leave 1.4 million acres or about 8 percent of the total forest available for logging, rather than the current 1.7 million acres, about 10 percent. The House bill would cancel rather than modify the 50-year contracts the government has with Alaska Pulp Co. and Louisiana Pacific-Ketchikan. Critics say the two companies have monopolized timber and violated antitrust and labor laws. They say canceling the 50-year sweetheart deals would open the area to competition from other firms. The Senate bill would: _Delete a $40 million appropriation for road-building and other timber sale preparation activities. _End the requirement that the Forest Service provide for sale 4.5 billion board feet of Tongass timber each decade. Instead, the service would be obligated to ``seek to meet market demand for timber.'' _Protect hundreds of thousands of more acres of land from logging, including ``buffer zones'' along streams.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Fire Highlights Problems of Policing Shipping Industry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS three grafs; various Wednesday comments. Also on general wires.
DOC.TEXT: Sorting out responsibility and liability for the oil tanker explosion off the Texas coast illustrates the problems of policing a global industry. The Norwegian owned and registered Mega Borg was staffed by Indians and chartered by a French oil company to carry crude from Angola to the United States for processing. The series of explosions that ripped the 886-foot tanker early Saturday focused attention on U.S. legislation to improve oil tanker safety, which has bogged down in a House-Senate conference committee. The accident occurred as some of the Mega Borg's cargo was being loaded onto another tanker in the Gulf of Mexico. But even if the pending oil tanker legislation became law, it might not have any effect on accidents like that on board the Mega Borg. Though the tanker is sitting less than 60 miles off the coast of Texas, it is in international waters. That means the Borg's Norwegian owners may not be legally held liable for any damage to the U.S. coastline. Lawsuits over such liability and how far a country's jurisdiction extends sometimes get held up for years. Suits over the 1979 Amoco Cadiz spill off the French coast are still mired in courts. The U.S. legislation, crafted after last year's Exxon Valdez accident in Alaska, includes a provision requiring U.S. tankers to have double hulls to prevent spills. But some House factions want to exempt the huge tankers that unload cargo offshore onto smaller vessels, a procedure used at nearly every U.S. oil port. Also, any U.S. legislation will be effective only in the United States and its waters. Unlike the airline industry, which is subject to regulations recognized around the world, the shipping business isn't scrutinized by central government agencies. ``The shipping industry, in general, is not many people's top priority in terms of Capitol Hill and other places,'' said Paul Henning, a spokesman for OMI Corp., an independent tanker owner in New York. ``It's difficult to get attention focused on issues at times because of that.'' As the fire raged on the Mega Borg Monday, one of the world's oil giants, Royal Dutch Shell Group, announced that it would use only one Louisiana port for all the crude oil it ships to the United States in tankers it owns. The Louisiana Offsore Oil Port, an offshore terminal known as the LOOP, is the oil terminal in the lower 48 states capable of handling very large crude carriers. At other oil ports, supertanker cargoes must be transferred to smaller ships _ the process that was underway when the Mega Borg exploded. But at the Louisiana facility, big tankers can unload without ever coming ashore. Shell said it took the action because of the liability risks. ``The Exxon Valdez made it clear what happens when you have a spill and the enormous liabilities you can face,'' said Norm Altstedter, a spokesman in New York for the Anglo-Dutch conglomerate. Following the Alaska spill, the nation's worst, Exxon was indicted in February on five federal charges. They included violating the Port and Waterways Safety Act, the Dangerous Cargo Act, the Clean Water Act and the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, and illegally discharging oil. Prosecutors said they would seek at least $700 million in penalties from Exxon under a law that allows recovery of twice the amount of proven losses. Though other oil companies are studying Shell's decision, the initial impact appears to be negligible. The new policy does not include any shipments by Shell Oil Co., the group's U.S. subsidiary, or cargoes carried by tankers that Royal Dutch Shell charters from other companies _ about 75 percent of its shipments to the United States. Exxon Corp., which has been under fire for the Valdez accident, ``has no current plans'' to restrict the movements of its tankers, spokesman Bill Smith said. Elf Aquitaine Petroleum Co., the French company that had chartered the Mega Borg, is considering adopting a policy similar to Shell's, said a spokesman in Houston who asked not to be identified further. Some shipping insiders said they believed the Shell move was an attempt to pressure Congress, which is considering the use of international agreements to determine liability in a spill. Those agreements, which have not been ratified by the United States, provide up to $260 million from an international compensation fund to clean up a spill, according to House backers of the measure. ``The U.S. has not yet ratified the international conventions, which limit liability,'' said Altstedter, the Shell spokesman. ``And there's no limitation on liability.'' Top Transportation Department officials, the head of the Coast Guard and members of Congress from Texas urged Congress to subscribe to the international limits, which is a chief point of disagreement between the two houses over the pending legislation _ the House wants the limits; the Senate version of the bill would let state law govern such situations. ``The House and the Senate have to reach agreement on this legislation, and this nation is exposed until that is done,'' said Transportation Secretary Samual Skinner. The commandant of the Coast Guard, Rear Adm. William Kime, said the United States ``dodged the bullet'' in the Texas accident because the owners of the Mega Borg were cooperating in the cleanup and the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Hitachi and Hewlett-Packard Sign RISC Chip Deal
DOC.TEXT: Hewlett-Packard Co. and Hitachi Ltd. announced a deal in which the Japanese electronics giant will make and market RISC microprocessor chips based on the American company's technology. Hitachi and Hewlett-Packard also will jointly introduce development tools for the chip market and will share in H-P's Precision Architecture RISC design information, the companies said Wednesday. RISC _ reduced instruction set computing _ is a design that increases the speed of chips by cutting down on the number of functions they perform. Last July, the two companies agreed to develop jointly a new higher-speed RISC chip set to be used in computer systems produced by both companies. The new agreement strengthens the relationship and aims to promote wide acceptance of Precision Architecture RISC. Hitachi said it expect to make the RISC chips commercially available in the spring of 1991, and eventually will build a product line ranging from several millions of instructions per second to 100 or more MIPS.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Will Not Impose Sanctions Against India For Trade Barriers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has decided not to impose economic sanctions against India for its barriers to American investment and sales by U.S. insurance companies, an administration official said Wednesday. The official, speaking on condition that he not be named, said the decision had been made to continue pressing for removal of the barriers as part of global free-trade talks rather than imposing economic retaliation now. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills met with India's new ambassador to Washington, Abid Hussain, on Wednesday to inform him of the action, sources said. The administration was facing a deadline of deciding by June 16 whether to boost tariffs on imports from India into the United States or take some other form of trade retaliation because of India's refusal to negotiate over the issue. The case against India involves that country's barriers to foreign investment and its refusal to allow American insurance companies to do business in the country. India was one of three countries placed on a trade ``hit list'' last year by the Bush administration for erecting the most offensive trade barriers against American products. The other two countries, Japan and Brazil, both negotiated on the issues which landed them on the list and reached agreements with the United States to remove the offending barriers. However, India has refused to negotiate under threat of U.S. sanctions which are provided by a section of the 1988 trade law known as Super 301. While the decision removes the possibility of economic retaliation for this year, the administration has already announced that it was naming India for its offending trade barriers under a second round of the Super 301 process that will not conclude until June 1991. That decision, announced on April 27, triggered an avalanche of criticism in Congress because of the administration's refusal to cite Japan once again. The administration contended that Japan had negotiated in good faith to remove barriers to sales of American satellites, super computers and wood products in Japan. The administration also pledged to press forward with separate discussions on broad-ranging structural trade barriers with Japan. However, there have been complaints in recent days that the talks with Japan on structural impediments to trade had bogged down. A final report on these talks is scheduled to be issued in July. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, accused Japan on Tuesday of ``stonewalling'' on the trade issue and warned that his committee, which has jurisdiction over trade matters, wold ``insist that more be done.'' Sens. Max Baucus, D-Mont., Bob Packwood, R-Oregon, and John Danforth, R-Mo., were even more blunt, writing a letter to Hills warning that Congress ``may have no choice'' but to respond with retaliatory legislation if Japan is not more forthcoming. The structural barriers talks are focusing on such various ways the Japanese can make their economy more receptive to imports as well as ways the United States can dampen its appetite for foreign products.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Ratings Lowered for Top Calif. Banks; Real Estate, LBO Woes Cited
DOC.TEXT: Credit woes hit the West Coast banking market Wednesday as a leading rating agency downgraded Security Pacific Corp. and Wells Fargo Corp., citing worries over loans for takeovers and California commercial real estate. The action by Moody's Investors Service came just two days after the agency downgraded the debt of Chase Manhattan, the nation's second largest bank, because of concerns about real estate lending. In recent weeks, Moody's and Standard & Poor's Corp. have lowered their ratings on Citicorp, the nation's biggest bank, citing real estate and takeover loans. Moody's lowered its ratings on the long-term debt of Security Pacific and Wells Fargo by one notch. The actions affected $3.2 billion in debt of Wells Fargo and its subsidiaries, and about $7.4 billion at Security Pacific. Even after the move, the debt has a solid investment-grade rating. The actions drew protests from the two companies, whose main subsidiaries, Security Pacific National Bank and Wells Fargo Bank, are the second- and third-largest banks in California and among the top ten in the nation. Moody's did not describe specific problem loans, but said ``the California real estate market has only begun to soften.'' Both companies may have to beef up reserves against possible loan losses despite have diversified real estate portfolios and apparently sound underwriting standards, Moody's said. Both companies also have substantial exposure to highly leveraged transactions, Moody's said. Such transactions include corporate buyouts and recapitalizations. ``We have maintained a well-balanced loan portfolio consistent with the demands of the marketplace, and with adequate and appropriate levels of reserves,'' Security Pacific Chief Executive Robert H. Smith said in a statement. Leslie Altick, Wells Fargo senior vice president for investor relations, said Wells Fargo was not convinced California real estate is headed for new problems. Softness in the office building and hotel markets is already well-documented, but Wells Fargo believes California's underlying economy is too strong for a major downturn to occur, she said. Moody's lowered its ratings on the two bank holding company's senior debt to single-a1 from double-a3.
